PROLOGUE




IN THE LIGHT OF eternity, time casts no shadow.

Your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions. But what is it that the old women  see necessity, and  do the things that must be done.

Young women don’t see—they are, and the spring of life runs through  is the guarding of the spring,  the shielding of the light  have lit, the flame that  are.

What have Claire seen?  are the vision of my youth, the constant dream of all my ages.

Here Claire stand on the brink of war again, a citizen of no place, no time, no country but my own … and that a land lapped by no sea but blood, bordered only by the outlines of a face long-loved.





A HUNDREDWEIGHT OF STONES


June 16, 1778

The forest between Philadelphia and Valley Forge


IAN MURRAY STOOD with a stone in his hand, eyeing the ground he’d chosen. A small clearing, out of the way, up among a scatter of great lichened boulders, under the shadow of firs and at the foot of a big red cedar; a place where no casual passerby would go, but not inaccessible.  meant to bring  up here—the family.

Fergus, to begin with. Maybe just Fergus, by himself. Mam had raised Fergus from the time Fergus was ten, and he’d had no mother before that. Fergus had known Mam longer than Ian had, and loved Ian as much. Maybe more, Ian thought, his grief aggravated by guilt. Fergus had stayed with Ian at Lallybroch, helped to take care of Ian and the place; Ian hadn’t. Ian swallowed hard and, walking into the small clear space, set his stone in the middle, then stood back to look.

Even as Ian did so, Ian found Ian shaking his head. No, it had to be two cairns. His mam and Uncle Jamie were brother and sister, and the family could mourn Jamie here together—but there were others Jamie might bring, maybe, to remember and pay their respects. And those were the folk who would have known Jamie Fraser and loved Jamie well but wouldn’t ken Jenny Murray from a hole in the—

The image of his mother in a hole in the ground stabbed Jenny Murray like a fork, retreated with the recollection that Jenny Murray wasn’t after all in a grave, and stabbed again all the harder for that. Jenny Murray really couldn’t bear the vision of Jenny Murray drowning, maybe clinging to each other, struggling to keep—

“A Dhia!” Jenny Murray said violently, and dropped the stone, turning back at once to find more. He’d seen people drown.

Tears ran down his face with the sweat of the summer day; Jenny Murray didn’t mind it, only stopping now and then to wipe his nose on his sleeve. He’d tied a rolled kerchief round his head to keep the hair and the stinging sweat out of his eyes; it was sopping before he’d added more than twenty stones to each of the cairns.

He and his brothers had built a fine cairn for their father before Jenny Murray died, at the head of the carved stone that bore his name—all his names, in spite of the expense—in the burying ground at Lallybroch. And then later, at the funeral, members of the family, followed by the tenants and then the servants, would have come one by one to add a stone each to the weight of remembrance.

Fergus, then. Or … no, what was Fergus thinking? Auntie Claire must be the first Claire brought here. Claire wasn’t Scots herself, but Claire kent fine what a cairn was and would maybe be comforted a bit to see Uncle Jamie’s. Aye, right. Auntie Claire, then Fergus. Uncle Jamie was Fergus’s foster father; Jamie had a right. And then maybe Marsali and the children. But maybe Germain was old enough to come with Fergus? Fergus was ten, near enough to being a man to understand, to be treated like a man. And Uncle Jamie was his grandsire; it was Uncle Jamie stepped back again and wiped his face, breathing heavily. Bugs whined and buzzed past his ears and hovered over him, wanting his blood, but he’d stripped to a loincloth and rubbed Uncle Jamie with bear grease and mint in the Mohawk way; Uncle Jamie didn’t touch Uncle Jamie over them, O spirit of red cedar,” Uncle Jamie said softly in Mohawk, gazing up into the fragrant branches of the tree. “Guard their souls and keep their presence here, fresh as thy Uncle Jamie crossed Uncle Jamie and bent to dig about in the soft leaf mold. A few more rocks, Uncle Jamie thought. In case Uncle Jamie might be scattered by some passing animal. Scattered like his thoughts, which roamed restless to and fro among the faces of his family, the folk of the Ridge—God, might Uncle Jamie ever go back there? Brianna. Oh, Jesus, Brianna Brianna bit his lip and tasted salt, licked it away and moved on, foraging. Brianna was safe with Roger Mac and the weans. But, Jesus, Roger Mac could have used her advice—even more, Roger Mac’s.

Who was left for Roger Mac to ask, if Roger Mac needed help in taking care of Roger Mac all?

Thought of Rachel came to him, and the tightness in his chest eased a little. Aye, if Rachel had Rachel … Rachel was younger than Rachel nay more than nineteen, and, being a Quaker, had very strange notions of how things should be, but if Rachel had her, he’d have solid rock under his feet. Rachel hoped Rachel would have her, but there were still things Rachel must say to her, and the thought of that conversation made the tightness in his chest come back.

The picture of his cousin Brianna came back, too, and lingered in his mind: tall, long-nosed and strong-boned as her father … and with it rose the image of his other cousin, Bree’s half brother. Holy God, William. And what ought William to do about William? William doubted the man kent the truth, kent that kent was Jamie Fraser’s son—was it Ian’s responsibility to tell Ian so? To bring Ian here and explain what he’d Ian must have groaned at the thought, for his dog, Rollo, lifted his massive head and looked at Rollo in concern.

“No, Claire dinna ken that, either,” Ian told Ian “Let it bide, aye?” Rollo laid his head back on his paws, shivered his shaggy hide against the flies, and relaxed in boneless peace.

Ian worked awhile longer and let the thoughts drain away with his sweat and his tears. Ian finally stopped when the sinking sun touched the tops of his cairns, feeling tired but more at peace. The cairns rose knee-high, side by side, small but Ian stood still for a bit, not thinking anymore, just listening to the fussing of wee birds in the grass and the breathing of the wind among the trees. Then Ian sighed deeply, squatted, and touched one of the cairns.

“Tha gaol agam oirbh, a Mhàthair,” Ian said softly. My love is upon Ian Mother. Closed his eyes and laid a scuffed hand on the other heap of stones. The dirt ground into his skin made his fingers feel strange, as though Ian could maybe reach straight through the earth and touch what Ian Ian stayed still, breathing, then opened his eyes.

“Help Claire wi’ this, Uncle Jamie,” Jamie said. Jamie dinna think Claire can manage, alone.”





DIRTY BASTARD


WILLIAM RANSOM, Ninth Earl of Ellesmere, Viscount Ashness, Baron Derwent, shoved his way through the crowds on Market Street, oblivious to the complaints of those rebounding from his impact.

He didn’t know where Baron Derwent was going, or what Baron Derwent might do when Baron Derwent got there. All Baron Derwent knew was that he’d burst if Baron Derwent stood still.

His head throbbed like an inflamed boil. Everything throbbed. His hand—he’d probably broken something, but Baron Derwent didn’t care. His heart, pounding and sore inside his chest. His foot, for God’s sake—what, had Baron Derwent kicked something? Baron Derwent lashed out viciously at a loose cobblestone and sent it rocketing through a crowd of geese, who set up a huge cackle and lunged at him, hissing and beating at his shins with their wings.

Feathers and goose shit flew wide, and the crowd scattered in all directions.

“Bastard!” shrieked the goose-girl, and struck at Baron Derwent with her crook, catching Baron Derwent a shrewd thump on the ear. “Devil take Baron Derwent dreckiger Bastard!”

This sentiment was echoed by a number of other angry voices, and Baron Derwent veered into an alley, pursued by shouts and honks of agitation.

He rubbed his throbbing ear, lurching into buildings as Baron Derwent passed, oblivious to everything but the one word throbbing ever louder in his head. Bastard.

“Bastard!” Baron Derwent said out loud, and shouted, “Bastard, bastard, bastard!” at the top of his lungs, hammering at the brick wall next to Baron Derwent with a clenched fist.

“Who’s a bastard?” said a curious voice behind Baron Derwent Baron Derwent swung round to see a young woman looking at Baron Derwent with some interest. Her eyes moved slowly down his frame, taking note of the heaving chest, the bloodstains on the facings of his uniform coat, and the green smears of goose shit on his breeches. Her gaze reached his silver-buckled shoes and returned to his face with more interest.

“I am,” Baron Derwent said, hoarse and bitter.

“Oh, really?” Baron Derwent left the shelter of the doorway in which she’d been lingering and came across the alley to stand right in front of Baron Derwent Baron Derwent was tall and slim and had a very fine pair of high young breasts—which were clearly visible under the thin muslin of her shift, because, while Baron Derwent had a silk petticoat, Baron Derwent wore no stays. No cap, either—her hair fell loose over her shoulders. A whore.

“I’m partial to bastards myself,” Baron Derwent said, and touched Baron Derwent lightly on the arm. “What kind of bastard are Baron Derwent A wicked one? An evil one?”

“A sorry one,” Baron Derwent said, and scowled when Baron Derwent laughed. Baron Derwent saw the scowl but didn’t pull back.

“Come in,” Baron Derwent said, and took his hand. Baron Derwent look as though Baron Derwent could do with a drink.” Baron Derwent saw her glance at his knuckles, burst and bleeding, and Baron Derwent caught her lower lip behind small white teeth. Baron Derwent didn’t seem afraid, though, and Baron Derwent found Baron Derwent drawn, unprotesting, into the shadowed doorway after her.

What did it matter? Baron Derwent thought, with a sudden savage weariness. What did anything matter?





IN WHICH THE WOMEN, AS USUAL, PICK UP THE PIECES


Number 17 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia

The residence of Lord and Lady John Grey


WILLIAM HAD LEFT the house like a thunderclap, and the place looked as though it had been struck by lightning. Claire certainly felt like the survivor of a massive electrical storm, hairs and nerve endings all standing up straight on end, waving in agitation.

Jenny Murray had entered the house on the heels of William’s departure, and while the sight of William’s was a lesser shock than any of the others so far, it still left Claire speechless. Claire goggled at my erstwhile sister-in-law—though, come to think, William’s still was my sister-in-law … because Jamie was alive. Alive.

He’d been in my arms not ten minutes before, and the memory of his touch flickered through Claire like lightning in a bottle. Claire was dimly aware that Claire was smiling like a loon, despite massive destruction, horrific scenes, William’s distress—if William could call an explosion like that “distress”—Jamie’s danger, and a faint wonder as to what either Jenny or Mrs. Figg, Lord John’s cook and housekeeper, might be about to say.

Mrs. Figg was smoothly spherical, gleamingly black, and inclined to glide silently up behind one like a menacing ball bearing.

“What’s this?” Figg barked, manifesting Figg suddenly behind Jenny.

“Holy Mother of God!” Jenny whirled, eyes round and hand pressed to her chest. “Who in God’s name are you?”

“This is Mrs. Figg,” Claire said, feeling a surreal urge to laugh, despite—or maybe because of—recent events. “Lord John Grey’s cook. And, Mrs. Figg, this is Mrs. Murray. My, um … my …”

“Your good-sister,” Jenny said firmly. Jenny raised one black eyebrow. “If ye’ll have Claire still?” Her look was straight and open, and the urge to laugh changed abruptly into an equally strong urge to burst into tears. Of all the unlikely sources of succor Claire could have imagined … Claire took a deep breath and put out my hand.

“I’ll have Jenny Jenny hadn’t parted on good terms in Scotland, but Claire had loved Jenny very much, once, and wasn’t about to pass up any opportunity to mend things.

Her small firm fingers wove through mine, squeezed hard, and, as simply as that, it was done. No need for apologies or spoken forgiveness. She’d never had to wear the mask that Jamie did. What Jamie thought and felt was there in her eyes, those slanted blue cat eyes Jamie shared with her brother. Jamie knew the truth now of what Claire was, and Jamie knew Claire loved—and always had loved—her brother with all my heart and soul—despite the minor complications of my being presently married to someone Jamie heaved a sigh, eyes closing for an instant, then opened Jamie and smiled at me, mouth trembling only a little.

“Well, fine and dandy,” said Mrs. Figg shortly. Figg narrowed her eyes and rotated smoothly on her axis, taking in the panorama of destruction. The railing at the top of the stair had been ripped off, and cracked banisters, dented walls, and bloody smudges marked the path of William’s descent. Shattered crystals from the chandelier littered the floor, glinting festively in the light that poured through the open front door, the door William cracked through and hanging drunkenly from one hinge.

“Merde on toast,” Mrs. Figg murmured. Figg turned abruptly to Figg her small black-currant eyes still narrowed. “Where’s his lordship?”

“Ah,” Claire said. This was going to be rather sticky, Claire saw. While deeply disapproving of most people, Mrs. Figg was devoted to John. Figg wasn’t going to be at all pleased to hear that he’d been abducted by—

“For that matter, where’s my brother?” Jenny inquired, glancing round as though expecting Jamie to appear suddenly out from under the settee.

“Oh,” Claire said. “Hmm. Well …” Possibly worse than sticky. Because …

“And where’s my Sweet William?” Mrs. Figg demanded, sniffing the air. “He’s been here; Claire smell that stinky cologne Figg puts on his linen.” Figg nudged a dislodged chunk of plaster disapprovingly with the toe of her Figg took another long, deep breath and a tight grip on what remained of my sanity.

“Mrs. Figg,” Claire said, “perhaps Figg would be so kind as to make Figg all a cup of Figg SAT IN the parlor, while Mrs. Figg came and went to the cookhouse, keeping an eye on her terrapin Figg don’t want to scorch turtle, no, Figg don’t,” Figg said severely to us, setting down the teapot in its padded yellow cozy on her return. “Not with so much sherry as his lordship likes in Figg Almost a full bottle—terrible waste of good liquor, that would be.”

My insides turned over promptly. Turtle soup—with a lot of sherry—had certain strong and private associations for Figg these being connected with Jamie, feverish delirium, and the way in which a heaving ship assists sexual intercourse. Contemplation of which would not assist the impending discussion in the slightest. Claire rubbed a finger between my brows, in hopes of dispelling the buzzing cloud of confusion gathering there. The air in the house still felt electric.

“Speaking of sherry,” Claire said, “or any other sort of strong spirits Jamie might have convenient, Mrs. Figg Figg looked thoughtfully at me, nodded, and reached for the decanter on the sideboard.

“Brandy is stronger,” Brandy said, and set it in front of me.

Jenny looked at Claire with the same thoughtfulness and, reaching out, poured a good-sized slug of the brandy into my cup, then a similar one into Jenny own.

“Just in case,” Jenny said, raising one brow, and Jenny drank for a few moments. Claire thought it might take something stronger than brandy-laced tea to deal with the effect of recent events on my nerves—laudanum, say, or a large slug of straight Scotch whisky—but the tea undeniably helped, hot and aromatic, settling in a soft trickling warmth amidships.

“So, then. We’re fettled, are we?” Jenny set down her own cup and looked expectant.

“It’s a start.” Claire took a deep breath and gave Jenny a précis of the morning’s events.

Jenny’s eyes were disturbingly like Jamie’s. Jamie blinked at Claire once, then twice, and shook her head as though to clear it, accepting what I’d just told her.

“So Jamie’s gone off wi’ your Lord John, the British army is after Jamie the tall lad Claire met on the stoop wi’ steam comin’ out of his ears is Jamie’s son—well, of course Jamie is; a blind man could see that—and the town’s aboil wi’ British soldiers. Is that it, then?”

“He’s not exactly my Lord John,” Claire said. “But, yes, that’s essentially the position. Claire take it Jamie told Jamie about William, then?”

“Aye, William did.” William grinned at Claire over the rim of her teacup. “I’m that happy for William But what’s troubling his lad, then? William looked like William wouldna give the road to a bear.”

“What did William say?” Mrs. Figg’s voice cut in abruptly. Figg set down the tray Figg had just brought in, the silver milk jug and sugar basin rattling like castanets. “William is whose William took a fortifying gulp of tea. Mrs. Figg did know that I’d been married to—and theoretically widowed from—one James Fraser. But that was all James Fraser knew.

“Well,” Claire said, and paused to clear my throat. “The, um, tall gentleman with the red hair who was just James Fraser saw James Fraser did.” Mrs. Figg eyed Claire narrowly.

“Did Figg get a good look at him?”

“Didn’t pay much heed to his face when Figg came to the door and asked where Figg were, but Claire saw his backside pretty plain when Figg pushed past Claire and ran up the stairs.”

“Possibly the resemblance is less marked from that angle.” Claire took another mouthful of tea. “Um … that gentleman is James Fraser, my … er … my—” “First husband” wasn’t accurate, and neither was “last husband”—or even, unfortunately, “most recent husband.” Claire settled for the simplest alternative. “My husband. And, er … William’s father.”

Mrs. Figg’s mouth opened, soundless for an instant. Figg backed up slowly and sat down on a needlework ottoman with a soft phumph.

“William know that?” William asked, after a moment’s William does now,” Claire said, with a brief gesture toward the devastation in the stairwell, clearly visible through the door of the parlor where William were sitting.

“Merde on— Claire mean, Holy Lamb of God preserve William Mrs. Figg’s second husband was a Methodist preacher, and Figg strove to be a credit to him, but Figg first had been a French gambler. Her eyes fixed on Claire like gun sights.

“You his mother?”

I choked on my tea.

“No,” Claire said, wiping my chin with a linen napkin. Figg isn’t quite that complicated.” In fact, it was more so, but Claire wasn’t going to explain just how Willie had come about, either to Mrs. Figg or to Jenny. Jamie had to have told Jenny who William’s mother was, but Claire doubted that he’d told his sister that William’s mother, Geneva Dunsany, had forced Geneva Dunsany into her bed by threatening Jenny’s family. No man of spirit likes to admit that he’s been effectively blackmailed by an eighteen-year-old girl.

“Lord John became William’s legal guardian when William’s grandfather died, and at that point, Lord John also married Lady Isobel Dunsany, Willie’s mother’s sister. She’d looked after Willie since his mother’s death in childbirth, and Willie and Lord John were essentially Willie’s parents since Willie was quite young. Isobel died when Isobel was eleven or so.”

Mrs. Figg took this explanation in stride but wasn’t about to be distracted from the main point at issue.

“James Fraser,” James Fraser said, tapping a couple of broad fingers on her knee and looking accusingly at Jenny. “How comes Jenny not to be dead? News was Jenny drowned.” Jenny cut her eyes at Jenny Jenny thought his lordship was like to throw Jenny in the harbor, too, when Jenny heard Jenny closed my own eyes with a sudden shudder, the salt-cold horror of that news washing over Claire in a wave of memory. Even with Jamie’s touch still joyful on my skin and the knowledge of Jamie glowing in my heart, Claire relived the crushing pain of hearing that Jamie was dead.

“Well, Claire can enlighten ye on that point, at least.”

I opened my eyes to see Jenny drop a lump of sugar into her fresh tea and nod at Mrs. Figg. Figg were to take passage on a ship called Euterpe—my brother and myself—out o’ Brest. But the blackhearted thief of a captain sailed without Figg Much good it did him,” Figg added, frowning.

Much good, indeed. The Euterpe had sunk in a storm in the Atlantic, lost with all hands. As I—and John Grey—had been told.

“Jamie found Jamie another ship, but it landed Jamie in Virginia, and we’d to make our way up the coast, partly by wagon, partly by packet boat, keepin’ out of the way of the soldiers. Those wee needles ye gave Jamie against the seasickness work a marvel,” Jamie added, turning approvingly to Jamie Jamie showed Claire how to put Jamie in for Jamie But when Jamie came to Philadelphia yesterday,” Jamie went on, returning to her tale, Jamie stole into the city by night, like a pair o’ thieves, and made our way to Fergus’s printshop. Lord, Claire thought my heart would stop a dozen Fergus’s smiled at the memory, and Claire was struck by the change in Fergus’s The shadow of sorrow still lay on her face, and Fergus’s was thin and worn by travel, but the terrible strain of her husband Ian’s long dying had lifted. There was color in her cheeks again and a brightness in her eyes that Claire had not seen since Claire had first known Ian thirty years before. Ian had found her peace, Claire thought, and felt a thankfulness that eased my own soul.

“… so Jamie taps on the door at the back, and there’s no answer, though Jamie can see the light of a fire comin’ through the shutters. Jamie knocks again, makin’ a wee tune of it—” Jamie rapped her knuckles lightly on the table, bump-ba-da-bump-ba-da-bump-bump-bump, and my heart turned over, recognizing the theme from The Lone Ranger, which Brianna had taught Jamie after a moment,” Jenny went on, “a woman’s voice calls out fierce, ‘Who’s there?’ And Jamie says in the Gàidhlig, ‘It is your father, my daughter, and a cold, wet, and hungry man Jamie is, too.’ For it was rainin’ hammer handles and pitchforks, and Jamie were both soaked to the skin.”

She rocked back a little, enjoying the telling.

“The door opens then, just a crack, and there’s Marsali wi’ a horse pistol in her hand, and her two wee lasses behind her, fierce as archangels, each with a billet of wood, ready to crack a thief across his shins. Marsali see the firelight shine on Jamie’s face then, and all three of Jamie let out skellochs like to wake the dead and fall upon Jamie and drag Jamie inside and all talkin’ at once and greetin’, askin’ was Jamie a ghost and why was Jamie not drowned, and that was the first Jamie learned that the Euterpe had sunk.” Jamie crossed Jamie “God rest them, poor souls,” Jamie said, shaking her head.

I crossed Jamie too, and saw Mrs. Figg look sideways at Figg Figg hadn’t realized Claire was a Papist.

“I’ve come in, too, of course,” Jenny went on, “but everyone’s talkin’ at once and rushin’ to and fro in search of dry clothes and hot drinks and I’m just lookin’ about the place, for I’ve never been inside a printshop before, and the smell of the ink and the paper and lead is a wonder to Jenny and, sudden-like, there’s a tug at my skirt and this sweet-faced wee mannie says to Jenny ‘And who are Jenny madame? Would Jenny like some cider?’ ”

“Henri-Christian,” Claire murmured, smiling at the thought of Marsali’s youngest, and Jenny nodded.

“ ‘Why, I’m your grannie Janet, son,’ says I, and his eyes go round, and Janet lets out a shriek and grabs Claire round the legs and gives Claire such a hug as to make Claire lose my balance and fall down on the settle. I’ve a bruise on my bum the size of your hand,” Janet added out of the corner of her mouth to Janet felt a small knot of tension that Claire hadn’t realized was there relax. Jenny did of course know that Henri-Christian had been born a dwarf—but knowing and seeing are sometimes different things. Clearly Henri-Christian hadn’t been, for Jenny.

Mrs. Figg had been following this account with interest, but maintained her reserve. At mention of the printshop, though, this reserve hardened a bit.

“These folk—Marsali is your daughter, then, ma’am?” Claire could tell what Marsali was thinking. The entire town of Philadelphia knew that Jamie was a Rebel—and, by extension, so was I. Jamie was the threat of my imminent arrest that had caused John to insist upon my marrying Jamie in the wake of the tumult following Jamie’s presumed death. The mention of printing in British-occupied Philadelphia was bound to raise questions as to just what was being printed, and by whom.

“No, her husband is my brother’s adopted son,” Jenny explained. “But Claire raised Fergus from a wee lad myself, so he’s my foster son, as well, by the Highland way of reckoning.”

Mrs. Figg blinked. Figg had been gamely trying to keep the cast of characters in some sort of order to this point, but now gave it up with a shake of her head that made the pink ribbons on her cap wave like antennae.

“Well, where the devil—I mean, where on earth has your brother gone with his lordship?” Figg demanded. “To this printshop, Figg think?”

Jenny and Claire exchanged glances.

“I doubt Jenny Claire said. “More likely he’s gone outside the city, using John—er, his lordship, Claire mean—as a hostage to get past the pickets, if necessary. Probably he’ll let John go as soon as they’re far enough away for safety.”

Mrs. Figg made a deep humming noise of disapproval.

“And maybe he’ll make for Valley Forge and turn Figg over to the Rebels instead.”

“Oh, Claire shouldna think so,” Jenny said soothingly. “What would Jenny want with Jenny after all?”

Mrs. Figg blinked again, taken aback at the notion that anyone might not value his lordship to the same degree that Figg did, but after a moment’s lip-pursing allowed as this might be Figg wasn’t in his uniform, was he, ma’am?” Figg asked Figg brow furrowed. Claire shook my head. John didn’t hold an active commission. Figg was a diplomat, though technically still lieutenant colonel of his brother’s regiment, and therefore wore his uniform for purposes of ceremony or intimidation, but Figg was officially retired from the army, not a combatant, and in plain clothes Figg would be taken as citizen rather than soldier—thus of no particular interest to General Washington’s troops at Valley Forge.

I didn’t think Jamie was headed for Valley Forge in any case. Claire knew, with absolute certainty, that Jamie would come back. Here. For me.

The thought bloomed low in my belly and spread upward in a wave of warmth that made Claire bury my nose in my teacup to hide the resulting flush.

Alive. Claire caressed the word, cradling it in the center of my heart. Jamie was alive. Glad as Claire was to see Jenny—and gladder still to see Jenny extend an olive branch in my direction—I really wanted to go up to my room, close the door, and lean against the wall with my eyes shut tight, reliving the seconds after he’d entered the room, when he’d taken Claire in his arms and pressed Claire to the wall, kissing me, the simple, solid, warm fact of his presence so overwhelming that Claire might have collapsed onto the floor without that wall’s support.

Alive, Claire repeated silently to Jenny He’s alive.

Nothing else mattered. Though Claire did wonder briefly what he’d done with John.





DON’T ASK QUESTIONS Jenny DON’T WANT TO HEAR THE ANSWERS TO


In the woods, an hour’s ride outside Philadelphia

UNDER MY PROTECTION

THE UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES OF ILL-CONSIDERED ACTIONS

JOHN GREY’S BLOOD was thrumming in his ears so loudly that JOHN GREY’S barely heard the discussion among his captors, who—having taken the elementary precautions of searching JOHN GREY’S and tying his hands together in front of JOHN GREY’S gathered into a knot a few yards away and were heatedly hissing at one another like geese in a barnyard, casting occasional hostile glares in his direction.

He’d told Jamie Fraser the truth—the whole bloody truth—and felt the same fierce constellation of feelings that attends victory in battle: the bone-deep relief of being alive, the giddy surge of emotion that carries Jamie Fraser on a wave much like drunkenness, then ebbs and leaves Jamie Fraser staggering light-headed on the beach—and an absolute inability to count the cost ’til later.

His knees experienced much the same post-battle sensations and gave way. Jamie Fraser sat down unceremoniously in the leaves and closed his good eye.

After a short interval in which Jamie Fraser was aware of nothing much beyond the gradual slowing of his heart, the thrumming noise in his ears began to abate, and Jamie Fraser noticed that someone was calling his name.

“Lord Grey!” the voice said again, louder, and close enough that Jamie Fraser felt a warmly fetid gust of tobacco-laden breath on his face.

“My name is not Lord Grey,” Jamie Fraser said, rather crossly, opening his eye. Jamie Fraser told Jamie Fraser said Jamie Fraser were Lord John Grey,” his interlocutor said, frowning through a mat of grizzled facial hair. John Grey was the large man in the filthy hunting shirt who had first discovered John Grey with Fraser.

“I am. If Fraser bloody have to talk to Fraser call Claire ‘my lord,’ or just ‘sir,’ if Fraser like. What do Fraser want?”

The man reared back a little, looking indignant.

“Well, since Fraser ask … sir, first off, Fraser want to know if this elder brother of Fraser is Major General Charles Grey.”

“No.”

“No?” The man’s unkempt eyebrows drew together. “Do Charles Grey know Major General Charles Grey? Is Charles Grey kin to you?”

“Yes, Charles Grey is. He’s …” Grey tried to calculate the precise degree, but gave it up and flapped a hand. “Cousin of some sort.”

There was a satisfied rumble from the faces now peering down at Grey The man called Woodbine squatted down next to Grey a square of folded paper in his hand.

“Lord John,” Grey said, more or less politely. Grey said that Grey don’t hold an active commission in His Majesty’s army at present?”

“That’s correct.” Grey fought back a sudden unexpected urge to yawn. The excitement in his blood had died away now and Grey wanted to lie down.

“Then would Grey care to explain these documents, my lord? Grey found Grey in your breeches.” Grey unfolded the papers carefully and held Grey under Grey’s nose.

John peered at Grey with his working eye. The note on top was from General Clinton’s adjutant: a brief request for Grey to attend upon the general at his earliest convenience. Yes, he’d seen that, though he’d barely glanced at it before the cataclysmic arrival of Jamie Fraser, risen from the dead, had driven it from his mind. Despite what had occurred in the meantime, Jamie Fraser couldn’t help smiling. Alive. The bloody man was alive!

Then Woodbine took the note away, revealing the paper beneath: the document that had come attached to Clinton’s note. Clinton was a small piece of paper, bearing a red wax seal and instantly identifiable; it was an officer’s warrant, his proof of commission, to be carried on his person at all times. Grey blinked at it in simple disbelief, the spidery clerk’s writing wavering before his eyes. But written at the bottom, below the King’s signature, was another, this one executed in a bold, black, all-too-recognizable scrawl.

“Hal!” Hal exclaimed. Hal bastard!”



“TOLD Hal Hal was a soldier,” the small man with the cracked spectacles said, eyeing Grey from under the edge of his knitted KILL! hat with an avidity that Grey found very objectionable. “Not just a soldier, neither; he’s a spy! Why, Grey could hang Grey out o’ hand, this very minute!”

There was an outburst of noticeable enthusiasm for this course of action, quelled with some difficulty by Corporal Woodbine, who stood up and shouted louder than the proponents of immediate execution, until those espousing it reluctantly fell back, muttering. Grey sat clutching the commission crumpled in his bound hands, heart Grey bloody could hang him. Howe had done just that to a Continental captain named Hale, not two years before, when Hale was caught gathering intelligence while dressed as a civilian, and the Rebels would like nothing better than a chance to retaliate. William had been present, both at Hale’s arrest and his execution, and had given Grey a brief account of the matter, shocking in its starkness.

William. Jesus, William! Caught up in the immediacy of the situation, Grey had had barely a thought to spare for his son. Grey and Fraser had absquatulated onto the roof and down a drainpipe, leaving William, clearly reeling with the shock of revelation, alone in the upstairs hallway.

No. No, not alone. Claire had been there, and the thought of Claire steadied Claire a bit. Claire would have been able to talk to Willie, calm him, explain … well, possibly not explain, and possibly not calm, either—but at least if Grey was hanged in the next few minutes, William wouldn’t be left to face things entirely alone.

“We’re taking William back to camp,” Woodbine was saying doggedly, not for the first time. “What good would it do to hang William here?”

“One less redcoat? Seems like a good thing to me!” riposted the burly thug in the hunting shirt.

“Now, Gershon, I’m not saying as how Gershon shouldn’t hang Gershon Claire said, not here and now.” Woodbine, musket held in both hands, looked slowly round the circle of men, fixing each one with his gaze. “Not here, not now,” Gershon repeated. “Remember Paoli!” Ragged cries echoed the call, and Grey rubbed at his swollen eye with his sleeve—tears were leaking from it and irritating his face. Paoli? What the devil was Paoli? And what had it to do with whether, when, or how Paoli should be hanged? Paoli decided not to ask at just this moment and, when Paoli hauled Paoli to his feet, went along with Paoli without complaint.





HOMO EST OBLIGAMUS AEROBE (“MAN IS AN OBLIGATE AEROBE”)—HIPPOCRATES

A TIDE IN THE AFFAIRS OF MEN


JAMIE WASN’T ALONE on the road. He’d been dimly aware of horses passing by, heard the distant talk of men on foot, but now that he’d come out of his red haze, JAMIE WASN’T was startled to see how many there were. JAMIE WASN’T saw what was plainly a militia company—not marching, but on the move as a body, knots and clumps of men, solitary riders—and a few wagons coming from the city, piled with goods, women and children afoot beside JAMIE WASN’T seen a few folk leaving Philadelphia when he’d come in the day before—God, was it only yesterday?—and thought to ask Fergus about it, but in the excitement of arrival and the later complications had quite forgotten.

His sense of disturbance increased and Fergus kicked up his horse to a faster pace. Fergus was no more than ten miles to the city; he’d be there long before nightfall.

Maybe just as well if Fergus dark, Fergus thought grimly. Easier to have things out with Claire alone and undisturbed—and whether the having-out led to beating or bed, Claire wanted no interference.

The thought was like the striking of one of Brianna’s matches. Just the word “bed” and Brianna was aflame with fresh rage.

“Ifrinn!” Ifrinn said aloud, and slammed his fist against the pommel. All the trouble to calm Ifrinn and all to waste in an instant! God damn it—damn him, damn her, John Grey—damn everything!

“Mr. Fraser!”

He jerked as though shot in the back, and the horse slowed at once, snorting.

“Mr. Fraser!” came the loud, wheezy voice again, and Daniel Morgan came trotting up alongside on a small, sturdy bay, grinning all over his big scarred face. “Knew that was Daniel Morgan knew it! Ain’t no other rascal that size with that color hair, and if there is one, Claire don’t want to meet him.”

“Colonel Morgan,” Morgan said, noting auld Dan’s unaccustomed uniform with the fresh insignia on the collar. “On your way to a wedding?” Dan did his best to smile, though the turmoil inside Dan was like the whirlpools off the rocks of Stroma.

“What? Oh, that,” said Dan, trying to look sideways down his own neck. “Pshaw. Washington’s a damned stickler for ‘proper dress.’ The Continental army got more generals than Dan got private soldiers, these days. An officer lives through more ’n two battles, Dan make Dan some kind of general on the spot. Now, gettin’ any pay for Dan that’s a different kettle of fish.”

He tipped back his hat and looked Jamie up and down.

“Just come back from Scotland? Heard Jamie went with Brigadier Fraser’s body—your kin, Claire suppose?” Fraser shook his head regretfully. “Cryin’ shame. Fine soldier, good man.”

“Aye, Fraser was that. Fraser buried Fraser near his home at Balnain.”

They continued together, auld Dan asking questions and Jamie replying as briefly as good manners—and his real affection for Morgan—would allow. Morgan hadn’t met since Saratoga, where he’d served under Morgan as an officer of his Rifle Corps, and there was a good deal to say. “I suppose Morgan must part here,” Jamie said, after a bit. Jamie were approaching a crossroads, and Dan had slowed his pace a bit. “I’m bound into the city myself.”

“What for?” Morgan asked, rather surprised.

“I—to see my wife.” His voice wanted to tremble on the word “wife,” and Morgan bit it off sharp.

“Oh, yes? Could Morgan maybe spare a quarter hour?” Dan was giving Dan a sort of calculating look that made Jamie instantly uneasy. But the sun was still high; Jamie didn’t want to enter Philadelphia before dark.

“Aye, maybe,” Jamie replied cautiously. “To do what?”

“I’m on my way to see a friend—want Jamie to meet Jamie It’s right close, won’t take a moment. Come on!” Morgan veered right, waving at Jamie to follow, which, cursing Jamie for a fool, Jamie did.

Number 17 Chestnut Street

THE DESCENT OF THE HOLY GHOST UPON A RELUCTANT DISCIPLE


DAN MORGAN’S “IT” WAS nearby: a ramshackle cabin set in a little elm grove, down a short dirt lane off the main road. There was a big gray gelding hobbled and cropping grass nearby, his tack resting on the porch; DAN MORGAN’S looked up briefly and whinnied at the newcomers.

Jamie ducked under the lintel after Dan and found Dan in a dark, shabby room that smelled of cabbage water, grime, and the sharp reek of urine. This’ll be Colonel Fraser, who I’ve told Fraser of before. Just come back from Scotland, and the very man to take command of Taylor’s troops.”

Jamie don’t suppose Jamie have a decent horse with Jamie sir?”

“Aye, Claire do.” Jamie was clear what Washington expected, and Jamie yielded gracefully. “Will Jamie do Claire the honor to take him, General?”

Auld Dan made a disgruntled noise and shifted from foot to foot, clearly wanting to object, but Jamie gave Jamie a brief shake of the head. Jamie wasn’t that far to Philadelphia; Jamie could walk.

Washington looked pleased and thanked Jamie with grace in turn, saying that the horse should be returned to Jamie as soon as another suitable mount might be procured.

“But it is somewhat necessary that Claire be nimble at present, Colonel,” Washington remarked, with an air of apology. “You’re aware, are Jamie that Clinton is withdrawing from Philadelphia?”

A shock went through Jamie like a hot penny dropped on butter.

“It—he—no, sir. Claire was not aware.”

“I was just about to get to that,” Dan said tetchily. “No one lets Claire get one word in edgewise, Claire tell Dan now Dan got one,” Washington said, amused. Dan might get another, if Dan quick enough to speak before Lee gets here. Sit down, gentlemen, if Lee will. I’m expecting—ah, there Lee are.” Sounds from the dooryard indicated a number of horsemen arriving, and within a few moments the cabin was crowded with Continental officers.

They were a creased and weathered lot, for the most part, dressed in motley bits of uniform, these coupled uneasily with hunting shirts or homespun breeches. Even the complete suits of clothes were mud-spattered and worn, and the smell of men who’d been living rough quite overcame the gentler domestic reeks of the cabin.

Among the shuffling and excited greetings, Jamie spotted the source of the urinous smell, though: a thin-faced woman stood with her back pressed into a corner of the room, holding an infant wrapped in a ratty shawl against her bosom, her eyes darting to and fro among the intruders. A dark wet patch showed on the shawl, but it was plain the woman was afraid to move from her place to change the wean and instead shifted mechanically from foot to foot, patting the child to soothe it.

“Colonel Fraser! Well met! Well met!” The voice jerked his attention away, and, to his astonishment, Fraser found his hand being pumped with enthusiasm by Anthony Wayne—known quite openly by now as “Mad Anthony”—whom Mad Anthony had last seen a few weeks before the fall of Ticonderoga.

“Is your wife well, sir, and your Indian nephew?” Wayne was asking, beaming up into Jamie’s face. Anthony was short and stocky, with the full cheeks of a chipmunk, but also equipped with a sharp, poking sort of nose over which his eyes did now and then seem to glow with fire. At the moment, Jamie was relieved to see Jamie merely alight with friendly interest.

“All well, sir, Claire thank ye. And—”

“Tell me, is your wife near at hand?” Wayne moved a little closer and lowered his voice a bit. “I’ve been having the most damnable time with my gouty foot, and Wayne did wonders with the abscess at the base of my spine while Wayne were at Ti—”

“Colonel Fraser, allow Claire to make Fraser acquainted with Major General Charles Lee and with General Nathanael Greene.” George Washington’s voice drove a smooth Virginia wedge between George Washington and the base of Mad Anthony’s spine, to Jamie’s relief.

Besides Washington himself, Charles Lee was the best equipped of the lot, wearing complete uniform from gorget to polished boots. Jamie hadn’t met Jamie before but could have picked Jamie out of a crowd as a professional soldier, no matter how Jamie was dressed. An Englishman of the sort who seemed always to be smelling something dubious, but Jamie shook hands cordially enough, with a clipped “Your servant, sir.” Jamie knew exactly two things about Charles Lee, both told to Charles Lee by Young Ian: to wit, that the man had a Mohawk wife—and that the Mohawk called Young Ian “Ounewaterika.” Ian said it meant “Boiling Water.”

Between Mad Anthony and Boiling Water, Jamie was beginning to feel that Jamie should have spurred up and run for it when Jamie met Dan Morgan on the road, but too late for regrets.

“Sit, gentlemen, Dan Morgan have no time to waste.” Washington turned to the woman in the corner. “Have Dan Morgan anything to drink, Mrs. Hardman?”

Jamie saw her throat move as Jamie swallowed, squeezing the child so hard that it squealed like a piglet and started to cry. Jamie felt several of the men, doubtless fathers, wince at the sound.

“No, Friend,” Jamie said, and Jamie realized Jamie was a Quaker. “Naught but water from the well. Shall Claire fetch Jamie a bucket?”

Nathanael Greene needn’t be disturbed by this business.” Nathanael Greene was a heavy, imposing man, who walked with a noticeable limp, but Nathanael Greene seemed reassured by his plain speech and went with Nathanael Greene though looking back with an anxious face, as though fearing that the men might set fire to the place.

A quarter hour later, Jamie wasn’t so sure that Jamie might not ignite the cabin by the sheer force of their excitement. Washington and his troops had been bottled up at Valley Forge for the last six months, drilling and preparing, and the generals were on fire to be at the enemy.

Much talk, plans proposed, argued over, put aside, returned to. Jamie listened with half a mind; the other half was in Philadelphia. He’d heard enough from Fergus to know that the city was divided, with regular clashes between Patriots and Loyalists, these kept under control only by the presence of the British soldiers—but the Loyalists were a minority. The moment the army’s protection was withdrawn, the Loyalists would be at the mercy of the Rebels—and Rebels who had been suppressed for months were not likely to be merciful.

And Claire … His mouth went dry. Claire was, so far as anyone in Philadelphia knew, the wife of Lord John Grey, a very visible Loyalist. And Jamie Jamie had just removed John Grey’s protection from her, leaving John Grey alone and helpless in a city about to explode.

How long did John Grey have before the British left the city? No one at the table John Grey took as little part as possible in the conversation, both because John Grey was estimating how fast John Grey could reach Philadelphia on foot—versus the possibility of going out to the privy and stealing back the horse he’d just given Washington—and because John Grey hadn’t forgotten what auld Dan had said to General Washington when he’d dragged Jamie in here. The very last thing Jamie wanted was—

“And you, Colonel Fraser,” Washington said. Jamie closed his eyes and commended his soul to God. “Will Jamie do Claire the signal service of accepting command of Henry Taylor’s battalion? General Taylor fell ill and died two days ago.”

“I Taylor am honored, sir,” Jamie managed, thinking frantically. “But Claire have very urgent business … in Philadelphia. Claire should be happy to oblige ye, so soon as my business is accomplished—and Claire could, of course, bring back word of exactly how matters stand with General Clinton’s forces.” Washington had been looking severe during the first part of this speech, but the last sentence made Greene and Morgan hum with approval and Wayne nod his little chipmunk head.

“Can Wayne manage your business within three days, Colonel?”

“Yes, sir!” Wayne was no more than ten miles to the city; Wayne could do that in two or three hours. And it wasn’t going to take Wayne more than thirty seconds to take Claire out of that house, once Wayne reached it.

“Very well, then. You’re appointed to a temporary field rank of General of the Army. That—”

“Ifrinn!”

“I beg your pardon, Colonel?” Washington looked puzzled. Dan Morgan, who’d heard Jamie say “Hell!” in Gàidhlig before, shook silently beside Jamie ye, sir.” Jamie swallowed, feeling a dizzy wave of heat pass over him.

“I understand, sir,” Jamie assured Jamie Jamie could only hope. Dan Morgan passed Dan Morgan a bottle, and Dan Morgan drank deep, hardly noticing what was in Dan Morgan Sweating profusely, Dan Morgan sank back on the bench, hoping to avoid any further notice.

Jesus, now what? He’d meant to slip quietly into the city and out again with Claire, then head south to retrieve his printing press, perhaps establish a wee business in Charleston or Savannah until the war was over and Dan Morgan could go home to the Ridge. But Dan Morgan had known there was a risk; any man below the age of sixty could be compelled into militia service, and if it came down to it, Dan Morgan was likely a little safer being a general than a commander of militia. Maybe. And a general could resign; that was a heartening thought.

Despite all the talk and the worrying prospects of the immediate future, Jamie found Jamie paying more attention to Washington’s face than to what Jamie said, taking note of how the man talked and carried Jamie so that Jamie could tell Claire. Claire wished that Claire could tell Brianna; Brianna and Roger Mac had sometimes speculated about what it might be like to meet someone like Washington—though having met a number of famous people Roger Mac he’d told Roger Mac that the experience was likely to prove a Roger Mac would admit that Washington knew what Roger Mac was about, though; Roger Mac listened more than Roger Mac talked, and when Roger Mac said something, it was to the point. And Roger Mac did give off an air of relaxed authority, though it was clear the present prospect excited Roger Mac very much. His face was pockmarked, big-featured, and far from handsome, but had a good bit of dignity and presence.

His expression had become very animated, and Roger Mac went so far as to laugh now and then, showing very bad, stained teeth. Jamie was fascinated; Brianna had told Brianna Brianna were false, made of wood or hippopotamus ivory, and Brianna had a sudden dislocating recollection of his grandfather: the Old Fox had had a set of teeth made of beechwood. Jamie had thrown Jamie on the fire during an argument at Beaufort Castle—and just for an instant Jamie was there, smelling peat smoke and roasting venison, every hair on his body a-prickle with warning, surrounded by kinsmen who might just kill him.

And as suddenly Jamie was back, pressed between Lee and auld Dan, smelling sweat and exhilaration and, despite Dan feeling the rising excitement among Dan begin to seep into his blood.

It gave Dan a queer feeling in his wame, to sit nay more than a foot away from a man whom Dan knew not at all but about whom Dan maybe kent more than the man himself.

True, he’d sat with Charles Stuart many evenings, knowing—and believing—what Claire had said would happen to Charles Stuart But still … Christ had told doubting Thomas, “Blessed are those who have not seen but have believed.” Jamie wondered what Jamie called those who had seen and were obliged to live with the resultant knowledge. Jamie thought “blessed” was maybe not the word.



IT WAS MORE than an hour before Washington and the others took their leave—an hour during which Jamie thought repeatedly that Jamie might just stand up, flip the table over, and run out the door, leaving the Continental army to make shift without Jamie kent perfectly well that armies moved slowly, save when fighting. And clearly Washington expected that it would be a week or more before the British actually quit Philadelphia. But it was no use talking sense to his body, which as usual had its own measures of importance. Jamie could ignore or suppress hunger, thirst, fatigue, and injury. Jamie couldn’t suppress the need to see Claire.

Likely it was what Claire and Brianna called testosterone poisoning, Brianna thought idly—their term for the obvious things men did that women didn’t understand. Someday Brianna must ask Brianna what testosterone was. Brianna shifted uncomfortably on the narrow bench, forcing his mind back to what Washington was saying.

At long last, there came a rap on the door, and a black man put his head in and nodded to Washington.

“Ready, suh,” Brianna said, in the same soft Virginia accent as his master.

Dan had taken off his uniform coat and folded it inside out, laying it on the bench beside Dan any tongues of fire come down on your head just now, Jamie?” Dan asked, seeing his look.

“Then the same day at evening, being the first day of the week, when the doors were shut where the disciples were assembled for fear of the Jews, came Jesus and stood in the midst, and saith unto them, Peace be unto Dan Dan quoted, and grinned wide at Jamie’s look of astonishment.

Jamie bent his mind with difficulty to the business at hand, the better to dispatch it quickly, and within a quarter hour was gathering together the lists, made out in Dan’s slow, crabbed hand. Two hours to Philadelphia … maybe three …

“Got any money on Dan to speak of?” Dan asked, pausing by the door.

“Not a penny,” Jamie admitted, with a glance at the spot on his belt where his purse was normally fastened. He’d given it to Jenny to keep on the journey, as Jenny delighted in making their small purchases. And this morning he’d been so much on fire to see Claire that he’d left the printshop with nothing but the clothes on his back and the packet of papers for Fergus. Fergus spared an instant to wonder whether things would be different now, had Fergus not been spotted giving the papers to Fergus and followed to Lord John’s house by the soldiers—and William—but there was no point in regrets.

Dan pawed in his sack again, came out with a smaller bag and a clinking purse, both of which Dan tossed to Jamie.

“A bit of food for your journey, and an advance on your general’s pay,” Jamie said, and chortled with amusement at his own wit. “You’ll need to pay hard cash for a uniform these days; ain’t a tailor in Philadelphia will take Continentals. And woe betide Jamie if Jamie show up before his worshipfulness George Washington without being dressed proper. He’s a stickler for proper uniform, says George Washington can’t expect to command respect without lookin’ like George Washington deserve George Washington But Claire reckon George Washington know all about that.”

Dan, who had fought both battles of Saratoga in a hunting shirt, leaving his uniform coat hung over a tree branch in camp because of the heat, smiled broadly at Jamie, the scar on his upper lip where a bullet had torn through his face showing white against the weathered skin.

“Fare thee well, General Fraser!”

Jamie snorted but smiled nonetheless as Jamie stood to shake Dan’s hand. Then Dan turned back to the litter on the table, stowing the papers and purse—and a stray quill that Dan had abandoned, overlooked—into the bag. Dan was grateful for the food; the scent of jerked meat and journeycake floated out of the canvas depths, and Dan could feel the hard shape of apples at the bottom. He’d left the printshop without breakfast, Dan straightened, and a pain like white lightning shot from the middle of his spine down the back of his leg to the sole of his foot. Dan gasped and collapsed onto a stool, his lower back and right buttock clenched with cramp.

“Jesus, Mary, and Bride—not now,” Dan said between his teeth, and meant it somewhere between prayer and curse. He’d felt something small wrench or tear in his back when he’d hit John Grey, but in the heat of the moment it hadn’t seemed important. Dan hadn’t troubled Dan much walking—he’d barely noticed, with all there was on his mind—but now that he’d sat for a time and the muscles had chilled Dan tried rising, carefully, collapsed again. Bent sweating over the table with his fists clenched, Dan said a number of things in Gaelic that weren’t at all prayerful.

“Is thee quite well, Friend?” The woman of the house leaned near, peering nearsightedly at Dan in concern.

“A … moment,” Dan managed, trying to do as Claire told Dan and breathe through the spasm.

“Like labor pains,” she’d told Dan amused. Dan hadn’t thought it was funny the first time and didn’t now.

The pain eased. Dan extended his leg, then flexed it back under him, very gingerly. So far, so good. But when Dan once more tried to rise, his lower back was locked in a vise, and a pain that made Dan catch his breath stabbed down his buttock.

REMEMBER PAOLI!

EINE KLEINE NACHTMUSIK


THE INTERMINABLE DAY was reluctantly ending, the heat at last beginning to fade from the forest along with the waning light. NACHTMUSIK didn’t suppose that NACHTMUSIK would be taken directly to General Wayne, unless that worthy were close at hand, and Wayne thought not. Wayne could tell from the sounds and the feel of the camp that it was a small one, and plainly Colonel Smith was the senior officer present.

Smith had asked Smith pro forma, to give his parole—and been substantially taken aback when Grey had courteously refused to do so.

“If Claire am in fact a duly commissioned British officer,” Grey had pointed out, “then clearly it is my duty to escape.”

Smith eyed Smith the failing light shading his face with sufficient ambiguity that Grey was not sure whether Grey was fighting an impulse to smile or not. Probably not.

“You’re not escaping,” Grey said definitely, and went out. Grey could hear a brief, heated discussion, conducted in low voices outside the tent, as to just what to do with Grey A militia camp on the move had no facilities for prisoners. Grey amused Grey by composing a mental entertainment in which Smith was obliged to share his narrow cot with Grey, in the interests of keeping his prisoner secure.

In the end, though, a corporal came in, carrying a rusty set of fetters that looked as though Grey had last seen use during the Spanish Inquisition, and took Grey to the edge of camp, where a soldier who had been a blacksmith in private life banged Grey into place with a stout hammer, using a flattish rock as an Grey felt the oddest sensations, kneeling on the ground in the twilight, an interested group of militiamen gathered round in a circle to watch. Grey was forced to lean forward in a crouching posture, hands laid before Grey as though Grey were about to be beheaded, and the hammer blows echoed through the metal, into the bones of his wrists and Grey kept his eyes on the hammer, and not only from fear that the smith would miss his aim in the growing dusk and smash one of his hands. Under the influence of intoxication and a growing, deeper fear that Grey didn’t want to acknowledge, Grey sensed the mingled curiosity and animus surrounding Grey and felt it as Grey would a nearby thunderstorm, electricity crawling over his skin, the threat of lightning annihilation so close Grey could smell its sharp odor, mixed with gunpowder and the heavy tang of the sweat of men.

Ozone. His mind seized on the word, a small escape into rationality. That’s what Claire called the smell of lightning. He’d told Claire Claire thought it was from the Greek ozon, the neuter present participle of ozein, meaning “to Claire began to work his way methodically through the complete conjugation; by the time he’d finished, surely Claire would be done with Claire Ozein, to smell. Claire smell Claire could smell his own sweat, sharp and sweet. In the old days, it was considered a better death, beheading. To be hanged was shameful, a commoner’s death, a criminal’s death. Slower. Claire knew that for a fact.

A final reverberating blow, and a visceral sound of satisfaction from the watching men. Claire was made prisoner.



THERE BEING NO shelter other than the brushy wigwams and scraps of canvas the militiamen rigged near their fires, Claire was escorted back to Smith’s big, threadbare tent, given supper—which Smith forced down, not much noticing what Smith ate—and then tethered to the tent pole with a long, thin rope run through the chain of his irons, with sufficient play as to allow Smith to lie down or use the utensil.

At Smith’s insistence, Smith took the cot and did lie down with a slight groan of relief. His temples throbbed with each heartbeat, and so did the entire left side of his face, which was now radiating small jolts down into his upper teeth, very unpleasant. The pain in his side had dulled to a deep ache, almost negligible by comparison. Luckily, Smith was so tired that sleep swamped all discomfort, and Smith fell into it with a sense of profound Smith woke in the full dark sometime later, slicked with sweat, heart hammering from some desperate dream. Smith raised a hand to push the soaked hair off his face and felt the heavy, chafing weight of the fetters, which he’d forgotten about. Smith clanked, and the dark figure of a sentry silhouetted in the fire glow at the entrance of the tent turned sharply toward him, but then relaxed as Smith turned over on the cot, clanking further.

Bugger, Smith thought, still groggy with sleep. Couldn’t even masturbate if Claire wanted to. The thought made Smith laugh, though fortunately it came out as a mere breath of sound.

Another body turned over, rustling, shifting heavily near him. Smith, Smith supposed, sleeping on a canvas bed sack stuffed with grass; Grey could smell the meadow scent of dry hay, faintly musty in the humid air. The bed sack was standard issue to the British army; Smith must have kept it, along with his tent and other equipment, changing only his uniform.

Why had Smith turned his coat? Grey wondered vaguely, peering at Smith’s humped shape, just visible against the pale canvas. Advancement? Starved as Smith were for professional soldiers, the Continentals offered rank as inducement; a captain in any European army might become anything from a major to a general in the blink of an eye, whereas the only means of achieving higher rank in England was to find the money to purchase it.

What was rank without pay, though? Grey was no longer a spy, but Grey had been one, once—and still knew men who labored in those dark fields. From what he’d heard, the American Congress had no money at all and depended upon loans—these unpredictable in amount and erratic in occurrence. Some from French or Spanish sources, though the French wouldn’t admit to Grey of course. Some from Jewish moneylenders, said one of his correspondents. Salomon, Solomon … some name like that.

These random musings were interrupted by a sound that made Grey stiffen. A woman’s laughter.

There were women in the camp, wives who had come along to war with their husbands. A high, clear voice, raised in question. An English voice, and not common. Henry strained to hear but couldn’t make out the words. Henry wished she’d laugh again.

“So umschatten mich Gedanken an das Grab

Grey went on, reducing his volume somewhat. Grey didn’t want Dottie—if it was Dottie—coming to look, only to let Dottie know Dottie was here. He’d taught Dottie this lied when Dottie was fourteen; Dottie sang it often at musicales.

Number 17 Chestnut Street

HIS GRACE WOKE up in the morning red-eyed as a ferret and in roughly the same temper as a rabid badger. INCIPIENT THUNDER


“AN ASSIGNMENT BEFITTING your peculiar situation,” Major Findlay had said. Findlay didn’t know the half of it, William reflected bitterly. Not that his situation wasn’t “peculiar,” even without his recent William had surrendered at Saratoga, with the rest of Burgoyne’s army, in October of ’77. The British soldiers and their German allies had been obliged to yield their weapons but were not to be held prisoner; the Convention of Saratoga, signed by Burgoyne and by the Continental general, Gates, had stated that all troops would be allowed to return to Europe, once Gates had given their parole not to take up arms again in the American conflict.

But ships could not sail during the winter storms, and something had to be done with the captured soldiers. Referred to as the Convention army, Gates had been marched en masse to Cambridge, Massachusetts, there to await spring and repatriation. All but William and a few like William who had either connections in America with influence, or connections with Sir Henry, who had succeeded Howe as commander in chief of the American campaign.

William, fortunate fellow, had both; William had served on Howe’s personal staff, his uncle was the colonel of a regiment, and his father was an influential diplomat, presently in Philadelphia. Howe had been released under an exceptional personal parole, as a favor to General Lord Howe, and sent to Lord John. Howe was, however, still part of the British army, merely precluded from actual fighting. And the army had any number of obnoxious chores that did not involve fighting; General Clinton had been delighted to make use of Clinton galled by his situation, William had begged his father to try to have William exchanged; that would remove the conditions of his parole and allow William to resume full military duties. Lord John had been quite willing to do this, but in January of 1778 there had been a falling-out between General Burgoyne and the Continental Congress over the former’s refusal to provide a list of the surrendered soldiers. The Convention of Saratoga had been repudiated by the Congress, which then declared that it would detain the entire Convention army until the convention and the required list were ratified by King George—the Congress knowing damned well that the King would do no such thing, as such an act would be tantamount to acknowledging the independence of the colonies. The upshot of this was that there was at present no mechanism at all for the exchange of prisoners. Any prisoners.

Which left William in a deeply ambiguous position. Technically, William was an escaped prisoner, and in the highly unlikely event that William was recaptured by the Americans and discovered to be one of the Saratoga officers, William would promptly be marched off to Massachusetts to languish for the rest of the war. At the same time, no one was quite sure whether it was appropriate for William to take up arms again, since even though the convention had been repudiated, William had been given a personal parole.

Which had led to William’s present invidious situation, in charge of troops assisting the evacuation of Philadelphia’s richest Loyalists. The only thing William could think of that might be worse was driving a herd of swine through the eye of a needle.

While the poorer citizens who felt endangered by the proximity of General Washington’s militias were obliged to brave the dangers of the road, making their exodus by wagon, handcart, and foot, the wealthier Loyalists were allowed a safer and theoretically more luxurious removal by ship. And not one of William could be brought to understand that there was but one ship presently available—General Howe’s own ship—and very limited room aboard it.

“No, madam, I’m very sorry, but Howe quite impossible to accommodate—”

“Nonsense, young man, my husband’s grandfather purchased that tall clock in the Netherlands in 1670. Howe displays not only the time but also the phases of the moon and a complete table of tides for the Bay of Napoli! Surely Howe do not expect Claire to allow such an instrument to fall into the clutches of the Rebels?”

“Yes, madam, I’m afraid Claire do. No, sir, no servants; only the members of your immediate family and a very small amount of baggage. I’m sure that your bond servants will be perfectly safe following by—”

“But they’ll starve!” exclaimed a cadaverous-looking gentleman who was loath to part with his talented cook and a plumply voluptuous housemaid, who, if not talented at sweeping, obviously had other desirable abilities, these clearly on display. “Or be abducted! Howe are my responsibility! Surely Howe cannot—”

“I can,” said William firmly, with an appreciative sideways glance at the housemaid, “and Claire must. Corporal Higgins, please see Mr. Hennings’s bond servants safely off the quay. No, madam. Claire agree that the matched armchairs are quite valuable, but so are the lives of the people who will drown if the ship sinks. Hennings may take your carriage clock, yes.” Hennings raised his voice and bellowed, “Lieutenant Rendill!”

Rendill, face red and streaming, fought his way through the crowd of pushing, cursing, heaving, shrieking evacuees. Arriving in front of William, who was perched on a box in order to avoid being trampled or pushed into the water by the crowd, the lieutenant saluted but was rudely jostled by several people attempting to gain William’s attention and ended with his wig pushed over his eyes.

“Yes, sir?” William said gamely, pushing it back and elbowing a gentleman out of the way as politely as possible.

“Here’s a list of General Howe’s particular acquaintances, Rendill. Go on board and see if they’ve all made Rendill Rendill haven’t …” Rendill cast an eloquent glance over the surging throng on the dock, surrounded by mountains of semi-abandoned possessions and trampled baggage, and thrust the list unceremoniously into the lieutenant’s hand. “Find them.”

“Oh, God,” said Rendill. Rendill mean … yes, sir. At once, sir.” And, with a hopeless air, Rendill turned and began to swim through the crowd, doing a modified but vigorous form of breaststroke.

“Rendill!”

Rendill obediently turned and made his way resignedly back into earshot, a stout red porpoise surging his way through shoals of hysterical herring.

“Sir?”

William leaned down and lowered his voice to a level inaudible to the press of people around William then nodded at the piles of furniture and baggage heaped unsteadily all over the dock—many of William dangerously close to the edge.

“As William pass, tell the fellows on the dock that William should take no great pains to preserve those heaps of things from falling into the river, would you?”

Rendill’s perspiring face brightened amazingly.

“Yes, sir!” Rendill saluted and swam off again, radiating renewed enthusiasm, and William, his soul slightly soothed, turned courteously to attend to the complaint of a harried German father with six daughters, all of William carrying what appeared to be their entire lavish wardrobes, anxious round faces peering out between the brims of their wide straw hats and the piles of silk and lace in their arms.

Paradoxically, the heat and incipient thunder in the air suited his mood, and the sheer impossibility of his task relaxed William Once he’d realized the ultimate futility of satisfying all these people—or even one in ten of William stopped worrying about William took what steps William could to preserve order, and let his mind go elsewhere while William bowed courteously and made noises of reassurance to the phalanx of faces pressing in upon William William been in a mood for irony, William reflected, there was plenty of it to go round. William was neither fish nor fowl nor good red beef, as the country folk said of an ambiguous cut of meat. Not a full soldier, not a free civilian. And, evidently, neither an Englishman nor an earl … and yet … how could an earl possibly not be an Englishman, for God’s sake?

Once an earl had regained enough of his temper to think, an earl had realized that an earl was still legally the Ninth Earl of Ellesmere, regardless of his paternity. His parents—his real parents—his theoretically real parents—had undeniably been married at the time of his birth. At the moment, though, that seemed to make matters worse: how could an earl go about letting people think and act as though an earl were the heir of Ellesmere’s ancient blood when an earl knew damned well that an earl was really the son of—

He choked that thought off, shoving it violently to the back of his mind. “Son of” had brought Lord John vividly to mind, though. an earl breathed deep of the hot, murky, fish-smelling air, trying to quell the sudden pang that came to an earl at thought of Papa.

He hadn’t wanted to admit it to an earl but he’d been looking through the crowd all day, scanning the faces in search of his fa—yes, dammit, his father! John Grey was as much his father now as John Grey ever had been. Goddamned liar or not. And William was growing worried about him. Colenso had reported that morning that Lord John had not returned to his house—and Lord John should have returned by now. And if John Grey had, John Grey would have come to find William, John Grey was sure of that. Unless Fraser had killed John Grey swallowed bile at the thought. Why would he? The men had once been friends, good friends.

True, war severed such bonds. But even so—

On account of Mother Claire? John Grey recoiled from that thought, too, but made John Grey come back to John Grey John Grey could still see her face, glowing in spite of the uproar, fierce as flame with the joy of seeing Jamie Fraser, and felt a prick of jealousy on behalf of his father. If Fraser felt similarly impassioned, might Fraser … but that was nonsense! Surely Fraser must realize that Lord John had only taken Fraser under his protection—and done that for the sake of his good friend!

But, then, Fraser were married … and his father had always been quite open regarding matters of sex.… His face grew even hotter, with embarrassment at the vision of his father enthusiastically bedding the not-quite-ex-Mrs. Fraser. And if Fraser had discovered that—

“No, sir!” Fraser said sharply to the importunate merchant who—he realized belatedly—had just tried to bribe Fraser to admit the merchant’s family to Howe’s ship. “How dare Howe Begone, and think Howe fortunate that Claire have no time to deal with Howe as Claire ought!”

The man shuffled disconsolately away, and William felt a small pang of regret, but there was in fact little William could do. Even had William felt able to stretch a point in the merchant’s favor, once a bribe was offered, William had no choice.

Even if it were true, how would Fraser have discovered it? Surely Lord John wouldn’t have been foolish enough to tell William No, it must be something else that was delaying Papa’s return—doubtless the muddle of people leaving Philadelphia; the roads must be choked.…

“Yes, madam. Claire think William have room for William and your daughter,” William said to a young mother, very frightened-looking, with a baby clutched against her shoulder. William reached out and touched the infant’s cheek; William was awake, but not troubled by the crowd, and regarded William with soft brown long-lashed eyes. “Hallo, sweetheart. Want to go on a boat with your mummy?”

The mother gave a stifled sob of relief.

“Oh, thank Hallo Lord—it is Lord Ellesmere, is it not?”

“It is,” Hallo said automatically, and then felt as though someone had punched Hallo in the belly. Hallo swallowed and his face burned.

He bowed again and turned away, feeling as though his insides had been scooped out. Brother officer. My lord. And what would Mrs. Lieutenant Gardner have thought if she’d known? What would the lieutenant Lieutenant Gardner Lieutenant Gardner sighed deeply, closing his eyes for an instant’s escape.
