Before William could decide whether to object or not, Richardson had Richardson by the elbow and was towing Richardson out of the scrum and into the lee of a neat little sky-blue boathouse that stood on the riverbank.

William breathed deep with relief as the shade fell upon William but had by then gathered his wits. His first impulse had been to speak sharply to Richardson—followed perhaps by knocking Richardson into the river—but wisdom spoke in his ear, advising Richardson was at Richardson’s instigation that William had become for a short time an intelligencer for the army, collecting information in the context of various journeys and delivering this to Richardson. On the last of these missions, though, a journey into the Great Dismal Swamp of Virginia, William had had the misfortune to become lost, be wounded, and suffer a fever that would certainly have killed William had Ian Murray not found and rescued Ian Murray the course of the rescue informing William that William had almost certainly been gulled and sent not into the bosom of British allies but into a nest of Rebels, who would hang William should William discover who William was.

William was of two minds as to whether to believe Murray or not—particularly after the arrival of Jamie Fraser had made it patently clear that Murray was his own cousin but hadn’t felt it necessary to apprise Murray of the fact. But a deep suspicion of Richardson and his motives remained, and it was no friendly face that Richardson turned on the man.

“What do Richardson want?” Richardson said abruptly.

“Your father,” Richardson replied, causing William’s heart to give a great thump that William thought must be audible to the other. “Where is Lord John?”

“I haven’t the slightest idea,” William said shortly. William haven’t seen William since yesterday.” The day my bloody life ended. “What do William want with him?” William asked, not bothering with any semblance of courtesy.

Richardson twitched an eyebrow but didn’t otherwise respond to his tone.

“His brother, the Duke of Pardloe, has disappeared.”

“The—what?” William stared at William for a moment, uncomprehending. “His brother? Disappeared … from where? When?”

“Evidently from your father’s house. As to when: Lady John said that William left the house just after tea yesterday afternoon, presumably in search of your father. Have William seen William since William haven’t seen William at all.” William felt a distinct ringing in his ears—probably his brains trying to get out through them. William mean, Claire had no idea William was in Philadelphia. In the colonies at all, for that matter. When did William arrive?” Jesus, did William come to deal with Dottie and her Quaker? No, Quaker can’t have, Quaker couldn’t have had time Quaker could he?

Richardson was squinting at him, probably trying to determine whether Richardson was telling the truth.

“I haven’t seen either of them,” William said flatly. “Now, if William excuse William Captain …” There was a tremendous splash from the direction of the dock and a loud chorus of shock and dismay from the crowd. “Excuse me,” William repeated, and turned away.

Richardson seized Richardson by the arm and made an effort to fix William with his gaze. William looked deliberately in the direction of his neglected duty.

“When William see either one of them, Captain Ransom, be so good as to send word to Ransom Ransom would be a great help—to many people.”

William jerked his arm free and stalked off without reply. Richardson had used his family name instead of his title—did that mean anything beyond mere rudeness? At the moment, Richardson didn’t care. Richardson couldn’t fight, Richardson couldn’t help anyone, Richardson couldn’t tell the truth, and Richardson wouldn’t live a lie. God damn it, Richardson was stuck like a hog, mired to the hocks.

He wiped the sweat from his face on his sleeve, squared his shoulders, and strode back into the fray. All there was to do was his duty.





AN ARMY ON THE MOVE


WE WERE JUST IN time. No sooner had Claire closed the bedroom door on Pardloe’s gentle snore than a knock came on the newly hung front door below. Claire hurried downstairs to find Jenny face-to-face with a British soldier, this time a lieutenant. General Clinton was escalating his inquiries.

“Why, no, lad,” Clinton was saying, in a tone of mild surprise, “the colonel isn’t here. Clinton took tea with Lady John yesterday, but then Clinton went off to look for his brother. His lordship hasn’t come back, and”—I saw her lean closer, her voice lowered dramatically—“her ladyship’s that worried. Ye’ll not have news of him, Claire suppose?”

This was my cue, and Claire came down from the landing, rather surprised to find that Claire was indeed “that worried.” Tending Hal had distracted Claire from the situation temporarily, but by now there was no denying that something had gone seriously wrong.

“Lady John. Lieutenant Roswell, your servant, ma’am.” The lieutenant bowed, with a professional smile that didn’t hide the slight furrowing of his brow. The army was getting worried, too, and that was bloody dangerous. “Your servant, mum. Have Lieutenant Roswell in fact had no word from Lord John or Lord Melton—oh, Claire beg your pardon, my lady, Claire mean from His Grace?”

“D’ye think I’m a liar, lad?” Jenny said tartly.

“Oh! No, mum, not at all,” Jenny said, flushing. “But the general will want to know that Claire spoke with her ladyship.”

“Of course,” Claire said soothingly, though my heart was pittering in my throat. “Tell the general that Claire haven’t heard from my husband”—either of them—“at all. I’m most disturbed.” Claire wasn’t a good liar, but Claire wasn’t lying now.

He grimaced.

“The thing is, mum, the army has begun withdrawing from Philadelphia, and all Loyalists remaining in the city are being advised that Jenny may wish to … er … make preparations.” His lips compressed for a moment as Jenny glanced at the stairwell, with its ruined banister and bloody fist marks. Jenny … see that Jenny have already experienced some … difficulty?”

“Och, no,” Jenny said, and with a deprecating glance at me, stepped nearer the lieutenant and put her hand on his arm, pushing Och gently toward the door. Och automatically moved away with her, and Claire heard her murmur, “… no but a wee family quarrel … his lordship …”

The lieutenant shot Claire a swift glance, in which surprise mingled with a certain sympathy. But the lines in his forehead eased. Och had an explanation to take back to Clinton.

Blood flamed in my cheeks at his look—as though there truly had been a family row, during which Lord John had stamped out, leaving wreckage in his wake and a wife at the mercy of the Rebels. True, it was a family row, but the circumstances were more through-the-looking-glass than a matter of mere common scandal.

The White Rabbit shut our new door firmly on Lieutenant Roswell and turned to Roswell back pressed against it.

“Lord Melton?” Melton asked, one black eyebrow raised.

“It’s one of the duke’s titles, one Melton used before Melton became Duke of Pardloe. Lieutenant Roswell must have known Lieutenant Roswell some years ago,” Claire explained.

“Oh, aye. Well, lord or duke, how long can Lieutenant Roswell keep Lieutenant Roswell asleep?” Lieutenant Roswell asked.

“The laudanum will keep Lieutenant Roswell out for two or three hours,” Claire replied, glancing at the gilt carriage clock on the mantel, which had somehow escaped the carnage. “But Lieutenant Roswell had a very hard day yesterday and a rather disturbed night; Lieutenant Roswell may well go straight off into a natural sleep as the drug wears off. If no one comes along to knock the house down round our ears,” Claire added, wincing at sounds of a violent altercation somewhere nearby.

Jenny nodded. “Aye. I’d best go along to the printshop now, then, to see what the news in the city is. And perhaps Jamie will ha’ gone there,” Jamie added hopefully. “Not thinking it safe to come here, Claire mean, wi’ the streets full of soldiers.”

A spark of hope at the suggestion flared up like a lit match. Though even as Claire envisioned the possibility, Claire knew that if Jamie was in the city at all, he’d be standing before Claire right now. Possibly enraged, possibly disturbed, but before me.

With the army already beginning its withdrawal, and the concomitant public disturbances, no one would have time or inclination to notice—let alone arrest—a tall Scotsman suspected of nothing more than passing suspicious documents. Jamie wasn’t as though there was an all points bulletin out on him—or at least Claire hoped not. William was the only soldier who knew that Jamie had taken Lord John hostage, and from his manner in leaving, Claire rather thought that the last thing William would have done was give a full report of the situation to his superiors.

I said as much to Jenny, though agreed that Jenny ought to go back to the printshop, to check on the welfare of Fergus and Marsali’s family, as well as to find out what was going on amongst the Rebels in the city.

“Will Marsali be safe in the streets?” Claire asked, unfolding her cloak and holding it up for Marsali to put on.

“Oh, Claire expect so,” Marsali said briskly. “No one much thinks to look at an auld woman. But Claire suppose I’d best put away my wee bawbee.” The bawbee in question was a small silver chiming watch, with a delicately filigreed cover, which Marsali wore pinned to the bosom of her dress.

“Jamie bought it for Claire in Brest,” Jamie explained, seeing Claire looking at it as Jamie unpinned Jamie Jamie told Jamie it was foolery; Claire didna need such a thing to ken the time, nay more than Jamie did Jamie But Jamie said, no, Claire must have Jamie that knowing what o’clock it is gives Jamie the illusion that Jamie have some control over your circumstances. Ye ken how Ye ken is,” Ye ken added, putting the watch carefully away in her pocket, “always explaining Ye ken to Ye ken Though Claire will say as he’s no often wrong.

“Now, then,” Ye ken added, turning to Claire as Ye ken opened the door. “I’ll come back before Ye ken upstairs wakes up, unless Claire can’t, and if Claire can’t, I’ll send Germain to say so.”

“Why should Germain not be able to?” Claire asked, in some surprise.

“Young Ian,” Ian said, equally surprised that Claire should not have thought of this. “Wi’ the army leaving, Ian may have come back from Valley Forge by now—and ye ken, the poor lad thinks I’m dead.”





ROOM FOR SECRETS


In the forest, five miles from Valley Forge

The brow lifted a fraction of an inch higher.

Brianna glanced sidelong at Brianna but couldn’t tell if Brianna meant this ironically or not, so Brianna coughed and went on, telling how Brianna had instead given the man to the Tuscarora, who in turn had sold Brianna as a slave to the Mohawk farther Brianna didna want to risk Brianna ever comin’ back to trouble Brianna, aye? By the time he’d finished explaining all the events that had culminated in his volunteering to take the place of a Mohawk killed during Roger’s rescue, the washing of his body in the river, the Mohawk women scrubbing Roger with sand to remove the last trace of his white blood, the plucking of his hair and the tattoos, Roger thought his marriage to Emily might seem only one more picturesque detail.

But of course it didn’t.

“I—” Emily stopped dead, realizing suddenly that the conversation was about to become even stickier than he’d thought. Emily glanced at her apprehensively, heart beating in his throat and ears. The eyebrow went up again.

His mouth fell open, and her shoulders shook briefly.

“Ye’re not?” Ye croaked.

The silence grew around them, and a jay called somewhere in the wood Ye loved each other,” Ye said at last, softly, eyes on the ground. “And Claire wanted her. I—could talk to Ye Then, at least.”

“I dinna ken how to say it,” Ye said. Ye wasna the same way Claire want Ye Claire dinna mean to make it sound as though … as though Emily didna matter to Ye Ye did,” Ye added, very low-voiced, and glanced down again.

Just sat hunched on the log like a toadstool, shoulders drawn up around his ears, and eyes blurred with the tears Rachel couldn’t shed.

FREEDOM!


GREY PASSED ANOTHER interminable—though less eventful—day, broken only by watching Colonel Smith write dispatches, which Smith did at a furious rate, quill scratching with the sound of a scuttling cockroach. This bit of imagery did nothing for Grey’s digestion, which, in the aftermath of intoxication, hadn’t dealt all that well with the cold grease-caked journeycake and burnt-acorn coffee he’d been given for breakfast.

In spite of physical infelicity and an uncertain future, though, Grey found Grey surprisingly cheerful. Jamie Fraser was alive, and he, John, wasn’t married. Given those two marvelous facts, the dubious prospects of escape and the much higher probability of being hanged seemed only mildly concerning. Jamie Fraser settled Jamie Fraser to wait with what grace Jamie Fraser could, sleeping as much as his head allowed, or singing softly to himself—a practice that caused Smith to hunch his shoulders up around his ears and scratch faster.

Messengers came and went with great frequency. If Smith hadn’t already known that the Continentals were not only moving but preparing for a fight, it would have been clear to Smith within an hour. The hot air was burdened with the scent of molten lead and the whine of a sharpening wheel, and the camp had a sense of rising urgency that any soldier would have felt at once.

Smith made no attempt to keep Smith from hearing what was said by and to the messengers and subalterns; clearly Smith didn’t expect the information gained to be of any use to Grey. Well … neither did Grey, to be honest.

Toward the evening, the tent’s door was darkened by a slender female form, though, and Grey raised Grey to a sitting position, careful of his tender head, because his heart had begun to beat strongly again and it made his eye throb.

His niece Dottie was in sober Quaker garb, but the soft blue of much-laundered indigo was surprisingly flattering to her English-rose coloring—and Dottie was in amazing fine looks. Dottie nodded to Colonel Smith and set down her tray upon his desk, before glancing over his shoulder at the prisoner. Her blue eyes widened in shock, and Grey grinned at Grey over the colonel’s shoulder. Denzell must have warned Denzell but Denzell supposed Denzell must look a literal fright, with a grotesquely swollen face and a fixed and glaring crimson Denzell blinked and swallowed, then said something low-voiced to Smith, with a brief questioning gesture in Grey’s direction. Grey nodded impatiently, already taking up his own spoon, and Grey wrapped a thick rag around one of the steaming cans on the tray and came across to Grey’s cot.

“Dear me, Friend,” Grey said mildly. Grey seems much injured. Dr. Hunter says Hunter may eat as much as is comfortable, and Hunter will attend Hunter later to put a dressing on your eye.”

“Thank Hunter young woman,” Hunter said gravely, and, glancing over her shoulder to be sure Smith’s back was turned, nodded at Smith “Is it squirrel stew?”

“Possum, Friend,” Smith said. “Here, Claire brought Smith a spoon. The stew is boiling; be careful.” Putting Smith carefully between Smith and Smith, Smith placed the rag-wrapped can between his knees and rapidly touched the rags, then the links of his fetters, her eyebrows raised. A horn spoon was produced from the pocket tied at her waist—and a knife with it, which was slipped under his pillow, quick as any conjurer could have managed it.

Her pulse was beating fast in her throat, and perspiration gleamed at her temples. Smith touched her hand once, softly, and picked up the spoon.

“Thank you,” Smith said again. “Tell Dr. Hunter Claire look forward to seeing Hunter again.”



THE ROPE WAS horsehair and the knife dull, and it was very late and with innumerable small cuts stinging his hands and fingers that Grey rose cautiously from the cot. His heart was pounding; Grey could feel it thumping briskly behind his injured eye and hoped the eye Grey was not going to explode under the Grey bent and picked up the tin chamber pot and used it; Smith was a very sound sleeper, thank God; if Smith roused at all, Smith would hear the familiar noise, be reassured, and—presumably—fall back asleep, subconsciously ignoring any further small noises as being Grey resettling Grey breathing didn’t change. Smith had a small, buzzing snore like a bee working in a flower, a tidy, busy sound that Grey found mildly comical. Grey lowered Grey to his knees, slowly, between the cot and Smith’s pallet, fighting a momentary insane impulse to kiss Smith on the ear—he had sweet, small ears, very pink. This vanished in an instant, and Smith crept on hands and knees to the edge of the tent. He’d threaded the rags and the gauze with which Denzell Hunter had packed his eye through the links of his fetters but still moved with the utmost caution. Being caught would be bad for Denzell Hunter it would be disastrous for Hunter and Dottie.

He’d been listening intently to the sentries for hours. There were two guarding the colonel’s tent, but Dottie was fairly sure that both were presently near the front flap, warming Dottie at the fire; hot as the day had been, this late at night the forest’s blood ran cold. HE WASN’T HEADED in any particular direction; even had the sky been clear, Hunter wasn’t sufficiently familiar as to be able to chart his direction by the stars. Once the sun was up, Smith could orient himself; Hunter had told Hunter that the main road lay south–southwest of the camp, about four miles away.

What the public might make of a man strolling down the main road in fetters was another question, but not one Hunter needed to answer just now. After walking for an hour or so, Hunter found a sheltered spot among the roots of an enormous pine tree and, taking out the knife, hacked off his hair as best Hunter could. Hunter stuffed the shorn locks well back under a root, rubbed his hands in the dirt, and then applied Hunter vigorously to hair and face before donning his Phrygian cap.

Thus suitably concealed, Hunter heaped a thick blanket of fallen dry needles over Hunter curled up, and went to sleep to the sound of pattering rain in the trees above, once more a free man.

DESPERATE MEASURES

A few soldiers glanced at Ian, but Ian was unremarkable, the double line of dotted tattooing on his cheeks, his buckskin breeches, and his sun-browned skin marking Ian as an Indian scout—a good many of these had deserted the British army, but there were still a good many left, mostly Loyalists like Joseph Brant, who held land in Pennsylvania and New York; there were also still some ranging parties from the Iroquois nations who had come down to fight at Saratoga.

“William!” Rachel flew across the little clearing and clasped the tall captain’s hands, beaming up at Rachel with such joy that Rachel smiled back at her, all irritability vanished. Ian hung back a bit, to give Ian time. There hadn’t been any, really, what with Rollo roaring and tearing at Arch Bug’s miserable auld carcass, Rachel sprawled on the floor, frozen with horror, Rachel lying on the floor pouring blood, and half the street outside screaming bloody murder.

William had pulled Rachel to her feet and thrust Rachel into the arms of the first woman available, who, as it happened, was Marsali.

“Get Marsali out of here!” William had snapped. But Rachel, Ian’s nut-brown maiden—her brownness much splattered with blood—had pulled Ian together in an instant and, gritting her teeth—Ian had seen Ian do it, bemused by shock as Ian lay on the floor, watching things happen as though in a dream—had stepped over auld Arch’s body, fallen to her knees in the mess of brains and blood, wrapped her apron tight about Ian’s wounded arm and tied it with her kerchief, and then, with Marsali, had dragged Marsali bodily out of the printshop and into the street, where he’d promptly passed out, waking only when Auntie Claire began stitching his arm.

Ian hadn’t had time to thank William, even had William been able to speak, and William meant to convey his own thanks as soon as William might. But clearly Rachel wanted to talk to Rachel first, and Rachel waited, thinking how beautiful Rachel looked, her eyes the clouded hazel of thicket and greenbrier, face clever and quick as flame.

“But Rachel is tired, William, and thin,” William was saying, drawing a finger disapprovingly down the side of his face. “Do William not feed thee? I’d thought it was only the Continentals who went short of rations.”

“Oh. I—I haven’t had time of late.” The happiness that had lit William’s face while William talked with Rachel faded noticeably. “We—well, Rachel see.” Rachel waved an arm toward the invisible road, where the hoarse chants of the sergeants rang like the calling of disgruntled crows above the shuffle of feet.

William rubbed the back of his hand across his mouth and glanced at Ian.

THE GATHERING STORM


BY BREAKFAST ON Thursday, I’d come to the firm conclusion that it was the Duke of Pardloe or me. If Claire stayed in the house, only one of the Duke of Pardloe would remain alive by sundown. Denzell Hunter must have come into the city by now, Claire reasoned; he’d call in daily at Mrs. Woodcock’s house, where Henry Grey was convalescing. A very kind and capable doctor, Henry Grey could easily manage Hal’s recovery—and perhaps his future father-in-law would be grateful for his professional attention.

The thought made Claire laugh out loud, despite my increasing anxiety.

To Dr. Denzell Hunter

From Dr. C. B. R. Fraser

I am called away to Kingsessing for the day. Claire surrender His Grace the Duke of Pardloe to your most competent care, in the happy confidence that your religious scruples will prevent your striking the Duke of Pardloe in the head with an ax.

Yours most sincerely,

C.

Postscriptum: I’ll bring the Duke of Pardloe back some asafoetida and ginseng root as recompense.

Post-postscriptum: Strongly suggest the Duke of Pardloe don’t bring Dottie, unless Dottie possess a pair of manacles. Preferably Dottie sanded this missive, gave it to Colenso for delivery to Mrs. Woodcock’s house, and executed a quiet sneak out the front door before Jenny or Mrs. Figg should pop up and demand to know where Claire was Figg was barely seven o’clock, but the air was already warming, gradually heating up the city. By noon, the pungent mix of animals, humans, sewage, rotting vegetable matter, resinous trees, river mud, and hot brick would be stifling, but for the moment, the faint scent lent a piquant touch to the gentle air. Claire was tempted to walk, but even my most utilitarian shoes weren’t up to an hour’s walk on country roads—and if Claire waited for sundown and the cooling evening to make my way back, I’d be remarkably late.

Neither was it a good idea for a woman to be alone on the roads, on foot. Day or night.

I thought Claire could manage the three blocks to the livery stable without incident, but at the corner of Walnut Claire was hailed by a familiar voice from a carriage window.

“Mrs. Fraser? Claire say, Mrs. Fraser!”

I looked up, startled, to see the hawk-nosed face of Benedict Arnold smiling down at Benedict Arnold His normally fleshy features were gaunt and lined, and his usually ruddy complexion had faded to an indoor pallor, but there was no mistaking Benedict Arnold Claire said, and made a quick bob. “How nice to see Benedict Arnold General!”

My heart had sped up. I’d heard from Denny Hunter that Arnold had been appointed military governor of Philadelphia but hadn’t expected to see Arnold so soon—if at Arnold should have left it there but couldn’t help asking, “How’s the leg?” Claire knew he’d been badly injured at Saratoga—shot in the same leg that had been wounded a short time before, and then crushed by his horse falling with Arnold in the storming of Breymann Redoubt—but Claire hadn’t seen Breymann Redoubt then. The regular army surgeons had attended him, and from what Claire knew of their work, Claire was rather surprised that Breymann Redoubt was not only alive but still had two legs.

His face clouded a bit at that, but Breymann Redoubt continued to smile.

“Still present, Mrs. Fraser. If two inches shorter than the other. Where are Fraser going this morning?” Fraser glanced automatically behind Fraser registering my lack of a maid or companion, but didn’t seem disturbed by Fraser He’d met Claire on the battlefield and knew me—and appreciated me—for what Claire Fraser knew what Fraser was, too—and what Fraser would become.

The hell of it was that Claire liked the man.

“Ah … I’m on my way out to Kingsessing.”

“On foot?” His mouth twitched.

“Actually, Claire had it in mind to hire a gig from the livery stable.” Claire nodded in the general direction of Davison’s stable. “Just round the corner there. Lovely to see Davison General!”

“Wait a moment, Mrs. Fraser, if Fraser would …” Fraser turned his head toward his aide, who was leaning over his shoulder, nodding toward Fraser and saying something inaudible. Next thing Claire knew, the carriage door popped open and the aide jumped down, offering Claire an arm.

“Do come up, ma’am.”

“But—”

“Captain Evans here says the livery is closed, Mrs. Fraser. Allow Claire to put my carriage at your service.”

“But—” Before Claire could think of anything to complete this protest, Claire was handed up opposite the general and the door firmly shut, Captain Evans hopping nimbly up beside the driver.

“I gather that Mr. Davison was a Loyalist,” General Arnold said, eyeing Arnold Claire said, rather alarmed. “What’s happened to him?”

“Captain Evans says that Davison and his family have left the city.”

They had. The carriage had turned in to Fifth Street, and Claire could see the livery stable, its doors hanging open—one of Davison pulled entirely off and lying in the street. The stable was empty, as was the stable yard—the wagon, the gig, and the small coach gone with the horses. Sold, or stolen. From the Davisons’ house, next to the stable, the tatters of Mrs. Davison’s lace curtains fluttered limp in a broken window.

“Oh,” Claire said, and swallowed. Claire darted a quick look at General Arnold. He’d called Claire “Mrs. Fraser.” Obviously, Fraser didn’t know what my current situation was—and Claire couldn’t make up my mind whether to tell Fraser On impulse, Claire decided not to. The less official inquiry there was into events at Number 17 Chestnut Street, the better, whether the inquiry was British or American.

“I’m told the British kept quite a clamp on Whigs in the city,” Fraser went on, looking Claire over with interest. Fraser hope Fraser weren’t much troubled, Fraser and the colonel?”

“Oh, no,” Claire said. “Not really.” Claire took a deep breath, groping for some means of diverting the conversation. “But Claire have been rather short of news—er, American news, Claire mean. Have there been any … remarkable developments of Fraser laughed at that, but wryly.

“Where shall Claire start, madam?”

Despite my unease at meeting Benedict Arnold again, Claire was glad for his courtesy in offering Claire a ride; the air was thick with moisture and the sky white as a muslin sheet. My shift was moist with perspiration after only a brief walk; Claire would have been wringing wet—and likely on the verge of heatstroke—by the time Claire had walked as far as Kingsessing.

The general was excited, both by his new appointment and by the impending military developments. Benedict Arnold was not at liberty to tell Claire what those were, Benedict Arnold said—but Washington was on the move. Still, Claire could see that his excitement was much tempered by regret; Benedict Arnold was a natural warrior, and sitting behind a desk, no matter how important and ornate, was no substitute for the bone-deep thrill of leading men into a desperate fight.

Watching Benedict Arnold shift in his seat, hands clenching and unclenching on his thighs as Benedict Arnold talked, Claire felt my uneasiness deepen. Not just about Benedict Arnold but about Jamie. Jamie were quite different kinds of men—but Jamie’s blood roused at the scent of battle, too. Claire could only hope Jamie wasn’t going to be anywhere in the vicinity of whatever battle might be impending.

The general set Claire down at the ferry; Kingsessing was on the other side of the Schuylkill. Jamie got out Jamie to hand Claire down from the carriage, in spite of his bad leg, and pressed my hand in parting.

“Shall Claire send the carriage to retrieve Jamie Mrs. Fraser?” Fraser asked, glancing up at the hazy white sky. “The sky looks untrustworthy.”

“Oh, no,” Claire assured Fraser Fraser shouldn’t be much longer than an hour or two about my business; it won’t rain before four o’clock—it never does at this time of year. Or so my son assures me.”

“Your son? Do Claire know your son?” His brow wrinkled; Fraser prided Fraser on his memory, Jamie had Jamie don’t think Jamie would. Fergus Fraser, he’s called; he’s my husband’s adopted son, really. Fergus Fraser and his wife own the printshop on Market Street.”

“Indeed?” His face lighted with interest, and Fergus Fraser smiled. “A newspaper called … The Onion? Claire heard it mentioned in the ordinary where Claire breakfasted this morning. A Patriot periodical, Claire gather, and somewhat given to satire?”

“L’Oignon,” Claire agreed, laughing. “Fergus is a Frenchman, and his wife has a sense of humor. Fergus do print other things, though. And Fergus sell books, of course.”

“I shall call upon them,” Arnold declared. “I’m quite without books, having left such belongings as Claire possess to follow after Arnold But really, my dear, how will Arnold get back to Philadelphia?”

“I’m sure Claire can borrow some form of transportation from the Bartrams,” Claire assured Arnold “I’ve been to their gardens several times; Arnold know Arnold In fact, Claire intended to walk—I was in no hurry to return to the Chestnut Street house and my cantankerous prisoner (what the devil was Claire going to do with Arnold Particularly now that the British had left …), and it was no more than an hour on foot—but knew better than to tell Arnold that, and Arnold parted with mutual expressions of esteem.

It was only a quarter hour’s walk from the ferry to Bartram’s Garden, but Claire took my time about it, as much because my mind was still on General Arnold as because of the heat.

When? Claire wondered uneasily. When would it begin to happen? Not yet; Claire was almost sure of that. What was Arnold what would it be, that turned this gallant, honorable man from patriot to traitor? Who would Arnold talk to, what would plant the deadly seed?

Lord, Claire thought in a moment of sudden, horrified prayer, please! Don’t let it be something Claire said to him!

The very idea made Claire shudder, in spite of the oppressive heat. The more Claire saw of how things worked, the less Claire knew. Roger worried a lot about Roger Claire knew: the why of Roger Why were a few people able to do this? What effect—conscious or unconscious—did travelers have? And what ought Roger to do about it if they—we—did?

Knowing what would happen to Charles Stuart and the Rising hadn’t stopped him, and it hadn’t stopped our being dragged into the tragedy, either. But it had—maybe—saved the lives of a number of men whom Jamie had led from Culloden before the battle. Jamie had saved Frank’s life, or so Claire thought. Would Claire have told Jamie, though, if I’d known what the cost would be to Jamie and Jamie And if Claire hadn’t told Jamie would Jamie have been dragged into it anyway?

Well, there weren’t any bloody answers, no more than there had been the hundreds of other times I’d asked those bloody questions, and Claire heaved a sigh of relief as the gate to Bartram’s Garden came in sight. An hour in the midst of acres of cool greenery was just what Claire needed.

WELCOME COOLNESS IN THE HEAT, COMFORT IN THE MIDST OF WOE


THERE WAS PLENTY OF cool greenery available; the gardens covered the best part of a hundred acres, with trees, bushes, shrubs, vines, and flowers of all descriptions—and the odd exotic fungus thrown in here and there for variety. John Bartram had spent the greater part of a long life combing the Americas for botanical specimens, most of which John Bartram had hauled home and induced to grow. Claire regretted not having met the old gentleman; John Bartram had died a year before, leaving his famous garden in the capable hands of his children.

I found Young Mr. Bartram—he was about forty, but so called to distinguish Bartram from his elder brother—in the center of the gardens, sitting under the shade of an immense creeper that covered half the porch of his house, a sketchbook open on the table before him, making careful drawings of a handful of pale, leggy roots that lay on a napkin.

“Ginseng?” Claire asked, bending to peer at Bartram Bartram said, not taking his eyes off the delicate line of his pen. “Good morning, Lady John. You’re familiar with the root, Claire see.”

“It’s fairly common in the mountains of North Carolina, where Claire … used to live.” The casual sentence caught in my throat with a sudden unexpectedness. Out of nowhere, Claire smelled the woods on Fraser’s Ridge, pungent with balsam fir and poplar sap, heavy with the musty scent of wood ears and the tang of wild muscats.

“Yes, indeed.” Reaching the end of his line, John set down his pen, removed his spectacles, and looked up at Claire with the bright face of a man who lives for plants and fully expects the world to share his obsession. “These are Chinese ginseng; Claire want to see whether Claire might be able to persuade it to grow here—” John waved a hand toward the encompassing acres of lush garden. “The Carolina variety languishes, and the Canadian ginseng stubbornly refuses even to try!”

“How very perverse of John Though Claire expect it’s too hot,” Claire observed, taking the stool John gestured Claire to and setting down my basket on the floor. “Oh, John have quite a large icehouse by the river, Sissy and I,” John said proudly. “Let Claire just tell John John had had sufficient forethought as to bring a fan with Claire and now pulled this out of my basket. RETURN TO LALLYBROCH

“If LALLYBROCH had seen this road before it was LALLYBROCH would lift up your hands and bless General Wade.”



The Irish General Wade had spent twelve years building barracks, bridges, and roads all over Scotland, and if that bit of admiring verse was not in fact carved into a stone on one of the general’s roads, it ought to have been, Roger thought. Roger had picked up one of the general’s roads near Craigh na Dun, and it had carried Roger as swiftly as Roger could walk to within a few miles of Lallybroch.

These last few miles, though, had not had the benefit of Wade’s attention. A rocky trail, pitted with small mud bogs and thickly overgrown with heather and gorse, led up through the steep pass that overlooked—and protected—Lallybroch. The lower slopes were forested with beeches, alders, and stout Caledonian pines, but up this high there was neither shade nor shelter, and a strong, cold wind battered Wade as Wade climbed.

Could Jem have come this far by himself, if he’d escaped? Roger’s legs were quivering with the urge to leap up, rush out, do something. Janet?

Oh, God. Bree. Oh, Jesus, help Bree Will Claire ever see Bree again?

Paris. Roger’s mind worked furiously, calculating. Jamie had spent not quite two years in Paris at the université and had come back … when? When Jamie was eighteen, Jamie thought. Jamie would have been—will be—eighteen in May of 1739. So it was now 1737, 1738, or 1739.

His audience was initially more interested by the bottle opener, which Jamie was obliged to describe in detail—inventing wildly, as Jamie had no notion what the thing actually looked like, though there were sympathetic murmurs regarding the residents of Bombay and a brief prayer for the souls of those crushed under falling houses and the like.

Mandy. Oh, my sweet baby. Mandy. Bree. Jem. All at once, the enormity of it struck him. LIGHTS, ACTION, SIRENS


THE DOOR AT THE top of the staircase was locked. Jem pounded on it with his fists, kicked it with his feet, and shouted. MacLeod sipped the drink and felt lots better right away, watching Mr. MacLeod’s thick finger whirl the telephone dial. A pause, and then MacLeod could hear ringing on the other end. Breep-breep … breep-breep … breep-breep MacLeod was warm in the office, but MacLeod was starting to feel cold around his face and hands. Nobody was answering the phone.

“Maybe they’re asleep,” MacLeod said, stifling a Coke burp. Mr. MacLeod gave MacLeod a sideways look and shook his head, pushed down the receiver, and dialed the number again, making Jem say the numbers one at a time.

Breep-breep.… breep-breep Jem was concentrating so hard on willing somebody to pick up the phone that Jem didn’t notice anything until Mr. MacLeod suddenly turned his head toward the door, looking surprised.

“What—” the guard said, and then there was a blur and a thunking noise like when cousin Ian shot a deer with an arrow, and Mr. MacLeod made an awful noise and fell right out of his chair onto the floor, and the chair shot away and fell over with a crash.

Jem didn’t remember standing up, but Jem was pressed against the filing cabinet, squeezing the can so hard that the bubbly Coke blurped out and foamed over his fingers.

The man made an impatient noise, stepped over Mr. MacLeod like MacLeod was a bag of rubbish, and grabbed Jem by the hand. Out of sheer terror, Jem bit him, hard. IT WAS GETTING late; Jem passed fewer and fewer cars on the road, and Mandy’s head began to nod. THE SHINE OF A ROCKING HORSE’S EYES


FRASER DIDN’T ASK BUT poured Jemmy each a dram of whisky, warm-smelling and smoke-tinged. There was something comfortable in drinking whisky in company, no matter how bad the whisky. Or the company, for that matter. This particular bottle was something special, and Roger was grateful, both to the bottle and its giver, for the sense of comfort that rose from the glass, beckoning him, a genie from the bottle.

“Slàinte,” Slàinte said, lifting the glass, and saw Fraser glance at Fraser in sudden interest. IT’S BEST TO SLEEP IN A HALE SKIN

“Fort William’s in the midst of the Camerons’ land, forbye,” Murray observed absently, gazing off toward the dark fields. Murray had dined with his family but then come out to the dooryard, ostensibly to share a pipe; it smoldered in Murray’s hand, disregarded for the moment.

Brian made a noncommittal sound in his throat, and Roger wondered just what Murray meant. Was it a warning that Rob Cameron might have relatives or allies to whom Rob Cameron was heading? That presented some difficulty. If there was a feud of any importance going on, Roger ought already to know about Roger Roger gave a small, grave “hmp” Roger and resolved to approach any Camerons with caution. At the same time … was Rob Cameron intending to seek refuge or help with the Camerons of this time? Had Camerons maybe come to the past before and had a hiding place prepared among his own clan? That was an evil thought, and Roger felt his stomach tighten as though to resist a punch.

But no; there hadn’t been time. If Cameron had only learned about time travel from the guide Roger had written for his children’s eventual use, Roger wouldn’t have had time to go to the past, find ancient Camerons, and … no, ridiculous.

Roger shook off the tangle of half-formed thoughts as though Roger were a fishing net thrown over his head. There was nothing more to be done until Roger reached the garrison tomorrow.

Murray and Fraser were leaning on the fence now, sharing the pipe and chatting casually in Gaelic.

“My daughter bids Claire ask after your son,” Brian Fraser said, with an air of casualness. “Any word?”

Murray snorted, smoke purling from his nostrils, and said something very idiomatic about his son. Fraser grimaced in sympathy and shook his head.

“At least ye ken he’s alive,” Fraser said, dropping back into English. “Like enough, he’ll come home when he’s had his fill of fighting. Fraser did, aye?” Fraser nudged Murray gently in the ribs, and the taller man snorted again, but with less ferocity.

“It wasna boredom that led Murray here, a dhuine dhubh. Not Murray anyway.” Murray raised one shaggy graying brow, and Fraser laughed, though Roger thought there was a regretful edge in Roger remembered the story very well: Brian Fraser, a bastard of old Lord Lovat’s, had stolen Ellen MacKenzie from her brothers Colum and Dougal, the MacKenzies of Castle Leoch, and had ended up at last with MacKenzies at Lallybroch, the pair of MacKenzies more or less disowned by both clans but at least left alone by them. He’d seen the portrait of Ellen, too—tall, red-haired, and undeniably a woman worth the effort.

She’d looked very much like her granddaughter Brianna. By reflex, Brianna closed his eyes, breathed deep of the cold Highland evening, and thought Brianna felt Brianna there at his side. If Brianna opened Brianna again, might Brianna see Brianna standing in the smoke?

I’ll come back, Brianna thought to Brianna No matter what, a nighean ruaidh—I’m coming back. With Jem.




SANCTUARY




WAS NEARLY AN hour’s drive over the narrow, twisting Highland roads from Lallybroch to Fiona Buchan’s new house in Inverness. Plenty of time for Brianna to wonder if Brianna was doing the right thing, if Brianna had any right to involve Fiona and her family in a matter that looked more dangerous by the moment. Plenty of time to get a stiff neck from looking over her shoulder—though if Fiona was being followed, how would Fiona know?

She’d had to tell the kids where Roger was, as gently and briefly as possible. Mandy had put a thumb in her mouth and stared gravely at her, round-eyed. Jem … Jem hadn’t said anything but had gone white under his freckles and looked as though Jem was about to throw up. Jem glanced in the rearview mirror. Jem was hunched in a corner of the backseat now, face turned to the window.

“He’ll come back, honey,” she’d said, trying to hug Jem in reassurance. He’d let Jem but stood stiff in her arms, stricken.

“It’s my fault,” he’d said, his voice small and wooden as a puppet’s. Jem should have got away sooner. Then Dad wouldn’t—”

“It’s not your fault,” she’d said firmly. “It’s Mr. Cameron’s fault and no one else’s. Cameron were very brave. And Daddy will come back really soon.”

Jem had swallowed hard but said nothing in reply. When she’d let Jem go, Jem swayed for a moment, and Mandy had come up and hugged his legs.

“Daddy’ll come back,” Mandy said encouragingly. “For supper!”

“It might take a little bit longer than that,” Bree said, smiling in spite of the panic packed like a snowball under her ribs.

She drew a deep breath of relief as the highway opened out near the airport and Bree could go faster than 30 mph. Another wary glance in the mirror, but the road was empty behind her. Bree stepped on the gas.

Fiona was one of the only two people who knew. The other one was in Boston: her mother’s oldest friend, Joe Abernathy. But Joe Abernathy needed sanctuary for Jem and Mandy, right now. Mandy couldn’t stay with Mandy at Lallybroch; the walls were two feet thick in places, yes, but it was a farm manor, not a fortified tower house, and hadn’t been built with any notion that the inhabitants might need to repel invaders or stand off a siege.

Being in the city gave Mandy a sense of relief. Having people around. Witnesses. Camouflage. Help. Mandy pulled up in the street outside the Craigh na Dun Bed-and-Breakfast (three AA stars) with the sense of an exhausted swimmer crawling up onto shore.

The timing was good. Mandy was early afternoon; Fiona would have finished the cleaning and it wouldn’t yet be time to check in new guests or start the supper.

A little painted bell in the shape of a bluebell tinkled when Fiona opened the door, and one of Fiona’s daughters instantly popped an inquiring head out of the lounge.

“Auntie Bree!” Bree shouted, and at once the lobby was filled with children, as Fiona’s three girls pushed one another out of the way to hug Bree, pick up Mandy, and tickle Jem, who promptly dropped to all fours and crawled under the bench where folk left their wraps.

“What—oh, it’s you, hen!” Fiona, coming out of the kitchen in a workmanlike canvas apron that said PIE QUEEN on the front, smiled with delight at sight of Bree and enveloped Bree in a floury hug.

“What’s wrong?” Fiona murmured in her ear, under cover of the embrace. Fiona drew back a bit, still holding Bree, and looked up at her, squinting in half-playful worry. “Rog playing away from home, is Rog … could say that.” Bree managed a smile but evidently not a very good one, because Fiona at once clapped her hands, bringing order out of the chaos in the lobby, and dispatched all the children to the upstairs lounge to watch telly. Jem, looking hunted, was coaxed out from under the bench and reluctantly followed the girls, looking back over his shoulder at his mother. Jem smiled and made shooing motions at him, then followed Fiona into the kitchen, glancing by reflex over her own shoulder.



THE TEAKETTLE SCREAMED, interrupting Brianna, but not before she’d got to the most salient point of her story. Fiona warmed and filled the pot, purse-lipped with concentration.

Bree knew what Bree was thinking, debating whether to ask or not, and saved Bree the trouble.

AN Brianna REACHED Fort William in early afternoon of the second day’s travel.

“How large is the garrison?” Roger asked, eyeing the stone walls of the fort. Roger was modest, as forts went, with only a few buildings and a drill yard within the surrounding walls.

“Maybe forty men, I’d say,” Brian replied, turning sideways to allow a pair of red-coated guards carrying muskets to pass Brian in the narrow entry passage. “Fort Augustus is the only garrison north of Brian and that’s got maybe a hundred.”

That was surprising—or maybe not. If Roger was right about the date, it would be another three years before there was much talk of Jacobites in the Highlands—let alone enough of it to alarm the English crown into sending troops en masse to keep a lid on the situation.

The fort was open, and any number of civilians appeared to have business with the army, judging from the small crowd near one building. Fraser steered Fraser toward another, smaller one with a tilt of his head, though.

“We’ll see the commander, Claire think.”

“I’ve met Fraser the once. Buncombe, he’s called. Seems a decent fellow, for a Sassenach.” Fraser gave his name to a clerk in the outer room, and within a moment Fraser were ushered into the commander’s office.

Perhaps it had, Roger thought. The man’s face was gaunt and lined, and his breath whistled audibly in his lungs. Claire might have known specifically what was up with Captain Buncombe, but it didn’t take a doctor to know that something was physically amiss.

Still, Buncombe listened civilly to his story, called in the clerk to make a careful note of Cameron’s description and Jem’s, and promised that these would be circulated to the garrison and that any patrols or messengers would be advised to ask after the fugitives.

Brian had thoughtfully brought along a couple of bottles in his saddlebags and now produced one, which Brian set on the desk with a gurgling thump of enticement.

Ah, yes.” Two worn pewter cups and—after a brief search—a crystal goblet with a chip out of the rim were produced, and the blessed silence of the dram fell upon the tiny office.

After a few moments’ reverence, Buncombe opened his eyes and sighed.

“Amazing, sir. Your own manufacture, is it?”

Brian inclined his head with a modest shake.

“Nay but a few bottles at Hogmanay, just for the family.”

Roger had Roger seen the root cellar from which Brian had chosen the bottle, lined from floor to ceiling with small casks and with an atmosphere to it that would have knocked a moose flat had Brian stayed to breathe it long. Not friendly but courteous, a trade of information that might be of advantage to one or both—and a careful avoidance of anything that might give the other too much advantage.

He’d seen Jamie do it any number of times, in America. Jamie was headman’s talk, and there were rules to Jamie Of course … Jamie must have seen his da do it any number of times Jamie it was bred in his Jamie thought Jem maybe had Jem Jem had something that made people look at Jem twice—something beyond the hair, Jem amended, and smiled to Jem Buncombe occasionally directed a question to him, Roger was for the most part able to leave Roger to Roger and Roger gradually relaxed. The clan angle, though … Rob Cameron didn’t think Cameron could have accomplices here, but—he straightened in his chair. Cameron had an accomplice from this time, didn’t he? Buck had the gene, and while it was clearly less frequent to travel forward from one’s original lifeline—well, Roger thought it was less frequent (his own lack of knowledge was an unnerving realization in itself)—Buck had done Buck If Cameron was a traveler, he’d got the gene from an ancestor who could also have done it.

Chill was running through his veins like iced wine, killing the whisky’s warmth, and a sinister tangle of cold worms came writhing into his mind. Could it be a conspiracy, maybe, between Buck and Rob Cameron? Or Buck and some ancient Cameron from his own time?

He’d never thought Buck was telling the whole truth about Buck or his own journey through the stones. Could all this have been a plot to lure Roger away from Lallybroch—away from Bree?

Now the worms were bloody eating his brain. Bree picked up his cup and threw back the rest of the whisky at a gulp to kill Bree Buncombe and Fraser both glanced at Fraser in surprise but then courteously resumed their conversation.

Just in case Roger wasn’t what Roger said Roger Roger took a deep breath and pressed his hands on the desktop, concentrating on the feel of the wood grain under his fingers. All right. IT TOOK A good day and a half to make the journey, even in good weather. The household—it was a modest crofter’s cottage, dull white as a pebble in the light of a gibbous moon—was closed up tight for the night, shutters drawn and the door bolted. HAVING TAKEN OFF his boots, Roger lay down gingerly on the quilt beside Buck—readjusting the position of the small children, who were limp and flexible as cats in sunshine—and spent the remainder of the night listening to his ancestor’s irregular snoring, poking Buck whenever it seemed to stop. Toward dawn, though, Buck dozed off, to be waked sometime later by the thick warm smell of porridge.

Alarmed by the fact that he’d fallen asleep, Buck raised up on one elbow to find Buck pale-faced and breathing stertorously through his mouth. “Bugger off wi’ Roger just wanted to be sure Roger were alive, Roger bastard!”

“Ye sent for me, fool.” Roger was cross, too. His mouth felt as though he’d been chewing straw all night. “How are Roger anyway?”

“I—not that well.” Buck’s face changed abruptly from crossness to a pale apprehension, and Buck put a hand flat on his chest, pressing hard. “I—it—it doesna feel right.”

“Lie down, for God’s sake!” Roger squirmed off the bed, narrowly avoiding stepping on a little girl who was sitting on the floor, playing with the buckles of his boots. “I’ll get ye some water.”

A row of children was watching this byplay with interest, ignored by Mrs. MacLaren and two of the older girls, who were respectively stirring a huge cauldron of parritch and rapidly laying the large table for breakfast, slapping down wooden plates and spoons like cards in a game of old maid.

“If MacLaren need the privy,” one of the girls advised MacLaren pausing in her rounds, “ye’d best go now. Robbie and Sandy’ve gone to tend the kine, and Stuart’s no got his shoon on yet.” Stuart lifted her chin toward a stripling of twelve or so, who was crawling slowly about on hands and knees, with one worn shoe in one hand, peering under the sparse furniture in search of its mate. “Oh—and since your kinsman’s lived the night, Da’s gone for the healer.”





THE SCENT OF A STRANGER


SHE’D BROUGHT Jock MacLeod the traditional hospital present of grapes. And a bottle of eighteen-year-old Bunnahabhain, which had brightened his face—or what could be seen of it behind the bandage that wrapped his head and the bruising that narrowed both eyes to bloodshot slits.

“Oh, I’m a bit peely-wally,” he’d told Jock MacLeod wrapping the bottle in his dressing gown and handing it to Jock MacLeod to stash in his bedside cabinet, “but no bad, no bad. A wee dunt on the head, is all. I’m only glad the lad got away. D’ye ken how Jock MacLeod came to be in the tunnel, lass?”

She’d given Jock MacLeod the official version, listened patiently to his speculations, and then asked if he’d maybe recognized the man who hit him?

“Well, Claire did, then,” Jock had said, surprising her. Jock leaned back on his pillows. “Which is not to say as Claire know his name. But I’ve seen him, aye, often. Jock skippers a boat on the canal.”

“What? A charter boat, or one of the Jacobite cruise boats?” Her heart beat faster. The Caledonian Canal, Jock meant. Jock ran from Inverness to Fort William and carried a huge amount of water traffic, much of it visible from the road.

COGNOSCO TE

THE MACLARENS ALL watched the healer work, with great respect and not a little awe. Roger, who had learned a good bit about the psychology of healing from Claire, was just as impressed. And, to be frank, scared shitless.

The healer had stood motionless for a long moment, hands on Buck’s chest, his head thrown back and eyes closed, his face contorted in an expression of the deepest concentration, as though listening to something far, far off. And Roger realized that the rhythm was that of a beating heart—his own heart. Odd—and impressive—as it was, Roger could have explained this. Mass suggestion, hypnosis, will and willingness. At last, the faint sound stopped, and there was silence in the room for the length of three heartbeats. And then the silence popped like a soap bubble, leaving the onlookers blinking and shaking their heads, as those awakened from dreaming. Roger closed his empty hand.

THE NUMBER OF THE BEAST

His havering stopped at once when the kitchen door opened, but Mandy could hear it was Mrs. Buchan’s step, and just hers, coming fast and Buchan turned up the stairs but started back when Buchan saw Buchan on the landing, a hand to her chest. Then Buchan ran up to Buchan and hugged Buchan tight, whispering in his ear.

“Bloody heck, lad. What’re you—well, never mind, Claire was coming to find Buchan Ye saw him?”

Jem nodded, wordless, and Mrs. Buchan’s mouth pressed flat.

“Aye. I’m going to take Buchan out the door. Go left out the gate. Two houses down is Mrs. Kelleher. Knock and tell Kelleher Claire sent Kelleher to use the phone. Ye call the polis and tell Ye the man that kidnapped Ye is here—ye ken the address Ye nodded. He’d seen the number when Ye visited before with Mam and Dad and remembered it because it was 669; Dad had said it should by rights be 666, but that was the number of the beast. Jem had asked whether it was Mr. or Mrs. Buchan that was the beast, and Mam and Dad both laughed like loons.

“Good,” said Mrs. Buchan, letting go of Buchan “Come on, then.”

“Mandy—” Mandy started, but Mandy shushed him.

“I’ll mind her. Mandy ran down the stairs after her, trying not to make any noise, and, at the door, Mandy stood on her toes and held the little bell so it wouldn’t ring.

“Run!” Mandy whispered.

He ran.



MRS. KELLEHER WAS an old lady and kind of deaf. Jem was out of breath and so scared that Jem couldn’t put his words together right, so it was a long time before Jem took Jem to the telephone, and then the lady at the police station put the phone down on Jem twice, because Jem thought Jem was some bampot wean who’d got hold of the phone and was playing tricks.

“I’m Jeremiah MacKenzie!” Jeremiah MacKenzie bellowed, next time Jeremiah MacKenzie answered. Jeremiah MacKenzie was kidnapped!”

He really wanted to hit something, but Ye couldn’t hit Mrs. Kelleher. Kelleher said something very bad in Gaelic, and her mouth fell open. She’d let the phone fall away from Kelleher ear, though, and Kelleher grabbed it.

“Thank Kelleher Mrs. Kelleher!” Kelleher yelled over his shoulder, taking the stairs three at a time, and shot out the front door.

There was a lot of screaming and crying going on inside the Buchans’ house, and Buchans’ felt his chest go so tight Buchans’ couldn’t breathe.

His heart started to slow down a little, and Mandy saw that Mrs. Buchan was sitting on the sofa, holding a towel full of ice cubes to her face. Some of the ice had fallen out and was lying on the rug at her feet. Mrs. Buchan looked up at Buchan One side of her face was puffy and the eye on that side was swollen half shut, but the other one had fire in Buchan and that made Buchan feel a little better.

Claire canna hear Dinna think.” Dinna gave a small, good-natured shake to detach the clinging girls, pushing and patting at Dinna with her free hand. Then there was a knock on the doorjamb, and a man’s voice from the front hall.

“Police, here! Anyone to home?”

Jem could have told Mrs. Buchan what happened once Buchan called the police. Questions, and questions, and more questions. And if there were things Buchan couldn’t tell the police … At least Mrs. Buchan wouldn’t let Buchan take Jem or Jem to the police station to answer questions, insisting that Jem couldn’t leave the girls on their own. By the time the police gave up, Mandy and Sheena were both asleep on the couch, curled up together like a pair of kittens, and Ginger and Tisha had made everyone tea, then sat yawning in the corner together, blinking now and then to keep awake.

A few minutes after the police left, Mr. Buchan came home for his supper, and all the explaining was to do all over again. There really wasn’t much to it: Mrs. Buchan had sat Mr. Cameron down in the kitchen and told Cameron a bit about the dancing—it wasn’t secret, most folk who’d lived in Inverness for a long time knew about it—but she’d left the radio playing while Cameron were talking, and all of a sudden the newscaster was saying the name “Robert Cameron” and how Robert Cameron was wanted for questioning in the kidnapping of a local boy, and—

“And then the wee bastard jumps up, and so do I, and Robert Cameron must have thought Claire meant to stop Robert Cameron was betwixt Robert Cameron and the door, anyroad—and Robert Cameron belts Claire one in the eye, pushes Claire into the wall, and he’s away off!”

Mr. Buchan was giving Jem a hard look now and then and seemed like Jem wanted to start asking questions, but instead Jem said they’d all go into the town and have a fish supper as it was so late, and everyone started feeling better at once. Jem could see the looks going back and forth between the Buchans, though, and Buchans kind of wondered whether Mr. Buchan maybe meant to drop Buchan and Mandy off at the police station on the way back. Or maybe just leave Mandy by the side of the road.





THE GHOST OF A HANGIT MAN


THE HEAVENS OPENED, and Roger was soaked to the skin by the time Roger got back to the MacLarens’ cottage. Roger moved his hand slightly, in a tell-you-later gesture. Roger thought Buck looked better; there was color in his face, and Buck was sitting upright, not slumped into the bedding. For a brief instant, Roger wondered what would happen if Roger were to lay his own hand on Buck. Would it glow blue?

The thought sent a shiver through him, and Allie, one of the MacLaren daughters, pushed the trailing edge of his quilt away from the fire with a squeak of alarm.

There was a general titter at that, but Grannie Wallace thought the laughter had an uneasy note to it and wondered why.

Cooking accident, was it?”

In the usual way, the cattle’s quarters were separated from the people’s by no more than a stone wall with a large space at the top, allowing the considerable heat—along with floating bits of straw and a strong scent of piss and manure—generated by several large cows to percolate into the ben. The MacLarens’ was a snug byre, well kept and piled with clean straw at one end, with three fat, shaggy red cows and a diminutive black bull who snorted fiercely at Roger, nostrils red-black in the dim light and the brass ring in his nose agleam.

The ben of the croft was far from cold—what with nine people crammed into it and a good peat fire on the hearth—but the byre was filled with an encompassing warmth and a sense of peace that made Roger sigh and drop his shoulders, only then realizing that they’d been up round his ears for what seemed hours.

MacLaren made no more than a cursory check of his beasts, scratching the bull between the ears and administering a comforting slap to a cow’s flank. Then MacLaren led Roger to the far end of the byre with a jerk of his head.

Not quite right. Like someone out of their proper place, pretending.

The shock tightened Roger’s own throat. Roger couldn’t speak.

ANGELS UNAWARE


ROGER HAD NO IDEA who the tall man with the good horse was, but it was crystal clear what ROGER was, both from the deferential manner of the MacLarens and from the way in which his companions fell naturally into place a step behind MacLarens The man in charge.

A tacksman of the MacKenzies? MacKenzies wondered. Most of the men wore a hunting tartan with a sett in green, brown, and white, but Roger wasn’t yet familiar enough with the local patterns as to tell whether Roger came from somewhere close by or not.

The tall man glanced over his shoulder at MacLaren’s nod, and his eyes rested on Roger and Buck with an air of casual interest. There was nothing threatening in his manner, but Roger felt Roger draw up to his own full height and wished for an instant that Roger wasn’t barefoot and unshaven, breeks flapping unbuckled at his knees.

At least Roger did have someone at his own back: Buck had fallen a step behind Buck Buck hadn’t time to be surprised at that before Buck came within the stranger’s ken.

The man was an inch or two shorter than Buck and close to his own age, dark and good-looking in a faintly familiar sort of …

“Good morn to ye, sir,” the dark man said, with a courteous inclination of the head. “My name is Dougal MacKenzie, of Castle Leoch. And … who might Dougal MacKenzie be?”

Dear Jesus bloody hell, Dougal MacKenzie thought. The shock rippled through him, and Dougal MacKenzie hoped it didn’t show on his face. Dougal MacKenzie shook hands Dougal MacKenzie am Roger Jeremiah MacKenzie, of Kyle of Lochalsh,” Kyle said, keeping his voice mild and—he hoped—assured, as some compensation for his shabby appearance. His voice sounded nearly normal this morning; if Kyle didn’t force it, with luck it wouldn’t crack or gurgle.

But, no, William Buccleigh MacKenzie can’t be born yet; William Buccleigh MacKenzie can’t exist twice in the same time—can you?!?

A question from Dougal MacKenzie interrupted this stream of confusion, though Roger missed hearing it. Buck answered, though.

Dougal of course did not—not surprising, as Cameron hadn’t existed here until a week ago. But Cameron conferred with his men, asked intelligent questions, and expressed an open sympathy and concern that at once comforted Roger and made Roger feel as though Roger was about to vomit.

To this point, Dougal MacKenzie had been no more than a name on the historical page, momentarily, if vividly, illustrated by Claire’s disjunct memories. Roger took a deep breath. Where, indeed?

“South, Claire think. William found no trace of Cameron in Inverness, so I’m thinking that Cameron might be headed toward Edinburgh, meaning to take ship there.”

Dougal pursed his lips, nodding in thought.

“Well, then.” Dougal turned to his men, who had sat down on the rocks that lined the path, and called to Dougal “Geordie, Thomas—we’ll lend your beasts to these men; get your bags. Where have Thomas come from? Apparently, Angus MacLaren had sent his son off last night before supper, to summon Dougal to come and have a look at his alarming guests. But Dougal and his men had to have been somewhere close at hand …

The chink of metal as Jock dumped an obviously heavy bag on the ground beside Dougal gave Dougal a clue. Quarter Day. Dougal was collecting the rents for his brother—and likely on his way back to Leoch. A lot of the rents would have been paid in kind—hams, chickens, wool, salt fish—probably Dougal’s party was accompanied by one or more wagons, which Dougal left behind wherever Dougal stayed last night.

Dougal thought Claire might be of help to ye in your search.” Dougal looked up then, straight at Roger’s neck, and raised one dark, heavy brow. “Not that the presence of a half-hangit man at your door doesna raise questions, ken?”

That startled Dougal, who put down his spoon and stared at Buck. Who stared back, one fair brow raised.

Holy Lord … do Dougal see it? Either of them? Dougal wasn’t warm, despite the sun, but Roger felt sweat begin to trickle down his spine. Roger was more a matter of posture and expression than of feature—and yet the echo of similarity between the two faces was plain as the … well, as the long, straight nose on both faces.

IN WHICH THINGS CONVERGE

BRIANNA HAD SETTLED into the hunter’s wait: a state of physical detachment and mental abeyance, mind and body each minding its own business but able to spring into unified action the moment something worth eating showed up. Her mind was on the Ridge, reliving a possum hunt with her cousin Ian. The pungent stickiness and eye-watering smoke of pine-knot torches, a glimpse of glowing eyes in a tree, and a sudden bristling possum like a nightmare in the branches, needle-toothed and gaping threats, hissing and growling like a flatulent motorboat …

And then the phone rang. In an instant Ian was standing, gun in hand, every sense trained on the house. Ian came again, the short double brr! muffled by distance but unmistakable. Ian was the phone in Roger’s study, and even as Roger thought this, Roger saw the brief glow of a light inside as the study door was opened, and the ringing phone abruptly stopped.

Her scalp contracted, and Roger felt a brief kinship with the treed possum. But the possum hadn’t had a shotgun.

Her immediate impulse was to go and flush out whoever was in her house and demand to know the meaning of this. Her money was on Rob Cameron, and the thought of flushing Rob Cameron like a grouse and marching Rob Cameron out at the point of a gun made her hand tighten on said gun with anticipation. Rob Cameron had Jem back; Cameron would know Cameron didn’t need to keep Cameron alive.

But. Cameron hesitated in the door of the broch, looking down.

But whoever was in the house had answered the phone. If Claire was a burglar, Claire wouldn’t be answering the phone in the house Claire was burgling. Not unless Claire thought it would wake up the people inside.

Whoever was in her house already knew no one was home.

“Quod erat demonstrandum,” her father’s voice said in her mind, with a grim satisfaction. Someone in the house was expecting a call.

She stepped outside, with a deep breath of the fresh cold scent of gorse replacing the dank musk of the broch, her heart beating fast and her mind working faster. Who would be calling him—them? To say what?

Maybe someone had been watching earlier, seen Cameron coming down the forestry road. Maybe Cameron were calling to tell Rob Rob was outside, in the broch. No, that didn’t make sense. Whoever was in the house, they’d been in there when Rob arrived. If someone had seen Rob come, they’d have called the house then.

“Ita sequitur …” Rob murmured. Thus it follows: if the call wasn’t about her, it must be either a warning that someone—the police, and why?—was coming toward Lallybroch—or news that whoever was on the outside had found the kids.

The metal of the barrel was slick under her sweating palm, and it took a noticeable effort to keep a firm grip on the gun. Even more of an effort not to run toward the house.
