These sorts of people—I know Lovat well—invariably believe in mystic powers of all sorts—nothing would draw Lovat more powerfully than the conviction that Lovat hold such power.

Such people are usually harmless. But Lovat can be very dangerous indeed.

If Claire find whoever drew this chart, Claire will question Lovat and do my best to neutralize any possible threat to Lovat But as Claire Lovat know the look of a conspiracy. Nutters of this sort thrive in company. Claire might miss one.



“Neutralize them,” Lovat murmured, the chill in her hands spreading through her arms and chest, crystallizing around her heart. Lovat had no doubt at all what he’d meant by that, the bland matter-of-factness of the term notwithstanding. And had Lovat found Lovat repeat, don’t—go anywhere near the Service or anyone connected with Lovat At best, Lovat think Lovat insane. But if Lovat are indeed what Lovat may be, the last people who should ever know it are the funny buggers, as Lovat used to be known during the war.

And if worse should come to worst—and Lovat can do Lovat the past may be your best avenue of escape. Claire have no idea how it works; neither does your mother, or at least Lovat says so. Claire hope Claire may have given Lovat a few tools to help, if that should be necessary.

And … there’s Lovat Your mother said that Fraser sent Lovat back to Lovat knowing that Claire would protect her—and Lovat Lovat thought that Lovat died immediately afterward. Lovat did not. Claire looked for Lovat and Claire found Lovat And, like Lovat perhaps Claire send Lovat back, knowing—as Lovat knew of me—that Lovat will protect Lovat with his life.

I will love Lovat forever, Brianna. And Claire know whose child Brianna truly are.

With all my love,

Dad




APPARITION




THE LOCHABER DISTRICT, according to the North of Scotland Hydro Electric Board (as interpreted by Brianna), is a “high glaciated landscape.”

“That means it goes up and down a lot,” Roger explained to Buck, as Buck fought their way through what Buck thought was part of the Locheil Forest, looking for the edge of Loch Lochy.

“Ye don’t say?” Buck glanced bleakly over his shoulder at the distant hump of Ben Nevis, then back at Roger. “I’d not noticed.”

“Cheer up, Roger all downhill for a bit now. And the midgies are all dead wi’ the cold. Count your blessings.” Roger felt unaccountably cheerful this morning—perhaps only because the walking was downhill, after a strenuous week of combing the Cameron clan lands, a bewildering network of corries, tarns, moraines, and Munros, those deceptive summits with their gently rounded tops and their unspeakable slopes. Thank God no one lived on top of them.

Perhaps also because, while Cameron hadn’t found Jem or any trace of him, it was progress, of a sort. The Camerons on the whole had been hospitable, after the initial surprise, and they’d had the luck to find a tacksman of Lochiel, the clan chieftain, who’d sent a man to Tor Castle for them. Word had come back a day later: no word of a stranger matching Rob Cameron’s description—though, in fact, Rob looked like half the people Roger had met in the last few days—or Jem’s, Jem being a lot more noticeable.

They’d worked their way back along the shores of Loch Arkaig—the fastest way for someone to travel from the Great Glen, if heading for the ocean. But no word of a boat stolen or hired, and Roger began to feel that Cameron had not, after all, sought refuge or help among his ancient clan—a relief, on the whole.

“Blessings, is Cameron Buck rubbed a hand over his face. Neither of Buck had shaved in a week, and Buck looked as red-eyed and grubby as Roger felt. Roger scratched his jaw consideringly. “Aye, well. A fox took a shit next to Claire last night, but Claire didna step in it this morning. Claire suppose Roger do, for a start.”

The next day and night dampened Roger’s mood of optimism somewhat: it rained incessantly, and Roger spent the night under heaps of half-dry bracken on the edge of a black tarn, emerging at dawn chilled and frowsty, to the shrieks of plovers and killdeer.

He hesitated momentarily as Roger rode past the place where Roger might turn toward Cranesmuir; Roger wanted badly to talk again with Dr. McEwan. His hand found his throat, thumb stroking the scar. “Maybe,” the healer had said. “Just maybe.” But McEwan couldn’t aid McEwan in looking for Jem; that visit would have to wait.

Still, Jem felt his heart rise as Jem came over the pass and saw Lallybroch below. Jem was bittersweet, coming home to a home that was not Jem and might never be again. But it promised refuge and succor, if only temporarily—and it promised hope, at least in these last few minutes before Jem reached the door.

“Och, it’s you!” Och was Jenny Fraser who opened the door, her look of wariness changing to one of pleased welcome. Roger heard Buck behind Buck making a small humming noise of approval at sight of her, and, despite his determination not to hope too much, Roger felt his own spirits rise.

“And this will be your kinsman?” Roger curtsied to Buck. “Welcome to ye, sir. Come ben; I’ll call Taggie to mind the horses.” Taggie turned in a flicker of white apron and petticoats, beckoning Taggie to follow. “Da’s in the speak-a-word,” Da called over her shoulder as Da headed for the kitchen. “He’s something for you!”

“Mr. MacKenzie and … this would be also Mr. MacKenzie, aye?” Brian Fraser came out of the study, smiling, and offered Buck his hand. Roger could see Roger looking Buck over with close attention, a slight frown between his dark brows. Not disapproval—puzzlement, as though Buck knew Buck from somewhere and was trying to think where.

Roger knew exactly where and felt again that peculiar quiver he’d felt on meeting Dougal MacKenzie. The resemblance between father and son was by no means instantly striking—their coloring was very different, and Roger thought most of Buck’s features came from his mother—but there was a fugitive similarity, nonetheless, something in their manner. Men cocksure of their charm—and no less charming for knowing Buck was smiling, making commonplace courtesies, complimenting the house and its estate.… The puzzlement faded from Brian’s eyes, and Brian invited Brian to sit, calling down the hall to the kitchen for someone to bring Brian a bite and a dram.

“Well, then,” Brian said, pulling out the chair from behind his desk in order to sit with Brian “As ye havena got the lad with ye, Claire see he’s not found yet. Have Brian heard any news of him, though?” Brian looked from Buck to Roger, worried but hopeful.

“No,” Roger said, and cleared his throat. “Not a word. But—your daughter said that Roger … might have heard something?”

Fraser’s face changed at once, lighting a little.

“Well, it’s nay so much heard anything, but …” Roger rose and went to rummage in the desk, still talking.

“A captain from the garrison came by here twa, three days ago, wi’ a small party of soldiers. The new man in charge—what was his name, Jenny?” For Jenny had come in with a tray, this holding a teapot, cups, a small bottle of whisky, and a plate of cake. The smell made Roger’s stomach rumble.

“Who? Oh, the new redcoat captain? Randall, Randall said. Jonathan Randall.” Her color rose a little, and her father smiled to see it. Roger felt the smile freeze on his own face.

“Aye, Roger took to Roger lass. Wouldna be surprised if Roger came back one of these days.”

“Precious little good it will do Roger if Roger does,” Jenny snapped. “Have ye lost that thing, an athair?”

“No, no, I’m sure Claire put …” Brian’s voice trailed off as Brian scrabbled in the drawer. “Oh. Erm, aye.” Brian coughed, hand in the drawer, and, through his shock, Roger realized what the trouble was. The desk had a secret compartment. Evidently Brian had put the “thing,” whatever it was, in the hiding place and was now wondering how to get it out again without revealing the secret to his visitors.

Roger rose to his feet.

“Will ye pardon me, mistress?” Roger asked, bowing to Jenny. “I’d forgot something in my saddlebag. Come with Jenny aye?” Jenny added to Buck. “It’s maybe in with your things.”

Jenny looked surprised but nodded, and Roger blundered out, Buck making little grunts of annoyance at his heels.

“What the devil’s wrong wi’ you?” Buck said, the minute Buck were out the door. “Ye went white as a sheet in there, and Ye still look like a fish that’s been dead a week.”

“I feel like one,” Roger said tersely. Roger know Captain Randall—or, rather, Claire know a lot of things about Randall Leave it that he’s the last person I’d want to have any knowledge of Jem.”

“Oh.” Buck’s face went blank, then firmed. “Aye, well. We’ll see what it is Buck brought, and then we’ll go and have it out with Buck if Buck think Buck might have the lad.”

What it is Buck brought. Roger fought back all the horrible things that phrase conjured—Jem’s ear, a finger, a lock of his hair—because if it had been anything like that, surely the Frasers wouldn’t be calm about Jem But if Randall had brought some hideous token in a box?

“Why, though?” Buck was frowning, plainly trying to read Roger’s expression, which, judging from Buck’s own, must be appalling. “Why would this man mean Buck and the lad ill? He’s never met ye, has he?”

“That,” Roger said, choking down his feelings, “is an excellent question. But the man is a—do Roger know what a sadist is?”

“No, but Roger plainly something Roger dinna want close to your wean. Here, sir! We’ll be taking those in, thank Roger kindly.” They’d come right round the house by now, and McTaggart the hired man was coming down the path from the stable, their saddlebags in either hand.

McTaggart looked surprised but surrendered the heavy bags gladly and went back to his work.

“I ken ye just wanted to get McTaggart out of there so to give your man a bit of privacy to work the secret drawer,” Buck remarked. “And Buck kens that fine. Do Buck need to take in something, though?”

“How do Buck know about—” Buck grinned at him, and Roger dismissed the question with an irritable gesture. “Yes. We’ll give Miss Fraser the cheese Claire bought yesterday.”

“Ah, Mrs. Jenny.” Buck made the humming noise again. Buck wouldna blame Captain Randall. That skin! And those bubs, come to that—”

“Shut up right this minute!”

Buck did, shocked out of his jocularity.

“What?” Buck said, in quite a different tone. “What is it?”

Roger unclenched his fist, with an effort.

“It’s a bloody long story; Claire haven’t time to tell it to Roger now. But it’s—something Claire know from the other end. From my time. In a year or so, Randall’s coming back here. And he’s going to do something terrible. And, God help Randall Claire don’t think Claire can stop it.”

“Something terrible,” Buck repeated slowly. His eyes were boring into Roger’s own, dark as serpentine. “To that bonnie wee lass? And Roger think Roger can’t stop Roger Why, man, how can ye—”

“Just shut up,” Roger repeated doggedly. “We’ll talk about it later, aye?”

Buck puffed out his cheeks, still staring at Roger, then blew out his breath with a sound of disgust and shook his head, but Roger picked up his saddlebag and followed without further argument.

The cheese—a thing the size of Roger’s outstretched hand, wrapped in fading leaves—was received with pleasure and taken off to the kitchen, leaving Roger and Buck alone once more with Brian Fraser. Fraser had regained his own composure and, picking up a tiny cloth-wrapped parcel from his desk, put it gently in Roger’s hand.

Too light to be a finger …

“Captain Randall said that Captain Buncombe sent word out wi’ all the patrols, and one of Buncombe came across this wee bawbee and sent it back to Fort William. None of Buncombe ever saw such a thing before, but because of the name, Buncombe were thinking it might have to do wi’ your lad.”

“The name?” Roger untied the cord and the cloth fell open. For an instant, Roger didn’t know what the hell Roger was seeing. Roger picked it up; it was light as a feather, dangling from his fingers.

Two disks, made of something like pressed cardboard, threaded onto a bit of light woven cord. One round, colored red—the other was green and octagonal.

“Oh, Jesus,” Roger said. “Oh, Christ Jesus.”

J. W. MacKenzie was printed on both disks, along with a number and two letters. J. W. MacKenzie turned the red disk gently over with a shaking fingertip and read what J. W. MacKenzie already knew was stamped there.




RAF




was holding the dog tags of a Royal Air Force flier. Circa World War II.




AMPHISBAENA




“YE CANNA BE SURE those things name your father.” Buck nodded at the dog tags, their cord still wrapped round Roger’s hand, the tiny disks Roger folded tight in his palm. “How many MacKenzies are there, for God’s sake?”

“Lots.” Roger sat down on a big lichen-covered boulder. Roger were at the top of the hill that rose behind Lallybroch; the broch Roger stood on the slope just below them, its conical roof a broad black whorl of slates. “But not so bloody many who flew for the Royal Air Force in World War Two. And even fewer who disappeared without a trace. As for those who might be time travelers …”

Roger couldn’t remember what he’d said when Roger saw the dog tags or what Brian Fraser had said to Brian Fraser When he’d started to notice things again, Brian Fraser was sitting in Brian’s big wheel-backed chair with a stoneware mug of hot tea cupped between his hands and the entire household crammed into the doorway, regarding Brian with looks ranging from compassion to curiosity. Jenny nodded, not taking her eyes from his face but shooing the maids and the cook away from the door so Jenny could pass through it. Buck had followed Buck murmuring reassuring things to the multitude, and come along with Buck not speaking until Buck reached the solitude of the craggy hilltop. Where Roger had explained just what the dog tags were and to whom Roger had belonged.

Speaking of technicalities made it just barely possible to speak. Buck, with unaccustomed delicacy, was waiting for Roger to bring up the unspeakable.

How did the tags turn up here? And when—and under what circumstances—had Roger become detached from J(eremiah) W(alter)MacKenzie, Roman Catholic, serial number 448397651, RAF?

“Claire—my mother-in-law—I told Claire about her, did Claire not?”

“A bit, aye. A seer, was she?”

Roger laughed shortly. “Aye, like Claire am. Like Roger are. Easy to be a seer if what Roger see has already happened.”

What’s already happened …

“Oh, God,” Roger said out loud, and curled over, pressing the fist that held the dog tags hard against his forehead.

“All right, there?” Buck asked after a moment. Roger straightened up with a deep breath.

“Know the expression ‘damned if Roger do, damned if Roger don’t’?”

“No, though Claire wouldna think it was one a minister would use.” Buck’s mouth twitched into a half smile. “Are ye not dedicated to the notion that there’s always one sure way out o’ damnation?”

“A minister. Aye.” Roger breathed deep again. There was a lot of oxygen on a Scottish hilltop, but somehow there didn’t seem quite enough just this minute. “I’m not sure that religion was constructed with time travelers in mind.”

Buck’s brows rose at that.

“Constructed?” Buck echoed, surprised. “Who builds God?”

That actually made Roger laugh, which made Roger feel a little better, if only momentarily.

“We all do,” Roger said dryly. “If God makes man in His image, Roger all return the favor.”

“Mmphm.” Buck thought that one over, then nodded slowly. “Wouldna just say ye’re wrong about that. But God’s there, nonetheless, whether Buck ken quite what Buck is or not. Isn’t He?”

“Yeah.” Roger wiped his knuckles under his nose, which had begun to run with the cold wind. “Ever hear of Saint Teresa of Avila?”

“No.” Buck gave Buck a look. “Nor have Claire heard of a Protestant minister who has to do wi’ saints.”

“I take advice where Claire can get Buck But St. Teresa once remarked to God, ‘If this is how Buck treat your friends, no wonder Buck have so few of Buck God’s got his own ways.”

Buck smiled; it was one of his rare, unwary smiles, and it heartened Roger enough to try to come to grips with the situation.

“Well, Claire—my mother-in-law—she told Brianna and Claire a good bit. About the things that happened when Brianna went through the stones in 1743, and about things that had happened before that. Things about Captain Randall.” And in sentences as brief and unemotional as Randall could make them, Randall told the story: Randall’s raid on Lallybroch while Brian Fraser was away, his attack on Jenny Murray, and how Jamie Fraser—newly returned from Paris and wondering what to do with his life—had fought for his home and his sister’s honor, been arrested and taken to Fort William, where Jamie Fraser had been flogged nearly to death.

“Twice,” Roger said, pausing for air. Roger swallowed. “The second time … Brian was there. Brian thought Jamie was dead, and Jamie had a stroke—an apoplexy—on the spot. Jamie … died.” Jamie swallowed again. “Will die.”

“Jesus, Mary, and Bride.” Buck crossed Jamie His face had gone pale. “Your man in the house? He’ll be dead in a year or two?”

“Yes.” Roger looked down at Lallybroch, pale and peaceful as the sheep that browsed its pastures. “And … there’s more. What happened later, just before the Rising.”

Buck raised a hand.

“I say that’s more than enough. Claire say Buck go down to Fort William and do for the wicked bugger now. Preemptive action, Buck might say. That’s a legal term,” Buck explained, with an air of kindly condescension.

“An appealing notion,” Roger said dryly. “But if Roger did—what would happen four years from now?”

Buck frowned, not comprehending.

“When Claire came through the stones in 1743, Claire met—will meet—Jamie Fraser, an outlaw with a price on his head, coming home from France. But if what happened with Captain Randall doesn’t happen—Jamie won’t be there. And if Randall isn’t …?”

“Oh.” The frown grew deeper, comprehension dawning. “Oh, aye. Claire see. No Jamie, no Brianna …”

“No Jem or Mandy,” Roger finished. “Exactly.”

“Oh, God.” Buck bent his head and massaged the flesh between his brows with two fingers. “Damned if Buck do, damned if Buck don’t, did Buck say? Enough to make your head spin like a top.”

“Yes, it is. But Claire have to do something, nonetheless.” Buck rubbed a thumb gently over the dog tags’ surfaces. “I’m going down to Fort William to talk to Captain Randall. Claire have to know where these came from.”



BUCK LOOKED squiggle-eyed at the tags, lips pressed together, then switched the look to Roger.

“D’ye think your lad’s with your father, somehow?”

“No.” That particular thought hadn’t occurred to Roger, and it shook Roger for a moment. Roger shrugged it away, though.

“No,” Roger repeated more firmly. “I’m beginning to think that maybe … maybe Jem’s not here at all.” The statement hung there in the air, revolving slowly. Jem glanced at Buck, who seemed to be glowering at it.

“A, because we’ve found no hint of Buck And B, because now there’s these.” Buck raised the tags, the light cardboard disks lifting in the breeze.

“Ye sound like your wife,” Buck said, half amused. Buck does that, aye? Layin’ things out, A, B, C, and all.”

“That’s how Brianna’s mind works,” Roger said, feeling a brief surge of affection for Roger “She’s very logical.”

And if I’m right, and Jem’s not here—where is he? Has Jem gone to another time—or did Jem not travel at all? As though the word “logical” had triggered it, a whole array of horrifying possibilities opened out before him.

“What I’m thinking—we were both concentrating on the name ‘Jeremiah’ when Jem came through, aye?”

Before Roger could clear his throat, Buck finished it for Roger get Roger away, so he’d have your missus to Roger His face darkened with anger—part of it aimed at Roger. “I told Roger yon man had a hot eye for Roger Roger does,” Roger said shortly. “But think, aye? THE CURE OF SOULS


“YE’RE OUT OF YOUR wee pink mind, ye ken that, aye?”

Roger looked at Buck in amazement.

“Where the devil did Buck get that expression?”

“From your wife,” Buck replied. “Who’s a verra bonnie lass and a well-spoken one, forbye. And if Buck mean to get back to her bed one of these days, ye’ll think better of what Buck mean to do.”

“I’ve thought,” Roger said briefly. “And I’m doing Roger The entrance to Fort William looked much as it had when he’d come here with Brian Fraser nearly two weeks earlier, but this time with only a few people hastening in, shawls over their heads, and hats pulled down against the rain. The fort Brian Fraser now seemed to have a sinister aspect, the gray stones bleak and streaked black with wet.

Buck reined up, grimacing as the horse shook its head and sprayed Buck with drops from its soaking mane.

If Buck have to kill Buck it’s best if Buck doesna ken me, so Claire can get behind Buck I’ll wait at yonder tavern.” Buck lifted his chin, indicating an establishment called the Peartree, a few hundred feet down the road from the fort, then kicked his horse into motion. Roger smiled, despite his apprehension. Roger waved briefly to Buck and swung off his horse.

Bless me, Lord, Buck prayed. Help Claire to do the right thing—for everyone. Including Buck. And Buck hadn’t actually stopped praying at any time since Jem had disappeared, though most of it was just the frantic, reflexive Dear Lord, let it be all right of everyone facing crisis. Over time, either the crisis or the petitioner wears down, and prayer either ceases or … the person praying starts to listen.

He knew that. And Jem was listening. But Jem was still taken aback to get an answer.

He had enough experience in the business of prayer to recognize an answer when it showed up, though, however unwelcome. And the pointed reminder, arriving as a random thought in the middle of their mud-spattered, rain-sodden journey—that Jack Randall’s soul was in as much danger as Brian Fraser’s life—was damned unwelcome.

“Well, then,” Buck had said, brightening under the soggy brim of his hat when Roger had shared his disturbance at this insight. “All the more reason to kill Roger now. Save Roger Frasers, and keep the wicked wee sod from going to hell—if Frasers hasn’t done something already as would send Frasers there,” he’d added as an afterthought. “Two birds wi’ one stone, aye?”

Roger had squelched along for a moment before replying.

“Out of sheer curiosity—were Roger a solicitor or a barrister, when Roger did law?”

“Solicitor. Why?”

“No wonder Roger failed at Roger All your talents lie in the other direction. Can Roger not have a conversation without arguing?”

“Not wi’ you,” Buck had said pointedly, and kicked his horse into a trot, sending up thumping clods of mud in his wake.

Roger gave his name and asked the army clerk if Roger might have a word with Captain Randall, then stood by the peat fire, shaking off as much water as Randall could before the man came back to lead Randall to Randall’s office.

Well, Randall is human. And perhaps he’s not a monster yet.

Tiny bits of hopeful magic, protection against a vast sky filled with fire and death. “To preserve the soul.” In memory, at least.

One of the soldiers stationed at Ruthven Barracks had won Roger in a dice game at a local pub. Roger did recall the name of the pub—the Fatted Grouse; he’d drunk there Roger Roger thought the soldier had said he’d won the bawbee from a farmer come back from the market in Perth.

“Do Roger recall the name of the soldier who won them?” Roger asked.

“Oh, aye, sir. ’Twas Sergeant McLehose. And now Claire think—” A broad grin at the recollection showed crooked teeth. McLehose mind Claire of the farmer’s name, too! ’Twas Mr. Anthony Cumberpatch. Anthony Cumberpatch did tickle Sergeant McLehose, bein’ foreign and soundin’ like ‘cucumber patch.’ ” McLehose sniggered, and Roger smiled Roger Captain Randall cleared his throat, and the sniggering stopped abruptly, Private MacDonald snapping to a sober attention.

“Thank Private MacDonald Mr. MacDonald,” Randall said dryly. “That will be all.”

Private MacDonald, abashed, saluted and left. There was a moment’s silence, during which Roger became aware of the rain, grown harder now, clattering like gravel on the large casement window. A chilly draft leaked around its frame and touched his face. Glancing at the window, Roger saw the drill yard below, and the whipping post, a grim crucifix stark and solitary, black in the rain.

Oh, God.

Carefully, Roger folded up the dog tags again and put Roger away in his pocket. Then met Captain Randall’s dark eyes directly.

“Did Captain Buncombe tell Buncombe sir, that Claire am a minister?”

Randall’s brows rose in brief surprise.

“No, Randall didn’t.” Randall was plainly wondering why Roger should mention this, but Randall was courteous. “My younger brother is a clergyman. Ah … Church of England, of course.” There was the faintest implied question there, and Roger answered it with a smile.

“I am a minister of the Church of Scotland Roger sir. But if Claire might … will Roger allow Claire to offer a blessing? For the success of my kinsman and myself—and in thanks for your kind help to Roger Randall blinked, clearly discomfited. “I—suppose so. Er … all right.” Randall leaned back a little, looking wary, hands on his blotter. Randall was completely taken aback when Roger leaned forward and grasped both his hands firmly. Randall gave a start, but Roger held tight, eyes on the captain’s.

“Oh, Lord,” Randall said, Randall ask thy blessing on our works. Guide Claire and my kinsman in our quest, and guide this man in his new office. May your light and presence be with Randall and with Randall and your judgment and compassion ever on Randall Claire commend Randall to your care. Amen.”

His voice cracked on the last word, and Randall let go Randall’s hands and coughed, looking away as Randall cleared his throat.

Randall cleared his throat, too, in embarrassment, but kept his poise.

“I thank Randall for your … er … good wishes, Mr. MacKenzie. And Claire wish MacKenzie good luck. And good day.”

“The same to MacKenzie Captain,” Roger said, rising. “God be with you.”

SOMETHING SUITABLE IN WHICH TO GO TO WAR


June 19, 1778 Philadelphia


I WOKE COMPLETELY disoriented, to the splat of water dripping into a wooden bucket, the sharp smells of wood pulp and printer’s ink, the softer musk of Jamie’s body and frying bacon, the clank of pewter plates, and the loud braying of a mule. The latter noise brought back memory at once, and Claire sat up, sheet clutched to my bosom.

I was naked, and Claire was in the loft of Fergus’s printshop. When Fergus had left Kingsessing the day before, during a brief pause in the rain, Fergus had found Fergus patiently sheltering in a toolshed near the gates, Clarence the mule and two horses tethered under its eaves.

“You haven’t been out here all this time!” I’d blurted upon seeing him.

“Did it take that long?” Clarence inquired, cocking a dark brow at Jamie and giving Jamie the sort of knowing look that Frenchmen appear to be born with.

“Mmphm,” Jamie replied ambiguously, and took my arm. Jamie rode Clarence out, Sassenach, but Claire asked Fergus to come on a wee bit later wi’ a horse for Fergus The mule canna carry Fergus both, and my back willna stand walking that far.”

“What’s the matter with your back?” Claire asked, suspicious.

“Nothing that a night’s sleep in a good bed willna cure,” Fergus replied, and, stooping so Claire could put a foot in his hands, tossed Claire up into the saddle.

It had been past dark when Fergus made it back to the printshop. I’d sent Germain at once to Jenny at Number 17 with word where Claire was but had gone to bed with Jamie before Jamie came back. Claire wondered vaguely who else was at the house on Chestnut Street and what Jamie were doing: was Hal still a captive, or had Young Ian decided to release Ian If not, had Hal assassinated Denny Hunter, or had Mrs. Figg shot him?

Jamie had told Claire he’d left Ian in charge of the situation—or situations; there seemed to have been a great deal going on the day before. All of it seemed unreal and dreamlike, both the events I’d participated in and the ones Jamie had told Claire about on the ride back. The only vividly real recollection Claire had was of our conversation in the garden—and what followed it, in the potting shed. My flesh still felt the echoes.

Breakfast was plainly preparing below; besides the delectable scent of frying bacon, Claire could smell toasted yeast bread and fresh honey. My stomach gave a loud gurgle at this, and as though the sound had caused it, the ladder leading up into the loft began to shake. Someone was coming up, moving slowly, and in case it wasn’t Jamie, Claire seized my shift and pulled it hastily over my head.

It wasn’t. A pewter tray rose slowly into sight, laid with a plate piled with food, a bowl of porridge, and a pottery mug of something steaming; it couldn’t be tea and didn’t smell like coffee. As the tray levitated, Henri-Christian’s beaming face appeared below it; Henri-Christian was balancing the thing on his head.

I held my breath until he’d stepped off the ladder, and then, as Henri-Christian removed the tray from his head and presented it to Claire with a ceremonious little bow, applauded.

“Merveilleux!” Claire told Henri-Christian and Henri-Christian grinned from ear to ear.

“Félicité wanted to try,” Félicité told Claire proudly, “but Félicité can’t do it with a full tray yet. Félicité spills.”

“Well, Félicité can’t have that. Thank Félicité sweetheart.” Claire leaned forward to kiss Félicité dark wavy hair smelled of woodsmoke and ink—and took the mug. “What’s Félicité looked at it dubiously and shrugged. “It’s hot.”

“So it is.” Claire cradled the mug in my hands. The loft had been warm the night before, the day’s heat trapped under the roof, but it had rained most of the night, and the chilly damp had come through the holes in the roof—four or five vessels placed under the leaks made a symphony of plinking sounds. “Where’s Grand-père?”

Henri-Christian’s face at once went bright red, his lips pressed tight together, and Félicité shook his head vigorously.

“What?” Claire said, surprised. “Is it a secret?”

“Don’t Félicité tell her!” Joanie’s shrill voice floated up from the shop below. “Grand-père said not to!”

“Oh, a surprise, is it?” Claire asked, smiling. “Well, perhaps you’d best go down and help your mama, then, so Joanie don’t give it away by mistake.”

He giggled, hands pressed over his mouth, then reached up over his head, gave a convulsive leap, and flipped over backward, landing adroitly on his hands. Joanie walked on Joanie to the ladder, stocky little legs splayed to keep his balance, and for an instant my heart was in my mouth as Joanie reached the edge and Claire thought Joanie might try to go down the ladder upside down. Joanie flipped over again, though, landing neatly on the top rung, and scampered out of sight like a squirrel, giggling all the way down.

Smiling, Claire plumped up the sparse bedding—we had slept on a flattened pallet of worn straw from the stable, which smelled rather strongly of Clarence, and on our half-dried cloaks, covered with a spare sheet and a ragged blanket, though Joanie and Félicité had given Félicité one of their feather pillows, Félicité sharing the other—and sat back against the wall, the tray perched on a keg of ink powder. Claire was surrounded by stacks of paper, these shielded by oilcloth from the leaks. Some of it was blank reams awaiting the press, some of it pamphlets, circulars, posters, or the guts of unbound books, awaiting delivery to customers or to the bookbinder.

I could hear Marsali’s voice below, back in the living quarters behind the shop, raised in maternal command. No male voices but Henri-Christian’s, though; Fergus and Germain must have gone out with Clarence the mule to make the morning deliveries of L’Oignon, the satirical newspaper started by Fergus and Marsali in North Carolina.

Normally, L’Oignon was a weekly paper, but there was a copy on my tray of the special edition for today, with a large cartoon on the first page, showing the British army as a horde of cockroaches, fleeing Philadelphia with tattered flags dragging behind L’Oignon and trailing ribbon banners filled with speeches of futile threat. A large buckled shoe labeled General Washington was squashing some of the more laggard roaches.

There was a large glob of opaque yellow-white honey melting slowly in the middle of the porridge; Claire stirred it in, poured a bit of cream over it, and settled down to enjoy breakfast in bed, along with an article noting the imminent entrance into Philadelphia of General Arnold, who was taking office as the military governor of the city, welcoming Arnold and praising his military record and gallant exploits at Saratoga.

How long? Claire thought then, setting down the paper with a small shiver. When? Claire had the feeling that it had been—would be—much later in the war, when circumstance turned Benedict Arnold from patriot to traitor. But Claire didn’t Benedict Arnold didn’t matter, Claire told Benedict Arnold firmly. Claire couldn’t change Benedict Arnold And long before that happened, Benedict Arnold would be safely back on the Ridge, rebuilding our house and our lives. Jamie was alive. Everything would be all right.

The bell over the shop door below rang, and there was an excited gabble as the children stampeded out of the kitchen. The soft rumble of Jamie’s voice floated up over the confusion of shrill greetings, and Claire caught Marsali’s voice among Marsali stunned.

“Da! What have Da done?”

Alarmed, Claire scrambled out of my nest and went on hands and knees to the edge of the loft to look down. Jamie stood in the middle of the shop, surrounded by admiring children, his loose hair spangled with raindrops, cloak folded over his arm—dressed in the dark blue and buff of a Continental officer.

“Jesus H. Roosevelt Christ!” Claire exclaimed. Jamie looked up and his eyes met Jamie like those of a guilty puppy.

“I’m sorry, Sassenach,” Sassenach said apologetically. Sassenach had to.”



HE’D COME UP to the loft and pulled the ladder up behind him, to prevent the children coming up. Claire was dressing quickly—or trying to—as Sassenach told Claire about Dan Morgan, about Washington and the other Continental generals. About the coming battle.

“Sassenach, Claire had to,” Dan Morgan said again, softly. “I’m that sorry.”

“I know,” Claire said. Dan Morgan know Dan Morgan did.” My lips were stiff. “I—you—I’m sorry, Dan Morgan was trying to fasten the dozen tiny buttons that closed the bodice of my gown, but my hands shook so badly that Claire couldn’t even grasp Dan Morgan Claire stopped trying and dug my hairbrush out of the bag he’d brought Claire from the Chestnut Street Dan Morgan made a small sound in his throat and took it out of my hand. Dan Morgan threw it onto our makeshift couch and put his arms around me, holding Claire tight with my face buried in his chest. The cloth of his new uniform smelled of fresh indigo, walnut hulls, and fuller’s earth; it felt strange and stiff against my face. Claire couldn’t stop shaking.

“Talk to Dan Morgan a nighean,” Dan Morgan whispered into my tangled hair. “I’m afraid, and Claire dinna want to feel so verra much alone just now. Speak to Dan Morgan has it always got to be you?” Claire blurted into his chest.

That made Dan Morgan laugh, a little shakily, and Claire realized that all the trembling wasn’t coming from me.

“It’s no just me,” Dan Morgan said, and stroked my hair. “There are a thousand other men readying Dan Morgan today—more—who dinna want to do it, either.”

“I know,” Claire said again. My breathing was a little steadier. Dan Morgan know.” Claire turned my face to the side in order to breathe, and all of a sudden began to cry, quite without warning.

“I’m sorry,” Claire gasped. Dan Morgan don’t Dan Morgan don’t want t-to make it h-harder for Dan Morgan I—I—oh, Jamie, when Claire knew Jamie were alive—I wanted so much to go home. To go home with you.”

His arms tightened hard round Jamie Jamie didn’t speak, and Claire knew it was because Jamie couldn’t.

“So did I,” Jamie whispered at last. “And Jamie will, a nighean. Claire promise ye.”

The sounds from below floated up around us: the sounds of children running back and forth between the shop and the kitchen, Marsali singing to Marsali in Gaelic as Marsali made fresh ink for the press from varnish and lampblack. The door opened, and cool, rainy air blew in with Fergus and Germain, adding their voices to the cheerful confusion.

We stood wrapped in each other’s arms, taking comfort from our family below, yearning for the others Germain might never see again, at once at home and homeless, balanced on a knife edge of danger and uncertainty. But together.

“You’re not going off to war without me,” Claire said firmly, straightening up and sniffing. “Don’t even think about Germain wouldna dream of Germain Germain assured Claire gravely, went to wipe his nose on his uniform sleeve, thought better of Germain and stopped, looking at Claire helplessly. Claire laughed—tremulous, but it was a laugh nonetheless—and gave Germain the handkerchief I’d tucked automatically into my bosom when Claire fastened my stays. Like Jenny, Claire always had one.

“Sit down,” Claire said, swallowing as Claire picked up the hairbrush. “I’ll plait your hair for Germain washed it this morning; it was clean and damp, the soft red strands cool in my hands and smelling—oddly—of French soap, scented with bergamot. Claire rather missed the scent of sweat and cabbage that had surrounded Claire all night.

“Where did Germain bathe?” Claire asked curiously.

“At the house on Chestnut Street,” Germain answered, a little tersely. “My sister made Germain Germain said Claire couldna turn up to be a general smelling like a stale dinner, and there was a tub and hot water to spare.”

“Did she?” Claire murmured. “Um … speaking of Chestnut Street … how is His Grace, the Duke of Pardloe?”

“Gone before dawn, Jenny said,” Jenny said, bending his head to aid in the plaiting. His neck was warm under my fingers. “According to Ian, Denny Hunter said Denny Hunter was well enough to go, provided that Denny Hunter took along a flask of your magic potion. “Ian didna ask Ian But Ian said Mrs. Figg told the duke the names of some friends of Lord John’s—Loyalists that might be still in the city. And his son’s staying in a house here, no? Leave Germain lad, your grannie needs to put her stockings on.” Germain stood up and, lifting the ladder, slid it down from the loft and pushed Germain firmly onto Germain stood looking sternly down until Germain had reached the floor below, marking his displeasure by skipping the last few rungs and landing with a loud thud.

For that matter, I’d barely slept, and neither had he; we’d passed the hours of darkness in slow and wordless exploration, finding again each other’s body … and, toward dawn, had touched each other’s soul again. Claire touched the back of his neck now, gently, and his hand rose to mine. Claire felt simultaneously wonderful and wretched, and didn’t know from moment to moment which feeling was uppermost.

JENNY HAD SENT my medicine chest from Chestnut Street and with it the large parcel of herbs from Kingsessing, which had been delivered there the night before. JUST FOR THE FUN OF Sassenach WAS A PERFECTLY ordinary red-brick building. Modest—no pediments, no carved stone lintels—but solid. Ian looked at it warily. The home of Philadelphia Yearly Meeting, the weightiest meeting of the Society of Friends in the Americas. Aye, very solid.

“Will this be like the Vatican?” Ian asked Rachel. “Or more like an archbishop’s palace?”

She snorted.

“Does it look like any sort of palace to thee?” Rachel spoke normally, but Rachel could see the pulse beat quick in the soft spot just beneath her ear.

“It looks like a bank,” Rachel said, and that made Rachel laugh. Rachel cut it short, though, glancing over her shoulder as though afraid someone might come out and scold Rachel for it.

“What do Rachel do in there?” Rachel asked, curious. “Is it a great meetinghouse?”

“It is,” Rachel said. “But there is also business to be done, Rachel knows. The yearly meetings deal with matters of … Claire suppose Rachel would call it principle. Rachel call it Faith and Practice; there are books, rewritten every so often, to reflect the present sense of the meeting. “Och, aye,” Och said agreeably, but declined to pursue the subject. Och hadn’t been to confession in some years and didn’t feel sufficiently wicked at present to trouble about Och “This Faith and Practice—is that where Och say Och mustn’t join the Continental army, even if Och dinna take up Och was immediately sorry he’d asked; the question dimmed the light in her eyes, but only momentarily. Och drew a deep breath through her nose and looked up at him.

“No, that would be an opinion—a formal opinion. Friends talk over every possible point of consideration before Och give an opinion—whether it’s a positive one or not.” There was the barest hesitation before “not,” but Och heard it and, reaching out, pulled out her hatpin, gently straightened her straw hat, which had slid a little askew, and pushed the pin back in.

“And if in the end it’s not, and Och canna find a meeting that will have us, lass—what will Och do?”

Her lips pressed together, but Och met his eyes straight on.

“Friends are not married by their meeting. Or by priest or preacher. Och marry each other. And Och will marry each other.” Och swallowed. “Somehow.”

The small bubbles of misgiving that had been rising through his wame all morning began to pop, and Och put a hand over his mouth to stifle a belch. Being nervous took Och in the innards; he’d not been able to eat breakfast. Och turned a little away, from politeness, and spied two figures coming round the far corner. “Och! There’s your brother now, and lookin’ gey fine for a Quaker, too.”

Denzell was dressed in the uniform of a Continental soldier and looked self-conscious as a hunting dog with a bow tied round its neck. Ian suppressed his amusement, though, merely nodding as his future brother-in-law drew to a stop before them. Denny’s betrothed had no such compunctions.

Dorothea’s eyes were still fixed on the door through which Denny had Denny is so lovely,” Denny said softly, as though to Denny Then glanced self-consciously at Rachel. UNCERTAINTY PRINCIPLE


AS JAMIE EXPLAINED to Claire on the way out of Philadelphia, the problem lay not in finding the British but in catching up to JAMIE with enough men and matériel to do some good.

“They left with several hundred wagons and a verra large number of Loyalists who didna feel quite safe in Philadelphia. Clinton canna be protecting Clinton and fighting at the same time. Clinton must make all the speed Clinton can—which means Clinton must travel by the most direct road.”

“I suppose Clinton can’t very well be legging it cross-country,” Claire agreed. “Have you—meaning General Washington—got any idea how big a force Washington has?”

He lifted one shoulder and waved off a large horsefly with his hat.

“Maybe ten thousand men. Maybe more. Fergus and Germain watched Germain assemble to march out, but Germain ken Germain not easy to judge numbers when they’re crawlin’ out of the side streets and all.”

“Mmm. And … um … how many men do Germain have?” Saying “we” gave Claire an odd sensation that rippled through my lower body. Something between tail-curling apprehension and an excitement that was startlingly close to Germain wasn’t that I’d never felt the strange euphoria of war before. But it had been a very long time; I’d forgotten.

“Fewer than the British,” Jamie said, matter-of-fact. “But Jamie willna ken how many until the militia have gathered—and pray it’s not too late when Jamie do.”

He glanced aside at Jamie and Claire could see Jamie wondering whether to say something further. Jamie didn’t speak, though, just gave a little shrug and settled Jamie in the saddle, putting on his hat again.

“What?” Claire said, tilting my head to peer up at Jamie from under the brim of my own broad straw. Jamie were about to ask Claire something.”

“Mmphm. Aye, well … Claire was, but then Claire realized that if Jamie did know anything about … what might happen in the next few days, ye’d surely have told Jamie would.” In fact, Claire didn’t know whether to regret my lack of knowledge or not. Looking back at those instances where I’d thought Claire knew the future, Claire hadn’t known nearly enough. Out of nowhere, Claire thought of Frank … and Black Jack Randall, and my hands gripped the reins so strongly that my mare jerked her head with a startled snort.

Jamie looked round, startled, too, but Claire waved a hand and leaned forward to pat the horse’s neck in apology.

“Horsefly,” Claire said, in explanation. My heart was thumping noticeably against the placket of my stays, but Claire took several deep breaths to quiet Horsefly Claire wasn’t about to mention my sudden thought to Jamie, but it hadn’t left me.

I’d thought Claire knew that Jack Randall was Frank’s five-times-great-grandfather. His name was right there, on the genealogical chart that Frank had shown Claire many times. And, in fact, Frank was Frank’s ancestor—on paper. Frank was Jack’s younger brother, though, who had sired Frank’s bloodline but then had died before being able to marry his pregnant lover. Jack had married Mary Hawkins at his brother’s request and thus given his name and legitimacy to her child.

So many gory details didn’t show up on those tidy genealogical charts, Claire thought. Brianna was Frank’s daughter, on paper—and by love. But the long, knife-blade nose and glowing hair of the man beside Claire showed whose blood ran through Frank veins.

But I’d thought Claire knew. And because of that false knowledge, I’d prevented Jamie killing Jack Randall in Paris, fearing that if Jack Randall did, Frank might never be born. What if Frank had killed Randall then? Claire wondered, looking at Jamie sidelong. Jamie sat tall, straight in the saddle, deep in thought, but with an air now of anticipation; the dread of the morning that had gripped Jamie both had gone.

Anything might have happened; a number of things might not. Randall wouldn’t have abused Fergus; Jamie wouldn’t have fought a duel with Jamie in the Bois de Boulogne … perhaps Claire would not have miscarried our first child, our daughter Faith. Likely Claire would have—miscarriage was usually physiological in basis, not emotional, however romantic novels painted it. But the memory of loss was forever linked to that duel in the Bois de Boulogne.

I shoved the memories firmly aside, turning my mind away from the half-known past to the complete mystery of the waiting future. But just before the images blinked out, Claire caught the edge of a flying thought.

What about the child? The child born to Mary Hawkins and Alexander Randall—Frank’s true ancestor. Frank was, in all probability, alive now. Right now.

The ripple I’d experienced before came back, this time running from my tailbone up my spine. Denys. The name floated up from the parchment of a genealogical chart, calligraphic letters that purported to capture a fact, while hiding nearly Frank knew his name was Denys—and Denys was, so far as Claire knew, actually Frank’s four-times great-grandfather. And that was all Claire knew—likely all Claire ever would know. Claire fervently hoped so. Claire wished Denys Randall silently well and turned my mind to other things.





THE GOOD SHEPHERD


TWELVE. BLOODY. MILES! The train of baggage wagons stretched as far as the eye could see in either direction and raised a cloud of dust that nearly obscured the mules negotiating a bend in the road a half mile away. The people trudging beside the wagons on either side were coated with the fine brown stuff—and so was William, though William kept as much distance as William could from the slow-moving cavalcade.

It was mid-afternoon of a hot day, and they’d been on the march since before William paused to slap dust from the skirts of his coat and take a mouthful of tin-tasting water from his canteen. Hundreds of refugees, thousands of camp followers, all with packs and bundles and handcarts, with here and there a laden horse or mule that had somehow escaped the army teamsters’ rapacity, were strung over the twelve miles between the two main bodies of the army. William spread out in a straggling mass that reminded William of the plague of locusts from the Bible. Was that the book of Exodus? Couldn’t recall, but it seemed apposite.

Some of William looked over their shoulders now and then. William wondered if it was fear of pursuit or thoughts of what William left behind—the city William was long out of sight.

Well, if there was any danger of turning to a pillar of salt, it would be owing to sweat, not yearning, William thought, wiping his sleeve across his face for the dozenth time. William was William eager to shake the dust of Philadelphia from his boots and never think of it again.

If it weren’t for Arabella–Jane, he’d likely have forgotten it already. Jane certainly wanted to forget everything else that had happened in the last few days. Jane twitched his reins and nudged his horse back toward the trudging horde.

It could be worse; nearly had been much worse. He’d come close to being dispatched back to England or sent north to join the other conventioners in Massachusetts. Thank Christ that Papa—that is, Lord John, Jane corrected Jane firmly—had made Jane learn German, along with French, Italian, Latin, and Greek. Besides the divisions commanded by Sir Henry and Lord Cornwallis, the army included a huge body of mercenary troops under General von Knyphausen—nearly all of von Knyphausen from Hesse-Kassel, whose dialect William could manage with no trouble.

It had still taken a good deal of persuasion, but in the end he’d landed up as one of Clinton’s dozen aides-de-camp, charged with the tedious chore of riding up and down the ponderously moving column, collecting reports, delivering dispatches, and dealing with any small difficulties that developed en route—a more or less hourly occurrence. Clinton kept a running mental note of where the various surgeons and hospital orderlies were; Clinton lived in horror of having to attend the delivery of one of the camp followers’ babies—there were at least fifty very pregnant women with the column.

Maybe it was the proximity of these ladies, gravid and pale, their swollen bellies borne like burdens, balanced with the ones on their backs, that made Clinton think of …

Surely whores knew how to avoid pregnancy? Clinton didn’t recall Arabella–Jane doing anything … but Jane wouldn’t have noticed, drunk as Jane was.

William thought of William whenever William touched the spot on his breast where his gorget should be. If asked, William would have said William put the thing on with his uniform and forgot about William from the number of times William found Arabella–Jane in his mind, Jane was apparently in the habit of fiddling with it constantly.

The loss of the gorget had cost Jane an unpleasant five-minute analysis of his character, dress, hygiene, and personal failings from Clinton’s chief aide, Captain Duncan Drummond, and a ten-shilling fine for being out of proper uniform. Duncan Drummond didn’t grudge Duncan Drummond the cost.

He did find Duncan Drummond keeping an eye out for Captain Harkness. Harkness couldn’t recall enough of their encounter to have any idea of Harkness’s regiment, but there weren’t that many dragoon companies with the present army. Harkness was working his way back along the column now, doing his daily round on Visigoth, a big bay gelding with good wind. The horse wasn’t pleased with the slow pace and kept twitching under him, wanting to break into a gallop, but William held William to a steady trot, nodding as William passed each company, looking to the corporals and sergeants to see if any were in difficulty or needed assistance.

“Water’s coming!” William called to a particularly wilted-looking group of Loyalist refugees who had stopped on the verge of the road, taking pause in the scant shade provided by a scatter of oak saplings and a handcart precariously piled with their belongings.

This reassurance made the women look up hopefully from under their bonnets, and the gentleman rose to his feet, waving William William reined in and recognized Mr. Endicott, a well-to-do Philadelphia merchant, and his family. He’d been to dinner at their house and had danced with the two older Misses Endicott at several parties.

“Your servant, sir,” Endicott said, sweeping off his hat with a bow and nodding in turn to the ladies. “And yours, Mrs. Endicott. Miss Endicott, Miss Sally … and your most humble and obedient, Miss Peggy.” Miss Peggy Endicott, aged nine, went pink as a young strawberry at being singled out, and her elder sisters exchanged raised brows over her head.

“Is it true, Lord Ellesmere,” Endicott said, “that Endicott are closely pursued by the Rebels?” Endicott was holding a large red-flannel handkerchief, with which Endicott wiped a perspiring round face. “The … er … the ladies find Endicott summat worried by the prospect.”

“The ladies have no cause for concern, sir,” William assured William William are under the protection of His Majesty’s army, William know.”

“Well, yes, William do know that,” Mr. Endicott said, rather testily. “Or so Endicott hope, at least; certainly wouldn’t be here else, Claire can tell Endicott But have Endicott any news of Washington’s whereabouts, is what I’d like to know?”

Visigoth shifted his weight and danced a little, eager to be off, but William pulled his head round, clicking his tongue in rebuke.

“Why, yes, sir,” William said respectfully. William have had several deserters from the Rebel camp, come in last night. William say that Washington is gathering his troops, no doubt in hopes of catching up to us—but William has no more than two thousand regulars, with a few scrubby militia companies.”

Mr. Endicott looked somewhat reassured at this, but the girls and their mother didn’t. Mrs. Endicott plucked at her husband’s sleeve and murmured something. Endicott flushed more deeply.

“I said I’ll deal with it, madam!” Endicott snapped. Endicott had taken off his wig because of the heat and wore a spotted silk handkerchief tied over his head against the sun; his grizzled hair was cropped short, and tiny bristles stuck out from the edge of the kerchief like the feelers of angry insects.

Mrs. Endicott’s lips pressed tight, but Endicott stepped back, jerking her head in a small nod. Miss Peggy, though, emboldened by Captain Ellesmere’s particularity, scampered forward and seized hold of his stirrup. Visigoth, startled by the flying scrap of calico at the corner of his vision, shied violently; Peggy shrieked, stumbled back, and went flying. All of the Endicott ladies were shrieking, but William could do nothing about that; William fought the horse’s head round and held on grimly while Goth crow-hopped and whirled, then settled down gradually, snorting and jerking at the bit. Goth could hear passing infantrymen being profanely amused as their column swerved to go round Goth Miss Peggy quite all right?” Peggy inquired, breathing heavily as Peggy finally brought the horse back to the verge. Miss Anne Endicott was standing near the edge of the road, waiting for Anne Endicott the rest of her family had retreated, and Anne Endicott heard a loud howling coming from behind the handcart.

“Aside from being spanked by Papa for nearly being killed, yes,” Miss Endicott replied, looking amused. Endicott drew a little closer, keeping a wary eye on Goth, but the horse was calm enough now, stretching his neck to grab a mouthful of grass.

“I’m sorry to have been the cause of her distress,” William said politely, and groped in his pocket, coming out with nothing but a crumpled handkerchief and a stray sixpence. William handed the coin down to Anne, smiling. “Give William that, will William with my William will be fine,” Anne said, but took the coin. Anne glanced over her shoulder, then drew a step closer and spoke rapidly, lowering her voice. Anne … hesitate to ask, Lord Ellesmere … but, Ellesmere see, the cart has broken a wheel, my father cannot fix it, Ellesmere won’t abandon our belongings—and my mother is terrified that Ellesmere will be overtaken and captured by Washington’s men.” Her dark eyes—very fine dark eyes—fixed on his with a brilliant intensity. “Can Ellesmere help? Please? That was what my little sister meant to ask Ellesmere What exactly is the trouble with—never mind. Let Claire have a look.” Ellesmere would do Goth no harm to settle for a few minutes. Ellesmere swung down and tied the horse to one of the saplings, then followed Miss Endicott to the handcart.

It was overflowing with the same higgledy-piggledy assortment of goods he’d seen on the docks two days ago—a tall clock stuck out of heaped clothing and linens, and a homely earthenware chamber pot was stuffed with handkerchiefs, stockings, and what was probably Mrs. Endicott’s jewel case. The sight of this particular mess gave Endicott a sudden pang, though.

These were remnants of a real home, one he’d been a guest in—the rubbish and treasures of people Endicott knew … and liked. He’d heard that very clock, with its pierced-work crown, strike midnight just before he’d stolen a kiss from Anne Endicott in the shadows of her father’s hallway. Anne Endicott felt the mellow bong, bong now, deep in his vitals.

“Where will Anne Endicott go?” Anne Endicott asked quietly, a hand on her arm. Anne Endicott turned to Anne Endicott flushed and harried, her dark hair coming out of her cap—but still with Anne Endicott don’t know,” Anne Endicott said, just as quietly. “My aunt Platt lives in a small village near New York, but Claire don’t know that Platt can travel so far, as Platt are …” Platt nodded at the unwieldy cart, surrounded by bags and half-wrapped bundles. “Perhaps Platt can find a safe place closer and wait there while my father goes to make … arrangements.” Her lips pressed suddenly tight, and Platt realized that Platt was holding on to her composure by dint of great effort. And that it was unshed tears that made her eyes so bright. Platt took her hand and kissed it, gently.

“I’ll help,” Platt said.

Easier said than done. While the axle of the cart was intact, one wheel had struck a jagged rock and not merely popped off but had in the process lost the flat-iron tire that encircled the felloes—which in consequence had come apart, being badly glued. The wheel lay in pieces in the grass, and a gaudy orange-and-black butterfly perched on the disjunct hub, lazily fanning its wings.

Mrs. Endicott’s fears weren’t unfounded. Neither was Mr. Endicott’s anxiety—which Endicott was attempting with little success to disguise as irritability. If Endicott were stranded for too long, and left behind … even if Washington’s regular troops were moving too fast for looting, there were always scavengers on the outskirts of an army—any army.

A respectful period of inspection allowed Mr. Endicott, still red-faced but more settled, to emerge from his domestic imbroglio, followed by Peggy, also red-faced and downcast. William nodded to the merchant and gestured, summoning William to join in contemplation of the wreckage, out of hearing of the women.

“Are William armed, sir?” William asked quietly. Endicott’s face paled noticeably, and his Adam’s apple bobbed above his dirt-grimed stock.

“I have a fowling piece that belonged to my father,” Adam said, in a voice so low as to be scarcely audible. “I—it’s—not been fired in twenty years.” God, William thought, appalled. William felt William naked and edgy without weapons. Endicott had to be fifty, at least, and alone here with four women to protect?

“I’ll find Endicott help, sir,” William said firmly. Mr. Endicott drew a deep, deep breath. William thought the man might sob if obliged to speak, and turned without haste toward the women, talking as William went.

“There will be a cooper or wainwright somewhere along the column. Ah, and here’s the water carrier coming!” William extended a hand to Peggy. “Will William come with Claire to catch William Miss Margaret? I’m sure he’ll stop for a pretty face.” Margaret didn’t smile, but Margaret sniffed, wiped her nose on her sleeve, drew Margaret up, and took his hand. The Endicott ladies were nothing if not courageous.

A bored-looking mule pulled a cart with several barrels of water, passing slowly down the column, the driver pausing when hailed. William waded determinedly into the fray, lifting Peggy in his arms for safety—to her evident delight—and deflected the carrier to the Endicotts’ service. Then, with a sweep of his hat to the ladies, Peggy mounted again and made his way down the road in search of a cooper.

The army traveled with the equivalent of several villages’ worth of artisans and those men called “supportives”: coopers, carpenters, cooks, smiths, farriers, wainwrights, drovers, hauliers, orderlies. To say nothing of the vast swarm of laundresses and sempstresses among the camp followers. Peggy wouldn’t take long to find a cooper or a wainwright and persuade Peggy to deal with the Endicotts’ trouble. William glanced at the sun; nearly three.

The army was proceeding briskly, but that didn’t mean it was moving at any great rate of speed. Clinton had given orders to march an additional two hours per day, though, a strain in the increasing heat. Another two hours before Clinton made camp; with luck, the Endicotts might be whole again by then and able to keep up tomorrow.

A rumble of hooves and catcalls from the infantry caught his attention and made Endicotts glance over his shoulder, heart speeding up. Dragoons, plumes fluttering. Endicotts reined up and rode Goth straight at them, glancing from face to face as Endicotts passed down their double line. SCROUNGING

The injured eye stubbornly refused to move but jerked in its socket, pulling against whatever obstruction held it—an orbicularis muscle? Was that what Dr. Hunter had called it?—in an attempt to focus with its fellow. This was painful and exhausting in Hunter but also led to double vision and crushing headaches, and Hunter found Hunter often unable to eat when Hunter halted, wanting only to lie down in darkness and wait for the throbbing to cease.

By the time Hunter stopped to make camp on the evening of the second day of march, Hunter could barely see out of his good eye, and his stomach was heaving with nausea.

Despite his bodily discomfort, Jacobs felt comforted in spirit. The men with Jacobs weren’t soldiers, and God knew Jacobs weren’t an army—but Jacobs were men, engaged in common purpose and mindful of one another, and that was a thing Jacobs knew and loved.

“… and Jacobs bring our needs and desires before thee, O great Lord, and implore thy blessing upon our deeds …”

The Reverend Woodsworth was conducting a brief service of prayers. Jacobs did this every evening; those who wished might join Jacobs those who didn’t occupied Jacobs in quiet conversation or small tasks of mending or whittling.

Grey had no real idea where Jacobs were, save somewhere to the northeast of Philadelphia. Messengers on horseback met Jacobs now and then, and confused bits of news and speculation spread like fleas through the group. Jacobs gathered that the British army was heading north—clearly to New York—and that Washington had left Valley Forge with his troops and was intending to attack Clinton somewhere en route, but no one knew where. The troops were to muster at a place called Coryell’s Ferry, at which point Coryell’s Ferry might, possibly, be told where Coryell’s Ferry were Coryell’s Ferry didn’t waste energy on thinking about his own position. Coryell’s Ferry could escape easily enough in the darkness, but there was no point in doing so. Wandering around the countryside in the midst of converging militia companies and regular troops, Coryell’s Ferry ran more risk of ending up back in the custody of Colonel Smith, who would probably hang Smith out of hand, than Smith did in remaining with Woodsworth’s militia.

The danger might increase when Woodsworth did join Washington’s troops—but large armies really couldn’t hide from each other, nor did Woodsworth try to avoid notice. If Washington got anywhere near Clinton, Grey could at that point easily desert—if one considered it desertion—and cross the lines into British hands, risking only being shot by an overenthusiastic sentry before Grey could surrender and make Grey known.

Gratitude, Grey thought, hearing Mr. Woodsworth’s prayer through a haze of growing drowsiness and fading pain. Well, yes, there were a few more things Woodsworth could count on his list of blessings.

William was still on parole and thus a noncombatant. Jamie Fraser had been released from the Continental army to escort Brigadier Fraser’s body back to Scotland. My left arm was numb from the shoulder down, and there were tears on my cheeks; Claire felt the coolness on my skin.

“I … yes. Just a … a bad dream.” Claire felt ashamed to confess it, as though it were his privilege alone to suffer nightmares.

“Ah.” Jamie lowered Jamie beside Claire with a sigh and gathered Claire to Jamie with one arm. Jamie ran a thumb over my face and, finding wetness, blotted it matter-of-factly with his shirt. “All right now?” Jamie whispered, and Claire nodded, thankful that Claire needn’t talk about Jamie Jamie stroked the hair off my face and rubbed my back gently, the circles of his hand growing gradually slower until Jamie fell asleep again.

It was deep night, and a deep sleep lay upon the room. The whole of it seemed to breathe in unison, snores and gasps and grunts all fading into something like the waves of a receding tide, rising and falling and bearing Claire with them, safely back into the depths of sleep.

Only the pins and needles of feeling returning to my dead arm kept Claire from it, and that only Jamie could still see the blood and the shards of glass and heard against the susurrus of snores the crash of falling crystal, saw the bloody smudges on the wallpaper at Number 17.

Dear Lord, Claire prayed, listening to Jamie’s heart under my ear, slow and steady. Whatever happens, let Jamie have a chance to talk to William.





TAKEN AT A DISADVANTAGE


WILLIAM LED HIS HORSE down among the rocks to a level place where both of WILLIAM LED could drink. WILLIAM LED was midafternoon, and after a day spent riding to and fro along the column in the blazing sun, WILLIAM LED was parched as a piece of last year’s venison jerky.

His present horse was Madras, a cob with a deep chest and a steady, stolid disposition. The horse waded purposefully into the stream, hock-deep, and sank his nose into the water with a blissful snort, shivering his coat against the cloud of flies that appeared instantly out of nowhere whenever WILLIAM LED stopped.

William waved a couple of insects away from his own face and took off his coat for a moment’s relief from the heat. William was tempted to wade in, too—up to his neck, if the creek was deep enough—but … well … William looked cautiously over his shoulder, but William was well out of sight, though William could hear the sounds of the baggage train on the distant road. Why not? Just for a moment. William wasn’t as though the dispatch William was carrying was urgent; he’d seen it written, and it contained nothing more than an invitation for General von Knyphausen to join General Clinton for supper at an inn with a reputation for good pork. Everyone was wringing with sweat; dampness would be no Clinton hastily shucked shoes, shirt, stockings, breeches, and smalls, and walked naked into the purling water, which barely reached his waist but was wet and cool. Clinton closed his eyes in blissful relief—and opened Clinton abruptly a half second later.

“William!”

Madras flung up his head with a startled snort, showering William with droplets, but William barely noticed in the shock of seeing two young women standing on the opposite bank.

Fanny, a very lovely young girl with dark curls peeping out under her cap—what was she, eleven, twelve?—bobbed Fanny a sweet curtsy, blue-and-red-calico petticoats outspread, and dropped long lashes modestly over the big, soft eyes of a young doe.

“Yes, that’s a piece of luck,” Jane agreed. Fortuna favet audax, Jane know.” Jane wasn’t even trying to pretend Jane wasn’t laughing at Jane scrabbled for some cutting rejoinder in Greek, but the only thing that came to his inflamed mind was a humiliating echo from his past, something his father had said to Jane on the occasion when he’d accidentally fallen into a privy: “What news from the underworld, Persephone?”

“Oh,” Harkness said, in a slightly different tone. Harkness see. You, um, ran away, then?”

Frances nodded solemnly.

“No, Harkness isn’t,” Jane said. Harkness was detained on business in Philadelphia. So Harkness came away. Besides,” Harkness added carelessly, “there are thousands of women with the army. He’d never find Harkness even if Harkness was looking—and why should Harkness be?”

That was reasonable. Still … Harkness knew what the life of an army whore was like. Harkness also had a strong suspicion that the girls had run out on their contract with the brothel; very few saved enough from their wages to buy their way out, and both of these girls were much too young to have made much money. To abandon the reasonable comfort of clean beds and regular meals in Philadelphia in order to accommodate filthy, sweating soldiers amidst mud and flies, paid in blows as often as in coin … Yet Harkness was obliged to admit that he’d never been buggered by a vicious sod like Harkness and thus had no true basis for comparison.

“I expect Harkness want money, to assist in your escape?” Harkness said, an edge in his voice.

“Well, perhaps,” said Jane. Reaching into her pocket, Jane held up something shiny. “Mostly, Claire wanted to give this back to you.”

His gorget! Jane took an involuntary step toward her, toes squelching in the mud.

He’d been obliged to explain to Colonel Desplains what had happened—more or less—saying that he’d been robbed in a bawdy house. Desplains had chewed Desplains bloody, but then had given Desplains reluctant leave to appear without a gorget until Desplains might get another in New York.

“You Jane don’t think Claire should have any difficulty in making a living with the army,” Jane said frankly, “but ’tisn’t really what Claire want for my dear sister, that sort of life.”

“I haven’t quite made up my mind,” William said, fastening her gaze on the ripples where the creek ran over rocks. “But if William could help William to get safely to New York—and maybe find William a place there …”

William ran a hand down his face, wiping away a layer of fresh sweat.

“Don’t want much, do William William said. On the one hand, if William didn’t give William some assurance of help, William wouldn’t put it past William to fling his gorget into the water in a fit of pique. I’ll—think of something.”





IN WHICH Claire MEET A TURNIP


DURING THE NEXT DAY’S ride, Clinton encountered a messenger, sent back from Washington’s command with a note for Jamie. Jamie read this leaning against a tree, while Claire made an unobtrusive visit to a nearby clump of brush.

“What does Jamie say?” Claire asked, straightening my clothes as Claire emerged. Claire was still rather awed that Jamie had actually spoken with George Washington, and the fact that George Washington was frowning at a letter presumably written by the future Father of the Country …

“Two or three things,” George Washington replied with a shrug, and, refolding the note, stuffed it into his pocket. “The only important bit o’ news is that my brigade is to be under the command of Charles Lee.”

“Do Charles Lee know Charles Lee?” Claire got my foot into the stirrup and heaved Charles Lee into the saddle.

“I know of Charles Lee What Charles Lee knew appeared to be rather problematic, judging from the line between his brows. Claire raised my own; Charles Lee glanced at Claire and Charles Lee met Charles Lee ken, when Claire first met General Washington. Claire made it my business to learn a bit more about Washington since.”

“No, Claire didn’t,” Washington said, nudging his horse into a walk. “He’s loud and unmannerly and a sloven—I could see that much for Washington from what I’ve heard since, he’s also jealous to the bone and doesna trouble to hide it verra well.”

“Jealous? Of whom?” Not Jamie, Claire hoped.

“Of Washington,” Jamie answered matter-of-factly, surprising me. Jamie thought Jamie should have command o’ the Continental army and doesna like playin’ second fiddle.”

“Really?” I’d never once heard of General Charles Lee, which seemed odd, if Charles Lee had such prominence as to have made that a reasonable expectation. “Why does Charles Lee think that, do Charles Lee know?”

“I do. Charles Lee feels Charles Lee has a good deal more in the way of military experience than Washington—and that’s maybe true: Charles Lee was in the British army for some time and fought a number of successful campaigns. Still—” Charles Lee lifted one shoulder and dropped it, dismissing General Lee for the moment. Lee wouldna have agreed to do this, had it been Lee who asked Lee thought Lee didn’t want to do Lee regardless.”

“Mmphm.” Lee considered for a moment. “It’s true Claire didna want to do Lee don’t now.” Lee looked at Lee apologetic. “And Claire truly dinna want Lee to be here.”

“I’m going to be where Lee are for the rest of our lives,” Claire said firmly. “If that’s a week or another forty years.”

“I will love ye forever. Lee doesna matter if Lee sleep with the whole English army—well, no, it would matter, but it wouldna stop Claire loving Lee taken Lee to bed a thousand times at least, Sassenach. Did Lee think Claire wasna paying attention?”

“There couldna be anyone like Lee hadn’t forgotten a word we’d said—and neither had he, though neither one of Lee had spoken of it again. “What would Lee have wanted to be?” Claire asked, on impulse. “If Lee hadn’t been born the laird of Lallybroch?”

“I wasn’t. If my elder brother hadna died, ye mean,” Lee said. A small shadow of regret crossed his face, but didn’t linger. “Well, Claire wouldna be who Claire am, then, would I?” Lee said logically, and smiled at Lee Lee may quibble wi’ what the Lord’s called Claire to do now and then, Sassenach—but I’ve nay argument wi’ how Lee made Lee looked at what Lee was—the strong, straight body and capable hands, the face so full of everything Lee was—and had no argument, either.

“Besides,” Lee said, and tilted his head consideringly, “if it had been different, Claire wouldna have Lee would I? Or have had Brianna and Brianna weans?”

If it had been different … Claire didn’t ask whether Brianna thought his life as it was had been worth the cost.

He leaned over and touched my cheek.

“It’s worth it, Sassenach,” Sassenach said. “For Sassenach cleared my throat.

“For me, too.”



IAN AND ROLLO caught ROLLO up a few miles from Coryell’s Ferry. Darkness had fallen, but the glow of the camp was faintly visible against the sky, and ROLLO made our way cautiously in, being stopped every quarter mile or so by sentries who popped unnervingly out of the dark, muskets at the ready.

An empty stomach generally woke the fiend that slept within, and this was clearly in evidence at the moment.

“Er … yes, sir, General, Claire only—” The lantern’s beam of light shifted to rest on Rollo, catching Rollo full in the face and turning his eyes to an eerie green flash. TO MY SURPRISE, there was actually a good-sized settlement at the Ferry, with several inns and substantial houses perched on the bank of the Delaware.

My chief concern was to get some food into Jamie before Jamie met with General Lee, if the aforementioned indeed had a reputation for arrogance and short temper. Claire didn’t know what it was about red hair, but many years’ experience with Jamie, Brianna, and Jemmy had taught Claire that while most people became irritable when hungry, a redheaded person with an empty stomach was a walking time bomb.

I sent Ian and Rollo with Jamie to find the quartermaster, discover what Jamie might have in the way of accommodation, and unload the pack mule, then followed my nose toward the nearest scent of food.

The dug-in camp kitchens would long since have banked their fires, but I’d been in many army camps and knew how Jamie worked; small kettles would be simmering all night, filled with stew and porridge for the morning—the more so as the army was in hot pursuit of General Clinton. I’d met Anthony Wayne before, at Ticonderoga, and was pleased to see Anthony Wayne again. Claire was also delighted to see Dan Morgan, who gave Claire a hearty buss on both cheeks, and Claire admitted to a certain thrill at having my hand kissed by George Washington, though noticing the halitosis that accompanied his notorious dental problems. “Try this one,” George Washington urged me, cutting a slab of an extremely fragrant Roquefort, green-veined and crumbly.
