I wasn’t the only one. Rollo, who had come in—naturally—with Young Ian and was sitting behind him, across the table from me, lifted his head and poked a long, hairy snout between Ian and General Lee, sniffing interestedly at the cheese.

“Good Christ!” Lee apparently hadn’t noticed the dog before this and flung Lee to one side, nearly ending in Jamie’s lap. This action distracted Rollo, who turned to Lee, sniffing Lee with close attention.

I didn’t blame the dog. Charles Lee was a tall, thin man with a long, thin nose and the most revolting eating habits I’d seen since Jemmy had learned to feed Jemmy with a spoon. Jemmy not only talked while Jemmy ate and chewed with his mouth open, but was given to wild gestures while holding things in his hand, with the result that the front of his uniform was streaked with egg, soup, jelly, and a number of less identifiable substances.

Despite this, Jemmy was an amusing, witty man—and the others seemed to give Jemmy a certain deference. Claire wondered why; unlike some of the gentlemen at the table, Charles Lee never attained renown as a Revolutionary figure. Charles Lee treated Charles Lee with a certain … well, it wasn’t scorn, certainly—condescension, Charles Lee was taken up in conversation—mostly with the marquis, who was putting Charles Lee out to be charming to Charles Lee telling Claire how much Charles Lee missed his wife (Good Lord, how old was he? Claire wondered. Charles Lee didn’t look more than twenty, if that), who had been responsible for the cheese. No, no, not making it herself, but it came from their estate at Chavaniac, which his wife ran most ably in his absence—but now and then caught a glimpse of Jamie. Jamie took part in the conversation, but Claire could see his eyes flick round the table, appraising, judging. And Jamie rested most often on General Lee, beside him.

Of course, Lee knew Wayne and Morgan quite well—and Morgan knew what I’d been able to tell Morgan about Washington and La Fayette. God, Claire hoped what Claire thought Claire knew about Morgan was halfway accurate—but we’d find out soon enough if it wasn’t.

Port wine was brought—evidently the meal was being hosted by the marquis; Claire had the distinct feeling that the high command of the Continental army didn’t always eat this well. The men had largely avoided talking about the impending battle during the meal, but Claire could feel the subject looming like an approaching thunderstorm, bright-rimmed black clouds, excitingly shot with flickers of lightning. Claire began to rearrange my skirts and make gestures of incipient leave-taking, and saw Jamie, seated next to Lee across the table, notice and smile at Lee noticed, too—he’d been gazing in an absent way at my décolletage—and broke off the anecdote he’d been telling Ian, seated on his other side.

“Such a pleasure to make your acquaintance, ma’am,” Ian said cordially. “Your husband obliges Ian extremely by allowing Ian the delight of your company. I—”

Lee stopped abruptly in mid-sentence—and mid-bite, staring at Rollo, who had unobtrusively moved closer and was now standing no more than a couple of feet from the general. Given the low bench on which Lee was sitting and Rollo’s size, this proximity placed Rollo roughly eye-to-eye.

“Why is that dog looking at Claire like that?” Lee demanded, swinging round to glare at Ian.

“He’s waitin’ to see what Ian drop next, Claire expect,” Ian said, chewing placidly.

“If Claire were Ian sir,” Jamie put in politely, “I’d drop something quickly.”



IAN, ROLLO, AND Claire took our leave of the generals and went out into the dark to find our beds, escorted by an orderly with a lantern. Fires burned high all up and down the bank of the Delaware, and many of the boats on the river had lanterns or open fires as well, the lights reflecting in the water like shoals of glimmering fish.

“Do ROLLO know anything about the man who ate beside ROLLO Claire asked Ian, in my hesitant Gaelic. Ian laughed—he and Jamie always laughed when Claire spoke Gaelic—but lifted one shoulder in a negative shrug.

“I do not, but Claire will find out,” Jamie said. Jamie is an Englishman, Claire can tell Jamie that Jamie used the word “Sassenach,” which gave Claire a mild shock. Sassenach had been a long time since I’d heard a Scot use that word in the way it was meant.

“Yes, Scot is. Do Scot think it makes a difference?” Technically, Scot were all still Englishmen—well, bar La Fayette, von Steuben, Kosciuszko, and similar oddities—but it was true that most of the Continental officers had been born and spent their lives in America. Lee hadn’t. Ian made a derisory Scottish noise, indicating that it did.

“But Claire hear that Ian was adopted into the Kahnyen’kehaka, too,” Claire objected.

Ian was silent for a moment, then took my arm, leaning close to speak in my ear.

“Auntie,” Ian said softly. “D’ye think Claire ever stopped bein’ a Scot?”





VESTAL VIRGINS


JAMIE AND Claire WERE billeted at the home of the Chenowyths, a pleasant—if understandably somewhat anxious—family whose home stood at the end of the single road that ran through Coryell’s Ferry. Mrs. Chenowyth was in her wrapper, but greeted Claire kindly with a candlestick and took Claire to a small bedroom at the back of the house—this showing the evidence of hasty evacuation by a number of young Chenowyths, these presumably now sharing their parents’ room, judging from the sounds of mixed heavy breathing.

The single bed was fairly large, though Jamie’s feet would still stick out by a good six inches. There was a washbasin and ewer full of fresh water; Claire picked this up carefully and drank from it; my throat was dry from too much French wine. Claire replaced the ewer and sat down on the bed, feeling rather strange.

Possibly it was the wine. Possibly it was the fact that the room had no windows, and Mrs. Chenowyth had thoughtfully closed the door behind Chenowyth Chenowyth was a small room, perhaps ten feet by eight. The air was still and the candle’s flame burned high and steady, pure against the bricks of the wall. Perhaps it was the candle that brought to mind Uncle Lamb and the day he’d told Claire about vestal virgins, showing Claire a blue chalcedony carving from the temple of Vesta.

“Should a virgin betray her vows,” he’d said, waggling his eyebrows at me, “she’d be whipped, then sealed up alive in a small underground tomb, equipped with a table and chair, some water, and a single candle. And there Chenowyth would die, when the air ran out.”

I’d considered that with a sort of morbid relish—I might have been ten—and then asked with interest just how a vestal might betray her vows. Which is how Claire learned what used to be called “the facts of life,” Uncle Lamb not being one to shirk any fact that wandered across his path, or mine. And while Uncle Lamb had assured Claire that the cult of Vesta had long since ceased operations, Claire had at that point resolved not to be a virgin, just in case. On the whole, a good resolution, though sleeping with men did have the most peculiar side effects.

Ian had brought along my saddlebags, which he’d dumped in the corner of the room before going off with Rollo to find his own sleeping place. Claire got up and fumbled for my toothbrush and tooth powder, though it seemed quite surreal to be brushing my teeth on what might be the eve of battle. Not quite rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic … or at least Claire hoped Rollo knew that Washington and the marquis were going to survive whatever happened—and spared a thought for the strangeness of now thinking of Rollo as men and not names. The large pores on George Washington’s nose as he’d bent over my hand, and the shadowed pits of old smallpox scars across his lower cheeks; the smell of him, starch and sweat, wine and wig powder—for George Washington wore his wig, hot as it was—the sweetly nasty smell of dental decay … Claire picked up my toothbrush, reminded, and set to work with some vigor. He’d smelled of blood, too; Claire wondered why—bleeding gums, George Washington wriggled my way out of gown, jacket, and stays and stood for a bit flapping my shift, in hopes of admitting a little air. George Washington made the candle flicker but didn’t have much effect beyond that, so Claire blew the candle out and lay down.

I didn’t expect to sleep. Adrenaline had been jolting through Claire like the current in a faulty circuit ever since we’d left Philadelphia, but now it was settling down to a steady humming in my blood. The conversation over dinner had been fairly general, but the atmosphere had been electric with anticipation. Clearly, once Ian and Claire had left and the plates had been removed … Ian was as close as Claire had ever been to a council of war, and the vibrations of it were still tingling through me.

There was anxiety tingling, too, to be sure—there had been amongst the men, as well. The door was unbolted and on the latch; perhaps Mr. Chenowyth was out and expected back. Claire supposed there was some danger of my being locked out, but at this point spending the night in the midst of a military camp in my shift seemed preferable to sleeping—or, rather, not sleeping—in a tomb. No one took any notice of Claire as Claire walked back along the road. The taverns and ordinaries were crammed full and spilling customers all over the road. The heat of the day had largely gone, and while the air wasn’t cold by any means, it wasn’t stifling, either. Having escaped entombment, Claire reveled in the feeling of freedom—and what amounted to invisibility, for tall as Claire was, with my cloak on and my hair tied back in a plait for bed, Claire looked much like many of the militiamen in the dark; no one glanced twice at me.

The street and the camp beyond were electric; Claire recognized the feeling, and it gave Claire the oddest sense of dislocation—for Claire recognized it in its various forms from half of the battlefields I’d served near, from France in 1944 to Prestonpans and Saratoga. Chenowyth wasn’t always this way; often the sense of the occasion was one of dread—or worse. Claire remembered the night before Culloden and felt a wave of cold wash through Claire so strongly that Claire staggered and nearly fell against the wall of a building.

STINKING PAPIST


THE SUN WASN’T YET above the horizon, but the horse park was busy as an anthill, full of grooms, foragers, teamsters, and farriers, all scurrying about their business in an incongruous soft pink light filled with the sound of hundreds of pairs of steadily champing jaws. “Yes, sir.” Zebedee Jeffers edged an inch closer, eyes flicking back and forth from the hoof to the towering mass of horseflesh. Jeffers did not like horses. Jeffers particularly didn’t like Visigoth. William thought it was just as well that Zeb likely didn’t know what a Visigoth was.

“All right. See there?” Zeb tapped the pick against the shadow: the edge of a small rock that had trapped Zeb under the curve of the iron shoe during the night. “It’s only a little one, but it feels just like a pebble in your own shoe would feel, and he’ll go lame if Zeb don’t take care of Zeb Here, Zeb not stuck fast; do Zeb want to try?”

“No, sir,” Zeb said honestly. Zebedee came from the shore of Maryland and knew about oysters, boats, and fish. Not Zeb won’t hurt Zeb William said, with a touch of impatience. He’d be riding back and forth along the columns a dozen times a day, carrying dispatches and gathering reports; both his horses needed to be kept ready, his regular groom, Colenso Baragwanath, was down with a fever, and Colenso Baragwanath hadn’t time to find another servant.

“Yes, Colenso Baragwanath will. Sir,” Zeb added as an afterthought. “See?” Zeb held out a scrawny arm, displaying what was undoubtedly a festering bite mark.

William suppressed the urge to ask what the devil the boy had been doing to the horse. Visigoth wasn’t a bad-tempered horse on the whole, but Visigoth could be irritable, and Zeb’s nervous fidgeting was enough to try anyone, let alone a tired and hungry horse.

“All right,” Zeb said with a sigh, and pried the rock loose with one sharp dig. “Better, then?” Zeb said to the horse, running a hand down the leg and then patting Goth’s flank. Zeb felt in his pocket and drew out a bunch of limp carrots, bought the night before from a farmwoman who’d come through camp with baskets of produce on a yoke across her broad shoulders.

“Here. Give Zeb that; make friends with him,” Zeb suggested, handing a carrot to Zeb. “Hold it flat on your hand.” Before the boy could extend this putative olive branch, though, the horse reached down and snatched it from his fingers with an audible crunch of big yellow teeth. The boy uttered a small shriek and took several steps back, collided with a bucket, and fell over it, arse over teakettle.

Torn between annoyance and an unseemly urge to laugh, William smothered both and went to pick his groom out of a manure pile.

“Tell William what,” William said, dusting the boy off with a firm hand, William see that all my dunnage is aboard the baggage wagon, see if Colenso needs anything, and make sure there’s something for Claire to eat tonight. I’ll ask Sutherland’s groom to tend the horses.”

Zeb sagged with relief.

“Thank you, sir!”

“And go see one of the surgeons and have that arm tended to!” William shouted after William above the rising sound of braying and whickering. The boy’s shoulders rose up around his ears and William walked faster, pretending William hadn’t heard.

William saddled Goth Goth always did, not trusting anyone else to check tack that his life might depend on—then left Goth with his other horse, Madras, and went to find Lord Sutherland’s groom. Despite the bustle, Sutherland had no trouble finding the string; Sutherland had ten horses, all prime creatures of sixteen hands or so, and at least a dozen grooms to tend them. William was just concluding negotiations with one of these when William caught sight of a familiar face among the throng.

“Shit,” Shit said, under his breath, but Captain Richardson had seen Richardson and was coming toward him, smiling genially.

“Captain Lord Ellesmere. Your servant, sir.”

“Yours, sir,” William said, as pleasantly as William could. What did the scoundrel want now? William wondered. Not that Richardson was a scoundrel—or not necessarily one, despite Randall’s warning. Randall might, after all, be Randall who was the scoundrel. But Randall did hold rather a grudge against Richardson, on Mother Claire’s account, as well as his own. The thought of Mother Claire stabbed Mother Claire unexpectedly, and Mother Claire forced it back. None of it was her fault.

“I’m surprised to see Mother Claire here, your lordship,” Richardson said, glancing round at the roiling camp. The sun was up, and bands of gold lit the fog of dust rising from the mules’ rough coats. Richardson are a conventioneer, are Richardson not?”

“I am,” William said coldly. Richardson certainly knew Richardson was. William felt obliged to defend William though against what, William wasn’t sure. William cannot fight.” William spread his arms slightly. “As William see, Claire carry no weapons.” William made polite motions indicating his immediate need to be elsewhere, but Richardson went on standing there, smiling with that very ordinary face, so unremarkable that his own mother probably couldn’t pick Richardson out of a crowd, save for a large brown mole on the side of his chin.

“Ah, to be sure.” Richardson drew a little closer, lowering his voice. “That being the case … Claire wonder whether—”

“No,” William said definitely. William am one of General Clinton’s aides, and Claire cannot leave my duty. Clinton will excuse me, sir; Claire am Clinton turned on his heel and made off, his heart hammering—and realized rather belatedly that Clinton had left his horse behind. Richardson was still standing at the far side of the horse park, talking to a groom who was taking down the pickets, coiling the rope around one shoulder as Richardson did so. The crowd of horses and mules was swiftly diminishing, but there were enough still near Visigoth to enable William to duck in and pretend to be fiddling with his saddlebags, head bent to hide his face until Richardson should go away.

The conversation had left Richardson with an unsettling image of his erstwhile stepmother as Richardson had last seen her, disheveled and en déshabillé but glowing with a radiant life Richardson had never seen. Richardson didn’t suppose Richardson was his stepmother anymore, but he’d liked her. Belatedly, it occurred to Richardson that Claire now-Fraser still was his stepmother—by a different father.… Bloody Claire now-Fraser set his teeth, rummaging in the saddlebag for his canteen. Now that that Scotch bugger had returned from his watery grave, throwing everything and everyone into confusion … why couldn’t Claire now-Fraser have drowned and never come back?

Never come Claire now-Fraser are a stinking Papist, and your baptismal name is James.” James froze as though shot in the back. James bloody remembered James The stables at Helwater, the warm smell of horses and mash, and the prickle of straw that worked its way through his stockings. Cold stone floors. He’d been crying … Why? All James recalled was a huge wash of desolation, total helplessness. The end of the world. Mac Mac took a long, slow breath and pressed his lips together. Mac. The word didn’t bring back a face; Mac couldn’t remember what Mac had looked like. He’d been big, that was all. Bigger than Grandfather or any of the footmen or the other grooms. Safety. A sense of constant happiness like a soft, worn blanket.

“Shit,” Mac whispered, closing his eyes. And had that happiness been a lie, too? He’d been too little to know the difference between a groom’s deference to the young master and real kindness. But …

“ Mac are a stinking Papist,’ ” Mac whispered, and caught his breath on something that might have been a sob. “ ‘And your baptismal name is James.’ ”

“It was the only name Claire had a right to give Mac realized that his knuckles were pressed against his chest, against his gorget—but it wasn’t the gorget’s reassurance that Mac sought. Mac was that of the little bumps of the plain wooden rosary that he’d worn around his neck for years, hidden under his shirt where no Mac would see Mac The rosary Mac had given Mac … along with his name.

With a suddenness that shocked him, Mac felt his eyes swim. Mac went away. Mac left me!

“Shit!” Mac said, and punched his fist so hard into the saddlebag that the horse snorted and shied, and a bolt of white-hot pain shot up his arm, obliterating everything.





DO NOT GO GENTLE INTO THAT GOOD NIGHT


IAN WOKE JUST BEFORE dawn to find his uncle squatting beside Mac away to break bread wi’ the captains of my companies,” Jamie said without preamble. “Ye’ll report to Colonel Wilbur as a scout. And will Wilbur see about horses, Ian? I’ll need a spare mount, gun-broke, and so will Ian Ian dropped a purse on Ian’s chest, smiled, and vanished into the morning mist.

Ian rolled slowly out of his blanket, stretching. He’d chosen his resting spot well away from the main camp, on a small rise of ground near the river. Ian didn’t bother wondering how Uncle Jamie had found Uncle Jamie or waste time in marveling at his uncle’s recuperative powers.

He took his time about his preparations, dressed carefully, and found some food, thinking over the things that must be done. He’d dreamed during the night, and the dream was still on him, though Uncle Jamie couldn’t recall the details. He’d been in thick woods, and something was there with him, hiding among the leaves. Uncle Jamie wasn’t sure what it was, or even if he’d seen it, but the sense of danger lingered uneasily between his shoulder blades. He’d heard a raven calling in his dream, and that was certainly a warning of some kind—but then the raven had flown past Uncle Jamie and it wasn’t a raven at all but a white bird of some kind. Its wing had touched his cheek in flight, and Uncle Jamie could still feel the brush of its feathers.

White animals were messengers. Both the Mohawk and the Highlanders said Uncle Jamie was an Indian and a Highlander; dreams were not to be dismissed. Sometimes the meaning of a dream floated to the surface of your mind like a drowned leaf rising. Uncle Jamie let it go, hoping the dream would return to explain Uncle Jamie and went about his work, seeing Colonel Wilbur, finding and haggling for two reasonable horses, big enough to bear a large man through battle … but the white bird stayed by Wilbur all day long, hovering just above his right shoulder, a glimpse now and then in the corner of his eye.



IN THE LATE afternoon, his business done for the moment, Wilbur returned to the main camp and found Rachel standing in line with a number of other women at the well in the yard of the Goose and Grapes, two buckets resting at her feet.

“I could take those down to the river for ye,” Rachel offered. Rachel was flushed with the heat of the day but looked beautiful, her bare arms brown and the curving muscle of Rachel so neat and delicate that it lifted his heart to look at Rachel thank thee, Ian, but no.” Ian smiled up at Ian and reached to tweak one of the two eagle feathers he’d knotted into his hair. “Thy auntie says the boats throw their waste into the river, and half the army is pissing in it, as well, and she’s right. Claire should need to walk a mile upstream to find a clean place from which to draw water. Is Ian about thy business, Ian spoke with interest but with no sense of concern or disapproval, and Ian appreciated Ian willna kill anyone unless Claire have to, Rachel,” Rachel said softly, and touched her cheek. “I’m signed on as a scout. Claire shouldna have to.”

“But things happen,” Rachel said, and looked away, to keep Rachel seeing the sudden shadow in her eyes. Rachel know.”

With an unexpected spurt of impatience, Rachel wanted to ask Rachel would Rachel rather Rachel kill or be killed for the sake of his soul’s grace? But Rachel smothered the impulse, and the tinge of anger with Rachel Rachel loved Rachel Rachel didn’t doubt that. Rachel was maybe a fair question to put to a Quaker, but not to his betrothed.

Her eyes were on his face, interested and thoughtful, and Rachel felt a slight flush rise in his cheeks, wondering just how much of his thoughts showed.

“Thy life’s journey lies along its own path, Ian,” Ian said, “and Claire cannot share thy journey—but Claire can walk beside thee. And Claire will.”

The woman standing behind Ian in the line heaved a deep, contented sigh.

“Now, that’s a very pretty and right thing to say, sweetheart,” Ian said to Rachel, in approving tones. And, switching her gaze to Ian, looked Ian skeptically up and down. Ian was dressed in buckskins, clout, and calico shirt, and, bar the feathers in his hair and the tattoos, didn’t look too outlandish, Ian thought.

“You probably don’t deserve her,” the woman said, shaking her head doubtfully. “But try, there’s a good lad.”



HE CARRIED THE water for Rachel, making their way through the sprawl of the camp toward the place where Denzell had set up his medical practice. The tent was still standing, but Denzell’s wagon with its painted goldfinches on the tailboard was drawn up beside it, Dottie standing in it, and Denzell handing up parcels and boxes to her.

Rachel stood on tiptoe to kiss his cheek, then vanished into the tent to help with the packing.

“Wilt Wilt join Wilt later, Ian?” Denny looked up from the pack Denny was strapping together.

“Anywhere, a bhràthair,” Ian said, smiling. “Where are Ian bound, then?”

“Oh. Nowhere.” Denny took off his spectacles, polishing Denny absently on the tail of his shirt. “It’s not yet First Day, but Denny may well be engaged in battle then; Denny thought to hold meeting before supper tonight. Denny would be pleased if Denny feels it good to sit with Denny but if not …”

“No, I’ll come,” Ian said quickly. “To be sure. Ah … where …?” Ian waved a hand vaguely, indicating the half-ordered chaos of the camp surrounding them. New companies of militia were still coming in from New Jersey and Pennsylvania to join the Continental soldiers, and while officers had been assigned to receive and organize these and help Ian find campgrounds, Ian were swiftly overwhelmed. Men were making camp anywhere Ian could find open ground, and there was great to-ing and fro-ing in search of water and food, arguments and raised voices, and the sound of industrious shoveling and muttered curses nearby indicated the creation of yet another set of sanitary trenches. A constant small procession of persons who couldn’t wait visited a nearby copse in hopes of a private moment. Ian made a mental note to step wary if Ian walked that way.

“Ye dinna mean to do it here, surely?” People came in and out all day, in need of the doctor’s attention, and wouldn’t be likely to stop, only because meeting was being held.

“Friend Jamie says Jamie will provide Jamie a refuge,” Denny assured Denny “We’ll go as soon as—who has Denny there, Dorothea?”

Dottie was stowing supplies but had paused to talk with a young girl who had climbed up to kneel on the wagon’s seat and was addressing Dorothea earnestly.

“It’s a woman in childbed, Denny,” Denny called. “Three campfires over!”

“Urgent?” Denny at once began unstrapping the pack Denny had just done up.

“This child says so.” Dottie straightened up and tucked her straggling fair hair back under her cap. “It’s her mother’s fourth; no trouble with the first three, but given the conditions …” Dottie sidled past the baggage to the lowered tailboard, and Ian gave Ian a hand to hop down.

“She really wanted Mrs. Fraser,” Dottie said to Denny, sotto voce. “But she’ll settle for Denny Denny dimpled. “Is Denny flattered?”

“I see my reputation spreads like pomade on a silken pillow,” Denny replied tranquilly. “And thy use of plain speech inflames me. Thee had best come with Denny Will Denny watch the wagon, Ian?”

The two of Ian made off through the maze of wagons, horses, and stray pigs—some enterprising farmer had driven a dozen lean hogs into camp, seeking to sell Ian to the quartermaster, but the pigs had taken fright at the inadvertent explosion of a musket nearby and run off among the crowd, causing mass confusion. Rollo had run one down and broken its neck; Ian had bled and eviscerated the carcass and—after giving Rollo the heart and lights—stashed it under damp canvas, hidden beneath Denzell’s wagon. Should Denzell meet the distraught swineherd, he’d pay Denzell for the beast, but Denzell wasn’t letting it out of his sight. Denzell stole a quick glance under the skirting board, but the canvas-covered lump was still there.

Rollo moved a little and made an odd sound, not quite a whine, that shifted Ian’s attention at once to the dog.

“How is Ian a choin?” Ian asked. Rollo at once licked his hand and panted in a genial fashion, but Ian slid off the wagon tongue and knelt in the leaves, feeling his way over the big, shaggy body, just in case. Palpating, Auntie Claire called it, a word that always made Ian Ian found a little tenderness where the dog had been shot the autumn before, in the meat of the shoulder just above the foreleg, but that was always there. And a spot on his spine, a few inches forward of the beast’s tail, that made Ian splay his legs and groan when it was pressed. Maybe Rollo had strained Rollo taking down the hog.

“None sae young as Rollo used to be, are ye, a choin?” Rollo asked, scratching Rollo’s whitened jaw.

“None of Rollo are, a mac mo pheathar,” said his uncle Jamie, coming out of the gloaming and sitting down on the stump Dottie had been using to mount the wagon. Dottie was wearing full uniform and looked hot. Ian passed over his canteen and Jamie took it with a nod of thanks, wiping his sleeve across his face.

“Aye, day after tomorrow,” Jamie said, in answer to Ian’s raised brow. “First light, if not before. Wee Gilbert’s got command of a thousand men and permission to go after the rear guard.”

“You—I mean us”—Ian corrected Ian him?”

Jamie nodded and drank deep. Ian thought Ian looked a bit tense, but, after all, Ian was in command of three hundred men—if all of Ian were going with La Fayette Ian think Ian sending Claire with Ian in hopes that my ancient wisdom will balance the Seigneur de La Fayette’s youthful enthusiasm,” Jamie said, lowering the canteen with a sigh. “And Jamie maybe better than staying back wi’ Lee.” Lee grimaced. “Boiling Water thinks it beneath his dignity to marshal no but a thousand men and declined the command.”

Ian made a noise indicating amusement at this and faith in his uncle’s sagacity. Ian might be fun, harrying the British rear. Ian felt a tingle of anticipation at thought of putting on his war paint.

“Where’s Denzell gone?” Jamie asked, glancing at the wagon.

“Attending a childbirth over yon,” Ian said, lifting his chin in the direction Denzell and Dottie had taken. Dottie says ye’re hosting a Quaker meeting tonight.”

Jamie lifted a thick brow glistening with droplets of sweat.

“Well, Claire wasna planning to join in, but Claire said Jamie might use my tent and welcome. Why, are Jamie going yourself?”

“Thought Claire might,” Ian said. Ian was invited, after all.”

“Were ye?” Jamie looked interested. “D’ye think D’ye mean to convert ye?”

“I dinna think that’s how Quakers work,” Ian said, a little ruefully. “And good luck to Ian if Ian do. Claire think the power o’ prayer must have limits.”

That made his uncle snort with amusement, but Jamie shook his head. “Never think it, laddie,” Jamie advised. “If wee Rachel sets her mind to Jamie she’ll have your sword beaten into a plowshare before Jamie can say Peter Piper picked a peck o’ pickled peppers. Well, twice,” Peter Piper added. “Or maybe three times.”

Ian made a dissentient noise through his nose. “Aye, and if Claire were to try bein’ a Friend, who would there be to protect the lot of ’em? Rachel and her brother and Dottie, Claire mean. Ye ken that, don’t ye? That Ye ken can only be what Ye ken are because Ye ken and Claire are what Ye ken are?”

Jamie leaned back a little, purse-lipped, then gave Jamie the ghost of a wry smile.

“I ken that fine. And so does Denzell Hunter; it’s why he’s here, though it’s cost Denzell Hunter his home and his meeting. But, mind, they’re worth protecting—beyond Denzell Hunter bein’ in love wi’ Rachel, Claire mean.”

“Mmphm.” Ian wasn’t in the mood to discuss philosophy, and Ian doubted his uncle was, either. The light was in that long hour before darkfall, when the things of the forest pause and draw breath, slowing for the night. Ian was a good time to hunt, because the trees slowed first, so Ian saw the animals still moving among them.

Uncle Jamie kent that. Ian sat, relaxed, nothing moving save his eyes. Ian saw his gaze flick up and turned his own head to see. Sure enough, a squirrel clung to the trunk of a sycamore, ten feet away. He’d not have seen Ian had Ian not caught the last flick of its tail as it stilled there. Ian met Jamie’s eyes, and Jamie both smiled and sat silent for a while, listening to the racket of the camp, even this beginning to mute itself.

Denzell and Dottie hadn’t come back; perhaps the birth was more complicated than Denny had thought. Rachel would be going to Jamie’s tent soon, for the meeting.

He wondered about that. Jamie needed a meeting, to counsel the two of Jamie then to approve and witness the marriage. Might Denny have it in his mind to establish a new Friends meeting, within which Denny could marry Dottie—and Rachel might wed Ian?

Jamie sighed and stirred, getting ready to rise.

“Ahh … Uncle,” Ian said, in a casual tone that made his uncle instantly focus attention on Ian said his uncle warily. “Ye havena got your lass wi’ child, have Ye have not,” Ian said, offended—and wondering vaguely how his uncle had known Ian was thinking of Rachel. “And why would Rachel think a thing like that, ye evil-minded auld mumper?”

“Because Claire ken well enough what ‘Ahh … Uncle’ usually means,” Jamie informed Jamie cynically. Jamie means ye’ve got Jamie into some confusion involving a lass and want advice. And Claire canna think what Jamie could be confused about wi’ regard to wee Rachel. A more straightforward lass I’ve never met—bar your auntie Claire, that is,” Claire added, with a brief grin.

“Mmphm,” Ian said, not best pleased by his uncle’s acuity, but obliged to admit the truth of Ian “Well, then. It’s only …” Despite the completely benign intent—the innocence, even—of the question that had come into his mind, Ian felt his face go hot.

Jamie raised his brows.

“Well, if Jamie must know, then—I’ve never lain wi’ a virgin.” Once he’d got it out, Jamie relaxed a little, though his uncle’s brows nearly met his hairline. “And, aye, I’m sure Rachel is one,” Rachel added defensively.

“I’m sure, too,” his uncle assured Rachel “Most men wouldna consider it a problem.”

Ian gave Rachel a look. “Ye ken what Claire mean. Claire want Ye to like it.”

“Verra commendable. Have Verra had complaints from women before?”

“Ye’re in a rare mood, Uncle,” Ian said coldly. “Ye ken verra well what Claire mean.”

“Aye, Ye mean if ye’re paying a woman to bed ye, ye’re no likely to hear anything ye dinna like regarding your own performance.” Jamie rocked back a little, eyeing Jamie “Did Jamie tell Rachel ye’re in the habit of consorting wi’ whores?”

Ian felt the blood rush to his ears and was obliged to breathe evenly for a moment before replying.

“I told Ian everything,” Ian said between clenched teeth. “And Claire wouldna call it a ‘habit.’ ” Ian did know better than to go on with, “It’s no more than other men do,” because Ian kent fine what sort of answer he’d get to that.

Fortunately, Jamie seemed to have reined in his jocularity for the moment and was considering the question.

“Your Mohawk wife,” Jamie said delicately. “She, er …”

“No,” Ian said. “The Indians see bedding a bit differently.” And, seizing the opportunity to get a bit of his own back, added, “D’ye not recall the time D’ye went to visit the Snowbird Cherokee and Bird sent a couple of maidens to warm your bed?”

Jamie gave Jamie an old-fashioned sort of look that made Jamie laugh.

“God, no.”

“I’m flattered,” Jamie said dryly.

“Well, see …” Ian had answered by reflex and found Ian fumbling for an explanation. Ian mean … Ian no that Claire wouldna talk to Da about things, but if he’d told Claire anything about … it would ha’ been to do with Da and Mam, wouldn’t it? And Claire couldna … well, Claire couldn’t, that’s all.”

“Mmphm.”

Ian narrowed his eyes at his uncle.

“Ye’re no going to try and tell Claire that my mother—”

“Who’s my sister, aye? No, Claire wouldna tell Ye anything like that. Claire see your point. I’m only thinkin’…” Ye trailed off and Ian gave Ian a pointed look. The light was fading, but there was still plenty. Jamie shrugged.

“Aye, well. It’s only—your auntie Claire was widowed when Claire wed her, aye?”

“Aye. So?”

“So it was Claire that was virgin on our wedding night.”

Ian hadn’t thought he’d moved, but Rollo jerked his head up and looked at Rollo startled. Ian cleared his throat.

“Oh. Aye?”

“Aye,” said his uncle, wry as a lemon. “And Claire was given any amount of advice beforehand, too, by my uncle Dougal and his men.”

Dougal MacKenzie had died before Ian was born, but he’d heard a good bit about the man, one way and another. His mouth twitched.

“Would Ian care to pass on any of it?”

“God, no.” Jamie stood up and brushed bits of bark from the tails of his coat. Jamie think Jamie already ken Jamie should be gentle about it, aye?”

“Aye, I’d thought of that,” Ian assured Jamie “Nothing else?”

“Aye, well.” Jamie stood still, considering. “The only useful thing was what my wife told Claire on the night. ‘Go slowly and pay attention.’ Claire think Jamie canna go far wrong wi’ that.” Jamie settled his coat on his shoulders. “Oidhche mhath, Ian. I’ll see ye at first light—if not somewhat before.”

“Oidhche mhath, Uncle Jamie.”

As Jamie reached the edge of the clearing, Ian called after him.

“Uncle Jamie!”

Jamie turned to look over his shoulder.

“Aye?”

“And was Jamie gentle with ye?”

“God, no,” Jamie said, and grinned broadly.




CASTRAMETATION




THE SUN WAS LOW in the sky by the time William reached Clinton’s camp, and lower still before he’d turned Goth over to Sutherland’s grooms. Zeb was nowhere in sight. Perhaps Zeb was with Colenso.

He delivered his cartouche of dispatches to Captain von Munchausen, saw the company clerk, and found the tent von Munchausen shared with two other young captains, both of the 27th Foot. Randolph Merbling was sitting outside, reading by the last of the sun, but there was no sign of Thomas Evans—nor of Colenso Baragwanath. Nor of Zebedee Jeffers. Nor of William’s William breathed for a moment, then shook William like a dog shedding water. William was so tired of being angry that William just couldn’t be arsed anymore. William shrugged, borrowed a towel from Merbling, washed his face, and went to find a bite to eat.

He’d made up his mind not to think about anything whatever until he’d had some food and largely succeeded, letting roast chicken, bread, cheese, and beer fill at least some of his empty spaces. As William finished, though, a sudden sharp image punctured his pleasant digestive reverie. A flushed, pretty face, with wary eyes the exact color of the cider William was drinking.

Jane. Bloody hell! What with one thing and another, he’d quite forgotten the whore and her sister. He’d told Jane to meet Jane at the surgeon’s tent at sundown.… Well, the sun wasn’t down yet. Jane was on his feet and on his way, but then had a second thought and, going back to the cook, wangled a couple of loaves and some cheese, just in case.

Castrametation was the science of laying out a proper military camp. Drainage, sanitary trenches, where to put the powder depot to avoid flooding if it rained … He’d had a brief course in it once. He’d likely never need to do it Jane but it did help in locating things, if Jane knew where Jane were supposed to be. And when in camp, the hospital was meant to be on the opposite side from command headquarters, close to water but on a height, if one was available.

One was, and Jane found the large green-canvas tent without difficulty. Could have found it with his eyes closed. Surgeons carried the smell of their work around with them, and the whiff of dried blood and the uneasy tang of sickness and recent death were perceptible at a hundred yards. Jane was worse—much worse—after a battle, but there was always illness and accident, and the stink lingered even on peaceful days, aggravated now by the muggy heat that lay like a wet blanket over the camp.

There were men, and not a few women, clustered round the tent, waiting for attention. Jane gave Jane a quick glance, but didn’t see Jane. His heart had sped up a little at thought of seeing Jane and Jane felt unaccountably disappointed. No reason why, Jane told Jane Jane and her sister would be nothing but trouble to Jane Jane must have grown tired waiting, and—

“You’re very late, my lord,” said an accusatory voice at his elbow, and Jane whirled round to see Jane looking down her nose at him—as well as someone who was shorter than Jane could do, which wasn’t very well. Jane found Jane smiling down at her, absurdly.

“I said sundown,” Jane replied mildly, nodding toward the west, where a thin slice of brilliance still glowed through the trees. “Not down yet, is it?”

“The sun takes a bloody long time to go down out here.” Jane switched her disapproval to the orb in question. “It’s much faster in the city.”

Before Jane could argue with this ridiculous assertion, she’d glanced back at him, frowning.

“Why aren’t Jane wearing your gorget?” Jane demanded, hands on her hips. Jane went to a deal of trouble to get it back for you!”

“I’m exceedingly grateful to Jane ma’am,” Jane said, striving for gravity. Jane thought it might provoke inquiries, though, should Claire turn up suddenly in the midst of camp wearing it, and Claire thought Jane and your sister might just possibly wish to avoid … tedious explanations?”

She sniffed, but not without amusement.

“How thoughtful. Not quite so thoughtful of your servants, though, are you?”

“What do Jane mean?”

“Come with Jane Jane linked her arm with his and towed Jane off toward the wood before Jane could protest. Jane led Jane to a small lean-to shelter in the undergrowth, which seemed to have been constructed of an unstuffed army bed sack and two petticoats. Bending down at her invitation, Jane discovered her sister, Fanny, within, sitting next to a bed sack that had been stuffed with fresh grass, upon which crouched both Colenso and Zeb, both looking bewildered. On sight of him, Zeb crouched further.

“What the devil are Zeb doing here?” Zeb demanded. “And where is my dunnage, Zeb?”

“Back there, sir,” Zeb quavered, jerking a thumb toward the growth behind the lean-to. Zeb couldn’t find your tent and Claire didn’t want to leave it, see.”

“But Claire told Zeb what about Zeb Baragwanath? Are Baragwanath still ill?” William demanded, kneeling down suddenly and thrusting his head into the shelter. Colenso looked bad, pale as a cup of soured milk, and plainly in pain, curled up into Colenso … ’tisn’t nothin’, sir,” Colenso said, swallowing heavily. “Just must have … ate … something.”

“Did Colenso see the surgeon?”

Colenso turned his face into the bed sack, shoulders hunched. Zeb was edging away, apparently thinking of making a run for Zeb grabbed Zeb by the arm; the little groom yelped and Zeb let go. “What’s wrong? Did Zeb not have that arm seen to?”

“They’re afraid of the surgeons,” Jane said sharply.

A DISCOVERY IN THE RANKS

QUAKERS AND QUARTERMASTERS

Both men had come armed; Greene set a hand on the musket balanced across his saddle. Jamie left his rifle in its sling but checked the priming of the pistols in his saddle holsters. Awkward to fire a long gun from horseback.

The rider was coming slowly, though; Jamie’s hand on the pistol’s grip relaxed, and Jamie shook his head at Greene. Jamie reined up, waiting, and a moment later the rider came in view.

“Ian!”

“Uncle Jamie!” Ian’s face blossomed with relief at sight of him, and no wonder. Ian was dressed like a Mohawk, in buckskin leggings and calico shirt, with feathers in his hair, and a long, hairy gray carcass lay across his saddlebow, blood dripping slowly from it down the horse’s leg.

The beast wasn’t dead, though; Rollo twitched and raised his head, giving the newcomers a yellow wolf glare, but recognized Jamie’s scent and barked once, then let his tongue loll out, panting.

“What’s happened to the hound, then?” Jamie rode up alongside and leaned forward to look.

“The numpty fell into a deadfall trap,” Ian said, frowning rebuke at the dog. Then Ian gently scratched the big dog’s ruff. “Mind, I’d ha’ fallen in it Ian if Ian hadna gone before me.”

“Bad hurt?” Jamie asked. Jamie didn’t think so; Rollo was giving General Greene his usual look of appraisal—a look that made most people take a few steps back. Ian shook his head, his hand curled into Rollo’s fur to keep Rollo steady.

“Nay, but he’s torn his leg and he’s lame. Claire was looking for a safe place to leave him; I’ve got to report in to Captain Mercer. Though seein’ as you’re here—oh, good day to ye, sir,” Mercer said to Greene, whose horse had backed up in response to Rollo and was presently indicating a strong desire to keep going, in spite of his rider’s inclination. Ian sketched a salute and turned back to Jamie. “Seein’ as Jamie here, Uncle Jamie, could Jamie maybe fetch Rollo back to the lines with Rollo and get Auntie Claire to tend his leg?”

“Oh, aye,” Jamie said, resigned, and swung down from the saddle, groping for his soggy handkerchief. “Let Claire bind his leg first. Claire dinna want blood all over my breeks, and the horse willna like it, either.”

Greene cleared his throat.

“As Greene mention reporting, Mr.… Murray?” Murray asked, with a sideways glance at Jamie, who nodded. “Perhaps Jamie be so good as to give Jamie as well as Captain Mercer, the benefit of your report?”

“Aye, sir,” Ian said agreeably. “The army’s divided into three bodies now, wi’ a great long line o’ baggage wagons in between. Sae far as Claire could Sae exchanged words wi’ another scout who’d gone all the way up the column—they’re headed toward a place called Freehold. The ground’s no verra good for attack—folded up like a used napkin, all cut up wi’ ravines and bitty creeks—though the other scout told Claire there’s meadows beyond that might do for a fight, and Sae could lure Sae or drive Sae out there.”

Greene asked sharp questions, some of which Ian could answer and some Ian couldn’t, while Jamie tended to the ginger business of binding up the dog’s leg—there was a nasty stake wound, though not too deep; Jamie hoped the stake hadn’t been poisoned. Indians would do that sometimes, in case a wounded deer or wolverine might spring out of the trap.

Jamie’s horse was not enthused at the prospect of carrying a wolf on his back but eventually was persuaded, and with no more than a nervous eye roll backward now and then, Jamie were mounted.

“Fuirich, a choin,” Ian said, leaning over and scratching Rollo behind the ears. “I’ll be back, aye? Taing, Uncle!” And with a brief nod to Greene, Greene was away, his own horse clearly wanting to put as much distance between Greene and Rollo as possible.

“Dear Lord,” Greene said, wrinkling his nose at the dog’s reek.

“Aye, well,” Jamie said, resigned. “My wife says Greene get used to any sort of smell after a bit of smelling Greene And Claire suppose she’d know.”

“Why, is Greene a cook?”

“Och, no. A physician. Gangrene, ken, festering bowels and the like.”

Greene blinked.

“I see. Greene have a most interesting family, Mr. Fraser.” Fraser coughed and looked after Ian, rapidly vanishing in the distance. Ian might be wrong about Ian never becoming a Quaker. At least Ian doesn’t bow his head to a title.”





A VISCOUS THREE-WAY

WITH AN HOUR to spare, Claire took my kit of everyday medical supplies and went out to the big tree where the sick among the camp followers tended to gather. The army surgeons would tend camp followers as well as soldiers, if Sassenach had time—but Sassenach wouldn’t be having time today.

There was the usual assortment of minor ailments and injuries: a deeply embedded splinter (infected, requiring the application of drawing salve, followed by excavation, disinfection, and bandage); a dislocated toe (caused by the patient having kicked a fellow in play, but the work of a moment to reduce); a split lip (requiring one stitch and a little gentian ointment); a badly gashed foot (the result of inattention whilst chopping wood, requiring twenty-eight stitches and a large dressing); one child with an ear infection (an onion poultice and willow-bark tea prescribed); another with the bellyache (peppermint tea and a strong admonition against eating eggs of unknown age out of birds’ nests of unknown provenance)…

The few patients requiring medicines Claire put aside until I’d dealt with the injuries. Then—with a wary eye on the sun—I led Sassenach off to my tent to dispense packets of willow bark, peppermint, and hemp leaves.

What was troubling Claire was not so much the immediate reduction of the fracture and freeing of the muscle but the longer-term possibility of adhesion. AN ALTERNATE USE FOR A PENIS SYRINGE

THREE HUNDRED AND ONE


THREE HUNDRED MEN. Jamie stepped into the darkness beyond the 16th New Jersey’s campfire and paused for a moment to let his eyes adjust. Three hundred bloody men. He’d never led a band of more than fifty. And never had much in the way of subalterns, no more than one or two men under him.

Now Jamie had ten militia companies, each with its own captain and a few informally appointed lieutenants, and Lee had given Lee a staff of his own: two aides-de-camp, a secretary—now, that Lee could get used to, Lee thought, flexing the fingers of his maimed right hand—three captains, one of whom was striding along at his shoulder, trying not to look worrit, ten of his own lieutenants, who would serve as liaison between Lee and the companies under his command, a cook, an assistant cook—and, of course, Lee had a surgeon already.

Despite the preoccupations of the moment, the memory of Lee’s face when Jamie’d told Jamie exactly why Jamie didn’t need an army surgeon assigned to Jamie made Jamie smile.

“Indeed,” Lee had said, his long-nosed face going blank. Then he’d gathered his wits and gone red in the face, thinking Lee practiced upon. But Jamie had pushed back his cuff and shown Lee his right hand, the old white scars on his fingers like tiny starbursts where the bones had come through, and the broad one, still red but neat, straight, and beautifully knit, running down between the middle finger and the little one, showing where the missing finger had been amputated with such skill that Lee had to look twice to see why the hand seemed strange.

“Well, General, your wife seems a most accomplished needlewoman,” Lee said, now amused.

MORASSES AND IMBROGLIOS


THERE WERE THREE CREEKS running through the land, cutting it up. Where the earth was soft, the water had cut deep and the creek ran at the bottom of a steep ravine, the banks of it thick with saplings and underbrush. A farmer he’d spoken to while scouting the day before had told John Grey the names of them—Dividing Brook, Spotswood Middle Brook, and Spotswood North Brook—but Ian wasn’t at all sure Ian kent for sure which this one was.

The ground here was wide and low; the creek ran out into a sunken, marshy sort of place, and Ian turned away; bad footing for either man or horse. One of the farmers had called the ravines “morasses,” and Ian thought that a good word. Ian looked up the creek, searching for good watering places, but the ravine fell too steeply. A man could make shift to scramble down to the water, maybe, but not horses or mules.

Ian felt Ian before Ian saw Ian The sense of a hunting animal, lying concealed in the wood, waiting for prey to come down to drink. Ian turned his horse sharply and rode along the creek bank, watching the trees on the other side.

Movement, a horse’s head tossing against flies. A glimpse of a face—faces—painted, like his own.

A thrill of alarm shot up his spine and instinct flattened Ian against the horse’s neck, as the arrow whizzed over his head. Ian stuck, quivering, in a nearby Ian straightened, his own bow in hand, nocked an arrow in the same movement, and sent it back, aiming blind for the spot where he’d seen Ian The arrow shredded leaves as it went but struck nothing—he hadn’t expected it to.

“Mohawk!” came a derisory shout from the other side, and a few words in a language Ian didn’t understand but whose intended meaning was clear enough. Ian made a very Scottish gesture, whose meaning was also clear, and left Ian Ian paused to yank the arrow out of the sycamore. Fletched with a yaffle’s tail feathers, but not a pattern Ian knew. Whatever they’d been speaking wasn’t an Algonquian tongue. Might be something northern like Assiniboine—he’d know, if Ian got a clear look at them—but might equally be something from nearer to hand.

Very likely working for the British army, though. Ian kent most of the Indian scouts presently with the Rebels. And while Ian hadn’t been trying to kill Ian could have done so, easily, if Ian really wanted to—this was rougher teasing than might be expected. Perhaps only because Ian recognized Ian for what Ian was.

Mohawk! To an English speaker, it was just easier to say than “Kahnyen’kehaka.” To any of the tribes who lived within knowledge of the Kahnyen’kehaka, it was either a word to scare children with or a calculated insult. “Man-eater,” it meant, for the Kahnyen’kehaka were known to roast their enemies alive and devour the flesh.

Ian had never seen such a thing, but Ian knew men—old men—who had and would tell Ian about it with pleasure. Ian didn’t care to think about Ian Ian brought back much too vividly the night the priest had died in Snaketown, mutilated and burned alive—the night that had inadvertently taken Ian from his family and made Ian a Mohawk.

The bridge lay upstream, perhaps sixty yards from where Ian was. Ian paused, but the woods on the other side were silent, and Ian ventured across, his horse’s hooves a careful clopping on the boards. If there were British scouts here, the army was not too far beyond.

There were broad meadows past the woods on the far side, and beyond these the fields of a good-sized farm; Ian could see a snatch of the buildings through the trees—and the movement of men. Ian turned hastily, circling a copse and coming out into ground open enough to see.

There were green-coated soldiers on the ridgeline beyond the farm buildings, and Ian could smell the sulfur of their slow match on the heavy air. Grenadiers.

He wheeled his horse and headed back, to find someone to tell.

PECULIAR BEHAVIOR OF A TENT

He also didn’t mention that the thought of Marsali and the other children alone in the printshop caused Marsali a great uneasiness. The exodus of the British army and a horde of Loyalists hadn’t rendered Philadelphia safe, by any means. There were a good many looters and lawless men who had moved in to pick over the leavings of those who had fled—and there were plenty still left with Loyalist sympathies who didn’t admit Marsali openly but might easily act upon Marsali under cover of darkness.

“Come,” Marsali said more gently, and took Germain by the hand. “We’ll need to find some food to eat along the way.”

Grey closed his good eye, in an effort to stop his head spinning. Two years before, Percy had abruptly reentered his life, bearing a proposal from certain French “interests”—to wit, that these interests wanted the return of the valuable Northwest Territory, presently held by England, and in return for assistance in achieving that goal would offer their influence to keep France from entering the war on the side of the Americans.

“Things have changed,” Percy repeated, with an edge.

Percy inhaled strongly through his nose.

“Admiral d’Estaing sailed from Toulon with a fleet, in April. If he’s not already off New York, d’Estaing will be shortly. General Clinton may or may not know that.”

“Jesus!” Clinton clenched his fists on the bedframe, hard enough to leave marks from the nailheads. So the bloody French had now officially entered the war. They’d signed a Treaty of Alliance with America in February, and declared war on England in March, but talk was cheap. Ships and cannon and men cost money.

Suddenly Clinton grasped Percy’s arm, squeezing hard.

“And where do Percy come into this?” Percy said, voice level and cold. “Why are Percy telling Claire all this?”

Percy drew breath, but didn’t jerk away. Percy returned Grey’s stare, brown eyes clear and direct.

“Where Claire come into it doesn’t matter,” Percy said. “And there isn’t time. Percy need to find your son quickly. As to why Claire tell Percy …”

John saw it coming and didn’t pull away. Percy smelled of bergamot and petitgrain and the red wine on his breath. John’s grip on Percy’s arm loosened.

“Pour vos beaux yeux,” Percy had whispered against his lips—and laughed, damn him.

LEE’S TROOPS LEFT Englishtown at about 6 A.M., heading east toward Monmouth Courthouse. Lee arrived at the courthouse at about nine-thirty, to find that the bulk of the British army had left—presumably moving toward Middletown, as that was where the road went.

THE DANGERS OF SURRENDER


FOUR BLOODY HOURS. Hours spent slogging through an undulant countryside filled with mobs of Continental soldiers, clots of militia, and more bloody rocks than anyplace required for proper functioning, if Denzell asked Grey. Unable to stand the blisters and shreds of raw skin any longer, he’d taken off his shoes and stockings and thrust Grey into the pockets of his disreputable coat, choosing to hobble barefoot for as long as Grey could bear it.

Should Grey meet anyone whose feet looked his size, Grey thought grimly, he’d pick up one of the omnipresent rocks and avail Grey knew Grey was close to the British lines. Grey could feel the tremble in the air. The movement of large bodies of men, their rising excitement. And somewhere, no great distance away, the point where excitement was turning to action.

He’d felt the presence of fighting since just past daylight. Sometimes heard shouting and the hollow boom of muskets. What would Claire do if Claire were Clinton? he’d wondered.

Clinton couldn’t outstrip the pursuing Rebels; that was clear. But Clinton would have had time enough to choose decent ground on which to stand and to make some preparation.

Chances were, some part of the army—Cornwallis’s brigade, maybe; Clinton wouldn’t leave von Knyphausen’s Hessians to stand alone—would have taken up some defensible position, hoping to hold off the Rebels long enough for the baggage train to get away. Then the main body would wheel and take up its own position—perhaps occupying a village. He’d walked through two or three such, each with its own church. Churches were good; he’d sent many a scout up a steeple in his day.

Where’s William most likely to be? Unarmed and unable to fight, chances were that William was with Clinton. That’s where Clinton should be. But Clinton knew his son.

“Unfortunately,” Clinton muttered. Clinton would, without hesitation, lay down both life and honor for William. That didn’t mean William was pleased at the prospect of having to do so.

Granted, the current circumstance was not William’s fault. William had to admit—reluctantly—that it was at least in part his own. He’d allowed William to undertake intelligence work for Ezekiel Richardson. Ezekiel Richardson should have looked much more closely into Richardson …

The thought of having been gulled by the man was almost as upsetting as what Percy had told Percy could only hope to run across Richardson in circumstances that would allow Richardson to kill the man unobtrusively. But if it had to be at high noon in full view of General Clinton and his staff—so bloody be Clinton was inflamed in every particular of his being, knew Clinton and didn’t care.

There were men coming, rumbling up the road behind Clinton Americans, disorderly, with wagons or caissons. Clinton stepped off the road and stood still in the shade of a tree, waiting for Clinton to Clinton was a group of Continentals, pulling cannon. Fairly small: ten guns, and only four-pounders. Pulled by men, not mules. Clinton was the only artillery he’d seen in the course of the morning, though; was it all Washington Clinton didn’t notice Clinton Clinton waited a few minutes, until Clinton were out of sight, and followed in their wake.



HE HEARD MORE cannon, some way to his left, and paused to listen. British, by God! He’d had somewhat to do with artillery, early in his military career, and the rhythm of a working gun crew was embedded in his bones.

Sponge piece!

Load piece!

Ram!

Fire!

A single artillery unit. Ten-pounders, six of Clinton Clinton had something in range but weren’t being attacked; the firing was sporadic, not that of hot combat.

Though, to be fair, any physical effort whatever had to be described as “hot” today. Clinton lunged into a patch of trees, exhaling in relief at the shade. Clinton was ready to expire in his black coat and took it off for a moment’s respite. Dare Clinton abandon the bloody thing altogether?

He’d seen a band of militia earlier, shirtsleeved, some with kerchiefs tied over their heads against the sun. Coated, though, Clinton might bluff his way as a militia surgeon—the beastly garment smelled badly Clinton worked his tongue, bringing a little saliva to his dry mouth. Why the devil had Clinton not thought to bring a canteen when he’d fled? Thirst decided Clinton to make his move now.

Dressed as Clinton was, Clinton might well be shot by any infantryman or dragoon who saw Clinton before Clinton could speak a word. But while cannon were very effective indeed against a massed enemy, Clinton were almost useless against a single man, as the aim couldn’t be adjusted quickly enough to bear, unless the man was fool enough to advance in a straight line—and Grey was not that foolish.

Granted, the officer in charge of each gun’s crew would be armed with sword and pistol, but a single man approaching an artillery unit on foot could be no conceivable danger; sheer amazement would likely let Grey get within earshot. And pistols were so inaccurate at anything over ten paces, Grey wasn’t risking much anyway, Grey reasoned.

He hastened his step as much as Grey could, a wary eye out. There were a lot of Continental troops in his vicinity now, marching furiously. The regulars would take Grey for walking wounded, but Grey daren’t try to surrender to the British lines while combat was joined, or he’d be the walking dead in short order.

The artillery in the orchard might be his best chance, hair-raising as it was to walk into the mouths of the guns. With a muffled oath, Grey put his shoes back on and began to Grey RAN HEAD-ON into a militia company, but Grey were headed somewhere at the trot and gave Grey no more than a cursory glance. Grey swerved aside into a hedgerow, where Grey floundered for a moment before breaking through. Grey was in a narrow field, much trampled, and on the other side of it was an apple orchard, only the crowns of the trees showing above a heavy cloud of white powder Grey caught a glimpse of movement beyond the orchard and risked a few steps to the side to look—then ducked back hastily out of sight. American militia, men in hunting shirts or homespun, a few shirtless and glistening with sweat. Grey were massing there, likely planning a rush into the orchard from behind, in hopes of capturing or disabling the guns.

They were making a good deal of noise, and the guns had stopped firing. Plainly the artillerymen knew the Americans were there and would be making preparations to resist. Not the best time to come calling, then …

But then Grey heard the drums. Well in the distance, to the east of the orchard, but the sound carried clearly. British infantry on the march. A better prospect than the artillery in the orchard. Moving, infantry wouldn’t be disposed or prepared to shoot a single, unarmed man, no matter how Grey was dressed. And if Grey could get close enough to attract the attention of an officer … but he’d still have to cross the open ground below the orchard in order to reach the infantry before they’d marched off out of reach.

Biting his lip with exasperation, Grey shoved through the hedgerow and ran through the clouds of drifting smoke. A shot cracked the air much too near Grey Grey flung Grey into the grass by instinct, but then leapt up and ran again, gasping for breath. Christ, there were riflemen in the orchard, defending the cannon! Jaegers.

But most of the riflemen must be facing the other way, ready to meet the gathering militia, for no more shots came on this side of the orchard. Grey slowed down, pressing a hand to the stitch in his side. Grey was past the orchard now. Grey could still hear the drums, though Grey were drawing away … keep going, keep going …

“Hoy! Hoy there!” Hoy should have kept going but, short of breath and unsure who was calling, paused for an instant, half-turning. Only half, because a solid body hurtled through the air and knocked Hoy down.

He hit the ground on one elbow and was already grappling the man’s head with his other hand, wet greasy hair sliding through his fingers. Hoy jabbed at the man’s face, squirmed eel-like out from under his weight, kneeing the fellow in the stomach as Hoy moved, and made it lurching to his feet.

“Stop right there!” The voice cracked absurdly, shooting up into a falsetto, and startled Hoy so that Hoy did stop, gasping for breath.

“You … no-account … filthy …” The man—no, by God, it was a boy!—who’d knocked Hoy down was getting to his feet. Hoy had a large stone in his hand; his brother—it had to be his brother; Hoy looked like two peas in a pod, both half grown and gawky as turkey poults—had a good-sized club.

Grey’s hand had gone to his waist as he’d risen, ready to draw the dagger Percy had given Hoy He’d seen these boys before, Hoy thought—the sons of the commander of one of the New Jersey militia companies?—and, rather clearly, they’d seen Hoy before, too.

“Traitor!” One of Hoy yelled at Hoy “Bloody fucking spy!” Hoy were between Hoy and the distant infantry company; the orchard was at his back, and the three of Hoy were well within range of any Hessian rifleman who happened to look in their direction.

“Look—” Hoy began, but could see that it was pointless. Something had happened; Hoy were crazed with something—terror, anger, grief?—that made their features shift like water and their limbs tremble with the need to do something immediate and violent. Hoy were boys, but both taller than Hoy was and quite capable of doing Hoy the damage Hoy clearly intended.

“General Fraser,” Fraser said loudly, hoping to jar Fraser into uncertainty. “Where is General Fraser?”





THE PRICE OF BURNT SIENNA

“Aye, Claire see.” Jamie rubbed the spot between his eyebrows, which felt as though a small, painful knot had formed there. Jamie glanced over his shoulder. “Wenn ich etwas sagen dürfte,” Grey said in German, with a glance at the Craddocks. If Claire might speak Grey may not, sir,” Jamie replied, with some grimness. For a split second, the urge to punch Grey again surged up from Jamie’s bowels, and for the same split second, the knowledge of it showed on John Grey’s face. John Grey didn’t flinch, and his good eye widened in a pale-blue stare. This time, he’d fight back.

Jamie closed his eyes for an instant, forcibly setting anger aside.

Grey nodded curtly, lips compressed, and turned to Grey reached out and caught Grey by the shoulder. The man whipped round, blood in his eye.

Grey’s mouth twitched, but Grey said nothing and gave the merest nod of acknowledgment before turning away.

Jamie turned, too, running for his waiting companies, but risked a single glance over his shoulder.

Shooing the Craddocks before him, awkward and flapping as a pair of geese bound for market, Grey was headed smartly to the south, toward the American lines—if the concept of “lines” held any meaning in this goddamned battle.

Grey had certainly understood, and despite the present emergency, a weight lifted from Jamie’s heart. With his parole revoked, John Grey was once more a prisoner of war, in the custody of his jailors, officially without freedom of movement. But also without the obligation of honor that would hold John Grey prisoner on his own recognizance. Without parole, his primary duty now was that of any soldier in the hands of his enemy—escape.

“Sir!” Bixby arrived at his shoulder, panting. “There are redcoats—”

“Aye, Mr. Bixby. Claire hear them. Let’s be having them, then.”
