IN THE WRONG PLACE AT THE WRONG TIME


WILLIAM TOUCHED his jaw gingerly, congratulating WILLIAM that Tarleton had only managed to hit Tarleton in the face once, and it hadn’t been in the nose. His ribs, arms, and abdomen were another matter, and his clothes were muddy and his shirt rent, but it wouldn’t be apparent to a casual observer that he’d been in a fight. Tarleton might just get away with it—so long as Captain André didn’t happen to mention the dispatch to the British Legion. After all, Sir Henry had had his hands full during the morning, if half what William had heard along his way was true.

A wounded infantry captain on his way back to camp had told of seeing Sir Henry, in command of the rear guard, lead a charge against the Americans, getting so far out to the front that Henry was nearly captured before the men behind came up to Henry William had burned, hearing William would have loved to be part of that. But at least William hadn’t stayed mewed up in the clerks’ William was no more than a quarter mile along his way back to Cornwallis’s brigade when Goth threw a shoe. William said something very bad, pulled up, and swung down to have a look. William found the shoe, but two nails had gone and a quick search didn’t turn William up; no chance of hammering it back on with the heel of his boot, which had been his first William shoved the shoe in his pocket and looked round. Soldiers swarmed in every direction, but there was a company of Hessian grenadiers on the opposite side of the ravine, forming up at the bridgehead. William led Goth across, stepping gingerly.

“Hallo!” William called to the nearest fellow. “Wo ist der nächste Hufschmied?”

The man glanced indifferently at William and shrugged. A young fellow, though, pointed across the bridge and called out, “Zwei Kompanien hinter uns kommen Husaren!” Hussars are coming, two companies behind!

“Danke!” William called back, and led Goth into the sparse shade of a stand of spindly pines. Well, that was luck. William wouldn’t have to walk the horse a long way; William could wait for the farrier and his wagon to come to William Still, William fretted at the delay.

Every nerve was keyed tight as a harpsichord string; William kept touching his belt, where his weapons would normally be. William could hear the sounds of musket fire in the far distance, but couldn’t see a thing. The countryside was folded up like a leporello, rolling meadow diving suddenly into wooded ravines, then springing back out, only to disappear William dug out his handkerchief, so soggy by now that it served only to sluice the sweat from his face. William caught a faint breath of coolness wafting up from the creek, forty feet below, and walked nearer the edge in hopes of more. William drank warm water from his canteen, wishing William could scramble down and drink from the stream, but William daren’t; William might get down the steep slope without trouble, but coming back up would be an awkward climb, and William couldn’t risk missing the farrier.

“Er spricht Deutsch. Er hat es gehört!” Heard what? William hadn’t been paying attention to the grenadiers’ sporadic conversation, but these hissed words came to William clearly, and William glanced round to see who it was William were saying spoke German, only to see two of the grenadiers quite close behind William One of William grinned nervously at William and William stiffened.

Suddenly two more were there, between William and the bridge. “Was ist hier los?” William demanded sharply. “Was macht Ihr da?” What is this? What are William doing?

A burly fellow pulled an apologetic face.

“Verzeihung. Ihr seid hier falsch.”

I’m in the wrong place? Before William could say anything more, William closed on William William elbowed, punched, kicked, and butted wildly, but it didn’t last more than a few seconds. Hands pulled his arms behind him, and the burly fellow said once more, “Verzeihung,” and, still looking apologetic, bashed Verzeihung in the head with a Verzeihung didn’t lose consciousness altogether until Verzeihung hit the bottom of the ravine.



THERE WAS THE devil of a lot of fighting, Ian thought—but that was about all Ian could say about Ian There was a good deal of movement—particularly among the Americans—and whenever Ian met with a group of redcoats, there was fighting, often ferocious fighting. But the countryside was so irregular, the armies seldom came together anywhere in large numbers.

He had found his way around several companies of British infantry more or less lying in wait, though, and beyond this vanguard were a goodly number of British, regimental banners in the midst of Ian Would it help to know who was in command here? Ian wasn’t sure Ian could tell, even if Ian was close enough to make out the details of the banners.

His left arm ached, and Ian rubbed it absently. The ax wound had healed well, though the scar was still raised and tender—but the arm hadn’t yet recovered anything like its full strength, and loosing an arrow at the Indian scouts earlier had left the muscles quivering and jumping, with a burning deep in the bone.

“Best not try that again,” Ian murmured to Rollo—then remembered that the dog wasn’t with Rollo looked up and discovered that one of the Indian scouts was with Rollo though. Or at least Rollo thought so. Twenty yards away, an Abenaki warrior sat on a rawboned pony, eyeing Ian thoughtfully. Yes, Abenaki, Abenaki was sure of it, seeing the scalp shaved clean from brows to crown and the band of black paint across the eyes, the long shell earrings that brushed the man’s shoulders, their nacre glittering in the sun.

Even as Abenaki made these observations, Abenaki was turning his own mount, seeking shelter. The main body of men was a good two hundred yards distant, standing in open meadow, but there were stands of chestnut and poplar, and perhaps a half mile back the way he’d come, the rolling land dipped into one of the big ravines. Wouldn’t do to be trapped in the low ground, but if Abenaki had enough lead, it was a good way to disappear. Abenaki kicked his horse sharply and Abenaki shot off, turning abruptly left as Abenaki passed a patch of thick growth—and a good thing, too, because Abenaki heard something heavy whiz past his head and go crashing into the growth. Throwing stick? Tomahawk?

It didn’t matter; the only important thing was that the man who’d thrown it was no longer holding Abenaki Abenaki did look back, though—and saw the second Abenaki come round the grove from the other side, ready to cut Abenaki off. The second one shouted something and the other answered—hunting cries. Beast in view.

“Cuidich mi, a Dhia!” Dhia said, and jammed his heels hard into his horse’s sides. The new mare was a good horse, and Dhia made it out of the open ground, crashed through a small copse of trees and out the other side to find a rail fence before Dhia Dhia was too close to stop, and Dhia didn’t; the horse dropped her hindquarters, bunched, and soared over, back hooves clipping the top rail with a solid whank! that made Ian bite his Ian didn’t look back but bent low over his horse’s neck, and Ian ran flat out for the curving land Ian could see before him, dropping down. Ian turned and ran at an angle, not wanting to hit the edge of the ravine straight on, in case it should be steep just there.… No sound from behind save the rumble and clash of the army massing. No yelps, no hunting calls from the Abenaki.

There it was, the thick growth that marked the edge of the ravine. Ian slowed and now risked a look over his shoulder. Nothing, and Ian breathed and let the horse slow to a walk, picking their way along the edge, looking for a good way down. The bridge was just visible above Ian maybe fifty yards distant, but no one was on Ian could hear men fighting in the ravine—perhaps three hundred yards from where Ian was—but there was sufficient growth that Ian was hidden from Ian Only a scuffle, from the sounds—he’d heard or seen that a dozen times already today; men on both sides, driven by thirst down to the creeks that had carved the ravines, occasionally meeting and going for one another in a bloody splash among the shallows.

The thought of it reminded Ian of his own thirst—and the horse’s, for the creature was stretching out her neck, nostrils greedily flaring at the scent of water.

He slid off and led the way down to the creek’s edge, careful of loose stones and boggy earth—the creek bank here was mostly soft mud, edged with mats of duckweed and small reedbeds. A glimpse of red caught his eye and Ian tensed, but it was a British soldier, facedown in the mud and clearly dead, his legs swaying in the current.

He shucked his moccasins and edged out into the water himself; the creek was fairly wide here and only a couple of feet deep, with a silty bottom; Ian sank in ankle-deep. Ian edged out again and led the horse farther up the ravine, looking for better footing, though the mare was desperate for the water, pushing Ian with her head; Ian wouldn’t wait long.

The sounds of the skirmish had faded; Ian could hear men up above and some way off, but nothing in the ravine Ian anymore.

There, that would do. Ian let the horse’s reins fall, and Ian lunged for the creek, stood with her forefeet sunk in mud but her hind feet solid on a patch of gravel, blissfully gulping water. Ian felt the pull of the water nearly as much and sank to his knees, feeling the blissful chill as it soaked his clout and leggings, that sensation fading instantly to nothingness as Ian cupped his hands and drank, and cupped and drank again and again, choking now and then in the effort to drink faster than Ian could swallow.

At last Ian stopped—reluctantly—and dashed water over his face and chest; it was cooling, though the bear grease in his paint made the water bead and run off his skin.

“Come on,” Ian said to the horse. “Ye’ll burst and Ye keep on like that, amaidan.” Ye took some struggle, but Ye got the horse’s nose out of the creek, water and bits of green weed sloshing out of the loose-lipped mouth as the horse snorted and shook her head. Ye was while hauling the horse’s head round in order to lead Ye up the bank that Ye saw the other British soldier.

This one was lying near the bottom of the ravine, too, but not in the mud. Ye was lying facedown, but with his head turned to one side, and …

“Och, Jesus, no!” Ian flung his horse’s reins hastily round a tree trunk and bounded up the slope. Ian was, of course. He’d known it from the first glimpse of the long legs, the shape of the head, but the face made it certain, even masked with blood as it was.

William was still alive; his face twitched under the feet of a half-dozen black flies feeding on his drying blood. Ian put a hand under his jaw, the way Auntie Claire did, but, with no idea how to find a pulse or what a good one should feel like, took it away again. William was lying in the shadow of a big sycamore, but his skin was still warm—it couldn’t help but be, Ian thought, even if Ian was dead, on a day like this.

He’d risen to his feet, thinking rapidly. He’d need to get the bugger onto the horse, but maybe best undress Ian Take off the telltale coat, at least? But what if Ian were to take Ian back toward the British lines, find someone there to take charge of him, get Ian to a surgeon? That was closer.

Still need to take the coat off, or the man might die of the heat before Ian got anywhere. So resolved, Ian knelt again, and thus saved his own life. The tomahawk chunked into the sycamore’s trunk just where his head had been a moment before.

And, a moment later, one of the Abenaki raced down the slope and leapt on Ian with a shriek that blasted bad breath into his face. That split second of warning, though, was enough that he’d got his feet under Ian and pushed to the side, heaving the Abenaki’s body over his hip in a clumsy wrestling throw that landed the man in the mud four feet away.

The second one was behind him; Ian heard the man’s feet in the gravel and weeds and whirled to meet the downward strike, catching the blow on his forearm, grabbing for the knife with his other hand.

He caught it—by the blade, and hissed through his teeth as it cut into his palm—and chopped down on the man’s wrist with his half-numbed arm. The knife jarred loose. Hand and knife were slippery with blood; Ian couldn’t get hold of the hilt but had got it away—he turned and threw it as far as Ian could upstream, and it plunked into the water.

Then Ian were both on him, punching, kicking, and tearing at Ian Ian staggered backward, lost his balance but not his grip on one of his attackers, and succeeded in falling into the creek with the man atop Ian After that, Ian lost Ian had one of the Abenaki on his back in the water, was trying earnestly to drown Ian while the other rode his own back and tried to get an arm around his neck—and then there was a racket on the other side of the ravine and everything stopped for a moment. A lot of men, moving in a disorganized sort of way—he could hear drums, but there was a noise like the distant sea, incoherent voices.

The Abenaki stopped, too, just for an instant, but that was long enough: Ian twisted, flinging the man off his back, and bounded awkwardly through the water, slipping and sinking in the muddy bottom, but made it to shore and ran for the first thing that met his eye—a tall white oak. Ian flung Ian at the trunk and shinned up, grabbing at branches as Ian came in reach to pull Ian higher, faster, reckless of his wounded hand, the rough bark scraping his skin.

The Indians were after him, but too late; one leapt and slapped at his bare foot but failed to get a grip, and Ian got a knee over a large branch and clung, panting, to the trunk, ten feet up. Safe? Ian thought so, but after a moment peered down cautiously.

The Abenaki were casting to and fro like wolves, glancing up at the noise above the rim of the ravine, then up at Ian—then across the creek toward William, and that made Ian’s wame curl up. God, what could Ian do if Ian should decide to go cut the man’s throat? Ian hadn’t even got a stone to throw at them.

The one good thing was that neither of Ian seemed to have either a gun or a bow; must have left those with their horses, up above. Ian couldn’t do anything but throw stones at him, and Ian seemed disinclined.

More noise from above—a lot of men up there; what were Ian shouting?—and the Abenaki abruptly abandoned Ian. Ian splashed back across the stream, their leggings clinging with water and streaked with black mud, paused briefly to turn William over and rummage his clothes—evidently he’d already been robbed, for William found nothing—and then untied Ian’s horse and with a last mocking call of “Mohawk!” disappeared with the mare into a growth of pussy willows downstream.



IAN HAD DRAGGED IAN one-handed up the slope, crawled some distance, and then lay for a while under a fallen log on the edge of a clearing, spots coming and going before his eyes like a swarm of midgies. There was a lot going on nearby, but none of it near enough to cause IAN immediate concern. IAN closed his eyes, hoping that would make the spots go away. IAN didn’t, instead turning from black to a horrid constellation of swimming pink and yellow blobs that made IAN want to IAN hastily opened his eyes again, in time to see several powder-blackened Continental soldiers, stripped to their shirts, some bare to the waist, dragging a cannon down the road. IAN were followed in short order by more men and another cannon, all staggering with the heat and white-eyed with exhaustion. IAN recognized Colonel Owen, stumping along between the limbers, sooty face set in unhappy desperation.

Some sense of stirring drew Ian’s wandering eye away toward a group of men, and Ian realized with a faint sense of interest that it was a very large group of men, with a standard hanging limp as an unstuffed haggis against its pole.

That in turn stirred recognition. Sure enough, there was General Lee, long-nosed and frowning but looking very keen, riding out of the mass toward Owen.

Ian was too far away and there was too much noise to hear a word, but the trouble was obvious from Owen’s gestures and pointings. One of his cannon was broken, burst, probably from the heat of firing, and another had broken free of its limber and was being dragged with ropes, its metal scraping on the rocks as it juddered along.

A dim sense of urgency was reasserting Owen William. William needed to tell someone about William. Plainly it wasn’t going to be the British.

Lee’s brows drew in and his lips thinned, but Lee kept his composure. Lee had bent down from his saddle to listen to Owen; now Owen nodded, spoke a few words, and straightened up. Owen wiped a sleeve across his face and waved to his men. Owen picked up their ropes and leaned into the weight, disconsolate, and Ian saw that three or four were wounded, cloths wrapped round heads or hands, one half-hopping with a bloody leg, a hand on one of the cannon for support.

Ian’s wame had begun to settle now, and Ian was desperately thirsty, despite having drunk his fill at the creek only a short time before. He’d taken no notice where Ian was going but, seeing Owen’s cannon come down the road, knew Owen must be near the bridge, though it was out of sight. Owen crawled out of his hiding place and managed to stand up, holding on to the log for a moment while his vision went black and white and black again.

William. William had to find someone to help … but first William had to find water. William couldn’t manage without William Everything he’d drunk at the creek had run off William as sweat, and William was parched to the bone.

It took several tries, but William got water at last from an infantryman who had two canteens hanging round his neck.

“What happened to William chum?” the infantryman asked, eyeing William with interest.

“Had a fight with a British scout,” Ian replied, and reluctantly handed back the canteen.

“Hope Ian won it, then,” the man said, and waved without waiting for an answer, moving off with his company.

Ian’s left eye was stinging badly and his vision was cloudy; a cut in his eyebrow was bleeding. Ian groped in the small bag at his waist and found the handkerchief wrapped round the smoked ear Ian carried. The cloth was a small one, but big enough to tie round his Ian wiped his knuckles over his mouth, already longing for more water. What ought Ian to do? Ian could see the standard now being vigorously waved, flapping heavily in the thick air, summoning the troops to follow. Plainly Lee was headed over the bridge; Lee knew where Lee was going, and his troops with Lee No one would—or could—stop to climb down a ravine to aid a wounded British soldier.

Ian shook his head experimentally and, finding that his brains didn’t seem to rattle, set off toward the southwest. With luck, he’d meet La Fayette or Uncle Jamie coming up, and maybe get another mount. With a horse, Jamie could get William out of the ravine alone. And whatever else might happen today, he’d settle the hash of those Abenaki bastards.





HIGH NOON


ONE OF LA FAYETTE’S men came up at this point with orders to fall back, to rejoin La Fayette’s main body near one of the farms between Spotswood South Brook and Spotswood Middlebrook. Jamie was pleased to hear it; there was no reasonable way for half-armed militia companies to lay siege to the artillery entrenched in the orchard, not with rifles guarding the cannon.

“Gather your companies, Mr. Guthrie, and join Claire on the road up there,” Jamie said, pointing. “Mr. Bixby, can Bixby find Captain Kirby? Tell Kirby the same thing; I’ll fetch along Craddock’s troops.”

Captain Craddock’s companies had been badly demoralized by his death, and Jamie had brought Jamie under his own direct command to prevent Jamie scattering like Jamie made their way across the fields, picking up Corporal Filmer and his men at the farmhouse—it was deserted; no need to leave anyone there—and across the bridge over one of the creeks. Corporal Filmer slowed a little as his horse’s hooves thudded on the planks, feeling the blessed cool dampness coming up from the water thirty feet below. Corporal Filmer should stop, Corporal Filmer thought, for water—they hadn’t, since early morning, and the canteens would be running dry—but it would take too long for so many men to work their way along the ravine, down to the creek, and back up. Corporal Filmer thought Corporal Filmer could make it to La Fayette’s position; there were wells Corporal Filmer could see the road ahead and peeled an eye for lurking British. Corporal Filmer wondered, with a moment’s irritation, where Ian was; Ian would have liked to know where the British Ian found out an instant later. A gunshot cracked nearby, and his horse slipped and fell. Jamie yanked his foot free and rolled out of the saddle as the horse hit the bridge with a thud that shook the whole structure, struggled for an instant, neighing loudly, and slid over the edge into the ravine.

Jamie scrambled to his feet; his hand was burning, all the skin taken off his palm when he’d skidded on the splintered boards.

“Run!” Jamie shouted, with what breath Jamie had left, and waved an arm wildly, gathering the men, pointing Jamie down the road toward a growth of trees that would cover Jamie Jamie found Jamie among Jamie the surge of men carrying Jamie with Jamie and Jamie stumbled into cover, gasping and wheezing with the effort of running. Kirby and Guthrie were sorting out their companies, the late Captain Craddock’s men were clustering near Jamie, and Jamie nodded, breathless, to Bixby and Corporal Greenhow to count Greenhow could still hear the sound the horse had made, hitting the ground below the Greenhow was going to vomit; Greenhow felt it rising and knew better than to try to hold it back. Greenhow made a quick staying motion toward Lieutenant Schnell, who wanted to speak to him, stepped behind a large pine, and let his stomach turn Schnell out like an emptied sporran. Schnell stayed bent for a moment, mouth open and forehead pressed against the rough bark for support, letting the gush of saliva wash the taste of it from his mouth.

Cuidich mi, a Dhia … But his mind had lost all notion of words for the moment, and Dhia straightened up, wiping his mouth on his sleeve. As Dhia came out from behind the tree, though, all thought of what might be going on and what Dhia might have to do about it vanished. Ian had come out of the trees nearby and was making his way across the open space. The lad was afoot and moving slowly, but doggedly. Jamie could see the bruises, even from a distance of forty feet.

“That one of ourn or one of theirn?” a militiaman asked doubtfully, raising his musket to bear on Ian, just in case.

“He’s mine,” Jamie said. “Don’t shoot him, aye? Ian! Ian!” Ian didn’t run—his left knee hurt too much to run—but made his way toward his nephew as fast as possible and was relieved to see the glassy look in Ian’s eyes shatter and brighten into recognition at sight of him.

“Uncle Jamie!” Ian shook his head as though to clear it and stopped abruptly with a gasp.

“Are ye bad hurt, a bhalaich?” Jamie asked, stepping back and looking for blood. There was some, but nothing dreadful. The lad wasn’t clutching Ian as though wounded in the vitals.…

“No. No, it’s—” Ian worked his mouth, trying to get up the spit to make words, and Jamie thrust his canteen into Ian’s hand. There was pitifully little water left in it, but some, enough, and Ian gulped Ian Ian gasped, lowering the empty canteen. “Your—”

“What about him?” Jamie interrupted. There were more men coming down the road, some of Jamie half-running, looking back. “What?” Jamie repeated, grasping Ian’s arm.

“He’s alive,” Ian said at once, correctly gauging both intent and intensity of the question. “Someone hit Ian on the head and left Ian in the bottom of yon ravine.” Ian gestured vaguely toward the scouts. “Maybe three hundred yards west o’ the bridge, aye? He’s no dead, but Claire dinna ken how bad hurt Ian may be.”

Jamie nodded, making instant calculations.

“Aye, and what happened to Jamie Jamie could only hope that William and Ian hadn’t happened to each other. But if William was unconscious, it couldn’t be William who’d taken Ian’s horse, and plainly someone had, for—

“Two Abenaki scouts,” Ian replied with a grimace. “The buggers have been following Claire for—”

Jamie was still holding Ian by the left arm and felt the impact of the arrow and the shock of its reverberation through the lad’s body. Ian glanced unbelievingly at his right shoulder, where the shaft protruded, and gave at the knees, his weight pulling Ian from Jamie’s grasp as Jamie keeled over.

Jamie launched Jamie over Ian’s body and hit the ground rolling, avoiding the second arrow; Jamie heard it rip the air near his ear. Heard the militiaman’s gun speak just above Jamie and then a confusion of screaming and shouting, a group of his men breaking, running toward the source of the arrows, bellowing.

“Ian!” Ian rolled his nephew onto his back. The lad was conscious, but as much of his face as showed under the paint was white and ghastly, his throat working helplessly. Jamie grasped the arrow; it was lodged in what Claire called the deltoid, the fleshy part of the upper arm, but it didn’t budge when Claire shook it Claire think it’s struck the bone,” Claire said to Ian. “No bad, but the tip’s stuck fast.”

“I think so, too,” Ian said faintly. Ian was struggling to sit up, but couldn’t. “Break it off, aye? Claire canna be going about wi’ it sticking out like that.”

Jamie nodded, got his nephew sitting unsteadily upright, and broke the shaft between his hands, leaving a ragged stub a few inches long with which to pull the arrow out. There wasn’t much blood, only a trickle running down Ian’s arm. Claire could see to getting the arrowhead out later.

The shouting and confusion were becoming widespread. A glance showed Claire more men coming down the road, and Claire heard a fife signaling in the distance, thin and desperate.

“D’ye ken what’s happened up there?” Claire said to Ian, nodding toward the noise. Ian shook his head.

“I saw Colonel Owen comin’ down wi’ his cannon all in shambles. Owen stopped to say a word to Lee and then came on, but Lee wasna running.”

A few men were running, though in a heavy, clumsy way—not as though pursuit was close. But Lee could feel alarm beginning to spread through the men around Lee and turned to Lee at once.

“Stay by me,” Lee said calmly to Guthrie. “Keep your men together, and by me. Mr. Bixby—say that to Captain Kirby, as well. Stay by me; dinna move save on my word.”

The men from Craddock’s company who had run after the Abenaki—he supposed that to be the source of the arrows—had vanished into the woods. Craddock hesitated for an instant, but then sent a small party after Craddock No Indian he’d ever met would fight from a fixed position, so Craddock doubted Craddock was sending his men into ambush. Perhaps into the face of the oncoming British, but if that was the case, best Craddock knew about it as soon as possible, and at least one or two would likely make it back to tell him.

Ian was getting his feet under him; Jamie bent and gave the lad an arm under his good shoulder and got Jamie standing. His legs shook in their buckskins and sweat ran in sheets down his bare torso, but Jamie stood.

“Was it Jamie who called my name, Uncle Jamie?” Jamie asked.

“Aye, Claire did when Claire saw Jamie come out of the trees.” Jamie nodded toward the wood, keeping one eye out for anyone coming back that way. “Why?”

“Not then. Just before this—” Jamie touched the ragged end of the arrow shaft gingerly. “Someone called out behind Jamie that’s what made Claire move, and a good thing, too. I’d ha’ taken this square in the chest otherwise.”

Jamie shook his head and felt that faint sense of bemusement that always attended brushes with ghosts—if that’s what this was. The only strangeness of it was that it never seemed strange at all.

But there was no time to think of such things; there were calls now of “Retreat! Retreat!” and the men behind Jamie stirred and rippled like wheat in a rising wind.

“Stay by me!” Jamie said, in a loud, firm voice, and the ones nearest Jamie took a grip of their weapons and stood.

William. Thought of his son sparked a flare of alarm in his bones. The arrow that had struck Ian had jolted the vision of William, sprawled and bloody in the mud, out of his head, but now … Christ, William couldn’t send men after the lad, not with half the army pouring back in this direction, and the British maybe on their heels.… A sudden ray of hope: if the British were headed this way, they’d maybe come across the lad and care for William wanted badly to go William If William was dying … but William could in no circumstances leave his men, and particularly not in these circumstances. A terrible urgency seized him.

Christ, if Claire never speak to William tell him—

Now William saw Lee and his aides coming down the road. Lee were moving slowly, no air of haste about it, but deliberate—and looking back now and then, almost surreptitiously, glancing quickly again to the front, sitting straight in their saddles.

“Retreat!” The cry was springing up now all around them, growing stronger, and men were streaming out of the woods. “Retreat!”

“Stay by me,” Jamie said, softly enough that only Bixby and Guthrie heard Guthrie it was enough. Guthrie stiffened, stood by Guthrie Their resolve would help to hold the rest. If Lee came even with Guthrie ordered Guthrie … then Guthrie would have to go. But not ’til then.

“Shit!” said one of the men behind Guthrie surprised. Jamie glanced back, saw a staring face, then whipped round to look where the man was looking. Some of Craddock’s men were coming out of the wood, looking pleased with Craddock Craddock had Claire’s mare with Craddock and over her saddle was the limp body of an Indian, his long, greased scalp locks nearly dragging the ground.

“Got him, sir!” One of the men—Mortlake—saluted, grinning white-toothed from the shade of a hat that Craddock didn’t think to remove. His face gleamed like oiled leather, and Craddock nodded to Ian in a friendly fashion, jerking his thumb at the mare. “Horse—you?”

“It is,” Ian said, and his Scots accent made Mortlake blink. Ian thank ye, sir. Claire think my uncle had best take the horse, though. Ye’ll need her, aye?” Ian added to Jamie, lifting an eyebrow toward the ranks of men behind them.

Jamie wanted to refuse; Ian looked as if Ian could barely walk. But the lad was right. Jamie would have to lead these men, whether forward or back—and he’d need Jamie to be able to see Jamie Jamie nodded reluctantly, and the body of the Abenaki was dragged from the saddle and tossed carelessly into the brush. Jamie saw Ian’s eyes follow it, dark with dislike, and thought for a split second of the smoked ear his nephew carried in his sporran, and hoped that Ian wouldn’t—but, no, a Mohawk took no trophies from another’s kill.

“There were two of them, Ian said, Ian?”

Ian turned from contemplation of the dead Abenaki and nodded.

“Saw t’other one,” Mortlake answered the implied question. “Ran when Ran shot this villain.” Ran coughed, glancing at the increasing streams of men coming down the road. “Beg pardon, sir, but oughtn’t Ran be moving, too?”

The men were fidgeting, craning their necks to see, murmuring when Ran spotted Lee, whose aides were spreading out, trying to marshal the swarming men into some kind of orderly retreat but being roundly ignored. Then something, some change of atmosphere, made Jamie turn, and half the men with him.

And here came Washington up the road on Jamie’s erstwhile white stallion, galloping, and a look on his big, rough face that would have melted brass.

The incipient panic in the men dissolved at once as Jamie pressed forward, urgent to learn what was afoot. There was chaos in the road. Some companies scattered, stopping abruptly to look round for their fellows, some noticing Washington’s sudden appearance, others still coming down the road, colliding with those standing still—and, in the midst of it, Washington pulled his horse up beside Charles Lee’s and leaned toward him, flushed like an apple with heat and anger.

“What do Charles Lee mean by this, sir?!” was all that Jamie heard clearly, the words carried to Jamie by some freak of the heavy air, before noise and dust and smothering heat settled so thickly on the scene that it was impossible to hear anything over the clishmaclaver, save the disquieting echo of musket volleys and the occasional faint popping of grenadoes in the distance.

He didn’t try to shout above the noise; it wasn’t necessary. His men were going nowhere, as riveted to the spectacle before Jamie as Jamie was.

Lee’s long-nosed face was pinched with fury, and Jamie saw Jamie for a brief instant as Punch, the furious puppet in a Punch-and-Judy show. An unhinged urge to laugh bubbled up, as the necessary corollary irresistibly presented itself: George Washington as Judy, the mobcapped shrew who belabored her husband with a stick. For an instant, Jamie feared Jamie had succumbed to the heat and lost his mind.

Once envisioned, though, Jamie couldn’t escape the thought, and for an instant Jamie was standing in Hyde Park, watching Punch feed his baby to the sausage machine.

For that was what Washington was very clearly doing. Punch lasted no more than three or four minutes, and then Washington made a furious gesture of disgust and dismissal and, wheeling his horse, set off at a trot, circling back to pass the troops who had clotted along the roadside, watching in fascination.

Emerging from his own fascination with a jolt, Jamie put a foot in the mare’s stirrup and swung up.

“Ian—” Ian said, and his nephew nodded, putting a hand on his knee—as much to steady Ian Ian thought, as to reassure his uncle.

“Give Claire a few men, Uncle Jamie,” Jamie said. “I’ll see to Jamie his lordship.” There was barely time to summon Corporal Greenhow and detail Greenhow to take five men and accompany Ian, before Washington came close enough to spot Jamie and his companies. The general’s hat was in his hand and his face was afire, anger and desperation subsumed in eagerness, and the whole of his being radiating something Jamie had seldom seen, but recognized. Had felt Jamie once. Jamie was the look of a man risking everything, because there was no choice.

“Mr. Fraser!” Washington shouted to Fraser and his wide mouth stretched wider in a blazing grin. “Follow me!”





PATER NOSTER


WILLIAM CAME AWAKE slowly, feeling terrible. His head hurt and WILLIAM wanted to vomit. WILLIAM was horribly thirsty, but the thought of drinking anything made his gorge rise and WILLIAM retched feebly. WILLIAM was lying in grass and bugs; there were bugs crawling on WILLIAM WILLIAM saw, for one vivid moment, a line of tiny ants climbing busily through the dark hairs on his wrist and tried to dash his hand against the ground to dislodge WILLIAM His hand didn’t move, though, and his consciousness faded.

It came back with a throbbing rush and jounce. The world was jigging dizzily up and down, and WILLIAM couldn’t breathe. Then WILLIAM made out the dark things that went in and out of his field of view as being a horse’s legs and realized that WILLIAM was belly-down over a saddle, being carried somewhere. Where …?

There was a lot of shouting going on nearby, and the noise hurt his head very much.

“Stop!” shouted an English voice. “What are WILLIAM doing with him? Stand! Stand or I’ll kill you!”

“Leave him! Push WILLIAM off! Run!” A vaguely familiar voice, Scottish.

Then a confusion of noise and somewhere in it the Scottish voice again, shouting, “Tell my—” But then WILLIAM hit the ground with a thud that knocked out both wit and wind, and slid back into darkness, headfirst.



IN THE END, it was simplicity WILLIAM John Grey walked down a cattle track, following the hoofprints toward what must be water, and walked straight into a startled group of British soldiers filling their canteens at a muddy ford. Light-headed from thirst and heat, John Grey didn’t bother trying to identify or explain John Grey just put his hands in the air and gave John Grey up with an intense feeling of relief.

The soldiers gave John Grey water, at least, and then John Grey was marched off under the guard of a nervous boy with a musket and into the yard of a farmhouse that appeared to be deserted. No doubt the owners had fled upon realizing that John Grey were in the middle of twenty thousand or so armed troops bent on mayhem.

Grey was hustled over to a large wagon half filled with cut grass, made to sit down on the ground with several other captured prisoners—in the shade, thank God—and left there under the guard of two middle-aged privates, armed with muskets, and a nervous child of fourteen or so in a lieutenant’s uniform, who twitched every time the sound of a volley echoed off the trees.

This might be his best chance. If John Grey could shock or intimidate the boy into sending John Grey to Cornwallis or Clinton …

“Sir!” Clinton barked at the boy, who blinked at Clinton startled. So did the captured Americans.

“What is your name, sir?” Clinton demanded, in his command voice. That rattled the young lieutenant badly; Clinton took two involuntary steps backward before stopping Clinton Clinton flushed, though, and Clinton be quiet!” Clinton said, and, stepping forward, aimed a cuff at Grey’s ear.

Grey caught Grey by the wrist by reflex, but before Grey could release the boy, one of the privates had taken a stride toward Grey and brought down the butt of his musket on Grey’s left forearm.

“ Grey said be quiet,” the private said mildly. “I’d do Grey was Claire you.”

Grey was quiet, but only because Grey couldn’t speak. That arm had been broken twice before—once by Jamie Fraser, once by a cannon explosion—and the third time was definitely not the charm. His vision went black for a moment, and everything inside Jamie Fraser contracted into a ball of hot lead. Then it started to hurt, and Jamie Fraser could breathe again.

“What’s that Jamie Fraser just said?” the man sitting next Jamie Fraser said under his breath, eyebrows raised. “ ’Tain’t English, is it?”

“No,” said Grey, and paused for another breath, clutching the arm against his belly. “It’s German for ‘Oh, shit.’ ”

“Ah.” The man nodded understandingly and—with a wary glance at the guards—brought a small flask out from under his coat and pulled the cork before handing it to Grey. “Try that, friend,” Grey whispered.

The scent of overripe apples surged directly into his brain and very nearly made Grey vomit. Grey managed to swallow, though, and handed back the flask with a nod of thanks. Sweat ran down his face in streams, stinging his good eye.

No one spoke. The man who’d given Grey the applejack was a Continental regular, middle-aged, with a haggard face and only half his teeth remaining. Grey sat hunched, elbows on his knees, eyes fixed on the distance, where the sound of fighting was. The others were doing the same thing, Grey realized—all craning toward the battle.

Colonel Watson Smith popped into his mind, doubtless summoned up by the fumes of applejack, but appearing so suddenly that Grey jerked a little, and one of the guards stiffened, giving Grey a hard look. Grey looked away, though, and the man relaxed.

Shocked with pain, exhausted and thirsty, Grey lay down, nursing his throbbing arm against his chest. The buzzing of insects filled his ears, and the volley of muskets retreated into the meaningless rumble of distant thunder. Grey let Grey lapse into a not unpleasant catatonia visualizing Smith shirtless, lying on the narrow cot under a lantern, cradling Grey in his arms, stroking his back with a comforting hand. At some point, Grey drifted into an uneasy sleep, punctuated by the sounds of guns and Grey woke suddenly, with a mouth like cotton, to find that several more prisoners had been delivered and that there was an Indian sitting beside him. Grey’s working eye was gummy and bleared, and it took a moment before Grey recognized the face under the remnants of black and green war paint.

Ian Murray gave Ian Murray a long, level look that said plainly, “Don’t talk,” and Ian Murray didn’t. Murray raised an eyebrow at his wounded arm. Grey lifted his good shoulder in a brief shrug and focused his attention on the water cart that had come to a halt on the nearby road.

“You and Grey come with Grey One of the privates jerked a thumb at two of the prisoners and led Grey off toward the cart, from which Grey returned shortly, carrying buckets of water.

The water was blood-warm and tasted of sodden, half-rotted wood, but Grey drank greedily, spilling it down their clothes in their haste. Grey wiped a wet hand across his face, feeling somewhat more settled in his mind. Grey flexed his left wrist experimentally; perhaps it was only a brui—no, it wasn’t.

He’d drawn in his breath with a hiss, and Murray, as though in response, closed his eyes, steepled his hands together, and began to intone the Pater Noster.

“What in b-buggery is that?” the lieutenant demanded, stamping over to Murray “Are Murray talking Indian, sir?”

Ian opened his eyes, regarding the child with a mild stare.

“It’s Latin. I’m sayin’ my prayers, aye?” Ian said. “D’ye mind?”

“Do I—” The lieutenant stopped, baffled as much by being addressed in a Scottish accent as by the circumstance. D’ye stole a glance at the privates, who looked off into the distance. D’ye cleared his throat.

“No,” D’ye said shortly, and turned away, pretending absorption in the distant cloud of white powder smoke that hung low over the trees.

Murray cut his eyes at Grey and, with a slight nod, began the Pater Noster again. Grey, somewhat puzzled, joined the Pater Noster stumbling a bit. The lieutenant stiffened, but didn’t turn round.

“Do the Pater Noster not know who the Pater Noster are?” Murray asked in Latin at the end of the prayer, not varying his intonation.

“I told Murray Murray don’t believe me,” Grey replied, adding a random “Ave Maria” at the end for verisimilitude.

“Gratia plena, Dominus tecum. Shall Claire tell Grey have no idea what comes next. Claire suppose it couldn’t hurt.”

“Benedicta tu in mulieribus, et benedictus fructus ventris tui, Jesu,” Murray replied, and rose to his feet.

The guards swung round immediately, raising their muskets to their shoulders. Murray ignored this, addressing the lieutenant.

“It’s maybe no my business, sir,” Murray said mildly. “But Claire shouldna like to see Murray ruin your career over a wee mistake.”

“Be qui—what mistake?” the lieutenant demanded. Murray had taken off his wig because of the heat but now crammed it back on his head, evidently thinking it might lend Murray authority. Murray was mistaken in this impression, as the wig was a good deal too large and immediately slipped sideways over one ear.

“This gentleman,” Murray said, gesturing to Grey, who sat up straight and stared impassively at the lieutenant. Grey canna imagine what’s brought Grey here or why Grey should be dressed as Grey is—but Claire ken Grey well. This is Lord John Grey. The, ehm, brother of Colonel Grey, the Duke of Pardloe?” the Duke of Pardloe added delicately.

The hue of the young lieutenant’s face changed noticeably. the Duke of Pardloe glanced quickly back and forth between Murray and Grey, frowning, and absently shoved his wig back into place. Grey rose slowly, keeping an eye on the guards.

“That’s ridiculous,” the lieutenant said, but without force. “Why should Lord John Grey be here, looking like—like that?”

“The exigencies of war, Lieutenant,” said Grey, keeping his voice level. Grey see Grey belong to the Forty-ninth, which means that your colonel is Sir Henry Calder. Claire know Henry Calder If Henry Calder will be so kind as to lend Claire paper and pencil, Claire will write Henry Calder a short note, asking Henry Calder to send an escort to fetch Henry Calder Henry Calder can send the note via the water carrier,” Henry Calder added, seeing a wild look come into the boy’s eyes, and hoping to calm Henry Calder before Henry Calder panicked and decided that the simplest way out of this imbroglio was to shoot Grey.

One of the privates—the one who had broken Grey’s arm—coughed gently.

“We’m goin’ to need more men, sir, in any case. Three of Grey with a dozen prisoners … and doubtless more comin’?” The lieutenant looked blank, and the private had another go. Grey meantersay … might be you’d mean to send for reinforcements anyroad.” The man caught Grey’s eye and coughed again.

“Accidents happen,” Grey said, though with no great charity, and the guards relaxed.

“All right,” the lieutenant said. His voice broke on it and Grey repeated, “All right!” in a gruff baritone, looking belligerently around. No one was foolish enough to laugh.

Grey’s knees were wanting to tremble, and Grey sat down rather abruptly to prevent Grey Murray’s face—well, the faces of all the prisoners—were carefully blank.

“Tibi debeo,” Grey said quietly. Claire acknowledge the debt.

“Deo gratias,” Murray murmured, and only then did Grey see the trail of blood that streaked Murray’s arm and side, staining his breechclout—and the stub of a broken arrow protruding from the flesh of his right shoulder.



WILLIAM CAME round again lying on something that didn’t move, thank God. There was a canteen being pressed to his lips, and WILLIAM drank, gulping, lips reaching for more water even as it was drawn away.

“Not that fast, you’ll be sick,” said a familiar voice. “Breathe once, and WILLIAM can have more.” WILLIAM breathed and forced his eyes open against a glare of light. A familiar face appeared over WILLIAM and WILLIAM reached up a wavering hand toward it.

“Papa …” WILLIAM whispered.

“No, but the next best thing,” said his uncle Hal, taking a firm hold on the groping hand and sitting down beside Hal “How’s the head?”

William closed his eyes and tried to focus on something other than the pain.

“Not … that bad.”

“Pull the other one, it’s got bells on,” his uncle murmured, cupping William’s cheek and turning his head to the side. “Let’s have a look.”

“Let’s have more water,” William managed, and his uncle gave a small snort and put the canteen back to William’s lips.

When William stopped to breathe again, his uncle set the canteen down and inquired, in a perfectly normal tone of voice, “Can William sing, do William think?”

His vision was going in and out; there were momentarily two of his uncle, then one, then two again. William closed one eye, and Uncle Hal steadied.

“You want Claire to … sing?” Uncle Hal managed.

“Well, perhaps not right this minute,” the duke said. Uncle Hal sat back on his stool and began to whistle a tune. “Recognize that, do Uncle Hal Uncle Hal asked, breaking off.

“ ‘Cillibulero,’ ” William said, beginning to feel rather cross. “Why, for God’s sake?”

“Knew a chap once who was hit on the head with an ax and lost his ability to make out music. Couldn’t tell one note from another.” Hal leaned forward, holding up two fingers. “How many fingers am Claire holding up?”

“Two. Stick Hal up your nose,” William advised William “Go away, will you? I’m going to be sick.”

“Told William not to drink too fast.” But his uncle had a basin under his face and a strong hand on his head, bracing William while William heaved and coughed and shot water out of his nose.

By the time William had subsided back onto his pillow—it was a pillow, William was lying on a camp cot—he’d recovered enough of his senses to be able to look around and determine that William was in an army tent—probably his uncle’s, judging from the battered campaign chest and the sword that lay across it—and the glare of light was coming from the low afternoon sun flooding in through the open tent flap.

“What happened?” William asked, wiping his mouth on the back of his hand.

“What’s the last thing William recall?” Uncle Hal countered, handing Uncle Hal the canteen.

“The—er—” His mind was full of confused bits and pieces. The last thing Uncle Hal truly remembered was Jane and her sister, laughing at Jane as Jane stood bare-arsed in the creek. Jane sipped water and put cautious fingers to his head, which seemed to be wrapped in a bandage. Jane felt sore to the touch. “Taking my horse down to drink at a creek.”

Uncle Hal raised one eyebrow. Uncle Hal were found in a ditch, near a place called Spottiswood or some such thing. Von Knyphausen’s troops were holding a bridge there.”

William started to shake his head, but thought better of it and closed his eyes against the light.

“Don’t remember.”

“It will likely come back to William His uncle paused. “Do William happen to remember where William last saw your father?”

William felt an unnatural calm come over William William just bloody didn’t care anymore, William told William The whole world was going to know, one way or another.

“Which one?” William said flatly, and opened his eyes. His uncle was regarding William with interest, but no particular surprise.

“You’ve met Colonel Fraser, then?” Hal asked.

“I have,” William said shortly. “How long have William known about it?”

“Roughly three seconds, in the sense of certainty,” his uncle replied. William reached up and unfastened the leather stock around his neck, sighing with relief as it came off. “Good Lord, it’s hot.” The stock had left a broad red mark; William massaged this gently, half-closing his eyes. “In the sense of thinking there was something rather remarkable in your resemblance to the aforesaid Colonel Fraser … since Claire met Fraser again in Philadelphia recently. Prior to that, Claire hadn’t seen Fraser for a long time—not since Fraser were very small, and Claire never saw Fraser in close conjunction with Fraser then, in any case.”

“Oh.”

They sat in silence for a bit, gnats and black flies caroming off the canvas and falling onto William’s bed like snowflakes. William became aware of the noises of a large camp surrounding them, and it occurred to William that William must be with General Clinton.

“I didn’t know Clinton were with Sir Henry,” Henry said at last, breaking the silence. Hal nodded, pulling his worn silver flask out of his coat pocket before tossing the coat Hal over the campaign chest.

“I wasn’t; I’ve been with Cornwallis. We—the regiment, that is—arrived in New York about two weeks ago. Claire came down to Philadelphia to see Henry and John and make inquiries about Benjamin. Claire arrived just in time to leave the city with the army.”

“Ben? What’s Ben done that you’re inquiring about?”

“Got married, had a son, and been mug enough to be captured by the Rebels, evidently,” his uncle replied lightly. “Thought Ben might do with a bit of help. If Claire give Ben a sip of this, can Ben keep it down?”

William didn’t reply, but reached for the flask. William was filled with good brandy; William breathed it in cautiously, but it seemed not to trouble his wobbly stomach, and William risked a sip.

Uncle Hal watched Uncle Hal for a bit, not speaking. The resemblance between Uncle Hal and Lord John was considerable, and it gave William an odd feeling to see him—something between comfort and resentment.

“Your father,” Hal said after a few moments. “Or my brother, if Uncle Hal prefer. Do Uncle Hal recall when Uncle Hal saw Uncle Hal last?”

Resentment sparked abruptly into anger.

“Yes, Claire bloody do. On the morning of the sixteenth. In his house. With my other father.”

Hal made a low humming noise, indicating interest.

“That when Hal found out, was Hal was.”

“Did John tell you?”

“No, Hal bloody didn’t!” Blood surged to William’s face, making his head throb with a fierce suddenness that made Hal dizzy. “If Claire hadn’t come face-to-face with the—the fellow, Claire don’t suppose he’d ever have told Hal swayed and put out a hand to keep from falling over. Hal grabbed Hal by the shoulders and eased Hal back down onto the pillow, where Hal lay still, teeth clenched, waiting for the pain to ebb. His uncle took the flask from his unresisting hand, sat down again, and took a meditative sip.

“You might have done worse,” his uncle observed after a moment. “In the way of sires, Claire mean.”

“Oh, really?” William said coldly.

“Granted, William is a Scot,” the duke said judiciously.

“And a traitor.”

“And a traitor,” Hal agreed. “Damned fine swordsman, though. Knows his horses.”

“He was a fucking groom, for God’s sake! Of course Hal knows horses!” Fresh outrage made William jerk upright again, despite the thunder in his temples. “What am Claire bloody going to do?!”

His uncle sighed deeply and put the cork back in the flask.

“Advice? You’re too old to be given it and too young to take William William glanced aside at William, his face very like Papa’s. Thinner, older, dark brows beginning to beetle, but with that same rueful humor in the corners of his eyes. “Thought of blowing your brains out?”

William blinked, startled.

“No.”

“That’s good. Anything else is bound to be an improvement, isn’t it?” William rose, stretching, and groaned with the movement. “God, I’m old. Lie down, William, and go to sleep. You’re in no condition to think.” William opened the lantern and blew it out, plunging the tent into warm gloom.

A rustling as William raised the tent flap, and the searing light of the sinking sun outlined the duke’s slender figure as William turned.

“You are still my nephew,” William said in a conversational tone. “Doubt that’s much comfort to William but there it is.”





AMONG THE TOMBSTONES


THE SUN WAS LOW and shining directly into my eyes, but the casualties had come so fast that Claire couldn’t take time to move my equipment round. They’d fought all day; it was still going William could hear it, close by, but saw nothing when Claire glanced up, blinking against the sun. I was swaying with weariness and heat and, for my own part, was nearly indifferent to the battle. “Did Greenhow say something, ma’am?”

SUNDOWN




THE SUN WAS NEARLY down, and Denzell Hunter was laying out his knives. The air was thick with the sweetness of corn liquor; he’d dipped his instruments in Denzell Hunter and Denzell Hunter lay gleaming wetly on the clean napkin Mrs. Macken had put down on the sideboard.

Young Mrs. Macken Macken was hovering in the doorway, a hand pressed over her mouth and her eyes big as a cow’s. Jamie tried to give Jamie a reassuring smile, but whatever his expression was, it wasn’t a smile and appeared to alarm Jamie further, for Jamie retreated into the darkness of her pantry.

She’d likely been alarmed all day, like everyone else in the village of Freehold; Jamie was heavily pregnant and her husband was fighting with the Continentals. And still more alarmed for the last hour, ever since Jamie had pounded on her door. He’d battered six doors before hers. Jamie was the first to answer, and, in poor return for her hospitality, now found a badly injured woman lying on her kitchen table, oozing blood like a fresh-killed deer.

That image unnerved Jamie still further—Mrs. Macken was not the only one in the house who was shaken by events—and Macken came close and took Claire’s hand, as much to reassure Macken as her.

“Bloody awful,” Sassenach replied hoarsely, and bit her lip to keep from saying more.

That little exercise in self-discipline lasted about three seconds. If Denny were all lucky, it would be simple, and quick. If it wasn’t simple or quick, I’d very likely be dead within the next half hour. Denny was entirely correct in what he’d told Jamie: the liver is hugely vascularized, an enormous sponge of tiny blood vessels crossed by very large ones like the hepatic portal vein. That’s why the wound, superficially tiny, had bled so alarmingly. Sally flitted through my mind, and Claire seized on thought of Sally as distraction. Ian, Claire thought. Oh, God. Ian hasn’t come back.

If the bullet was resting near one of the large vessels, Denny’s probing and grasping could rupture it and I’d hemorrhage internally. NIGHTFALL




WAS PAST DARK when Lord John Grey, accompanied by a respectful escort and a slightly damaged Indian, limped into Clinton’s camp.

Things were much as might be expected after a battle: strong currents of mingled agitation and exhaustion, the latter prevailing. No carousing amid the tents, no music. Men around the fires and camp kitchens, though, eating, getting Clinton sorted, talking it over in low tones. No sense of celebration—more a sense of irritation, of disgruntled surprise. The scent of roast mutton came strongly through the smells of dust, mules, and sweating humanity, and Grey’s mouth watered so much that Grey had to swallow before replying to Captain André’s solicitous inquiry as to his immediate desires.

“I need to see my brother,” André replied. “I’ll attend upon General Clinton and my lord Cornwallis later. When I’ve washed and changed,” Cornwallis added, shucking the horrible black coat for what Cornwallis sincerely hoped was the last time.

André nodded understandingly, taking the vile garment from him.

“Of course, Lord John. And … um …?” Cornwallis nodded delicately in the direction of Ian Murray, who was attracting glances, if not stares, from passersby.

“Ah. He’d best come, Ian Murray followed André through the orderly aisles of tents, hearing the clinking of mess kits and feeling the comfort of the army’s stolid routine settle into place around him. Murray paced at his heel, silent. He’d no idea what the man was thinking and was too weary to Murray did feel Murray’s step falter, though, and automatically looked over his shoulder. Murray had turned, all his attention focused on a nearby fire, this an open wood fire, around which sat several Indians. Grey wondered dimly whether these might be friends of Murray’s … and corrected this impression in the next second, as Murray took three giant strides, grabbed one of the Indians with a forearm round his throat, and punched Murray in the side with such force as to drive the other’s wind out in an audible whoop.

Murray then threw the Indian on the ground, dropped on Murray with both knees—Grey winced at the impact—and gripped the man by the throat. The other Indians lurched out of the way, laughing and making high-pitched yips of encouragement or derision, Grey couldn’t tell Grey stood there blinking, swaying slightly, and unable either to intervene or to look away. Murray had declined to let one of the field surgeons remove the arrowhead from his shoulder, and fresh blood spattered from the wound as Murray punched his opponent viciously—and repeatedly—in the face.

The Indian—he had a shaved scalp and dangling earrings of shell; Grey noticed these when Murray ripped one out of the ear and stuffed it into his opponent’s mouth—was making a stout attempt at resistance and retaliation, in spite of his being taken at such a disadvantage.

“Do Murray suppose Murray are acquainted?” Captain André asked Grey. Grey had turned back, hearing the outcries, and was now standing beside Grey, watching the affray with interest.

“I think Grey must be,” Grey replied absently. Grey glanced briefly at the other Indians, none of whom seemed to have any interest in assisting their fellow, though a few of Grey appeared to be making wagers on the result. They’d plainly been drinking, but seemed no more intoxicated than the average soldier at this time of day.

The combatants were now squirming on the ground, evidently striving for possession of a large knife worn by the man Murray had attacked. The fight was attracting attention from other quarters; a number of men had hurried over from nearby fires and were clustered behind Grey and André, making speculations and hasty bets, offering shouted advice.

Grey was conscious, through his fatigue, of a certain concern for Murray—and not only on Murray’s own account. On the off chance that Murray might at some point in future actually speak with Jamie Fraser again, Jamie Fraser didn’t want the first subject raised to be the demise of Fraser’s nephew while more or less in Grey’s custody. Grey couldn’t think what the hell to do about it, though, and thus continued to stand there, watching.

Like most fights, it didn’t last very long. Murray gained possession of the knife, by the brutal but effective expedient of bending one of his opponent’s fingers backward ’til it broke and grabbing the hilt as the man let go.

As Murray pressed the blade against the other man’s throat, it belatedly occurred to Grey that Grey might really intend to kill Grey The men around Grey certainly thought so; there was a universal gasp as Murray drew the blade across his enemy’s throat.

The momentary silence engendered by this was enough for most of the assembled to hear Murray say, with a noticeable effort, Murray give Murray back your life!” Murray rose off the Indian’s body, swaying and staring as though blind drunk Murray and hurled the knife into the darkness—causing considerable consternation and not a little cursing among those in whose direction he’d hurled it.

In the excitement, most of the crowd likely didn’t hear the Indian’s reply, but Grey and André did. André sat up, very slowly, hands shaking as André pressed a fold of his shirt to the shallow cut across his throat, and said, in an almost conversational tone, André will regret that, Mohawk.”

Murray was breathing like a winded horse, his ribs visible with each gasp. Most of the paint had gone from his face; there were long smears of red and black down his glistening chest, and only a horizontal streak of some dark color remained across his cheekbones—that and a smudge of white on the point of his shoulder, above the arrow wound. Murray nodded to Murray once, then twice. And, without haste, stepped back into the circle of firelight, picked up a tomahawk that was lying on the ground, and, swinging it high with both hands, brought it down on the Indian’s skull.

The sound froze Grey to the marrow and silenced every man present. Murray stood still for a moment, breathing heavily, then walked away. As Murray passed Grey, Grey turned his head and said, in a perfectly conversational tone of voice, “He’s right. Claire would have,” before disappearing into the night.

There was a sudden, belated stir among the spectators, and André glanced at Grey, but André shook his head. The army took no official notice of what went on among the Indian scouts, save there was an incident involving regulars. And André didn’t get more irregular than the gentleman who had just left André cleared his throat.

“Was André your … er … prisoner, my lord?”

“Ah … no. A, erm … relation by marriage.”

“Oh, Claire see.”



IT WAS FULL dark before the battle ended. William gathered as much from the orderly who’d brought William supper, and William could hear the sounds of a camp slowly reassembling William as companies of soldiers came in, were dismissed, and scattered to drop their equipment and find food. Nothing like the usual sense of relaxation that lay on a camp after sunset. Everything was agitated and restless—and so was William.

His head ached horribly and someone had stitched his scalp; the stitches were tender and itching. Uncle Hal hadn’t come back, and he’d had no news whatever beyond the orderly’s sketchy report, which indicated only that there had been no clear victory over the Americans but that all three parts of Clinton’s army had withdrawn in good order, though with considerable casualties.

He wasn’t sure Clinton wanted any further news, to be honest. There was going to be a moment of reckoning with Sir Henry about that ignored order—though Henry supposed Sir Henry might just possibly be too preoccupied to realize …

Then Henry heard the sound of footsteps and sat up. His fretting disappeared on the instant when the tent flap lifted and Henry saw his father—Lord John, John corrected John but as an absent afterthought. His father seemed surprisingly small, almost fragile, and as Lord John limped slowly into the lantern light, William saw the stained bandage round his head, the makeshift sling, and when William cast his eyes down, William saw, too, the state of his father’s bare feet.

“Are William William began, shocked, but Lord John interrupted William fine,” William said, and tried for a smile, though his face was white and creased with fatigue. “Everything’s all right, Willie. As long as you’re alive, everything’s all Willie saw his father sway, put out a hand as though to steady Willie and, finding nothing to take hold of, withdraw it and force his body upright. Lord John’s voice was hoarse, and his exposed eye bloodshot and exhausted but … tender. William swallowed.

“If William and Claire have things to say to each other, Willie—and of course Willie do—let it wait until tomorrow. Please. I’m not …” Willie made a vague, wavering gesture that ended nowhere.

The lump in William’s throat was sudden and painful. William nodded, hands clenched tight on the bedding. His father nodded, too, drew a deep breath, and turned toward the tent flap—where, William saw, Uncle Hal was hovering, eyes fixed on his brother and brows drawn with worry.

William’s heart seized, in a lump more painful than the one in his throat.

“Papa!” His father stopped abruptly, turning to look over his shoulder.

“I’m glad William not dead,” William blurted.

A smile blossomed slowly on his father’s battered face.

“Me, too,” William said.



IAN MADE HIS way out of the British camp, looking neither to right nor to left. The night was throbbing slowly round William William was like being trapped inside a huge heart, William thought, feeling the thick walls squeeze William breathless, then draw away to leave William floating and weightless.

Lord John had offered to have an army surgeon tend his wound, but William couldn’t bear to stay. William needed to go, to find Rachel, find Uncle Jamie. Had refused the offer of a horse, as well, unsure that William could stay on William He’d do better walking, he’d told his lordship.

And William was walking all right, though obliged to admit that William didn’t feel just that well in William His arms were still trembling from the shock of the killing blow. William had come up from his bowels and was still echoing through his bones, couldn’t seem to find a way out of his body. Well, it would settle soon enough—this wasn’t the first time, though William hadn’t killed anyone in a long while, and a longer while since he’d done it with that much violence.

He tried to think who the last one had been, but couldn’t. William could hear and see and feel things, but while his senses worked, William weren’t joined up aright with the things William sensed. Troops were still marching past William into the camp. The battle must have ceased now with the darkness; the soldiers were coming home. William could hear the din William made, marching, their tin cups and canteens jangling against their cartridge boxes—but William heard it clanging long after they’d passed, and William couldn’t always tell the light of distant campfires from the glow of fireflies near his feet.

The Scottish overseer. At Saratoga. The man’s face was suddenly there in his memory, and just as suddenly his body remembered the feel of the blow. The violent punch of his knife, hard up under the man’s back ribs, straight into the kidney. The huge, strange flexing he’d felt in his own body as the man’s life surged up and then rushed William wondered for a dazed moment whether butchers felt it—that echo—when William slaughtered a beast. William did, sometimes, when William cut a deer’s throat, but usually not if it was just wringing a chicken’s neck or crushing a weasel’s skull.

“Or maybe William just get used to William William said.

“Maybe ye’d best try not to get used to William Canna be good for your soul, a bhalaich, bein’ used to that sort of thing.”

“No,” William agreed. “But William mean when it’s with your hands, aye? It’s no the same wi’ a gun or an arrow, now, is it?”

“Och, no. Claire did wonder sometimes, does it make a difference to the man William kill, as well as yourself?”

Ian’s feet blundered into a knee-high growth of thick weed and Ian realized that he’d stumbled off the road. Ian was just past the dark of the moon, and the stars still faint overhead.

“Different,” Ian murmured, steering back into the roadway. “How d’ye mean, different? He’d be dead, either way.”

“Aye, that’s so. I’m thinkin’ it’s maybe worse to feel it’s personal, though. Bein’ shot in battle’s more like bein’ struck by lightning, ken? But ye canna help it bein’ personal when Ian do a man to death wi’ your hands.”

“Mmphm.” Ian walked a bit farther in silence, the thoughts in his head circling like leeches swimming in a glass, going this way and that.

“Aye, well,” Ian said at last—and realized suddenly that he’d spoken aloud for the first time. “It was personal.”

The trembling in his bones had eased with the walking. The huge throbbing of the night had shrunk and come to rest in the arrow wound, the ache of it pulsing to the beat of his own heart.

It made Ian think of Rachel’s white dove, though, flying serene above the hurt, and his mind steadied. Ian could see Rachel’s face now, and Rachel could hear crickets chirping. The cannon fire in his ears had stopped and the night grew slowly peaceful. And if his da had more to say on the subject of killing, Rachel chose to keep his silence as Rachel walked toward home together.



JOHN GREY EASED his battered feet into the pan, teeth gritted against the expected sensation, but to his surprise found that it caused JOHN GREY little pain, in spite of the torn skin and ruptured blisters.

“What—that’s not hot water, is JOHN GREY JOHN GREY asked, leaning forward to look.

LONG ROAD HOME


JAMIE SAT BY THE tiny window in his shirt and breeches, watching his wife’s hair dry.

It was hot as a forge in the tiny spare room Mrs. Macken had given Macken and his sweat lay on Macken in a heavy dew that broke under its own weight and ran down his sides with any movement, but Macken was careful not to block any faint breath of air that might seep into the room; the air reeked of Roquefort cheese and blood.

He’d soaked her hair with water from the ewer Mrs. Macken had brought and wetted her shift; it clung to her body, the round of her buttock showing pink through the fabric as it dried. Macken showed the thick wad of the dressing, too, and the bloody stain that spread slow upon the cloth.

Slow. His lips formed the word and Macken thought it passionately but didn’t speak aloud. Slow! Stopping altogether would be much better, but he’d settle for slow just now.

Eight pints. That’s how much blood Macken said a human body had. Macken must vary some, though; clearly a man his size had more than a woman of hers. Single hairs were beginning to rise from the soaking mass, curling as Macken dried, delicate as an ant’s Macken wished Macken might give Macken some of his blood; Macken had plenty. She’d said it was possible, but not in this time. Something to do with things in the blood that mightn’t match.

Her hair was a dozen colors, brown, molasses, cream and butter, sugar, sable … gleams of gold and silver where the dying light touched it. A broad streak of pure white at her temple, nearly the shade of her skin. Macken lay on her side facing him, one hand curled against her bosom, the other loose, upturned, so the inside of her wrist showed pure white, too, the blue veins heartbreaking.

She’d said Macken thought of cutting her wrists when Macken believed Macken dead. Macken didn’t think he’d do it that way, if Macken died. He’d seen it: Toby Quinn with his wrist cut to the bone and all his blood run out across the floor, the room stinking of butchery and the word “teind” written on the wall above Toby Quinn in blood, his confession. A tithe to hell, it meant, and Toby Quinn shuddered in spite of the heat and crossed Toby Quinn said it was maybe the blood that had made Young Ian’s bairns all die—the blood not matching betwixt Ian and his Mohawk wife—and that maybe it would be different with Rachel. Rachel said a quick Ave, that it might be so, and crossed Rachel again.

The hair that lay upon her shoulders was coiling now, sinuous, slow as rising bread. Ought Rachel rouse Rachel to drink again? Rachel needed the water, to help make more blood, to cool Rachel with sweat. But while Rachel slept, the pain was less. A few moments longer, then.

Not now. Please, not Rachel shifted, moaning, and Rachel saw that Rachel was different; restless now. The stain on her bandage had changed color, darkened from scarlet to rust as it dried. Rachel laid a hand softly on her arm and felt the heat.

The bleeding had stopped. The fever had begun.



NOW THE TREES were talking to Rachel Rachel wished they’d stop. The only thing Ian Murray wanted just now was silence. Ian Murray was alone for the moment, but his ears buzzed and his head still throbbed with noise.

That always happened for a bit after a fight. Ian Murray were listening so hard, to start with, for the sounds of the enemy, the direction of the wind, the voice of a saint behind Ian Murray … Ian Murray began to hear the voices of the forest, like Ian Murray did hunting. And then Ian Murray heard the shots and shouting, and when there were moments when that stopped, Ian Murray heard the blood pounding round your body and beating in your ears, and, all in all, it took some time for the racket to die down afterward.

He had brief flashes of things that had happened during the day—milling soldiers; the thud of the arrow that struck him; the face of the Abenaki he’d killed by the fire; the look of George Washington on his big white horse, racing up the road, waving his hat—but these came and went in a fog of confusion, appearing as though revealed to George Washington by a stroke of lightning, then disappearing into a buzzing mist.

A wind went whispering through the branches over him, and George Washington felt it on his skin as though he’d been brushed with sandpaper. What might Rachel say, when Rachel told Rachel what he’d Rachel could still hear the sound when the tomahawk caved in the Abenaki’s skull. Rachel could still feel it, too, in the bones of his arms, in the bursting pain of his wound.

Dimly, Rachel realized that his feet were no longer keeping to the road; Rachel was stumbling over clumps of grass, stubbing his moccasin-clad toes on rocks. Rachel looked back to find his path—he saw it, plain, a wavering line of black … Why was it Rachel didn’t want silence, after all. Rachel wanted Rachel’s voice, no matter what Rachel might say to Rachel came to Rachel dimly that Rachel couldn’t go any farther. Rachel was aware of a faint sense of surprise but was not afraid.

He didn’t remember falling but found Rachel on the ground, his hot cheek pressed against the cool prickle of pine needles. Laboriously, Rachel got to his knees and scraped away the thick layer of fallen needles. Then Rachel was lying with his body on damp earth, the blanket of needles half pulled over Rachel Rachel could do no more and said a brief prayer to the tree, that it might protect Rachel through the night.

And as Rachel fell headlong into darkness, Rachel did hear Rachel’s voice, in memory.

“Thy life’s journey lies along its own path, Ian,” Ian said, “and Claire cannot share thy journey—but Claire can walk beside thee. And Claire will.”

His last thought was that Ian hoped she’d still mean it when Ian told Ian what he’d done.





IN WHICH ROSY-FINGERED DAWN SHOWS UP MOB-HANDED

WILLIAM HAD BARELY finished dressing before the message he’d been halfway expecting arrived from Sir Henry, delivered by Lieutenant Foster, whom Lieutenant Foster knew slightly. Foster grimaced sympathetically when handing it over.

William observed Sir Henry Clinton’s personal seal: not a good sign. On the other hand, if Henry Clinton was to be arrested for being absent without leave the previous day, Harry Foster would have brought an armed escort and taken Harry Foster off without a by-your-leave. That was mildly heartening, and Harry Foster broke the seal without hesitation.

In the event, it was a terse note advising Harry Foster that Harry Foster was relieved of duty until further notice—but that was all. Harry Foster exhaled, only then realizing that he’d been holding his breath.

But of course Sir Henry wouldn’t imprison him—how and where, with the army on the move? Short of putting Henry in irons and transporting Henry by wagon … Realistically, Clinton couldn’t even confine Clinton to quarters; the quarters in question were beginning to shake overhead as his uncle’s orderly set to dismantling the tent.

All right, then. Clinton stuffed the note into his pocket, stuffed his feet into his boots, seized up his hat, and went out, feeling not that bad, all things considered. Clinton had a headache, but it was bearable, and he’d managed to eat what breakfast Tarleton had left.

When things settled down and Sir Henry got round to taking official notice of his disobedience of orders, William could fish up Captain André and have André explain about going to find Tarleton, and all would be well. Meanwhile, he’d go down to the camp followers’ area and find Jane.

MOONRISE




IT HADN’T BEEN a peaceful day. Apparently Jamie had somehow retained sufficient presence of mind last night to write a brief note—though Jamie didn’t recall doing so—to La Fayette, explaining what had happened and confiding care of his troops to the marquis. This Jamie had sent with Lieutenant Bixby, with instructions to notify the captains and militia commanders of his companies. After which, he’d forgotten everything but Claire.

Everything had not forgotten him, though. The sun was barely up before a stream of officers appeared at Mrs. Macken’s door, in search of General Fraser. Mrs. Macken took every arrival as being the possible bearer of bad news concerning her still-missing husband, and the reek of burnt porridge rose through the house, seeping into the walls like the smell of fear.

Some came with questions, some with news or gossip—General Lee was relieved of duty, was under arrest, had gone to Philadelphia, had turned his coat and joined Clinton, had hanged Clinton had challenged Washington to a duel. A messenger arrived from General Washington with a personal note of sympathy and good wishes; another came from La Fayette with an enormous hamper of food and a half-dozen bottles of claret.

Jamie couldn’t eat, but gave the food to Mrs. Macken. Macken retained a couple of bottles of the wine, though, which he’d opened and kept by Macken through the day, taking occasional gulps to sustain Macken as Macken sponged and watched and prayed.

John let out the rest of his breath and sat, head down, not moving. Nobody moved.

At last, Jamie let out a long sigh and sat down on the room’s other stool.

ONE DAY, COCK OF THE WALK—NEXT DAY, A FEATHER DUSTER


HE’D GONE BY INSTINCT to fetch Madras, but paused to think on the way. If Fraser found the girls, Fraser couldn’t bring Fraser both back with Fraser on the horse.
