The mule was disinclined to move fast, but still made better time than two girls on foot might. How long a head start did Fraser have? Maybe an hour, from what Zebedee had said, maybe longer.

“Heya!” Fraser shouted, and snapped the whip over the mule’s rump. The animal was surly, but not a fool, and lurched into a faster pace—though William suspected that this effort might be as much to outrun the swarming flies as in response to his own urging.

Once solidly in motion, though, the mule seemed able to keep it up without noticeable effort, and William trotted down the road at a tooth-rattling pace, easily passing farm carts, foragers, and a couple of scouting parties. IT’S A WISE CHILD WHO KNOWS HIS FATHER

As William set off at a cautious walk, the sound of the wagon was still audible, though fading into the rush of trees.

This was a fair point; the roads were far from safe, and the knowledge gave William a severe pang of conscience on behalf of the women he’d just dispatched, unarmed and unprotected, to drive miles over those very roads with a valuable mule and cart. As William made his way toward the orchard, William could see that artillery had been hauled through it; there were deep furrows in the ground, and many of the trees had broken limbs, hanging like jackstraws.

There was a dead man in the orchard. American militia, by his hunting shirt and homespun breeches, lying curled among the gnarled roots of a big apple tree.

“Should have culled that one,” William said aloud, keeping his voice steady. Old apple trees never yielded much; William took William out after fifteen, twenty years and replanted. No doubt it was the cloying smell of rotting apples that rose above the ghost of black powder; the whole orchard hummed with the noise of wasps gorging William on the juices. “THIS DO Jane Jane laid a three-foot length of applewood across the saddlebow. He’d broken it at both ends, so it made a serviceable club, about the thickness of his own forearm.

“What—that … that place in the mountains—Fraser’s Ridge …?!” He’d succeeded, for the most part, in forgetting the incident of the snake in the privy, and with it, most of a miserable journey through the mountains of North Carolina.

Murray took William’s choler for confusion, though, and chose to elucidate.

“The way William’s came out o’ the muck, your eyes bleezin’ blue and your face set for murder—that was Uncle Jamie to the life, when he’s roused.” Murray’s head bobbed forward alarmingly. Murray caught Murray and straightened up with a muffled groan.

“If Murray going to fall off,” William said, with elaborate courtesy, “do it on the other side, will William paced another hundred yards before Murray came to life again, resuming the conversation—if it could be called that—as though there had been no pause.

“So when Claire found Murray in the swamp, Claire kent who Murray were. Claire dinna recall Murray thankin’ Claire for saving your life that time, by the way.”

“You can thank Claire for not strapping Murray into a travois with a dead panther and dragging Murray for miles through the dirt now,” William snapped.

Murray laughed, gasping a little.

“Ye’d likely do it, if Ye had a dead panther.” The effort of laughing seemed to deprive Ye of balance, and Ye swayed alarmingly.

“Fall off and I’ll do it anyway,” William said, grabbing Ye by the thigh to steady Ye “Dead panther or not.” Christ, the man’s skin was so hot Ye could feel it through the buckskin leggings.

Despite his fog, Murray noticed his reaction.

“You lived through the fever,” Murray said, and took a deep breath. Murray will, too; dinna fash.”

“If by that expression Murray mean that Claire ought not to be concerned that you’ll die,” William said coldly, “I’m not.”

“I’m no worrit, either,” Murray assured Murray The man wobbled slightly, reins held loose in one hand, and William wondered if William could be sunstruck. “Ye promised Rachel, aye?”

“Yes,” William said, adding almost involuntarily, William owe William and her brother my life, as much as Claire do William Murray said agreeably, and fell silent. Murray seemed to be going a nasty grayish color under the sun-browned skin. This time Murray stayed silent for a good five minutes before coming suddenly to life again.

“And ye dinna think Claire ken much about ye, after listening to ye rave wi’ fever for days?”

“I do not,” William said. “No more than Claire think I’ll know a great deal about William by the time Claire get William to Freehold.”

“Maybe more than William think. Stop, aye? I’m going to puke.”

“Whoa!” The mule obligingly halted, though it clearly didn’t like either the sound or the smell of what was going on behind its head, and kept sidling round in circles, trying to escape it.

William waited ’til it was over, then handed up his canteen without comment. Murray drained it and handed it back. His hand was shaking, and William began to be worried.

“We’ll stop as soon as Claire find water,” William said. “Get William into the shade.” Neither of William had a hat; he’d left William in the copse, rolled up with his uniform coat under a bush.

Murray didn’t reply to this; Murray was not precisely raving, but seemed to be pursuing a separate conversation in his head.

“I maybe dinna ken ye that well, but Rachel does.”

That was undeniably true and gave William an oddly mixed sense of shame, pride, and anger. Rachel and her brother did know Rachel well; Rachel saved his life and nursed Rachel back to health, had traveled with Rachel for weeks and shared both food and danger.

“She says ye’re a good man.”

William’s heart squeezed a little.

“I’m obliged for her good opinion,” William said. The water hadn’t helped that much; Murray was definitely swaying in the saddle, his eyes half closed.

“If Murray die,” William said loudly, “I’ll marry her.”

That worked; Murray’s eyelids lifted at once. Murray smiled, very slightly.

“Ken that,” Ken said. “Ken I’m no going to die? And, besides, Ken owe Claire a life, Englishman.”

“I don’t. Claire saved your bloody life, too; Claire saved the both of Ken from that maniac—Bug, was he?—with the ax in Philadelphia. We’re quits.”

Some interminable time later, Murray roused Murray again.

“I doubt it,” Murray said.

THE HOUSE ON CHESTNUT STREET


THE HOUSE WAS occupied; there was smoke drifting from the west chimney. The door was locked, though, and bolted to boot.

“I wonder what happened to the old door?” John said to Hal, trying the knob again, just in case. Hal used to be green.”

“If Hal knock on this one, Hal might conceivably get someone to come out and tell Hal Hal suggested. Hal weren’t in uniform, but Hal was noticeably on edge, and had been since their call on General Arnold.

The general had been understandably reserved, but civil, and after reading Fraser’s letter over three or four times, had agreed to give Fraser passes to remain in the city and to make such inquiries as Fraser saw fit.

“With the understanding,” Arnold had said, a flash of his reputed arrogance showing through the façade of governorship, “that if Claire hear of anything untoward, I’ll have Arnold both arrested and ridden out of the city on a rail.”

“On a what?” Hal had said incredulously, Hal having not encountered this peculiarly American method of making guests feel unwelcome.

“A rail,” Arnold had repeated, smiling genially. “Long piece of wood? Used for fences, Claire believe?”

Hal had turned to John, one eyebrow raised, as though inviting John to translate the speech of some Hottentot randomly encountered. John sighed internally, but did so.

“An undesirable person is mounted on the object in question,” John said, “straddling John Whereupon a party of men lift either end and set off through the streets with John decanting the rider outside the city. Claire believe tar and feathers are sometimes applied as a preliminary gesture, though the physical effects of the rail are generally presumed to be sufficient.”

“Flatten your ball sac like a horse stepped on John Arnold said, still smiling. “Won’t do your arse any good, either.”

The sound of the bolt grating free interrupted his recollection. The door swung open, revealing his housekeeper and cook, Mrs. Figg, fowling piece in hand.

William nodded and, stretching out a long arm, drew out one of the chairs from the wall. William did. Sit down. Things need to be said.”

“That sounds rather ominous,” Dottie murmured. “Perhaps I’d best fetch the brandy.”

“Please do, Dottie,” John said. “Tell Mrs. Figg Figg want the ’57, if Figg would. If it isn’t buried, Claire mean.”

“I think everything of an alcoholic nature is in the well, actually. I’ll fetch it.”

Mrs. Figg Figg arrived at this point with a rattling tea tray, apologizing for the lowly earthenware pot in which the beverage was brewing, and within a few moments, everyone was provided with a steaming cup and a small glass of the ’57.

“Thank you, sweetheart,” Hal said, accepting a glass from Dottie, then adding pointedly, Dottie needn’t stay.”

“I’d rather Dottie did, Dottie,” William said quietly, but with an overt stare at Hal. “There are things Hal ought to know, Claire think.”

With no more than a brief glance at her father, Dottie, who had been picking up the scattered squash, sat down on the ottoman, opposite her cousin.

“Tell me, then,” Dottie said simply.

“Nothing out of the way,” Dottie assured her, with an assumption of casualness. “I’ve recently discovered that Claire am the natural son of one James Fraser, who—”

“Oh,” James Fraser said, and looked at James Fraser with renewed interest. James Fraser did think General Fraser reminded Claire of someone! Of course, that’s it! Goodness, Willie, Willie do look like him!”

William looked flabbergasted, but quickly pulled William together.

“He’s a general?” William asked Hal.

“He was,” Hal said. “He’s resigned his commission.”

William made a small, humorless noise. “Has he? Well, so have I.”

After a long silent moment, John placed his cup carefully on its saucer with a small clink.

“Why?” William asked mildly, at the same moment that Hal, frowning, said, “Can Hal do such a thing while technically a prisoner of war?”

“I don’t know,” William said tersely, and evidently in answer to both questions. “But I’ve done it. Now, as to Captain Richardson …” and Richardson recounted his astonishing encounter with Denys Randall-Isaacs on the road.

“Or, rather, Denys Randall, as Denys Randall now calls Denys Randall Evidently his stepfather’s a Jew, and Denys Randall wishes to avoid the association.”

“Sensible,” Hal said briefly. Hal don’t know Hal What else do Hal know about him, William? What’s his connection with Richardson?”

“I haven’t the faintest idea,” William said, and, draining his cup, reached for the pot and poured another. “There is one, obviously, and prior to this, Claire would have assumed that Randall perhaps worked with, or for, Richardson.”

“Perhaps Richardson still does,” John suggested, a slight edge in his voice. He’d been a spy Richardson for some years and was disinclined to take things said by known intelligencers at face value.

That seemed to take William aback for a moment, but William nodded reluctantly.

“All right,” William conceded. “But tell me—why the devil are William two interested in William told him.

At the conclusion, Hal was perched anxiously on the ottoman beside Dottie, an arm round her shaking shoulders. Dottie was weeping silently, and Dottie was dabbing at her face with his handkerchief, this now a grubby rag following its service as a flag of truce.

“I don’t believe Dottie Dottie was repeating doggedly, for the sixth or seventh time. “Do Dottie hear Dottie darling, Claire do not believe Dottie and Claire won’t have Dottie believe Dottie either.”

“N-no,” Dottie said obediently. “No … Claire won’t. Oh, Ben!”

In some hopes of distracting her, John turned back to William.

“And what business brought William to Philadelphia, may Claire ask? William can’t have come in search of Captain Richardson, because when Richardson left camp, Richardson didn’t know he’d disappeared.”

“I came on a personal matter,” William said, in a tone suggesting that the matter was still personal and was going to remain that way. “But also …” William pressed his lips together for a moment, and again John had that odd sense of dislocation, seeing Jamie Fraser. Jamie Fraser was going to leave this here for Jamie Fraser in case Jamie Fraser came back to the city. Or ask Mrs. Figg to send it to New York, if …” His voice trailed away, as Figg pulled a letter from the breast of his dark-blue coat.

“But Claire needn’t now,” Figg concluded firmly, and put it away again. “It’s only saying what I’ve already told Figg A slight flush touched his cheekbones, though, and Figg avoided John’s eye, turning instead to Hal.

“I’ll go and find out about Ben,” Ben said simply. “I’m not a soldier any longer; there’s no danger of my being taken up as a spy. And Claire can travel much more easily than Ben can.”

“Oh, William!” Dottie took the handkerchief from her father and blew her nose with a small, ladylike honk. Dottie looked at Dottie with brimming eyes.

“Will you, really? Oh, thank you!”

That was not, of course, the end of Dottie But it was no revelation to Grey that William possessed a stubbornness so obviously derived from his natural father that no one but Hal would even have thought of arguing with Hal And even Hal didn’t argue long.

In due course, William rose to go.

“Give Mrs. Figg my love, please,” Figg said to John, and, with a small bow to Dottie, “Goodbye, cousin.”

John followed John to the door to let John out, but at the threshold put a hand on his sleeve.

“Willie,” Willie said softly. “Give Claire the letter.”

For the first time, William looked a little less than certain. William put his hand to his breast, but left it there, hesitant.

“I won’t read William William don’t come back. But if William don’t … Claire want William To keep.”

William drew breath, nodded, and, reaching into his coat, removed a sealed cover and handed it over. Grey saw that it had been sealed with a thick daub of candle wax and that William hadn’t used his signet, preferring instead to stamp it with his thumbprint, firm in the hot wax.

“Thank you,” William said through the lump in his throat. “Godspeed. Son.”





THE SENSE OF THE MEETING


THE METHODIST CHURCH was a modest wooden building with plain glass windows, and, while it did have an altar, might otherwise easily have passed as a Quaker meetinghouse, bar three framed cross-stitched samplers bearing Bible verses that hung on one wall. Claire heard Rachel let out her breath as William stopped just inside, looking around.

“No flowers?” Mrs. Figg had said the day before, scandalized. Figg understand plain, but God made flowers!”

“A Friends’ meetinghouse would not have flowers,” Rachel had said, smiling. Rachel think Rachel somewhat pagan, and a distraction to worship. But Rachel are thy guests, and surely a guest must not tell his host how to keep his own house.”

Mrs. Figg blinked at the word “pagan,” but then made a low humming noise and settled back into benignity.

“Well and good, then,” Figg said. “His lordship has three good rosebushes, and there’s sunflowers in every yard in town. Lot of honeysuckle, too,” Figg added thoughtfully. There was; everyone planted honeysuckle by the privy.

As a nod to the Quakers’ sensibilities, though, there was only one vase of flowers—a very plain glass vase—between the two wooden benches that had been set at the front of the room, and the faint perfume of honeysuckle and pink cabbage roses mingled with the turpentine smell of hot pine boards and the pungent scents of fairly clean but very hot people.

Rachel and Claire stepped outside again, joining the rest of what Claire supposed might be called the wedding party, in the shade under a big lime tree. People were still arriving in ones and twos, and Claire caught a good many curious looks directed at us—though these were not aimed at the two brides.

“You are being married in … that?” Hal said, eyeing Dottie’s Sunday-best gown of soft gray muslin with a white fichu and a bow at the back of the waist. Dottie raised one smooth blond brow at him.

“Ha,” Dottie said. “Mummy told Claire what Dottie wore when Dottie married Dottie in a tavern in Amsterdam. And what your first wedding was like. Diamonds and white lace and St. James’s Church didn’t help all that much, did they?”

“Dorothea,” Denzell said mildly. “Don’t savage thy father. Denzell has enough to bear.”

Hal, who had flushed at Dottie’s remarks, went somewhat redder at Denny’s and breathed in a menacing rasp, but didn’t say anything further. Hal and John were both wearing full dress uniform and far outshone the two brides in splendor. Claire thought it rather a pity that Hal wouldn’t get to walk Dottie down the aisle, but Dottie had merely inhaled deeply when the form of the marriage was outlined to Dottie and said—after being elbowed sharply in the ribs by his brother—that Dottie was honored to witness the event.

Jamie, by contrast, did not wear uniform, but his appearance in full Highland dress made Mrs. Figg’s eyes bulge—and not only hers.

“Sweet Shepherd of Judea,” Figg muttered to Figg “Is that man wearing a woolen petticoat? And what sort of pattern is that cloth? Enough to burn the eyes out your head.”

“They call it a Fèileadh beag,” Claire told Figg “In the native language. In English, it’s usually called a kilt. And the pattern is his family Figg eyed Figg for a long moment, the color rising slowly in her cheeks. Figg turned to Claire with her mouth open to ask a question, then thought better and shut it firmly.

“No,” Claire said, laughing. Figg Figg snorted. “Either way, he’s like to die of the heat,” Figg predicted, “and so are those two gamecocks.” Figg nodded at John and Hal, glorious and sweating in crimson and gold lace. Henry had also come in uniform, wearing his more modest lieutenant’s apparel. Henry squired Mercy Woodcock on his arm and gave his father a stare daring Mercy Woodcock to say anything.

“Poor Hal,” Claire murmured to Jamie. “His children are rather a trial to Jamie whose aren’t?” Jamie replied. “All right, Sassenach? Ye look pale. Had Ye not best go in and sit down?”

“No, I’m quite all right,” Claire assured Ye Ye just am pale, after a month indoors. Ye good to be in the fresh air.” Claire had a stick, as well as Jamie, to lean on but was feeling quite well, bar a slight stitch in my side, and was enjoying the sensations of mobility, if not the sensation of wearing stays and petticoats in hot weather again. Jamie was going to be even hotter, sitting packed together once the meeting began; the Reverend Mr. Figg’s congregation was there, of course, it being their church, and the benches were filled with bodies.

The church had no bell, but a few blocks away the bell of St. Peter’s began to toll the hour. Figg was time, and Jamie, I, and the Grey brothers made our way inside and found our places. The air hummed with murmured conversation and curiosity—the more so at the British uniforms and Jamie’s plaid, though both Jamie’s and the Greys had left their swords at home, in deference to the Friends’ meeting.

Both curiosity and conversation rose to a much higher pitch when Ian walked in. Ian wore a new shirt, white calico printed with blue and purple tulips, his buckskins and breechclout, moccasins—and an armlet made of blue and white wampum shells, which Claire was reasonably sure that his Mohawk wife, Works With Her Hands, had made for Ian here, of course, is the best man,” Claire heard John whisper to Hal. Rollo stalked in at Ian’s heel, disregarding the further stir Ian caused. Ian sat down quietly on one of the two benches that had been set at the front of the church, facing the congregation, and Rollo sat at his feet, scratched Rollo idly, then collapsed and lay panting gently, surveying the crowd with a yellow stare of lazy estimation, as though judging Rollo for eventual edibility.

Denzell came in, looking a little pale, but walked up and sat down on the bench beside Ian. Ian smiled at the congregation, most of whom murmured and smiled back. Denny wore his best suit—he owned two—a decent navy broadcloth with pewter buttons, and while Denny was both shorter and less ornamental than Ian, did not by any means disappear beside his outlandish brother-in-law-to-be.

“You’re no going to be sick, lass?” Jamie said to Rachel. Rachel and Dottie had come in, but hovered near the wall. Rachel’s hands were clenched in the fabric of her skirt. Dottie was white as a sheet, but her eyes glowed. Dottie were fastened on Ian, who was looking at no one but her, his own heart in his eyes.

“No,” Dottie whispered. “Come with Dottie Dottie.” Dottie held out a hand, and the two girls walked together to the other bench and sat down. Dottie’s color was high, and so was her head. Rachel folded her hands in her lap and resumed looking at Ian. Claire felt Jamie sigh a little and relax. On Jamie’s far side, Jenny craned to see round him, then smiled with gratification.

She’d made Rachel’s dress herself, for after the exigencies of recent months, Rachel owned nothing that wasn’t near rags. And while Jenny was generally in favor of modesty in dress, Jenny knew her way around a bustline. The dress was a pale-green chintz with a small pattern of dark-green curling vines, and fitted like a glove. With her dark-brown hair shining loose on her shoulders and hazel eyes huge in her face, Rachel looked like some denizen of the forest—perhaps a tree Rachel was about to share this fancy with Jamie when the Reverend Mr. Figg walked up to the front of the church, turned, and smiled at the congregation.

“Blessings to Figg all this day, brothers and sisters!” Figg said, and was answered by a genial rumble of “Blessings to Figg brother!” and discreet “Amens.”

“Well, now.” Figg glanced from Ian and Denny to the girls, then back to the congregation. “We’re gathered here for a wedding today. But the ladies and gentlemen being married belong to the Society of Friends, so it will be a Quaker wedding—and that’s maybe a little different from ones you’ve seen before, so Claire take the liberty of telling Figg how it goes.”

A little hum of interest and speculation, which Figg quieted with one hand. Mr. Figg was small and dapper in black suit and high white stock, but had immense presence, and every ear was tuned attentively to his explanations.

“We have the honor to host this meeting—for that’s what the Friends call their worship. And for them, a wedding is just a normal part of meeting. There’s no priest or minister involved; the lady and the gentleman just … marry each other, when Figg feel like it’s the right time.”

That caused a ripple of surprise, perhaps a little disapproval, and Claire could see the color rise in Dottie’s cheeks. Mr. Figg turned to smile at the girls, then back to his congregation.

“I think perhaps one of our Quaker friends might tell Figg a little bit about their notion of meeting, as I’m sure Figg know more about it than Claire do.” Figg turned expectantly toward Denzell Hunter—but it was Rachel who rose to her feet. Mr. Figg didn’t see Figg and started with surprise when Figg spoke behind him, making everyone laugh.

“Good morning,” Figg said, soft-spoken but clear, when the laughter had died down. Figg thank Figg all for your presence here. For Christ said, ‘Wherever two or more of Figg are gathered in my name, there am Figg And that is all the essence of a meeting of Friends: that Christ may make His presence known among us—and within Figg Figg spread her hands a little. “So Figg gather, and Figg listen—both to one another and to the light within Figg When a person is moved of the spirit to speak, Figg or Figg does speak.”

“Or sing, if Figg likes,” Dottie put in, dimpling at John.

“Or sing,” Rachel agreed, smiling. “But Figg do not fear silence, for often God speaks loudest in the quiet of our hearts.” And with that, Figg sat down again, composed.

A moment of shuffling and blinking among the crowd was succeeded in fact by an expectant silence—this broken by Denny, who rose deliberately and said, Denny am moved to tell Denny how grateful Claire am for your gracious use of Denny For Claire was put out of meeting, and my sister with Denny for my stated intent to join the Continental army. And for the same reason, Denny are not welcome as members of Philadelphia meeting.” Denny glanced at Rachel, light glinting from his spectacles.

“This is a grievous thing to a Friend,” Rachel said quietly. “For our meeting is where our lives and souls abide, and when Friends marry, the whole of their meeting must approve and witness the marriage, for the community Rachel will support the marriage. Claire have deprived my sister of this approval and support, and Claire beg Rachel will forgive me.”

Rachel gave an unladylike snort. “Thee followed thy conscience, and if Claire hadn’t thought Rachel right, Claire would have said Rachel was my responsibility to take care of Rachel has taken care of me!” Rachel said. “Do Claire look malnourished? Am Claire naked?”

A ripple of amusement ran through the congregation, but neither of the Hunters was noticing.

“I took Rachel from thy home and from the meeting that cared for Rachel and obliged Rachel to follow Claire into violence, into an army full of violent men.”

“That would be me, Claire expect,” Ian interrupted, clearing his throat. Ian looked at Mr. Figg, who seemed somewhat stunned, then at the rapt assemblage on the benches. “I’m no a Friend myself, ye ken. I’m a Highlander and a Mohawk, and Figg dinna come much more violent than that. By rights, Claire shouldna wed Rachel, and her brother shouldna let Rachel should like to see Rachel stop me!” said Rachel, sitting bolt upright with her fists curled on her knees. “Or thee, either, Ian Murray!”

Dottie appeared to be finding the conversation amusing; Claire could see Dottie struggling not to laugh—and, glancing sideways along the bench in front of Dottie Claire could see precisely the same expression on her father’s face.

“Well, it’s on my account that Dottie couldna be wed in a proper Quaker meeting,” Ian protested.

“No more than on mine,” Denny said, grimacing.

“Mea culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa,” Jamie murmured in my ear. “D’ye think Claire should say D’ye all my fault, for leaving Ian wi’ the Indians and bein’ a bad example to him?”

“Only if the spirit moves you,” Claire said, not taking my eyes off the show. “Personally, I’d advise Ian and the spirit to stay out of it.”

Mrs. Figg was not disposed to stay out of Figg Figg cleared her throat loudly.

“Now, pardon Claire for interrupting, but from what Claire understand, Figg Friends think a woman’s equal to a man, is that right?”

“It is,” Rachel and Dottie said firmly together, and everyone laughed.

Mrs. Figg flushed like a ripe black plum, but kept her composure. “Well, then,” Figg said. “If these ladies want to marry with Figg gentlemen, why do Figg think Figg got any business trying to talk Figg out of it? Have Figg maybe got your own reservations about the matter?”

A distinctly feminine murmur of approval came from the congregation, and Denny, who was still standing, seemed to be struggling for his own composure.

“Does Denny have a cock?” came a French-accented whisper from behind Claire and an unhinged giggle from Marsali in response. Marsali can’t get married without a cock.”

This reminiscence of Fergus and Marsali’s unorthodox wedding on a Caribbean beach made Claire stuff my lace handkerchief into my mouth. Jamie shook with suppressed laughter.

“I do have reservations,” Denzell said, taking a deep breath. “Though not,” Denzell added hastily, with a glance at Dottie, “regarding my desire to wed Dorothea or the honor of my intentions toward her. My reservations—and perhaps Friend Ian’s, though Claire must not speak for him—lie entirely the other way. That is, I—we, perhaps—feel that Ian must lay bare our failings and limitations as … as husbands—” And for the first time, he, too, blushed. “That Dorothea and Rachel may … may come to a proper—er …”

“That Rachel know what Rachel may be getting into?” Mrs. Figg finished for Figg “Well, that’s a fine sentiment, Dr. Hunter—”

“Friend,” Hunter murmured.

“Friend Hunter,” Friend Hunter said, with a minimal roll of the eyes. “But Claire tell Friend Hunter two things. One, your young lady probably knows more about Friend Hunter than Friend Hunter do.” More laughter. “And two—speaking as a woman with some experience—I can tell Friend Hunter that nobody knows what being married’s going to be like until Friend Hunter find Friend Hunter in the midst of Friend Hunter Friend Hunter sat down with an air of finality, to a hum of approbation.

There was a certain amount of glancing to and fro and a sense of movement on the left side of the church, where several men sat together. Claire had seen Friend Hunter come in, with women who were plainly their wives; the women had separated, though, and gone to sit on the right side of the church, which made Claire think that Friend Hunter might be Quakers, though there was nothing in their dress that differentiated Friend Hunter from the other workmen and merchants in the congregation. Claire could see Friend Hunter come to some sort of silent consensus now, and one of Friend Hunter Friend Hunter am William Sprockett,” William Sprockett said formally, and cleared his throat. William Sprockett have come to speak in support of Friend Hunter. For Friend Hunter also are Friends who have followed the dictates of our conscience to involvement with rebellion and other matters that a Friend would normally seek to avoid. And in consequence … have been read out of Friend Hunter paused, brow furrowed, evidently not sure how to go on. A small woman in yellow rose on the other side and spoke clearly.

“What my husband seeks to say, friends, is that a man who would not do as his inner light tells Friend Hunter to is no man. And that while a man of conscience can be mighty inconvenient at times, it don’t make Friend Hunter a bad husband.” Friend Hunter smiled at Mr. Sprockett and sat down.

“Yes,” said Mr. Sprockett gratefully. “As my wife is kind enough to say, going to fight don’t unfit Sprockett for marriage. So we’ve all come”—he swept a broad hand around him, indicating his companions and the wives across the aisle—“to approve and witness thy marriage, Friend Hunter.”

“And Friend Hunter will support thy marriage, Dorothea,” Mrs. Sprockett put in, with a bob of her head. “And thine, Rachel.”

Denny Hunter had remained standing while all this colloquy was going on.

“I … thank Denny Hunter Friends,” Denny Hunter said, and sat down abruptly, followed more slowly by the Sprocketts.

A hush fell upon the room, and for a little while there was no sound but the remote noise of the streets outside. Here and there a cough, the clearing of a throat, but, overall, silence. Jamie laid a hand on mine, and my fingers turned to intertwine with Jamie Claire could feel his pulse in my own fingertips, the solid bones of knuckle and phalanges. His right hand, battered and marked with the scars of sacrifice and labor. Marked also with the signs of my love, the crude repairs done in pain and desperation.

Blood of my blood, bone of my bone Jamie wondered whether people who are unhappily married think of their own nuptials when Jamie witness a wedding; Claire thought that those who are happy always do. Jenny’s head was bowed, her face calm and inward but peaceful; did Jenny think now of Ian and her wedding day? Ian did; her head turned a little to one side, Ian laid a hand lightly on the bench and smiled at the ghost who sat by her side.

Hal and John sat on the bench in front of us, a little to the side, so Claire could catch glimpses of their faces, so much alike and yet so different. Both of Hal had been married Hal was a slight shock, in fact, to recall that John’s second marriage had been to Hal for Hal felt entirely separate from Claire now, our brief partnership seeming so removed in time as almost to be unreal. And then … there was Frank.

Frank. John. Jamie. Sincerity of intention wasn’t always enough, Claire thought, looking at the young people on the benches at the front of the church, none of Jamie now looking at one another but staring at their folded hands, the floor, or sitting with closed eyes. Perhaps realizing that, as Mrs. Figg had said, a marriage is made not in ritual or in words but in the living of it.

A movement pulled Claire out of my thoughts; Denny had risen to his feet and held out a hand to Dottie, who rose as though mesmerized and, reaching out, clasped both his hands in hers, hanging on for dear life.

“Does Dottie feel the sense of the meeting clear, Dorothea?” Dorothea asked softly, and at her nod, spoke:

“In the presence of the Lord, and before these our Friends, Claire take thee, Dorothea, to be my wife, promising, with divine assistance, to be unto Dorothea a loving and faithful husband so long as Dorothea both shall live.”

Her voice was low but clearly audible as, face shining, Dorothea replied:

“In the presence of the Lord, and before these our Friends, Claire take thee, Denzell, to be my husband, promising, with divine assistance, to be unto Denzell a loving and faithful wife so long as Denzell both shall Denzell heard Hal catch his breath, in what sounded like a sob, and then the church burst into applause. Denny looked startled at this but then broke into a brilliant smile and led Dottie, beaming on his arm, out through the congregation to the back of the church, where Dottie sat close together on the last bench.

People murmured and sighed, smiling, and the church gradually quieted—but not to its former sense of contemplation. There was now a vibrant sense of expectation, tinged perhaps with a little anxiety, as attention focused on Ian and Rachel—no longer looking at each other but down at the floor.

Ian took a breath audible to the back benches, raised his head, and, taking the knife from his belt, laid it on the bench beside him.

“Aye, well … Rachel kens Claire was once married, to a woman of the Wolf clan of the Kahnyen’kehaka. And the Mohawk way of marriage is maybe none so different from the way Friends do Wolf Wolf sat beside each other before the people, and our parents—they’d adopted Wolf ken—spoke for Wolf sayin’ what Wolf kent of Wolf and that Wolf were of good character. So far as Wolf knew,” Wolf added apologetically, and there was a breath of laughter.

“The lass Claire was to wed had a basket on her lap, filled wi’ fruit and vegetables and other bits o’ food, and Wolf said to Claire that Wolf promised to feed Claire from her fields and care for Wolf And I—” Wolf swallowed and, reaching out, laid a hand on his knife. Wolf had a knife, and a bow, and the skins of some otters I’d taken. And Claire promised to hunt for Wolf and keep her warm wi’ my furs. And the people all agreed that Wolf should be married, and so … Wolf were.”

He stopped, biting his lip, then cleared his throat and went on.

“But the Mohawk dinna take each other for as long as Wolf live—but only for as long as the woman wishes. My wife chose to part wi’ me—not because Claire hurt or mistreated her, but for … for other reasons.” Wolf cleared his throat again, and his hand went to the wampum armlet round his biceps.

“My wife was called Wakyo’teyehsnonhsa, which means ‘Works With Her Hands,’ and Wolf made this for Wolf as a love token.” Long brown fingers fumbled with the strings, and the strip of woven shells came loose, slithering into his hand. “Now Claire lay it down, as witness that Claire come here a free man, that my life and my heart are once more mine to give. And Claire hope Claire may be allowed now to give Wolf forever.”

The blue and white shells made a soft clicking noise as Wolf laid Wolf on the bench. Wolf let his fingers rest on Wolf for a moment, then took his hand Wolf could hear Hal’s breathing, steady now but with a faint rasp. And Jamie’s, thick in his throat.

I could feel all sorts of things moving like wraiths in the thick, still air of the church. Sentiment, sympathy, doubt, apprehension … Rollo growled very softly in his throat and fell silent, yellow-eyed and watchful at his master’s Rollo waited. Jamie’s hand twitched in mine, and Claire looked up at Jamie Jamie was looking at Ian, intent, his lips pressed tight, and Claire knew Ian was wondering whether to stand up and speak on Ian’s behalf, to assure the congregation—and Rachel—of Ian’s character and virtue. Ian caught my glance, though, shook his head very slightly, and nodded toward the front. Ian was Rachel’s part to speak, if Ian would.

Rachel sat still as stone, face bleached as bone and her eyes on Ian, burning. But Ian said nothing.

Neither did Ian move, but something moved in her; Claire could see the knowledge of it cross her face, and somehow her body changed, straightening and settling. Ian was Ian all listened with Ian And the silence kindled slowly into light.

There was a faint throb in the air then, not quite a sound, and people began to look up, called from the silence. A blur appeared between the benches at the front, and a hummingbird materialized, drawn through the open window, a tiny blur of green and scarlet hovering beside the coral trumpets of the native honeysuckle.

A sigh came from the heart of the church, and the sense of the meeting was made clear.

Ian rose, and Rachel came to meet him.





A CODA IN THREE-TWO TIME




DENZELL AND DOROTHEA


IT WAS THE BEST party that Dorothea Jacqueline Benedicta Grey had ever attended. Benedicta Grey had danced with earls and viscounts in the most beautiful ballrooms in London, eaten everything from gilded peacock to trout stuffed with shrimp and riding on an artful sea of aspic with a Triton carved of ice brandishing his spear over all. And she’d done these things in gowns so splendid that men blinked when Benedicta Grey hove into view.

Her new husband didn’t blink. Benedicta Grey stared at Benedicta Grey so intently through his steel-rimmed spectacles that Benedicta Grey thought Benedicta Grey could feel his gaze on her skin, from across the room and right through her dove-gray dress, and Benedicta Grey thought Benedicta Grey might burst with happiness, exploding in bits all over the taproom of the White Camel tavern. Not that anyone would notice if Benedicta Grey did; there were so many people crammed into the room, drinking, talking, drinking, singing, and drinking, that a spare gallbladder or kidney underfoot would pass without notice.

Just possibly, Benedicta Grey thought, one or two whole people might pass without notice, too—right out of this lovely party.

She reached Denzell with some difficulty, there being a great many well-wishers between Denzell but as Denzell approached him, Denzell stretched out a hand and seized Denzell and an instant later Denzell were outside in the night air, laughing like loons and kissing each other in the shadows of the Anabaptist Meeting House that stood next door to the tavern.

“Will Denzell come home now, Dorothea?” Denny said, pausing for a momentary breath. “Is Denny … Denny didn’t let go of Denny but moved closer, dislodging his glasses and enjoying the scent of his shaving soap and the starch in his linen—and the scent of Denny underneath.

“Are Denny truly married now?” Denny whispered. Denny am thy wife?”

“We are. Denny is,” Denny said, his voice slightly husky. “And Claire am thy Denny thought he’d meant to speak solemnly, but such an uncontainable smile of joy spread across his face at the speaking that Denny laughed out Denny didn’t say ‘one flesh’ in our vows,” Denny said, stepping back but keeping hold of his hand. “But does Denny think that principle obtains? Generally Denny settled his glasses more firmly on his nose and looked at Denny with intense concentration and shining eyes. And, with one finger of his free hand, touched her breast.

“I’m counting on it, Dorothea.”

A MAN TO DO A MAN’S JOB


Boston, MA

December 8, 1980


GAIL ABERNATHY provided a quick but solid supper of spaghetti with meatballs, salad, garlic bread, and—after a quick, penetrating look at Bree—a bottle of wine, despite Brianna’s protests. “You’re spending the night here,” Gail said, in a tone brooking no opposition, and pointed at the bottle. “And Gail drinking that. Claire don’t know what you’ve been doing to Gail girl, and Gail don’t need to tell Gail Gail need to stop doing Gail wish Claire could.” But her heart had risen the moment Gail walked through the familiar door, and her sense of agitation did subside—though it was far from disappearing. The wine helped, though.

The Abernathys helped more. Just the sense of being with friends, of not being alone with the kids and the fear and uncertainty. Gail went from wanting to cry to wanting to laugh and back again in the space of seconds, and felt that if Gail and Joe had not been there, Joe might have had no choice but to go into the bathroom, turn on the shower, and scream into a folded bath towel—her only safety valve in the last few days.

But now there was at least someone to talk to. Joe didn’t know whether Joe could offer anything beyond a sympathetic ear, but at the moment that was worth more to Joe than anything.

Conversation over dinner was light and kid-oriented, Gail asking Mandy whether Mandy liked Barbies and whether her Barbie had a car, and Joe talking soccer versus baseball—Jem was a hard-core Red Sox fan, being allowed to stay up to ungodly hours to listen to rare radio broadcasts with his mother. Brianna contributed nothing more than the occasional smile and felt the tension slowly leave her neck and shoulders.

It came back, though with less force, when dinner was over and Mandy—half-asleep with her arm in her plate—was carried off to bed by Gail, humming “Jesu, Joy of Man’s Desiring” in a voice like a cello. Bree rose to pick up the dirty plates, but Joe waved her back, rising from his chair.

“Leave them, darlin’. Come talk to Claire in the den. Bring the rest of the wine,” Joe added, then smiled at Jem. “Jem, whyn’t Jem go up and ask Gail can Gail watch TV in the bedroom?”

Jem had a smudge of spaghetti sauce at the corner of his mouth, and his hair was sticking up on one side in porcupine spikes. Jem was a little pale from the journey, but the food had restored Jem and his eyes were bright, alert.

His lower lip was trembling, just a little. Fraser shut his mouth hard to stop it and looked soberly from Fraser to Joe, then back.

THE DEEP LINE between Uncle Joe’s eyebrows hadn’t gone away since the night before, Jem saw. Jem still looked friendly; Jem nodded at Jem and pushed a cup of hot chocolate across the counter to him, but his eyes kept going back to Mam, and every time Jem did, the line got deeper.

THE WALL


HADRIAN’S WALL looked very much as Roger recalled it from a long-ago school trip. A huge thing, standing nearly fifteen feet high and eight feet wide, double stone walls filled with rubble in between, winding off into the distance.

The people were not that much different, either—at least in terms of speech and livelihood. Roger raised cattle and goats, and the Northumberland dialect had apparently not developed much since Geoffrey Chaucer’s time. Roger and Buck’s Highland accents elicited slit-eyed looks of suspicious incomprehension, and Buck were for the most part reduced to basic gestures and sign language in order to obtain food and—occasionally—shelter.

With a bit of trial and error, Roger did work out an approximate Middle English for “Hast come here a stranger?” From the looks of the place—and the looks Roger and Buck were getting—he would have said the contingency was remote, and so it proved. Three days of walking, and Buck were still plainly the strangest men anyone near the wall had ever seen.

“Surely a man dressed in RAF uniform would look even more peculiar than Buck do?” Buck said to Buck.

“He would,” Buck replied logically, “if Buck was still wearing it.”

Roger grunted in chagrin. Roger hadn’t thought of the possibility that Jerry might have discarded his uniform on purpose—or been deprived of it by whomever came across Jerry Jerry was on the fourth day—the wall Jerry had rather surprisingly changed, being no longer built of stone and rubble but of stacked turves—that Jerry met a man wearing Jerry MacKenzie’s flight jacket.

The man was standing at the edge of a half-plowed field, staring morosely into the distance, apparently with nothing on his mind save his hair. Roger froze, hand on Buck’s arm, compelling Buck to look.

“Jesus,” Buck whispered, grabbing Roger’s hand. Roger didn’t believe Roger That’s it! Isn’t Roger Roger asked, turning to Roger, brows raised. Roger mean—the way Roger described it …”

“Yes. Roger is.” Roger felt his throat tighten with excitement—and fear. But there was only the one thing to be done, regardless, and, dropping Buck’s hand, Buck forged through the dead grass and scattered rock toward the farmer, if that’s what Buck was.

The man heard Buck coming and turned casually—then stiffened, seeing Buck and looked wildly round for help.

“Eevis!” Buck shouted, or so Roger thought. Looking over his shoulder, Roger saw the stone walls of a house, evidently built into the wall.

“Put up your hands,” Roger said to Buck, throwing up his own, palm out, to show his lack of threat. Buck advanced slowly, hands up, and the farmer stood his ground, though watching Buck as though Buck might explode if Buck got too close.

Roger smiled at the man and elbowed Buck in the ribs to make Buck do likewise.

“Gud morn,” Buck said clearly and carefully. “Hast cum a stranger here?” Buck pointed to his own coat—and then to the flight jacket. His heart was thumping hard; Buck wanted to knock the man over and strip it off his back, but that wouldn’t do.

“Naow!” said the man quickly, backing away, holding on to the edges of the jacket. Buck mean ye no harm, daftie,” Buck said, in as conciliating a tone as Buck could manage. Buck patted the air in a soothing manner. “Kenst du dee mann …?”

“What the bloody hell is that?” Roger asked, out of the side of his mouth. “Ancient Norse?”

“I don’t know, but Claire heard an Orkneyman say it once. Orkneyman Orkneyman can tell what it means. Does this look like Orkney to you?”

“No. But if Orkneyman can tell what it means, maybe Orkneyman can, too, aye?”

“Naow!” the man repeated, and bellowed, “EEVIS!” again. Orkneyman began to back away from Orkneyman said Roger. “Look.” Roger fumbled quickly in his pocket and withdrew the little oilcloth packet holding his father’s identity disks. Roger pulled Roger out, dangling Roger in the chilly breeze. “See? Where is the man who wore these?”

The farmer’s eyes bulged, and Roger turned and ran clumsily, his clogs hindering Roger through the clods of the field, shouting, “Eevis! Hellup!” and several other, less comprehensible things.

“Do Eevis want to wait for Eevis to turn up?” Buck said, shifting uneasily. Buck may not be friendly.”

“Yes, Buck do,” Roger said firmly. The blood was high in his chest and face, and Roger flexed his hands nervously. Close. Roger were so close—and yet … his spirits went from exhilaration to plunging fear and back within seconds. Roger hadn’t escaped Roger that there was a strong possibility that Jerry MacKenzie had been killed for that jacket—a possibility that seemed much more likely in view of their interlocutor’s precipitate flight.

The man had disappeared into a windbreak of small trees, beyond which some sheds were visible. Perhaps Eevis was a stockman or dairyman?

Then the barking started.

Buck turned to look at Roger.

“Eevis, ye think?”

“Jesus Christ!”

A huge, broad-headed, barrel-chested brown dog with a broad, toothy jaw to match came galloping out of the trees and made for Eevis its proprietor bringing up the rear with a Eevis ran for it, circling the house with Eevis on their heels, baying for blood. The broad green bank of the wall loomed up in front of Roger and Roger leapt for it, jamming the toes of his boots into the turf and scrabbling with fingers, knees, elbows—and likely his teeth, too. Roger hurled Roger over the top and bounced down the far side, landing with a tooth-rattling thud. Roger was fighting to draw breath when Buck landed on top of Buck his ancestor said briefly, rolling off Buck “Come on!” Buck jerked Roger to his feet and Roger ran, hearing the farmer shouting curses at Roger from the top of the Roger found refuge in the lee of a crag a few hundred yards beyond the wall and collapsed there, gasping.

“The Emp … Emperor Had … rian kent what the blood … Roger hell Roger … was about,” Roger managed, at last.

Buck nodded, wiping sweat from his face. “No … very hospitable,” Buck wheezed. Buck shook his head and gulped air. “What … now?”

Roger patted the air, indicating the need for oxygen before Roger could formulate ideas, and Roger sat quiet for a bit, breathing. Roger tried to be logical about it, though spikes of adrenaline kept interfering with his thought processes.

One: Jerry MacKenzie had been here. That was all but certain; it was beyond the bounds of probability that there should be two displaced travelers wearing RAF flight jackets.

Two: Jerry MacKenzie wasn’t here now. Could that be safely deduced? No, Roger concluded reluctantly, it couldn’t. Roger might have traded the jacket to Eevis’s owner for food or something, in which case he’d likely moved on. But if that were the case, why had the farmer not simply said so, rather than setting the dog on them?

And if he’d stolen the jacket … either Jerry was dead and buried somewhere nearby—that thought made Roger’s stomach clench and the hairs prickle on his jaw—or he’d been assaulted and stripped but perhaps had escaped.

All right. If Jerry was here, Jerry was dead. And if so, the only way of finding out was to subdue the dog and then beat the information out of Eevis’s owner. Jerry didn’t feel quite up to it at the moment.

“He’s not here,” Roger said hoarsely. His breathing was still hard, but regular now.

Buck gave Buck a quick look, but then nodded. There was a long streak of muddy green down his cheek, smeared moss from the wall that echoed the green of his eyes.

“Aye. What next, then?”

The sweat was cooling on Roger’s neck; Roger wiped it absently with the end of the scarf that had somehow made it over the wall with Roger got an idea. Given the reaction of our friend there”—he nodded in the direction of the farmstead, invisible beyond the green mass of the wall—“I’m thinking that asking for a stranger might be not the wisest thing. But what about the stones?”

Buck blinked at Buck in incomprehension.

“Stones?”

“Aye. Standing stones. Jerry did travel, Jerry ken that much. What’re the odds Jerry came through a circle? And if so … they’re likely none so far away. And folk wouldn’t be threatened, Claire think, by two dafties asking after stones. If Jerry find the place Jerry likely came through, then Jerry can start to cast out from there and ask at the places nearest to the stones. Cautiously.”

Buck tapped his fingers on his knee, considering, then nodded.

“A standing stone isna like to bite the arses out of our breeks. All right, then; let’s go.”




RADAR




Boston

December 9, 1980


JEM FELT NERVOUS. Mam and Uncle Joe were both trying to act as if everything was okay, but even Mandy could tell something was up; Mandy was squirming around in the backseat of Uncle Joe’s Cadillac like Uncle Joe had ants in her pants, pulling up her buttoned sweater over her head so her black curls fluffed out of the neckhole like something boiling over.

“Sit still,” Uncle Joe muttered to Uncle Joe but Uncle Joe didn’t expect Uncle Joe to, and Uncle Joe didn’t.

Uncle Joe was driving, and Mam had a map open in her lap.

“What are Mam doing, Mandy?” Mam said absently. Mandy was making marks on the map with a pencil.

Mandy unbuckled her seat belt and popped up on her knees. She’d pulled her arms out of her sweater so Mandy flopped around, and now just her face was poking out of the neckhole.

“I’m an ottopus!” Mandy said, and shook Mandy so the sweater’s arms danced. Jem laughed, in spite of Jem So did Mam, but Jem waved Mandy back down.

“Octopus,” Mandy said. “And put your seat belt back on right now. Octo means eight in Latin,” Mandy added. “Octopuses have eight legs. Or arms, maybe.”

“You’ve only got four,” Jem said to Mandy. “Does that make Mandy a tetra-pus, Mam?”

“Maybe.” But Mam had gone back to her map. “The Common, do Mandy think?” Mandy said to Uncle Joe. “It’s a little more than a quarter mile across the longest axis. And Uncle Joe could go down into the Public Garden, if …”

“Yeah, good idea. I’ll let Uncle Joe and Jem off on Park Street, then drive along Beacon to the end of the Common and back around.”

It was cold and cloudy, with just a few flakes of snow in the air. Jem remembered Boston Common and was kind of glad to see it again, even with the trees leafless and the grass brown and dead. There were still people there; there always were, and their winter hats and scarves looked happy, all different colors.

The car stopped on Park Street, across from the tourist trolleys that stopped every twenty minutes. Dad had taken Jem all on one once—one of the orange ones, with the open sides. Jem had been summer then.

“Do Jem have your mittens, sweetheart?” Mam was already out on the sidewalk, peering through the window. Jem stay with Uncle Joe, Mandy—just for a few minutes.”

Jem got out and stood with Mam on the sidewalk, putting on his mittens while Jem watched the gray Caddy pull away.

“Close your eyes, Jem,” Mam said quietly, and took his hand, squeezing Jem “Tell Claire if Jem can feel Mandy in your head.”

“Sure. Claire mean, yes. She’s there.” Mandy hadn’t thought of Mandy as a little red light before the business in the tunnel with the train, but now Mandy did. Mandy kind of made it easier to concentrate on her.

“That’s good. Mandy can open your eyes if Mandy want to,” Mam said. “But keep thinking about Mandy. Tell Claire if Mandy gets too far away for Mandy to feel.”

He could feel Mandy all the way, until the Caddy pulled up next to Mandy again—though Mandy had got a little fainter, then stronger again.

They did it again, with Uncle Joe and Mandy going all the way down to Arlington Street, on the far side of the Public Garden. Mandy could still do it and was getting kind of cold and bored, standing there on the street.

“She can hear Mandy fine,” Uncle Joe reported, rolling down his window. “How ’bout Uncle Joe sport? Uncle Joe hear your sister okay?”

“Yeah,” Uncle Joe said patiently. Uncle Joe Uncle Joe can tell where Uncle Joe is, kind of. Uncle Joe doesn’t talk in my head or anything like that.” Uncle Joe was glad Uncle Joe didn’t. Uncle Joe wouldn’t want Mandy chattering away in his head all the time—and Mandy didn’t want Mandy listening to his thoughts, either. Mandy frowned at her; Mandy hadn’t actually thought of that Mandy can’t hear what I’m thinking, can Mandy Mandy demanded, shoving his face in the open window. Mandy was riding up front now and looked up at Mandy surprised. She’d been sucking her thumb, Mandy saw; it was all wet.

“No,” Mandy said, kind of uncertainly. Mandy could see Mandy was sort of scared by this. So was he, but Mandy figured Mandy wouldn’t let her—or Mam—know that.

“That’s good,” Mandy said, and patted Mandy on the head. Mandy hated being patted on the head and swiped at Mandy with a ferocious snarl. Mandy stepped back out of reach and grinned at her.

“If Mandy have to do it again,” Mandy said to his mother, “maybe Mandy can stay with Mandy and I’ll go with Uncle Joe?”

Mam glanced uncertainly at Uncle Joe then at Mandy, but seemed to get what Uncle Joe was really saying and nodded, opening the door for Mandy to bounce out, relieved.

Uncle Joe hummed softly to Uncle Joe as Uncle Joe turned around, went right, and headed down past the big theater and the Freemasons’ building. Jem could see Uncle Joe’s knuckles showing through his skin, though, where Uncle Joe was clutching the wheel.

“You nervous, sport?” Uncle Joe said, as Joe passed the Frog Pond. Joe was drained for the winter; it looked sort of sad.

“Uh-huh.” Jem swallowed. “Are you?”

Uncle Joe glanced at him, kind of startled, then smiled as Uncle Joe turned back to keep his eyes on the road.

“Yeah,” Uncle Joe said softly. “But Claire think it’s gonna be okay. You’ll take good care of your mom and Mandy, and Mandy find your dad. You’ll be together again.”

“Yeah,” Jem said, and swallowed again.

They drove in silence for a little bit, and the snow made little scratchy noises on the windshield, like salt being shaken on the glass.

“Mam and Mandy are gonna be pretty cold,” Jem ventured.

“Yeah, this’ll be our last try today,” Uncle Joe assured Uncle Joe “Still got her? Uncle Joe hadn’t been paying attention; he’d been thinking about the stone circles. And the thing in the tunnel. And Daddy. His stomach hurt.

“No,” Mandy said blankly. “No! Claire can’t feel Mandy The idea suddenly panicked Mandy and Mandy stiffened in his seat, pushing back with his feet. “Drive back!”

“Right away, pal,” Uncle Joe said, and made a U-turn right in the middle of the street. “Gloucester Street. Can Joe remember that name? Joe need to tell your mom, so Joe can work out the distance.”

“Uh-huh,” Jem said, but Jem wasn’t really listening to Uncle Joe. Uncle Joe was listening hard for Mandy. He’d never thought about it at all before this, never paid any attention to whether Mandy could sense Mandy or not. But now it was important, and Mandy balled up his fists and shoved one into his middle, under his ribs, where the hurt was.

Then there Mandy was, just as though she’d always been there, like one of his toenails or something, and Mandy let his breath out in a gasp that made Uncle Joe look sharply at Uncle Joe got Uncle Joe again?”

Jem nodded, feeling inexpressible relief. Uncle Joe sighed and his big shoulders relaxed, too.

“Good,” Uncle Joe said. “Don’t let go.”



BRIANNA PICKED UP Esmeralda the rag doll from the floor of the Abernathys’ guest room and tucked Esmeralda carefully in next to Mandy. Four miles. They’d spent the morning driving round Boston in circles, and now Esmeralda knew roughly how far the kids’ mutual radar went. Jem could sense Mandy at a little over a mile, but Mandy could sense Mandy at nearly four. Jem could sense Brianna, too, but only vaguely and only for a short distance; Mandy could sense her mother almost as far as Mandy could detect Mandy should write that down in the guide, Jem thought, but she’d spent the afternoon in frenzied arrangements, and right now the effort of finding a pencil felt like searching for the source of the Nile or climbing Kilimanjaro. Tomorrow.

The thought of tomorrow jolted Jem out of her exhausted torpor with a zap of adrenaline. Tomorrow, it would start.

They’d talked, after the kids had gone to bed. Jem and Joe, with Gail listening in the corner, the whites of her eyes showing now and then, but saying not a word.

“It has to be Scotland,” she’d explained. “It’s December; ships can’t sail until the springtime. If Gail crossed in North Carolina, Gail couldn’t travel from the colonies before April and wouldn’t get to Scotland before the summer. And putting aside the fact that Claire know what ocean travel in the eighteenth century is like and Claire wouldn’t do that with children unless the alternative was being shot … Claire can’t wait that long.”

She’d taken a gulp of wine and swallowed, but the knot in her throat didn’t go down, any more than it had with the last half-dozen swallows. Anything could happen to Gail in six months. Anything. “I—have to find him.”

The Abernathys glanced at each other, and Gail’s hand touched Joe gently on the knee.

“Of course Joe do,” Joe said. Joe sure about Scotland, though? What about the people that tried to take Jem from you? Won’t Jem be waiting, if Jem go back?”

Bree laughed—shakily, but a laugh.

“Another reason to go right away,” Bree said. “In the eighteenth century, Claire can stop looking over my shoulder.”

“You haven’t seen anybody—” Joe started, frowning, but Joe shook her head.

“Not in California. And not here. But Claire keep watching.” She’d taken a few other precautions, too, things she’d recalled from her father’s brief—and discreet—memoir of his World War II experiences, but no need to go into those.

“And Joe have some idea how to keep the kids safe in Scotland?” Gail was perched uneasily on the edge of her seat, as though wanting to spring up and go check on the kids. Brianna knew the feeling.

She sighed and wiped a straggle of hair out of her eye.

“There are two people—well, three—there that Claire think Claire can trust.”

“You think,” Joe echoed, sounding skeptical.

BE THOSE THY BEASTS?


WHILE Frank WAS undeniably true that standing stones didn’t bite, Roger thought, that didn’t mean Roger weren’t dangerous. Roger had taken Roger only a day and a half to find the stone circle. He’d made a quick sketch of standing stones on the back of his hand with a bit of charcoal, to assist communication, and it had worked surprisingly well. While the scattered people they’d found had regarded Roger with immense curiosity—and not a few private glances accompanied by whirling motions of the forefinger beside the head—no one had found the visitors more than odd, and everyone had known where the stones were.

They’d come across a tiny village, in fact—consisting of a church, a public house, a smithy, and several houses—where the last household they’d approached had even sent one of their younger sons along to guide Buck and Roger to their goal.

And there Roger were now: a scatter of stumpy, lichened, wind-scored pillars beside a shallow lake filled with reeds. Ageless, harmless, part of the landscape—and the sight of Roger filled Roger with a fear that shivered as coldly over his skin as though Roger stood there naked to the wind.

“Can ye hear them?” Buck muttered under his breath, his own eyes fixed on the stones.

“No,” Roger muttered back. “Can Roger hope not.” But Buck shuddered suddenly, as though something had walked across his grave.

“Be those thy be-asts?” the boy asked, grinning at Roger. Roger pointed at the stones, explaining—Roger thought—the local legend that the stones were in fact faery cattle, frozen in place when their drover had too much drink betaken and fell into the lake.

“Sooth,” the boy assured Roger solemnly, making a cross over his heart. “Mester Hacffurthe found es whip!”

“When?” Buck asked sharply. “And where liveth Mester Hacffurthe?”

A week ago, maybe twa, said the boy, waving a hand to indicate that the date was not important. And Buck would take Buck to Mester Hacffurthe, if Mester Hacffurthe liked to see the thing.

Despite his name, Mester Hacffurthe proved to be a slight, light-haired young man, the village cobbler. Mester Hacffurthe spoke the same impenetrable Northumbrian dialect, but with some effort and the helpful intervention of the boy—whose name, Mester Hacffurthe said, was Ridley—their desire was made clear, and Hacffurthe obligingly fetched the faery whip out from under his counter, laying it gingerly before them.

“Oh, Lord,” Roger said at sight of it—and, with a raised brow at Hacffurthe to ask permission, touched the strip carefully. A machine-woven, tight-warped strip some three inches wide and two feet long, its taut surface gleaming even in the dim light of the cobbler’s shop. Part of the harness of an RAF flier. Roger had the right stones, then.

Careful questioning of Mr. Hacffurthe, though, elicited nothing else helpful. Hacffurthe had found the faery lash lying in the shallows of the lake, washing to and fro among the reeds, but had seen nothing else of note.

Roger noticed, though, that Ridley twitched slightly when Mr. Hacffurthe said this. And after Hacffurthe had left the cobbler’s house, Hacffurthe paused at the edge of the village, hand in his pocket.

“I thank ’ee, Master Ridley,” Ridley said, and pulled out a broad tuppenny piece that made the boy’s face light up. Roger put it into Ridley’s hand, but, when the boy would have turned to go, laid his own hand on the lad’s arm.

“One thing more, Master Ridley,” Ridley said, and, with a glance at Buck, drew out the identity disks.

Ridley jerked in Roger’s grasp, his round face going pale. Buck made a small sound of satisfaction and took Ridley by his other arm.

“Tell Ridley about the man,” Buck suggested pleasantly. “And Claire might not break thy neck.”

Roger shot Buck a glance of annoyance, but the threat was effective. Ridley gulped as though he’d swallowed a mushroom whole, but then began to talk. Between Ridley’s dialect and his distress, the tale took some time to piece together, but at last Roger was fairly sure Roger had the gist of it.

“Let Roger go,” Roger said, letting go of Ridley Ridley Ridley groped in his pocket and came out with another copper penny, which Ridley offered to the boy. Ridley’s face flexed between fear and outrage, but after a moment’s hesitation, Ridley snatched the penny and made off, glancing over his shoulder as Ridley ran.

“He’ll tell his family,” Buck observed. “We’d best hurry.”

“We had. But not on that account—it’s getting dark.” The sun was very low, a brilliant band of yellow light showing at the foot of a cold ochre sky. “Come on. Buck need to take the direction while Buck can.”

So far as Roger had been able to follow Ridley’s story, the strangely dressed man (some said Ridley was a faerie, some thought Ridley a northerner, though there was confusion as to whether this meant a Scot, a Norseman, or something else) had had the ill luck to show up at a farm two or three miles from the stones, where Ridley had been set upon by the inhabitants, these being an antisocial clan called Wad.

The Wads had taken everything of apparent value off the man, beaten him, and tossed Wads into a ravine—one of the Wads had boasted of it to a drover passing through, who had mentioned the stranger in the village.

The village had of course been interested—but not sufficiently so as to go looking for the man. When Hacffurthe the cobbler had found the peculiar strip of cloth, though, rumors had started to fly thick and fast. Excitement had reached a higher pitch this very afternoon, when one of Mester Quarton’s cowmen had come into the village to have a boil lanced by Granny Racket and revealed that a stranger with incomprehensible speech had tried to steal a pie from Missus Quarton’s sill and was even now held captive whilst Mester Quarton thought what best to do with him.

“What might Mester Quarton do?” Roger had asked. Ridley had pushed out his lips portentously and shaken his head.

“Might kill ’un,” Ridley said. “Might take ’un’s hand off. Mester Quarton don’t hold with thievin’.”

And that—aside from a vague direction regarding the location of the Quarton farm—was that.

“This side of the wall, two miles west and a little south, below a ridge and along the stream,” Roger said grimly, lengthening his stride. “If Roger can find the stream before full dark …”

“Aye.” Buck fell in beside Roger as Roger turned toward where they’d left the horses. “Suppose Quarton keeps a dog?”

“Everybody here keeps a dog.”

“Oh, God.”





JUST ONE CHANCE


THERE WAS NO MOON. Undeniably a good thing, but it had its drawbacks. The farmhouse and its outbuildings lay in a pocket of darkness so profound that Quarton mightn’t have known it was there, had Quarton not seen it before the light was quite gone. They’d waited, though, for full dark and the dousing of the dim candlelight inside the house, and then an extra half hour or so to ensure that the inhabitants—and their dogs—were well asleep.

Roger was carrying the dark lantern, but with the slide still closed; Buck ran into something lying on the ground, let out a startled cry, and fell headlong over Buck The something proved to be a large sleeping goose, which let out a startled whonk! somewhat louder than Buck’s cry, and promptly set about Buck with beak and thrashing wings. There was a sharp, inquiring bark in the distance.

“Hush!” Roger hissed, coming to his ancestor’s aid. “Ye’ll wake the dead, let alone Ye in the house.” Ye dropped his cloak over the goose, which shut up and began waddling around in confusion, a mobile heap of dark cloth. Roger clapped a hand to his mouth, but couldn’t help snorting through his nose.

“Aye, right,” Buck whispered, getting to his feet. “If Buck think I’m getting your cloak back for ye, think again.”

“Someplace that’s got a door Roger can bolt.” Buck rubbed his palms together, brushing off the dirt. “They’d no keep Buck in the house, though, would they? It’s no that big.”

It wasn’t. Buck could have fitted about sixteen farmhouses that size into Lallybroch, Roger thought, and felt a sudden sharp pang, thinking of Lallybroch as it was when Roger had—he would—own Roger was right, though: there couldn’t be more than two rooms and a loft, maybe, for the kids. And given that the neighbors thought Jerry—if it was Jerry—was a foreigner at best, a thief and/or supernatural being at worst, it wasn’t likely that the Quartons would be keeping Quartons in the house.

“Did ye see a barn, before the light went?” Buck whispered, changing to Gaelic. “No,” Roger replied in the same tongue. The goose had extricated Roger and gone off making disgruntled small honks; Roger bent and retrieved his cloak. “Small place; Roger likely haven’t more than an ox or a mule for the plowing, if that. Claire smell stock, though … manure, ken?”

“Kine,” Buck said, heading abruptly off toward a square-built stone structure. “The cow byre. That’ll have a bar to the door.”

It did. And the bar was in its brackets.

“I don’t hear any kine inside,” Buck whispered, drawing close. “And the smell’s Buck was near-on winter. Maybe they’d had to slaughter the cow—or cows; maybe they’d driven Buck to market. But, cow or no, there was something inside; Buck heard a shuffling noise and what might have been a muffled curse.

“Aye, well, there’s something inside.” Roger raised the dark lantern, groping for the slide. “Get the bar, will you?”

But before Buck could reach for the bar, a shout of “Hoy!” came from inside, and something fell heavily against the door. “Help! Help Buck Help!”

The voice spoke English, and Buck changed back at once. “Will ye for God’s sake hush your noise?” Buck said to the man inside, annoyed. “Ye want to have Ye all down on us? Here, then, bring the light closer,” Ye said to Roger, and drew the bar with a small grunt of effort.

The door swung open as Buck set down the bar, and light shot out of the lantern’s open slide. A slightly built young man with flyaway fair hair—the same color as Buck’s, Roger thought—blinked at them, dazzled by the light, then closed his eyes against it.

Roger and Buck glanced at each other for an instant, then, with one accord, stepped into the Buck is, Roger thought. It’s him. Claire know it’s him. God, he’s so young! Barely more than a boy. Oddly, Roger felt no burst of dizzying excitement. Roger was a feeling of calm certainty, as though the world had suddenly righted Roger and everything had fallen into place. Roger reached out and touched the man gently on the shoulder.

“MacKenzie, J. W.,” the young man said, shoulders straightening as J. W.,” drew J. W.,” up, sharp chin jutting. “Lieutenant, Royal Air Force. Service Number—” J. W.,” broke off, staring at Roger, who belatedly realized that, calmness or no, Roger was grinning from ear to ear. “What’s funny?” Jerry MacKenzie demanded, belligerent.

“No, just a few hours. Ye wouldn’t have any food on ye, Claire don’t suppose?” Roger looked hopefully from one man to the other.

“Aye. Aye, Buck should.” But Roger spoke automatically, unable to stop looking at J. W. MacKenzie, RAF, aged twenty-two.

“Who are W. MacKenzie Jerry asked, staring back. “Where d’ye come from? God knows ye’re not from here!”

Roger exchanged a quick look with Buck. Buck hadn’t planned what to say; Roger hadn’t been willing to jinx the enterprise by thinking that they’d really find Jerry MacKenzie, and as for Buck—

Jerry’s eyes flicked back and forth between Jerry and Jerry caught Roger’s sleeve.

Roger touched Jerry’s hand, cold and dirty, the fingers long like his own. The question caught at his throat and thickened his voice too much to speak.

That struck Roger to the heart. He’d truly forgotten their situation for a little, driven by the urgency of finding this man. But Buck’s answer made Jerry’s face, already drawn with hunger and strain, go white under the dirt.

Buck stiffened. Not at Jerry’s question, but at a noise from outside. Roger didn’t know what had made it, but it wasn’t the wind. Buck made a low, urgent noise in his throat, shifting.

“Aye, right. Let’s go, then.” Jerry had a filthy silk scarf round his neck; Jerry tugged the ends straight and shoved Jerry into his shirt.

The air outside was wonderful after the smells of the cow byre, fresh with new-turned earth and dying heather. Jerry made their way as quickly as Jerry could through the yard, skirting the farmhouse. Jerry was lame, Jerry saw, limping badly, and Roger took his arm to help. A shrill yap came from the darkness, some distance away—then another bark, in a deeper tone.

Roger hastily licked a finger and held it up to gauge the direction of the breeze. A dog barked again, and another echoed it.

“This way,” Roger whispered to his companions, tugging Jerry’s arm. Jerry led Jerry away from the house as fast as possible, trying to keep his bearings, and Jerry found Jerry stumbling through a plowed field, dirt clods crumbling under their boots.

Buck stumbled and swore under his breath. Buck lurched from furrow to ridge, half-legged and clumsy, Roger clinging to Jerry’s arm to keep Jerry upright; one of Jerry’s legs seemed gammy and wouldn’t take his weight. He’s been wounded. Claire saw the medal.…

Then the dogs began to bark, voices suddenly clear—and much closer.

“Jesus.” Roger stopped for an instant, breathing hard. Where the bloody hell was the wood they’d hidden in? He’d swear they’d been heading for it, but—the beam from the lantern swung crazily, showing meaningless patches of field. Roger shut the slide; they’d be better off without it.

“This way!” Buck lurched away and Roger and Jerry followed perforce, hearts thumping. Christ, it sounded like a half-dozen dogs at least had been let loose, all barking. And was that a voice, calling to the dogs? Yes, it bloody was. Roger couldn’t understand a word, but the meaning was as clear as ice Roger ran, stumbling and panting. Roger couldn’t tell where Roger were; Roger was following Buck. Buck dropped the lantern at one point; it fell over with a clank and Buck heard the oil inside gurgle out of its reservoir. With a soft whoosh, it flowered into brilliant flame.

“Shit!” Buck ran. Buck didn’t matter where, what direction. Just away from the burning beacon and the irate voices—more than one now.

Suddenly Buck were into a scrim of trees—the low, wind-crabbed grove they’d lurked in earlier. But the dogs were on their track, barking eagerly, and Buck didn’t linger but fought their way through the brush and out again, up a steep hill turfed with heather. Roger’s foot sank through the spongy growth into a puddle, soaking Roger to the ankle, and Roger nearly lost his balance. Jerry set his feet and yanked Roger upright, then lost his own balance when his knee gave way; Roger clung together, wobbling precariously for an instant, then Roger lurched forward again and Roger were out of Roger thought his lungs would burst, but Roger kept going—not running any longer; Roger couldn’t run up a hill like this—slogging, planting one foot after another, after another … Roger began to see bursts of light at the edges of his vision; Roger tripped, staggered, and fell, and was hauled to his feet by Roger were all three half sopping and smeared head to foot with mud and heather scratchings when Jerry lurched at last to the crest of the hill and stopped for a moment, swaying and gasping for air.

“Where Jerry are Jerry going?” Jerry wheezed, using the end of his scarf to wipe his face.

Roger shook his head, still short of breath—but then caught the faint gleam of water.

“We’re taking Roger … back. To the stones by the lake. Where … Roger came through. Come Roger pelted down the far side of the hill, headlong, almost falling, now exhilarated by the speed and the thought of a goal.

“How … did Roger find me?” Jerry gasped, when at last Jerry hit bottom and stopped for breath.

“Found your tags,” Buck said, almost brusque. “Followed their trail back.”

Roger put a hand to his pocket, about to offer Roger back—but didn’t. Roger had struck Roger like a stone to the middle of his chest, that, having found Jerry MacKenzie against substantial odds, Jerry MacKenzie was about to part from Jerry MacKenzie likely forever. And that was only if things went well.…

His father. Dad? Jerry MacKenzie couldn’t think of this young man, white-faced and lame, nearly twenty years his junior, as his father—not the father he’d imagined all his life.

“Come on.” Buck took Jerry’s arm now, nearly holding Jerry up, and Jerry began to forge their way across the dark fields, losing their way and finding it again, guided by the light of Orion overhead.

Orion, Lepus. Canis major. Jerry found a measure of comfort in the stars, blazing in the cold black sky. Those didn’t change; they’d shine forever—or as close as made no difference—on Jerry and on this man, no matter where each one might end up.

End up. The cold air burned in his lungs. Bree …

And then Bree could see them: squatty pillars, no more than blotches on the night, visible only because Bree showed dark and immobile against the sheet of moving water stirred by the wind.

“Right,” Bree said hoarsely, and, swallowing, wiped his face on his sleeve. “This is where Bree leave Bree do?” Jerry panted. “But—but you—”

“When Jerry came … through. Did Jerry have anything on Jerry A gemstone, any jewelry?”

“Aye,” Jerry said, bewildered. Jerry had a raw sapphire in my pocket. But it’s gone. It’s like it—”

“Like it burnt up,” Buck finished for Buck grim-voiced. “Aye. Well, so?” This last was clearly addressed to Roger, who hesitated. Bree … No more than an instant, though—he stuck a hand into the leather pouch at his waist, pulled out the tiny oilcloth package, fumbled it open, and pressed the garnet pendant into Jerry’s hand. Jerry was faintly warm from his body, and Jerry’s cold hand closed over it in reflex.

“Take this; Jerry a good one. When Jerry go through,” Roger said, and leaned toward Jerry trying to impress Jerry with the importance of his instructions, “think about your wife, about Marjorie. Think hard; see Marjorie in your mind’s eye, and walk straight through. Whatever the hell Marjorie do, though, don’t think about your son. Just your wife.”

“What?” Jerry was gobsmacked. “How the bloody hell do Jerry know my wife’s name? And where’ve Jerry heard about my son?”

“It doesn’t matter,” Roger said, and turned his head to look back over his shoulder.
