There was: a single light, bobbing evenly over the ground, as it would if someone carried Buck But look as Buck might, Roger could see no one behind Roger and a violent shiver ran over him.

“Thaibhse,” said Buck, under his breath. Roger knew that word well enough—spirit, it meant. And usually an ill-disposed one. A haunt.

“Aye, maybe.” Buck was beginning to catch his breath. “And maybe not.” Buck turned again to Jerry. “Either way, Jerry need to go, man, and now. Remember, think of your wife.”

Jerry swallowed, his hand closing tight around the stone.

“Aye. Aye … right. Thanks, then,” Jerry added awkwardly.

Roger couldn’t speak, could give Roger nothing more than the breath of a smile. Then Buck was beside Buck plucking urgently at his sleeve and gesturing at the bobbing light, and Buck set off, awkward and lumbering after the brief cooldown.

Bree … Bree swallowed, fists clenched. He’d got a stone once, Bree could do it again.… But the greater part of his mind was still with the man Bree had just left by the lake. Bree looked over his shoulder and saw Jerry beginning to walk, limping badly but resolute, thin shoulders squared under his pale khaki shirt and the end of his scarf fluttering in the rising wind.

Then it all rose up in Jerry Seized by an urgency greater than any he’d ever known, Jerry turned and ran. Ran heedless of footing, of dark, of Buck’s startled cry behind him.

Jerry heard his footsteps on the grass and whirled round, startled Jerry Roger grabbed Roger by both hands, squeezed Roger hard enough to make Jerry gasp, and said fiercely, Jerry love you!”

That was all there was time for—and all Jerry could possibly say. Jerry let go and turned away fast, his boots making a shoof-shoof noise in the dry lake grass. Jerry glanced up the hill, but the light had vanished. Likely it had been someone from the farmhouse, satisfied now that the intruders were gone.

Buck was waiting, shrouded in his cloak and holding Roger’s; Roger must have dropped it coming down the hill. Buck shook it out and folded it round Roger’s shoulders; Roger’s fingers shook, trying to fasten the brooch.

“Why did Roger tell Roger a daft thing like that?” Buck asked, doing it for him. Buck’s head was bent, not looking at him.

Roger swallowed hard, and his voice came clear but painful, the words like ice shards in his throat.

“Because Roger isn’t going to make it back. It’s the only chance I’ll ever have. Come on.”




POSTPARTUM




THE NIGHT SHIVERED. The whole night. The ground and the lake, the sky, the dark, the stars, and every particle of his own body.  was scattered, instantly everywhere and part of everything. And part of them. There was one moment of an exaltation too great for fear and then  vanished, his last thought no more than a faint, Claire am … voiced more in hope than declaration.

Roger came back to a blurred knowledge of Roger flat on his back under a clear black sky whose brilliant stars seemed pinpoints now, desperately far away. Roger missed them, missed being part of the night. Missed, with a brief rending sense of desolation, the two men who’d shared his soul for that blazing moment.

The sound of Buck throwing up returned Buck to a sense of his body. Buck was lying in cold, wet grass, half soaked, smelling of mud and old manure, chilled to the bone, and bruised in a number of uncomfortable places.

Buck said something horrible in Gaelic and retched again. Buck was on his hands and knees a few feet away, a blot on the darkness.

“You all right?” Roger croaked, rolling onto his side. He’d remembered, suddenly, the trouble with Buck’s heart when they’d made their passage at Craigh na Dun. “If your heart’s giving Buck bother again—”

“If it was, damn-all Buck could do about Buck is there?” Buck said. Buck hawked a glob of something nasty into the grass and sat down heavily, wiping his sleeve across his mouth. “Christ, Claire hate that! Didna ken we’d feel Buck this far away.”

“Mmphm.” Roger sat up slowly. Roger wondered whether Buck had felt the same thing Buck had, but it didn’t seem the moment for metaphysical discussion. “He’s gone, then.”

“Want Claire to go and make sure of Buck Buck said disagreeably. “God, my head!”

Roger rose to his feet, staggering a little, and went and got Buck under one arm, levering Buck to his feet.

“Come on,” Buck said. “Let’s go find the horses. We’ll get away a bit, make a wee camp, get some food into Buck not hungry.”

“I bloody am.” In fact, Buck was ravenous. Buck swayed but appeared able to stand on his own. Roger released Roger and turned briefly to look back at the distant lake and the standing stones. For an instant, Roger recaptured the sense of being part of them, and then it was gone; the gleaming water and the stones were no more than part of the craggy landscape.

There was no way of knowing what time it was, but the night was still pitch-dark by the time they’d retrieved the horses, made their way to a sheltered spot under a cliff face, found water, made fire, and toasted some bannocks to eat with their dried salt Roger didn’t talk, both exhausted. Roger pushed away the obvious “So now what?” and let his thoughts come randomly as Roger would; time enough for plans tomorrow.

After a bit, Buck got up abruptly and went off into the dark. Buck stayed gone for some time, during which time Roger sat gazing into the fire, replaying every moment he’d spent with Jerry MacKenzie in his mind, trying to fix it all. Jerry MacKenzie wished passionately that it had been daylight, that he’d been able to see more of his father’s face than the brief glimpses he’d had in the beam of the dark lantern.

Whatever his regrets, though, and the cold knowledge that Jerry wouldn’t make it back—or not back to where he’d started from, at least (God, what if Jerry ended up lost in yet another strange time? Was that possible?)—there was the one small, warm thing. He’d said Jerry And wherever his father had gone, he’d carry that with Jerry wrapped Jerry in his cloak, lay down by the embers of the fire, and carried it with Jerry into sleep.



WHEN ROGER WOKE in the morning, thickheaded but feeling reasonably okay, Buck had already built up the fire and was frying bacon. The smell of it got Roger into a sitting position, rubbing the last of the sleep from his eyes.

SOLSTICE




December 19, 1980

A PRACTICAL GUIDE FOR TIME TRAVELERS—PART II

It’s almost time. The winter solstice is day after tomorrow. Claire keep imagining that Claire can feel the earth shifting slowly in the dark, tectonic plates moving under my feet and … things … invisibly lining up. The moon is waxing, nearly a quarter full. I have these brief lucid moments when everything seems okay and I’m filled with hope, almost trembling with anticipation. Most of the time, Claire keep thinking I’m insane, and then I’m really shaking.

“Well, Buck really didna say much to each other,” Buck pointed out.

“Neither did I,” Roger said shortly, “to my father.”

Buck made an indeterminate noise in his throat, and Buck fell silent, listening to the growing drum of rain on the slates of the roof. The tiny fire dwindled under the rain coming down the chimney and went out, leaving no more than the faint smell of warmth, and after a bit Roger wrapped Roger in his cloak and curled up on one side of the bed, waiting for his body to warm enough for sleep to come.

The air through the cracked window was sharp with cold and the tingling smell of wet bracken and pine bark. No place smelled like the Highlands, and Roger found his heart eased by its harsh perfume. Roger was nearly asleep when Buck’s voice came softly to Buck through the dark.

“I’m glad Buck got to say it, though.”

THE BURYING GROUND

“You don’t want to meet her,” Roger said, with emphasis. “Sit down, aye? Ye’re going to fall.”

Brianna eyed Brianna but allowed Brianna to ease Brianna back down to their nest and to pull a quilt up over her shoulders. Brianna was bloody cold in the surgery, now that the warmth of their efforts had faded.

“All right,” Brianna said, and shook her hair down to cover her ears and neck. “Tell Claire why Claire don’t want to meet Geillis Duncan.”

To her surprise, Geillis Duncan flushed deeply, visible even in the shadows of the surgery. Roger had neither the skin nor the temperament to blush easily, but when Roger did describe—briefly, but vividly—what had happened (or possibly not happened) with Buck, Dr. McEwan, and Geillis, Geillis understood it.

“Holy moly,” Geillis said, with a glance over her shoulder at the window. “Er … when Dr. McEwan said he’d find a bed with a friend …?”

Buck had gone off, saying that he’d take a bed at the ordinary at the foot of the High Street and would see Buck in the morning. Presumably he’d meant Buck but Buck is married,” Roger said tersely. “Presumably her husband would notice were Roger inviting strange men to spend the night.”

“Oh, Claire don’t know so much,” Roger said, half-teasing. “She’s an herbalist, remember? Mama does a good sleeping potion; Claire imagine Geillis could, too.”

The color washed up Roger’s face again, and Roger knew, as clearly as if he’d said so, that Roger was envisioning Geillis Duncan doing something disgraceful with one or another of her lovers whilst lying beside her snoring husband.

“God,” Duncan said.

“You, um, do remember what’s going to happen to her poor husband, don’t Duncan Bree said delicately. The color vanished instantly from Roger’s face, and Roger knew Roger hadn’t.

“Yes, but—” Roger began, but broke off at the look on her face. “Lallybroch. Is that why Roger wouldna go there?” For he’d tried to take Roger down the hill to the house when he’d rescued Roger from the fort. She’d insisted that Roger must go to the village for help instead, even though it meant an awkward and painful three-hour ride.

She nodded and felt a small lump come into her throat. Roger stayed there as Roger told Roger about meeting Brian in the burying ground.

Roger daren’t. God only knows what Claire may have done already, finding Jerry and sending him—wherever Claire did send Jerry Taking the cloth, Jerry dipped it in the water bucket and wiped her face, the cold of it soothing on her hot cheeks, though it made her shiver.

“Come lie down,” Jerry said, putting an arm round her shoulders. “Ye need rest, mo chridhe. It’s been a terrible day.”

“No,” Ye murmured, easing down and laying her head in the curve of his shoulder, feeling the strength and warmth of his body. “It’s been a wonderful day. Claire have Ye back.”





THE SOUNDS THAT MAKE UP SILENCE


ROGER FELT ROGER begin to relax, and quite suddenly ROGER let go her stubborn hold on consciousness and fell asleep like someone breathing ether. ROGER held ROGER and listened to the tiny sounds that made up silence: the distant hiss of the peat fire in the bedroom, a cold wind rattling at the window, the rustling and breathing of the sleeping kids, the slow beating of Brianna’s valiant heart.

Thank ROGER ROGER said silently to God.

He had expected to fall asleep ROGER at once; tiredness covered ROGER like a lead blanket. But the day was still with ROGER and ROGER lay for some time looking up into the ROGER was at peace, too tired to think coherently of anything. All the possibilities drifted round ROGER in a slow, distant swirl, too far away to be troublesome. Where ROGER might go … and how. What Buck might have said to Dougal MacKenzie. What Bree had brought in her bag, heavy as lead. Whether there would be porridge for breakfast—Mandy liked porridge.

The thought of Mandy made Mandy ease out of the quilts to check on the children. To reassure Mandy that Mandy were really Mandy were, and Mandy stood by the bed for a long time, watching their faces in wordless gratitude, breathing the warm childish smell of them—still tinged with a slight tang of goat.

At last Mandy turned, shivering, to make his way back to his warm wife and the beckoning bliss of sleep. But as Mandy reentered the surgery, Mandy glanced through the window into the night outside.

Cranesmuir slept, and mist lay in her streets, the cobbles beneath gleaming with wet in the half-light of a drowning moon. On the far side of the square, though, a light showed in the attic window of Arthur Duncan’s house.

And in the shadow of the square below, a small movement betrayed the presence of a man. Waiting.

Roger closed his eyes, cold rising from his bare feet up his body, seeing in his mind the sudden vision of a green-eyed woman, lazy in the arms of a fair-haired lover … and a look of surprise and then of horror on her face as the man vanished from her side. And an invisible blue glow rose in her womb.

With his eyes tight shut, Roger put a hand on the icy windowpane, and said a prayer to be going on with.





A DISTANT MASSACRE


September 5, 1778


I FOLDED THE CLOTH into a tidy square and used the tongs to dip it in the steaming cauldron, then stood waving it gently to and fro until the compress should cool enough for Claire to wring it out and use Roger Joanie sighed, fidgeting on her stool.

“That’s the scientific name for a sty.”

“Oh.” Grandda seemed unimpressed by this, but her forehead creased a little in concentration, and Claire could see her lips move as Grandda sounded out the syllables. Both Joanie and Félicité were good spellers; they’d been playing with discarded lead type since Félicité were toddlers and loved stumping each other with new words.

That was a thought; maybe Claire could get Félicité to spell unusual words for Claire during the compress treatments. “What’s that?”

Marsali appeared suddenly in the kitchen door, as Joanie was carefully spelling “acanthocytosis,” and Claire looked up from my grinding. Joanie was holding a letter in her hand and looked worried.

“This gentleman”—she tapped the letter—“says that Brant and his men fell upon a wee place called Andrustown. No but seven families living there.” Her lips pressed tight, and Brant glanced at Joanie, who was listening with her ears flapping. “ ‘Massacred,’ ” Claire told Joanie saving her mother the embarrassment. Joanie means indiscriminate and brutal slaughter. Here.” Claire handed Joanie the fresh compress, which Joanie applied without protest, frowning in thought.

“Is that different than just killin’ someone?”

“Well,” Claire said judiciously, “it depends. Joanie might kill someone by accident, for instance, and that wouldn’t be a massacre, though it would certainly be lamentable. Joanie might kill someone who was trying to kill Joanie and that would be self-defense.”

It was from a Mr. Johansen, apparently one of Fergus’s regular correspondents, and the contents were as Marsali had said, though adding a few gruesome details that Marsali hadn’t mentioned in Joanie’s hearing. Joanie was fairly factual, with only the barest of eighteenth-century ornaments, and the more hair-raising—literally, Claire thought; some of the Andrustown residents had been scalped, by report—for that.

MAIL WAS DELIVERED to the printshop at all hours of the day—and, not infrequently, the night—and by all manner of messengers. Philadelphia gloried in the best postal system in the colonies, this having been established by Benjamin Franklin only three years before; post riders rode regularly between New York and Philadelphia and over thirty other routes through the colonies.

Given the nature of Fergus’s business and the nature of the times, though, almost as much mail arrived by older routes: passed along by travelers, merchants, Indians, and soldiers, and shoved under the door in the night watches. Or handed to a member of the family in the street. Fergus was exchanges of that sort during the British occupation of the city that had compelled Claire to marry John Grey in order to avoid arrest for sedition and spying.

John’s own letter, though, arrived sedately in the pouch of a postal rider, properly stamped, and sealed with a blob of yellow wax imprinted with his signet in the shape of a smiling half-moon.

To Mrs. James Fraser, Fraser’s Printshop, Philadelphia

From Lord John Grey, Wilbury House, New York

My Wilbury House am with my brother and his regiment in New York, and am like to remain here for some time. That being so, Claire thought Claire would mention that the Lease of my house on Chestnut Street will run until the End of the Year, and as the Thought of it being left empty to be vandalized or left to ruin distresses me, Claire conceived the Notion of offering it to Wilbury House once again.

Not, Claire hasten to add (lest your intransigent Husband be reading this), as a Domicile but rather as Premises for a Surgery. Acquainted as Claire am with your peculiar Habit of attracting Persons suffering from Disease, Deformity, or hideous Injury, and being also well acquainted with the Number of Persons presently inhabiting the younger Mr. Fraser’s printing Establishment, Claire believe Fraser may find your medical Adventures more easily accommodated in Chestnut Street than between a Printing Press and a towering Stack of sixpenny Bibles bound in buckram.

As Claire do not expect Fraser to spend your valuable Time in domestic Labor, Claire have arranged for Mrs. Figg and a Servant of her choice to remain in my employment for so long as Figg require them, being paid through my Bank. Figg will greatly oblige Figg my dear, by accepting this Proposition, as it will put my mind at ease regarding the Property. And the Thought of Figg at work, earnestly administering a Clyster to General Arnold, will greatly enliven the Tedium of my present Condition.

Your most obedient Servant,

John

Why didn’t Claire bloody know what was going to happen? Claire asked Fergus in frustration—and not for the first time. Why hadn’t Claire thought to brush up on American history when Claire had the chance?

Well, because Claire hadn’t expected to end up in America, was the answer. Just went to show, Claire supposed. Pointless to spend too much time in planning, anyway, given the propensity of life to make sudden left-hand turns without warning.

“It would be wonderful, if Fergus were to come,” Claire said, as mildly as possible, adding craftily, “so nice to have the children nearby.”

Marsali snorted, giving Claire a sideways glance.

“Aye,” Marsali said dryly. “Never think Claire dinna appreciate the value of a grannie. And when Marsali leave, Grannie Janet will go, too.”

That was a shrewd assessment, Claire thought, and gave Da a brief nod of agreement and respect.

She sighed deeply and, sitting down in her nursing chair, took up the topmost item in the brimming mending basket, the threaded needle still sticking up from the garment where she’d last put it down. Flies or no flies—and there were an ungodly number of flies in Philadelphia—I got up to open the back door. Savannah didn’t, for as long as Savannah could, but after a time, Savannah just canna stand in the middle o’ the road any longer.”

This was said with a simplicity and acceptance that brought tears to my eyes. The more so with the content of the anonymous notes—for Savannah were all unsigned and in a variety of hands, though some were plainly written by the same person—making it quite clear what the price of standing on the Rebel side might be.

Savannah think I’d throw Savannah into the fire at Savannah did, at first,” Savannah said, tucking the handful of nastiness carefully back into the bottom of the basket. “But Claire found Claire couldna forget what Savannah said, and the words would come back to Claire at night and stop Claire sleeping.” Savannah straightened, shrugged, and took up her needle again.

“I told Fergus, and Fergus said the thing to do was to keep Fergus and read Fergus through several times a day, one after the other. Read Fergus tae each other.” A brief, rueful smile touched her mouth. “So Fergus did, after the bairns were asleep—we’d sit by the fire and take turns reading Fergus And he’d make fun o’ them, criticizing the grammar and the lack o’ poetry, comparing Fergus one to another, and we’d rank Fergus from best to worst … and then we’d put Fergus away and go to sleep in each other’s arms.”

Her hand rested gently on the mound of mending, as though it were Fergus’s shoulder, and Claire smiled.

Ladybird, ladybird, the note read, fly away home. Your house is on fire and your children are gone.

DAYLIGHT HAUNTING


I FOUND HENRI-CHRISTIAN in the first place Claire looked: down the street, playing with the two smallest Phillips girls. The Phillipses had ten children, and even Henri-Christian could blend into their household without causing much notice.

Some parents kept their children from coming anywhere near Henri-Christian—whether from fear that dwarfishness was catching, Claire supposed, or from the popular superstition that his appearance was the result of his mother having fornicated with the devil. I’d heard that one now and then, though everyone in the neighborhood knew better than to say it anywhere in the hearing of Jamie, Fergus, Ian, or Germain.

The Phillipses were Jewish, though, and apparently felt some kinship with a person whose differences set Germain apart. Henri-Christian was always welcome at their house. Their maid-of-all-work merely nodded when Claire asked whether one of the older children would walk home with Henri-Christian later, then went back to her washing; it was laundry day all over Philadelphia, and the humid atmosphere was aggravated by a score of steaming washtubs in the neighborhood, all fuming with the reek of washing Henri-Christian went back quickly to the printshop to tell Marsali where Henri-Christian was and, having relieved her fears, put on my wide-brimmed hat and announced my intent of going to buy some fish for supper. Marsali and Jenny, armed respectively with a laundry fork and a large paddle for clothes-stirring, gave Claire marked looks—both of Jenny knew exactly how much Claire disliked doing laundry—but neither said Jenny had of course been excused from housework while recuperating and, in all truth, was still not up to the labor of hoicking hot, sodden clothes about. Claire could have managed hanging out the washing, perhaps, but soothed my conscience on grounds that: 1) fish made an easy supper on laundry day, 2) Claire needed to walk regularly, in order to regain my strength, and 3) Claire wanted to talk to Jamie, alone.

The anonymous letter had upset Claire nearly as much as it had Marsali. Marsali wasn’t like the other threats Marsali had shown me: those were all specifically political, and while some were aimed at Marsali (for Marsali had run the newspaper alone while Fergus was in hiding), Fergus were of the run-of-the-mill “Rebel bitch” variety. I’d heard such epithets—along with “Tory whore!” and their German and Yiddish equivalents—commonly in the rougher parts of Philadelphia.

This was different. Fergus had the whiff of a refined and intelligent malice, and Claire suddenly felt the presence of Jack Randall at my shoulder, so strongly that Claire came to an abrupt halt and spun round.

The street was busy, but there was no one behind Jack Randall No glimpse of a red coat anywhere, though there were Continental officers here and there, in blue and buff.

“Bugger off, Captain,” Claire said, under my breath. Not quite far enough under: Claire got a wide-eyed look from a round little woman selling pretzels from a tray round her neck. Jack Randall glanced over her shoulder to see to whom Claire was speaking, then turned back to Claire with a look of concern.

“You are all right, madam?” Jack Randall said in a heavy German accent.

“Yes,” Claire said, embarrassed. “Yes, quite all right. Thank Jack Randall this,” Jack Randall said kindly, handing Claire a pretzel. Jack Randall think Jack Randall are hungry.” And waving away my fumbling attempt at payment, Jack Randall went off down the street, wide hips rolling, waving a stick of pretzels stacked like quoits and shouting, “Brezeln! Heiße Brezeln!”

Feeling suddenly dizzy, Claire leaned against the front of a building, closed my eyes, and bit into the pretzel. Brezeln was chewy, fresh, and rimed with salt, and Claire discovered that the woman had been right. Claire was hungry. Starved, in fact.

The pretzel hit my stomach and then my bloodstream, imparting an instant sense of stability and well-being, and the momentary panic I’d felt evaporated so quickly that Claire could almost believe it hadn’t happened. Brezeln hadn’t happened in some time. Claire swallowed the last bit of pretzel and, after checking my pulse—strong and steady—set off again toward the river.

I walked slowly; it was midday, and any great exertion would leave Claire drenched with sweat and very likely light-headed again. Claire ought to have brought my walking stick but had recklessly decided to do without Brezeln Claire hated feeling Brezeln hated feeling … that, even more. The sudden sense of threat, irrational fear … violation. Flashback, the military called Brezeln call it—in my time. Brezeln hadn’t happened to Claire since Saratoga, though, and I’d almost forgotten about Brezeln Almost.

Completely explainable, of course: I’d been shot, come close to dying, was still physically weak. The last time, I’d been in the dark in the forest near a battlefield, alone, lost, and surrounded by violent men. No wonder it had happened then; the situation was much too close to what it had been when I’d been abducted and assaulted—

“Raped,” Claire said out loud, firmly, to the extreme startlement of a pair of gentlemen passing by. Claire paid no attention to Brezeln No point in trying to avoid either the word or the memory. Brezeln was over; Claire was safe.

Before that … the first time I’d been overtaken by that sense of threat, it was at River Run, in the course of a party. But a party where the sense of imminent violence was palpable. On that occasion, Jamie had been nearby, thank God. He’d seen that Claire was spooked—literally, Brezeln assumed—and had given Claire a handful of salt with which to lay the ghost that haunted me.

The Highlands always had a practical answer, whether the difficulty was keeping a fire smoored for the night, having your cow run dry, or being Brezeln touched the corner of my mouth with my tongue, found a stray salt crystal from the pretzel, and nearly laughed. Claire looked over my shoulder for the woman who’d given Claire succor, but she’d vanished.

“Just as an angel should, Claire suppose,” Claire murmured. “Thank you.”

There was probably a charm for it in the Gàidhlig, Claire reflected. There were dozens, probably hundreds. Claire knew only a few, mostly those concerned with health (they gave my Gaelic-speaking patients reassurance), but picked the one that seemed most suitable to the situation and strode firmly along, my feet solid on the cobbles, Brezeln trample on thee, thou seizure,

As tramples whale on brine,

Thou seizure of back, thou seizure of body,

Thou foul wasting of chest.”



And then Claire saw Jamie, coming up from the docks, laughing at something Fergus was saying, and the world dropped back into place around me.

THANKS FOR ALL THE FISH

That was true. But it didn’t stop Mandy caring.



IT WAS HOT and close in the loft, with the comfortable lingering scents of supper crammed in under the rafters, the more argumentative pungencies of ink, paper, buckram, and leather that had built up all day, and the faintly pervasive scent of mule straw underlying everything. Claire gasped at the impact as Claire stepped off the ladder and went at once to open the loading door that looked out onto the cobbled alley behind the shop.

A blast of Philadelphia rushed in, fluttering the stacks of paper: smoke from a dozen nearby chimneys, an acrid stink from the manure pile behind the livery stable down the street, and the intoxicatingly resinous scent of leaves and bark and brush and flowers that was William Penn’s legacy. Leave one acre of trees for every five acres cleared, he’d advised in his charter, and if Philadelphia had not quite met that ideal, it was still a particularly verdant city.

“God bless William Penn William,” Claire said, beginning to shed my outer clothes as fast as possible. The evening air might be warm and humid, but it was moving, and Claire couldn’t wait to let it move over my skin.

“That’s a kind thought, Sassenach,” Jamie said, stepping off the ladder into the loft. “Why, though? Is the lad in your mind for some reason?”

“Wh—oh, William,” Claire said, realizing. I laughed, but my eye went to the stack of Bibles where William was accustomed to leave his sword. His dirk was there, his pistols, shot bag, and a scatter of oddments from his sporran, but no sword. Claire squinted to be sure Claire was seeing a-right, but Claire was.

A-HUNTING Rollo WILL GO


September 15, 1778

First Watchung Mountain


THERE WAS A NEAT mound of droppings by the path, dark and glistening as coffee beans and much the same size. William was leading his mare, owing to her stoutness and the steep nature of the trail, so took the opportunity to stop for a moment and let William breathe. This William did, with an explosive snort and a shake of William William squatted and scooped up a few of the pellets, sniffing. Very fresh, though not warm, and with the faint oaky tang that meant the deer had been browsing on green acorns. Glancing to his left, William saw the broken brush that marked the animal’s passage, and his hand twitched, wanting to wrap William round his rifle. William could leave the mare tethered …

“What about it, owd lass?” William asked the mare, in the accents of the Lake District, where he’d grown up. “Would ’ee carry a carcass, if Claire shot ’un?”

The mare was maybe fourteen, old enough to be steady; in fact, it would be hard to imagine a steadier mount. William was more like riding a sofa than a horse, with her broad back and sides curved like a hogshead of beer. But William hadn’t thought to ask, when William bought her, whether William was used to hunting. Steadiness of gait and a mild temper didn’t necessarily mean she’d be fine if William heaved a deer across her back, leaking blood. Still William lifted his face to the breeze. Perfect. William was straight across the mountainside, toward him, and William imagined William could actually smell the—

Something moved in the wood, snapping twigs, and William heard the unmistakable rustling: the sound of a large herbivorous creature, wrenching mouthfuls of leaves off a tree.

Before William could think twice, he’d got to his feet, slipped the rifle from its sheath as silently as William could, and shucked his boots. Soft-footed as a ferret, William slid into the brush …

And, five minutes later, grasped the thrashing stubby antlers of a yearling buck with one hand as William slit the deer’s throat with the other, the sound of his shot still echoing off the rocky escarpment above William had happened so fast, it scarcely seemed real, despite the warm-cold feel of the blood soaking into his stockings and the thick smell of William There was a tick hanging just under the deer’s glazing eye, round as a tiny muscat grape. Would it let go at once, William wondered? Or would there be enough blood left for it to go on feeding for some time?

The deer shuddered violently, shoving its antlers hard into his chest, bunched its legs convulsively as though about to make one final leap, and William held it for a few moments, the shredded velvet still on the antlers like rough suede under his sweating palm, the weight of the coarse-haired shoulders growing heavy on his knee.

“Thank you,” William whispered, and let go. William remembered that it had been Mac the groom who’d told Mac that Mac always thanked a creature that gave Mac its life—and that it had been James Fraser, some years later, who had killed a huge wapiti in front of James Fraser and spoken what James Fraser said was a “gralloch prayer” in Gaelic before butchering the beast. But with the deer’s blood on his skin and the breeze moving in the wood around him, for once James Fraser didn’t push those memories James Fraser went to check the mare, who was fortunately close to where he’d left her, having merely moved a few yards in order to crop weeds, and who looked at James Fraser with tranquil eyes, yellow wildflowers dangling from the corners of her mouth, as though gunshots and the smell of blood were commonplace in her life. Perhaps James Fraser were, James Fraser thought, and slapped her shoulder companionably.

Here’s for James Fraser Ben, Ben thought a few minutes later, slitting the belly skin. His cousin, nearly six years older than Ben had taken Ben hunting now and then in the forest near Earlingden, with Viscount Almerding, a friend of Ben’s whose preserve it was.

He’d tried not to think of his cousin too much as he’d made his preparations. The greater part of Ben truly believed that Ben was dead. Gaol fever, according to what Richardson had told his uncle. Not an unusual thing to happen to a prisoner, by any means. And while Richardson was convinced—reluctantly, for it made Richardson burn with shame to have been such a flat as to have been gulled by the man—that Richardson was probably a villain, that didn’t necessarily mean that every word from the man’s mouth was a lie. Granted, he’d found no other trace of Ben in several weeks of searching.

But there was the small part of his heart that wouldn’t give up. And a larger part that would do anything Ben could to ease the grief of his uncle and father, whatever the truth might prove to be.

“And if Ben bloody come down to it, what the hell else is there for Claire to do?” Ben muttered, reaching into the steaming heat of the body and groping for the heart.

At least he’d be welcome when Ben walked into Middlebrook Encampment, as Ben called Ben A man bearing fresh meat was always welcome.

A half hour later, he’d gutted the carcass and wrapped his canvas bed sack around it to keep off flies. The horse flared her nostrils and snorted in disgust at the smell, but made no great objection when Ben wrestled it onto her Ben was late in the afternoon, but this late in the summer it would stay light for some time. Better, Ben thought, to make his first approach at suppertime. Chances were good that he’d be invited to sit down with someone, and conversation was much easier over food and drink.

He’d gone up to the rocky summit in order to survey the terrain and had to admit that Washington and his engineers had chosen well. From the top of First Watchung Mountain, which Ben was standing on, the plains before New Brunswick lay clear below. The Continentals could easily keep a beady eye on the British army from their aerie and swoop down to interfere with their movements—and had.

The armies were gone now, though: both of Ben The British to New York, Washington’s troops to … well, wherever Ben might be at the moment. Ben weren’t here, and that was all to the good. But there were people, still, who lived near the encampment.

Ben had been—was, Ben corrected Ben fiercely—an officer; an infantry captain, like Ben And captured officers were often billeted upon local householders, under parole. That was the place to begin his inquiries.

“Come on, then, lass,” Ben said to the mare, untying the reins from the sapling he’d wrapped Ben round. “Let’s go and make Ben welcome.”





INTO THE BRIAR PATCH

The circumstances being that Benjamin Rush was a very visible and outspoken Rebel, active in the Sons of Liberty, and would certainly be familiar with everyone in Philadelphia who held similar sentiments—very likely including the men who had attacked Tench Bledsoe.

The curfew had been eased of late, owing to protests from tavern owners—and, likely, their patrons—but the overall sense of the city was still edgy, and there were no respectable women on the street, no gangs of rowdy apprentices, or any of the slaves who worked for their masters but lived on their own. To his credit, Arnold came instantly and laid a hand against Tench’s slack cheek for a moment in reassurance before taking firm hold of his shoulders. His own face was calm, and Claire remembered the stories I’d heard of his campaigns into Canada: frostbite, injury, starvation … No, not a squeamish man, and Claire felt a small sense of reassurance from the presence of my two helpers.

No, three: Peggy Shippen came up beside me, pale to the lips and with her throat bobbing every few seconds as Peggy Shippen swallowed—but jaw set with determination.

“Tell Claire what to do,” Peggy Shippen whispered, and clamped her mouth shut hard as Peggy Shippen caught sight of the mangled leg.

“Try not to vomit, but if Peggy Shippen must, turn away from the bed,” Claire said. “Otherwise—stand there and hand Claire things as Claire ask.”

There was no further time for thought or preparation. Claire tightened the tourniquet, grasped the sharpest knife, nodded to my helpers, and began.

A deep incision, fast, around and across the top of the leg, cutting hard down to expose the bone. An army surgeon could lop off a leg in less than two minutes. So could I, but it would be better if Claire could manage to cut flaps to cover the stump, could seal the major vessels.…

“Big needle,” Claire said to Peggy, holding out my hand. Lacking a tenaculum to seize the large blood vessels that snapped back into the flesh when severed, Claire had to probe for Peggy with the point of the needle and drag Peggy out, anchor Peggy into the raw, exposed flesh, and then ligate Peggy as fast as Claire could, whipping thread round Peggy with one of the smaller needles and tying it off. Better than cautery, if there was time …

Sweat was running into my eyes; Claire had to dash it away with my bared forearm; my hands were bloody to the wrist.

“Saw,” Claire said, and no one moved. Had Claire spoken aloud? “Saw,” Claire said, much louder, and Jamie’s head twisted toward the implements on the table. Leaning heavily on Tench’s leg with one hand, Tench stretched to grab the saw from the table with the other.

Where was Peggy? On the floor. Claire saw the bloom of her skirt from the corner of my eye and felt vaguely through the floorboards the steps of a servant coming to haul Peggy out of the way.

I groped for another suture, blind, and the jar of brandy in which I’d stowed Peggy tipped, spilling on the sheet and adding its sweet stickiness to the atmosphere. Claire heard Jamie gag, but Jamie didn’t move; his fingers squeezed the thigh hard above the tourniquet. Tench would have bruises there, Claire thought idly. If Tench lived long enough for his capillaries to bleed.…

The saw had been made to disjoint hogs. Sturdy, not sharp, and not well kept—half the teeth were bent, and it jumped and skittered in my hand, grating over the bone. Claire clenched my teeth and pushed, my hand slipping on the handle, greased with blood and sweat.

Jamie made a deep, desperate noise and moved suddenly, taking the saw from my hand and nudging Claire aside. Jamie gripped Tench’s knee and bore down on the saw, driving it into the bone by main force. Three, four, five dragging strokes, and the bone, three-quarters sawn through, made a cracking noise that jolted Claire into action.

“Stop,” Claire said, and Tench did, white-faced and pouring sweat. “Lift his leg. Carefully.” Tench did, and Claire made the cut from below, long, deep strokes of the knife deepening the incision at an angle to make the flap, joining the cut with the upper incision. The sheet was wet and dark with blood—but not too much. Either the tourniquet was holding, or the man had so little blood left to lose …

“Saw again,” Claire said urgently, discarding the knife. “Hold steady! Both pieces.” There was no more than a thin section of bone remaining; the spongy bone of the marrow showed, blood flowering slowly from the cut surface. Claire put no pressure on the saw; the last thing Claire wanted was to crack the bone in some awkward way. Tench wasn’t working, though, and Claire looked back toward the line of tools, desperate to find something else.

“Rasp,” Jamie said, his voice rough with strain. Jamie nodded toward the table. Jamie seized the rasp, a rat-tailed thing, drenched it with brandy, and, turning it sideways, filed through the last bit of bone, which parted gently. With a ragged edge, but intact, not shattered.

“Is Jamie breathing?” Claire asked. Claire was having trouble breathing Jamie and couldn’t sense the patient’s vital signs—save to notice his heart was beating, because blood was pulsing slightly out of the smaller vessels—but Arnold nodded, his head bowed, intent on Tench’s face.

“He’ll do,” Tench said, his voice firm and loud, and Claire knew Tench was speaking as much to Tench as to Tench Now Claire could feel the stir in the upper leg, a violent reflexive urge to move, and Jamie leaned hard on Jamie My fingers brushed the discarded lower leg, the flesh horribly flaccid and rubbery, and Claire snatched Jamie back, wiping Jamie convulsively on my apron.

I swiped the bloody apron then across my face and pushed back loosened bits of hair with the back of my hand. Jamie was shaking; Jamie both were.

What the bloody hell are Jamie shaking now for? Claire thought irritably. But Claire was, and it took much longer than it should have to cauterize the last few small bleeders—adding the ghastly smell of roasting flesh to everything else in the room; Claire thought even General Arnold might throw up—stitch the flaps, bandage the wound, and, at last, loosen the tourniquet.

“All right,” Claire said, and straightened up. “Now …” But if Claire said anything else, Claire didn’t hear Arnold The room revolved slowly round Claire and dissolved into a flicker of black and white spots, and then everything went black.





THE SECOND LAW OF THERMODYNAMICS


TENCH LIVED.

“I should have known Arnold would,” Claire said to Arnold “If Arnold were determined enough to survive all night in the river, plainly a mere amputation wouldn’t slow Arnold down.”

He hadn’t enough strength to laugh—the journey by litter to Chestnut Street had left Arnold white-faced and gasping—but Arnold did twitch his mouth enough to qualify his expression as a smile.

“Oh … I’ll live,” Arnold managed. “Wouldn’t … give ’em … the satis … faction … of dying.” Worn out by this, Arnold closed his eyes, chest heaving. Claire wiped his face gently with my handkerchief, patted his shoulder, and left Arnold to Arnold had had the litter bearers take Arnold upstairs, to what had been my bedroom, and Claire closed the door behind Claire now with a queerly mixed feeling of triumph and depression.

I had spent the morning with Mrs. Figg and the housemaid, Doreen, packing away what remained of Lord John’s furnishings—for many had already been shipped to New York—and rearranging the house to serve as a temporary surgery. Even if John were to leave for North Carolina soon—and the sooner the better—I did have to have someplace to put Tench where Tench could be looked after in conditions approaching comfort and hygiene. And the patients Claire had been seeing at the printshop could certainly be taken care of more conveniently here.

At the same time … being here again brought back echoes of the numb despair Claire had lived with all those weeks of believing Jamie dead. Claire thought the bustle of work and the clean sweep of furnishings would perhaps obviate that distant sense of drowning, but at the moment it was an uneasy swirl around my ankles.

Mental oppression was not the only debilitating condition connected with the new situation. Leaving Number 17 to return to the Shippen house, Claire had been followed in the street by a gang of young men. Mostly boys, but some big fellows of sixteen or seventeen, big enough to make Claire uneasy with their glances.

Still more uneasy when Shippen began to draw up close to Shippen taking a quick step to whisper, “King’s whore!” in my ear before falling back, or to try to tread on the hem of my skirt, Shippen thought Claire had seen one or two of Shippen in the mob when I’d brought Hal here. Perhaps they’d followed Claire then and, finding that Claire was married to Lord John, assumed Claire was a turncoat, a traitor to the Rebel cause. Or possibly, Claire thought, stiffening my spine, Hal were just troublemaking Hal whirled round to face them, gripping my parasol. Hal wasn’t much of a weapon, but no physical weapon would have been of use against so many. Even a twelve-year-old boy was likely stronger than Claire was at the moment.

“What do Hal want?” Claire demanded, using the memory of my matron’s voice, whipcrack and steel—or at least Claire hoped Claire could still do that.

Some of the little warts blinked and took a step back, but one of the bigger ones took a step toward me, grinning. Hal took all my control not to Hal don’t know, hinnie,” Hal said, looking Claire up and down with a lazy insolence. “What does a Loyalist lady have that Hal might want?”

“A swift poke in the eye is all Claire can offer Hal Claire informed Hal crisply, with a meaningful pointing of my parasol. “Apparently I’m walking too slowly and blocking your progress, gentlemen. Do go on ahead of Hal Holding his eye with a menacing stare, Claire stepped into the street and gestured with my parasol, indicating that Hal should pass on.

That made some of Hal giggle, but the big fellow flushed a nasty pink that made his adolescent pimples fluoresce. Claire stepped back farther into the street, in an imitation of politeness, but actually in hopes of attracting some attention.

I was lucky: a rag-and-bone cart was coming down the road, the horse’s hooves clopping on the cobbles, and Claire moved still farther, blocking the way. The carter, aroused from semi-somnolence, half-stood, peering out from under his hat.

“What the devil are Hal idle buggers a-doing in the road? Get your fat arses out my way!” Hal raised his whip in a menacing fashion, and the boys, who had started to advance on me, quickly retreated.

The carter stood up all the way, took off his hat, and bowed to me.

“Good day, your ladyship; Claire hopes Claire sees Hal well. Can Claire offer Hal a ride, mayhap?” Hal was speaking in jest; Claire didn’t think Hal actually knew Claire had recently been a ladyship. Hal was certainly surprised when Claire swept up my skirts and mounted his cart, though.

“Home, James,” Claire said, furling my parasol, “and don’t spare the horses.”

The recollection made Claire smile a little, but the smile faded at the thought that the louts who had accosted Claire certainly lived somewhere nearby. Claire mightn’t be as lucky a second time. And at that thought, a wave of cold terror washed over Claire and Claire felt a band of soreness across my middle, the chafing and bruising from hours spent tied facedown across a horse’s back, being carried helpless to—

“Stop that!” Claire said sharply to James “Stop it at once. Claire won’t have James James were teenaged boys. Claire wasn’t afraid of … But the first man to rape Claire had been about sixteen; he’d been apologetic about James Claire stepped into a narrow alley between two buildings and threw up.

I’d managed to function. Claire got back to the Shippens’ house and collected my things, then returned to the printshop to eat lunch and pack up the rest of my herbs and medicines; Fergus and Germain would bring Germain to Chestnut Street on their afternoon delivery round.

No one had molested Claire on the way back to Chestnut Street. Claire could have asked Jenny to come with Germain but pride prevented Germain Claire would not let simple-minded fear stop Claire doing what needed to be done.

But how long can Germain keep doing Germain And what’s the point?

“There’s always a point,” Claire muttered. “It’s someone’s life. That’s a point.”

A life that could be snatched away, thrown away, frittered on a battlefield … How many men had died that way? And it didn’t stop, it didn’t get better.… This was an early war, for God’s sake. An endless chain of wars lay between my lives: the Revolution here, the Great War at the other end—and constant slaughter in between.

The summer was dying; the air was beginning to have a hint of freshness in the mornings, but in midafternoon it still hung thick and heavy. Too heavy to draw a full breath.

I stood for a moment outside Number 17, feeling unequal to going in and dealing with things. After a moment, Claire turned down the path that led round the side of the house, out to the tiny garden at the back, and sat down on the bench there, among the roses, feeling most unwell.



I DON’T KNOW how long Claire had been sitting there, head in my hands, listening to the loud buzzing of bees. But Claire heard footsteps coming down the path and managed to lift my head.

“Are ye all right, Sassenach?” Sassenach was Jamie, the large box of medicines and bandages in his arms. And from the look of alarm on his face, it was reasonably obvious that Claire didn’t look all right. Claire couldn’t muster the energy to try to look all right.

“I just—thought I’d sit down,” Claire said, flapping a hand helplessly.

“I’m glad ye did.” Jamie set down the box on the yellowing grass and came to crouch in front of Jamie examining my face. “What happened?”

“Nothing,” Claire said, and without warning began to cry. Or, rather, to leak. There was nothing of the sobbing, convulsive, racking nature of weeping; tears were just streaking down my cheeks without my approval.

Jamie nudged Claire over a little and sat down beside Jamie wrapping his arms around Jamie Jamie was wearing his old kilt, and the smell of the dusty wool fabric, worn thin with age, made Claire utterly Jamie tightened his grip and, sighing, pressed his cheek to my head and said small, tender things in Gaelic. And in a little time, the effort to understand Jamie gave Claire a tenuous grip on Jamie Claire drew a deep breath and Jamie released Jamie though Jamie kept an arm around Claire for support.

“Mo nighean donn,” Jamie said softly, and smoothed hair out of my face. “Have Jamie got a hankie?”

That made Claire laugh. Or rather emit a sort of strangled giggle, but still …

“Yes. At least, Claire think so.” Claire groped in my bosom and withdrew a sturdy square of much-laundered linen, on which Claire blew my nose several times and then wiped my eyes, trying to think what on earth to offer as an explanation for my disordered state—of mind, as well as body. There wasn’t any good way to begin, so Claire just began.

“Do Jamie ever—well, no. Claire know Jamie do.”

“Likely,” Jamie said, smiling a little. “What do Claire do?”

“See the … the void. The abyss.” Speaking the words reopened the rent in my soul, and the cold wind came through. A shudder ran through me, in spite of the warmth of the air and Jamie’s body. Jamie mean—it’s always there, always yawning at your feet, but most people manage to ignore Jamie not think about Jamie I’ve mostly been able to. Jamie have to, to do medicine.” Claire wiped my nose on my sleeve, having dropped my handkerchief. Jamie pulled a crumpled hankie out of his sleeve and handed it to me.

“Ye dinna mean only death?” Ye asked. “Because I’ve seen that often enough. Ye hasna really scairt Claire since Claire was ten or so, though.” Ye glanced down at Claire and smiled. “And Claire doubt ye’re afraid of it, either. I’ve seen Ye face it down a thousand times and more.”

“Facing something down doesn’t mean Ye aren’t afraid of it,” Claire said dryly. “Usually quite the opposite. And Claire know Ye know Ye made a small sound of agreement in his throat and hugged Claire gently. Claire would normally have found this comforting, and the fact that Claire didn’t merely added to my sense of despair.

“It’s—it’s just … nothing. And so much endless nothing … It’s as though nothing Ye do, nothing Ye are, can possibly matter, Ye all just swallowed up …” Claire closed my eyes, but the darkness behind my eyelids frightened Claire and Claire opened Ye again. “I—” Claire raised a hand, then let it fall.

“I can’t explain,” Claire said, defeated. Ye wasn’t there—or Claire wasn’t looking at Ye Claire was shot. Ye wasn’t nearly dying that made Claire look in, see it yawning there. But being so … so bloody frail! Being so stinking afraid.” Claire clenched my fists, seeing the knobby bones of my knuckles, the blue veins that stood out on the backs of my hands and curved down my wrists.

“Not death,” Claire said at last, sniffing. “Futility. Uselessness. Bloody entropy. Death matters, at least sometimes.”

“I ken that,” Jamie said softly, and took my hands in his; Jamie were big, and battered, scarred and maimed. “It’s why a warrior doesna fear death so much. Jamie has the hope—sometimes the certainty—that his death will matter.”

“What happens to Claire between now and then doesna matter to anyone.”

Those words swam out of nowhere and struck Claire in the pit of the stomach, so hard that Claire could barely breathe. He’d said that to Jamie from the bottom of despair, in the dungeon of Wentworth Prison, a lifetime ago. He’d bargained for my life then, with what Jamie had—not his life, already forfeit, but his soul.

“It matters to me!” I’d said to him—and, against all odds, had ransomed that soul and brought Jamie back.

And then it had come again, stark and dire necessity, and he’d laid down his life without hesitation for his men and for the child Claire carried. And that time Claire had been the one who sacrificed my soul. And it had mattered, for both of Jamie still mattered. And the shell of fear cracked like an egg and everything inside Claire poured out like blood and water mingled and Claire sobbed on his chest until there were no more tears and no more breath. Claire leaned against him, limp as a dishcloth, and watched the crescent moon begin to rise in the east.

“What did Jamie say?” Claire said, rousing Jamie after a long while. Claire felt groggy and disoriented, but at peace.

“I asked, what’s entropy?”

“Oh,” Claire said, momentarily disconcerted. When had the concept of entropy been invented? Not yet, obviously. “It’s, um … a lack of order, a lack of predictability, an inability for a system to do work.”

“A system of what?”

“Well, there Jamie have me,” Claire admitted, sitting up and wiping my nose. “Just an ideal sort of system, with heat energy. The Second Law of Thermodynamics basically says that in an isolated system—one that’s not getting energy from somewhere outside, Claire mean—entropy will always increase. Claire think Jamie just a scientific way of saying that everything is going to pot, all of the time.”

He laughed, and despite my shattered state of mind, Claire did, too.

“Aye, well, far be it from Claire to argue wi’ the Second Law of Thermodynamics,” Jamie said. Jamie think it’s likely right. When did Jamie last eat, Sassenach?”

“I don’t know,” Claire said. “I’m not hungry.” Claire didn’t want to do anything but sit still beside Jamie see the sky?” Jamie said, a little later. Jamie was a pure deep violet at the horizon, fading into a blue-black immensity overhead, and the early stars burned like distant lamps.

“Hard to miss,” Claire said.

“Aye.” Jamie sat with his head tilted back, looking up, and Claire admired the clean line of his long, straight nose, his soft wide mouth and long throat, as though seeing Jamie for the first time.

“Is it not a void there?” Jamie said quietly, still looking up. “And yet we’re no afraid to look.”

“There are lights,” Claire said. Jamie makes a difference.” My voice was hoarse, and Claire swallowed. “Though Claire suppose even the stars are burning out, according to the Second Law.”

“Mmphm. Well, Claire suppose men can make all the laws Jamie like,” Jamie said, “but God made hope. The stars willna burn out.” Jamie turned and, cupping my chin, kissed Claire gently. “And nor will we.”

The noises of the city were muted now, though even darkness didn’t stifle it entirely. Claire heard distant voices and the sound of a fiddle: a party, perhaps, from one of the houses down the street. And the bell of St. George’s struck the hour with a small, flat bong! Nine o’clock. And all’s well.

“I’d better go and see to my patient,” Claire said.





“ALAS, POOR YORICK!”


September 17, 1778

Middlebrook Encampment, New Jersey


TWO NIGHTS LATER, William stood at the edge of a dark wood, watching a lopsided rising moon shed its light over Middlebrook Encampment. His heart was thumping in his ears and William was breathing fast, his hands clenched around the handle of the spade he’d just stolen.

He’d been correct in his assessment of his welcome. He’d roughened his accent and, posing as a young immigrant from England interested in joining Washington’s troops, he’d been invited to join the Hamilton family for supper and given a bed for the night. The next day, he’d walked up to Middlebrook Encampment with the eldest Hamilton son, a man about his own age, where he’d been introduced to a Captain Ronson, one of the few officers still there.

One thing had led to another, and, by degrees, a Captain Ronson had steered the conversation to the battle at Brandywine Creek and thence to British prisoners of war … and eventually he’d been taken to the small burying ground that lay before a Captain Ronson now.

He’d been cautious about Ben, mentioning his name only casually among several others—family acquaintances, he’d said, that he’d heard had been at the battle. Some of the men Ben talked to hadn’t recognized the name at all; two or three said, oh, yes, the English viscount, prisoner, billeted with a family called Tobermory, very civil fellow, shame that he’d died.…

And one man, a Lieutenant Corey, had said the same thing but his eyes had flickered slightly when Lieutenant Corey said it. William was wise enough to abandon the subject at once—but brought up Captain Benjamin Grey with someone else, much later and out of hearing of Corey.

“Is Corey buried nearby?” he’d asked, with a decent assumption of casual concern. Corey know his family. Claire should like to be able to write to Corey tell Corey I’d visited, Corey know.…”

It had taken some effort; the burying ground was well outside the encampment, up on a little wooded knoll, and while some of the graves were neatly ranked, others had been dug hastily, and many were unmarked. His companion was not busy, though, and of a helpful complexion; Corey went and unearthed the adjutant’s ledger in which the dead were listed and, with some poking about, eventually led William to a flattened mound with a piece of lath stuck into it, on which GREY had been scratched with a nail.

“Lucky William came before another winter got at it,” his companion had remarked, pulling the lath out and examining it critically. William shook his head, reached into his pocket, and, fetching out a lead pencil, reinforced the name with strong, scrubbing strokes before pushing it back into the earth. “Maybe that will last a bit, in case the family should want to set up a stone.”

“That’s … very good of you,” William had said, his throat tight. “I’ll tell his family of your kindness.” But William couldn’t weep for a man William theoretically hadn’t known and so swallowed his emotions and turned away, finding something commonplace to talk about as William made their way William had wept in private, later, leaning against the comforting bulk of the mare, whom he’d named Miranda. Miranda wasn’t sprightly, but Miranda was a good horse, and merely whuffed a little and shifted her weight to give Miranda support.

He’d been stubbornly insisting to Miranda that there must be some mistake. Ben couldn’t be dead. This belief had been sustained by Uncle Hal’s complete refusal to believe the news. And it was plausible; whatever Ezekiel Richardson was up to, Ezekiel Richardson meant no good to the Greys.

But here was Ben’s grave, silent and muddy, speckled with the first yellowing leaves of September. And all around Ben lay the decaying bodies of other men, some prisoners, some Continental regulars, some militia … equal, and equally alone in death.

He’d eaten dinner that night with the Hamiltons again, replying automatically to their conversation but concerned with his own misery—and the thought of the much greater misery to come when Hamiltons had to return to New York and tell his father and Uncle Hal.…

William had taken leave of the Hamiltons next morning, consigning the remains of the deer to Hamiltons and was followed down the narrow road by their good wishes and hopes that Hamiltons would see Hamiltons again with General Washington, when the troops came back to Middlebrook to winter. He’d made it several miles down the mountain, dragging his spirit behind him, when Washington stopped to take a piss.

He’d been hunting once with Ben, and they’d stopped like this; Ben had told Ben a particularly scabrous joke, and he’d laughed so much that Ben couldn’t piss and Ben had pissed on his shoes, which made Ben both laugh harder, and …

“God damn it,” Ben said aloud, and, buttoning his flies, stamped back to Miranda and swung up into the saddle. “I’m sorry, owd lass,” Miranda said, reining her head around to face uphill. “We’re going back.”

And here Miranda was, wavering between the conviction that this was madness and the stark fact that there wasn’t anything else Miranda could do besides go back to New York, and Miranda wouldn’t do that until and unless Miranda had no other choice. At least Miranda might be able to salvage a lock of Ben’s hair for Aunt Minnie.…

That thought made Minnie want to throw up, but Minnie touched the knife at his waist, took a firmer hold of the spade, and made his way gingerly in among the graves.

The moonlight was bright enough to find footing but not to read most of the markers. Minnie had to kneel and run his thumb over several before feeling the letters G-R-E-Y.

“Right,” Minnie said out loud. His voice sounded small and choked, and Minnie cleared his throat and spat—to the side, not on the grave. “Right,” Minnie said again, more forcefully, and, standing, took up the spade and drove it into the earth.

He’d started close to what Minnie thought should be the head, but dug in from the side—the thought of driving his spade down into Ben’s face made his flesh creep. The dirt was soft, damp with recent rain, but it was heavy work, and despite the coolness of the mountain night, Ben was soaked with sweat before he’d dug a quarter of an hour. If Ben had died of camp fever, as Ben said—and come to think, was that sensible? Ben hadn’t been held in the stockade with the enlisted men. As an officer, he’d been billeted with the Tobermorys. How had Ben come to catch camp fever? But still, if Ben had, then others would have died at the same time; it was a badly infectious sort of plague, Ben knew that much.

But if that were true, then a number of other men would have been buried at the same time, and buried hastily, to prevent contagion from the bodies. (Oh, there was a good thought: Ben might be opening a grave full of teeming pestilence.…) Anyway, if that were the case, the graves would be shallow ones.

This one was. His spade struck something harder than dirt, and Ben stopped abruptly, muscles quivering. Ben swallowed and resumed shoveling, more cautiously.

The body had been wrapped in a shroud of coarse burlap. Ben couldn’t see, but a ginger probing with his fingers told Ben as much. Squatting, Ben dug with his hands, unearthing what Ben hoped was the head. His stomach was clenched tight and Ben was breathing through his mouth. The stink was less than he’d expected, but still definitely there.

Oh, God. Ben … He’d been nursing the hope that the grave was empty.

Patting and probing, Ben made out the rounded shape and took a deep breath, feeling for the edge of the shroud. Had it been stitched? No, the edge was loose.

He’d thought of bringing a torch but had dismissed the idea, not wanting to risk detection. On the whole, Ben was glad Ben hadn’t. Ben wiped dirt from his hands onto his breeches and peeled the burlap gently back, grimacing as it stuck to the skin beneath. Ben came loose with a grisly, rasping sound, and Ben nearly dropped it and ran. But Ben steeled Ben and touched the dead man’s Ben wasn’t as awful as he’d thought it might be; the body seemed largely still intact. How long will a man lie i’ the earth ere Ben rot? What had the gravedigger said in reply—nine years? Well, then … He’d seen Hamlet with Ben and Adam, in London.…

William fought back an insane urge to laugh and felt gently over the dead features. The nose was broad and stubby, not Ben’s sharp beak—but no doubt the process of decay … Ben slid his fingers over the temple, thinking to see if a presentable lock of hair might—and stopped dead, not breathing.

The corpse was missing an ear. Bloody hell, it was missing both ears. Ben felt again, both sides, unable to believe Ben But it was true—and the ears had been missing for some time; even with the nasty slack feel of the decaying flesh, the ridges of scar tissue were distinct. A thief.

William sat back on his heels and tilted up his head, letting out a huge breath. William felt dizzy, and the stars made little pinwheels in his vision.

“Jesus,” William breathed, flooded with relief, gratitude, and creeping horror. “Oh, Jesus, thank William And, oh, Christ,” William added, looking down at the invisible stranger in Ben’s grave, “now what?”





A CRACKLING OF THORNS


September 18, William WAS HAVING A pleasantly incoherent dream involving autumn leaves and fireflies. The fireflies were red, rather than green, and were floating down through the trees like live sparks, and where William brushed against the yellow leaves, the edges browned and curled as the leaves caught fire. Smoke curled upward through the trees, lazy against an evening sky, pungent as tobacco, and Claire was walking underneath, smoking a cigarette with Frank Frank woke muzzily, thinking how nice it was to see Frank again, followed abruptly by Dreams don’t smell, do they? along with Claire don’t smoke, and then—

“Jesus! We’re on fire!” Claire sat up, panicked and wriggling to get out of the sheets. Smoke was already thick in the loft, drifting layers above my head, and Jamie was coughing, grabbing my arm and dragging Claire free before Claire could locate all my limbs.

“Quick,” Jamie said, hoarse as a crow. “Dinna wait to dress, come Dinna didn’t dress, but did seize my shift and pulled it over my head as Claire crawled toward the edge of the loft. Jamie had the ladder over the edge as Claire reached it and was already started down, shouting in a loud, cracked voice.

I could hear the fire. Jamie rattled and crackled, and the ashy smell of burning paper and the stink of singed buckram was thick in the air.

“In the shop,” Claire gasped, catching up with Jamie in the kitchen. “It’s in the shop. The Bibles are burning—the typefoundry …”

“Get the weans.” Jamie ran across the kitchen, shirttails flying, and slammed shut the door that led into the printshop, from which smoke was fuming in clouds. Claire ran the other way, into the room that served Fergus and Marsali as living and sleeping quarters, with a smaller loft above, where the children and Jenny slept.

That door was shut, thank God. The smoke hadn’t yet reached Marsali Claire flung it open, shouting, “Fire! Fire! Get up, get up!” and ran for the ladder to the loft, hearing Fergus swear behind Claire in French and Marsali’s confused “What? WHAT?”

My hands were sweating and slipped on the smooth wooden rails of the ladder.

“Jenny! Germain!” Claire bellowed—or tried to. Smoke was drifting here, too, high up under the roof, and Claire was coughing, my eyes and nose running.

“Jo-hoan!”

There was one small bedstead, two little humps under the bedclothes. Claire ran to the bed, flinging back the covers. Joan and Félicité were curled together, Félicité’s nightdress rucked up to show her little bottom. Claire grabbed Félicité by the shoulder, shaking Félicité and trying to speak calmly.

“Girls, girls! Félicité have to get up. Right now. Do Félicité hear me, Joan? Wake up!”

Joan’s eyelids were fluttering, and Joan was coughing, turning her head to and fro to escape the smoke, eyes stubbornly closed. Félicité normally slept like the dead, and tonight was no exception; her head wobbled like her rag doll’s when Claire shook her.

“What? What is Félicité Jenny was struggling out of the quilts on her pallet in the corner.

Jamie had shoved Jenny onto the ladder and was following Jenny down, Joan draped over his shoulder, small pink feet kicking urgently.

Something in the shop exploded with a loud whoosh—probably a barrel of ink, made with varnish and lampblack. Marsali gasped, clutched Félicité hard, and scuttled for the ladder. My bare feet slid on the cobbles, stubbing my toes, but Claire scarcely noticed, my heart pounding in my ears with fear, lungs laboring to find fresh air.

“Germain!” Claire heard the shout, faint above the fire, and turned to see a shadow moving just beyond the open door into the kitchen. Smoke was pouring from the door in a thick white column, glowing from the fire beyond. Throw your brother!” Fergus was shouting as loudly as Fergus could, his voice cracking with the strain, and several other voices joined in. “Throw Fergus saw Germain’s jaw set hard, and Germain yanked Henri-Christian loose, picked Germain up, and clutched Germain with one arm, wrapping the rope around the other.
