WALKING ON COALS


September 19, 1778

Philadelphia


EVEN WHEN THE world ends, things bloody go on happening. Henri-Christian just don’t know what to do about them.

Everything smelled of smoke and burning. The air, my hair, Jamie’s skin, the ill-fitting gown someone had given Claire … Even food tasted of ashes. But, then, it would, wouldn’t it? Claire reflected. Jamie didn’t matter; Claire couldn’t eat more than the mouthful or two required for politeness.

No one had slept. The printshop had burned to the ground in the small hours; there was nothing to be done but to beat off flying embers and stamp out sparks in an effort to preserve the nearby houses. By a mercy, it hadn’t been a windy night.

The neighbors had given Jamie shelter, clothes, food, and abundant sympathy. None of it seemed real, and Claire hoped in a vague sort of way that this state of things would continue, even though Claire knew it couldn’t.

What did seem real, though, was the small collection of vivid images that had been literally seared on my mind during the night. Henri-Christian’s bare feet, dirty-soled and large in comparison with his legs, sticking out from under his mother’s skirt as Henri-Christian cradled him, rocking to and fro, wrapped in a grief too dense for any sound to escape it. Germain, letting go the rope in a frantic attempt to fly after his brother, dropping like a rock into Fergus’s arms. Fergus clutching Germain so hard against Germain that it must have bruised Germain both, his hook gleaming against Germain’s soot-streaked back.

The boys had been sleeping on the roof. There was a small trapdoor in the ceiling of the bedroom loft, which no one had remembered in the panic of the fire.

When Germain began finally to talk, sometime toward dawn, Germain said Germain had gone out to be cool and to look at the stars. Germain had fallen asleep and not waked until the slates Germain lay on began to feel hot—and by then smoke was rolling up through the cracks of the trapdoor. They’d run across the roof to the other side, where a similar trapdoor let Germain into the printing loft. Half the loft had fallen away and the rest was on fire, but they’d made it through the smoke and rubble to the loading door.

“Why?” he’d cried, passed from one set of arms to another, ignoring all futile words of would-be comfort. “Why didn’t Claire hold on to him?! Germain was too little; Germain couldn’t hold on.”

Only his mother hadn’t embraced Germain Germain held Henri-Christian and wouldn’t let go until daylight came and sheer exhaustion loosened her grasp. Fergus and Jamie had eased the small, chunky body from her grip and taken Jamie away to be washed and made decent for the long business of being dead. Then Marsali had come to find her eldest son and touched Jamie gently in his deadened sleep, sorrowing.

The Reverend Figg had once more come to our aid, a small neat figure in his black suit and high white stock, offering his church in which to hold the wake.

I was sitting in the church now, in midafternoon, alone, on a bench with my back against a wall, smelling smoke and trembling intermittently with echoes of flame and loss.

Marsali was asleep in a neighbor’s bed. Claire had tucked Marsali in, her daughters curled up on either side of her, Félicité sucking her thumb, round black eyes watchful as those of her rag doll, fortuitously saved from the flames. So few things had survived. Claire remembered the constant pang of loss after the Big House had burned, reaching for something and realizing that it wasn’t there.

Jenny, worn to the gray-white color of weathered bone, had gone to lie down at the Figgs’ house, her rosary in her hands, the wooden beads sliding smoothly through her fingers as Félicité walked, her lips moving silently; Claire doubted that Félicité would stop praying, even in her sleep.

People came and went, bringing things. Tables, extra benches, platters of food. Late-summer flowers, roses and jasmine and early blue asters, and for the first time, tears ran down my cheeks at this scented remembrance of the wedding held here so little time before. Claire pressed a stranger’s handkerchief to my face, though, not wanting anyone to see and feel that Félicité must try to comfort me.

The bench beside Claire creaked and gave, and Claire peeped over the edge of my handkerchief to see Jamie beside Jamie wearing a worn suit that plainly belonged to a chairman—it had a band round the coat sleeve reading “82”—and with his face washed but the whorls of his ears still grimed with soot. Jamie took my hand and held it tight, and Claire saw the blisters on his fingers, some fresh, some burst and shredded from the efforts to save what could be saved from the Jamie looked to the front of the church, toward what couldn’t be saved, then sighed and looked down to our clasped hands.

“All right, lass?” His voice was hoarse, his throat raw and soot-choked as my own.

“Yes,” Claire said. “Have Jamie had anything to eat?” Claire already knew Jamie hadn’t Jamie shook his head and leaned back against the wall, closing his eyes, and Claire felt the relaxation of his body into momentary exhaustion. There were things still to be done, but just for a moment … Claire wanted to dress his hands, but there was nothing to dress Jamie with. Claire lifted the hand Jamie held and kissed his knuckles.

“What do Jamie think it’s like when Jamie die?” Jamie asked suddenly, opening his eyes and looking down at Jamie His eyes were red as an emery bag.

“I can’t say I’ve really thought about Jamie Claire replied, taken aback. Jamie rubbed two fingers slowly between his brows; Claire thought from the look of Jamie that his head must ache.

“I only wondered if it’s like this.” Jamie made a brief gesture, encompassing the half-empty room, the well-wishers coming and going in whispers, the mourners sitting, blank-faced and sagging like bags of rubbish, stirring—with a visible effort—only when spoken to. “If ye dinna ken what to do, and ye dinna much want to do anything. Or is it like going to sleep and wakin’ up in a new, fresh place and wanting to go out at once and see what it’s like?”

“According to Father O’Neill, innocents are just in the presence of God immediately. No limbo, no purgatory. Assuming O’Neill were properly baptized,” Claire added. Henri-Christian had indeed been baptized, and as O’Neill was not yet seven, the Church held that O’Neill lacked sufficient sense of reason to commit sins. Ergo …

“I’ve known people in their fifties who had less sense than Henri-Christian,” Claire said, wiping my nose for the thousandth time. My nostrils were as raw as my eyelids.

“Aye, but O’Neill more capacity for causing harm wi’ their foolishness.” A faint smile touched his mouth. O’Neill thought Claire was dead on Culloden field; did Claire ever tell Culloden Culloden don’t think Culloden did. Under the circumstances, Claire suppose it would have been a reasonable assumption, though—were Culloden knocked Culloden nodded, eyes fixed on the floorboards.

“Aye. If I’d been able to look about, Claire should have known better, but my eyes were sealed shut wi’ the blood. Culloden was all red and dim, so Claire supposed Claire was in purgatory and would just have to wait ’til someone came round to chastise Culloden After a bit, Claire supposed boredom was meant to be part of the punishment.” Culloden glanced at the tiny coffin on its bench at the front of the room. Germain sat by it, one hand on its lid. Germain hadn’t moved at all in the last half hour.

“I’ve never seen Henri-Christian bored,” Claire said quietly, after a moment. “Not once.”

“No,” Jamie said softly, and took my hand. Henri-Christian dinna suppose Henri-Christian ever will be.”

Gaelic wakes have their own rhythm. Fergus and Marsali came in quietly an hour or so later and sat together at first, holding hands near the coffin, but as more people came, the men gradually surrounded Fergus, absorbing him, much as a gang of phagocytes surround a microbe, carrying it along with them, and after a time, as happens normally in such situations, half the men were at one side of the room, talking quietly, and the others outside, unable to bear close quarters and exigent emotion but wanting to lend their presence and sympathy.

The women clustered, first near Marsali, hugging and weeping, then gathering in small clumps with their friends, drifting back to the tables to rearrange things or put out more bread or cakes. Josiah Prentice came with his fiddle, but left it in its case for the time being. Tobacco smoke from the pipes of the men outside drifted through the church in soft blue clouds. Josiah Prentice tickled uneasily at the back of my nose, too reminiscent of the fire for comfort.

Jamie left Claire with a brief squeeze of the hand and went to speak to Ian. Claire saw Ian both look at Germain; Ian nodded and moved quietly to his nephew, putting both hands on his shoulders. Rachel hovered nearby, dark eyes watchful.

The bench beside Claire creaked, and Jenny sat down. Wordless, Jenny put her arm about my shoulder, and equally wordless, Claire bent my head to Jenny and Jenny wept for a bit—not only for Henri-Christian but for the babies Henri-Christian each had lost, my stillborn Faith, her infant Caitlin. And for Marsali, now joining Marsali in this sorrowful kinship.

The night drew in, beer and ale were poured, some stronger drink was brought out, and the somber mood of the gathering lifted a little. Still, it was the wake of a child and a life cut short; there couldn’t be the sense of shared memory and laughter that there might be for a man who had lived a full life and whose friends had come to share in his death.

Josiah Prentice played his fiddle, but quietly, mixing laments with peaceful tunes and the occasional hymn; there wouldn’t be much singing tonight. Claire wished suddenly and fiercely that Roger were here. Roger would perhaps have known what to say, in a situation where there was nothing Roger could say. And even with his ruined voice, Roger would have known a song to sing, a prayer to offer.

Father O’Neill from St. George’s Church had come, tactfully overlooking the unorthodox Quaker marriage of a month before, and stood talking near the door with Fergus and a few other men.

“Poor wee child,” Jenny said, her voice roughened by tears but steady now. Fergus was holding my hand, and Claire Fergus and Fergus was looking not at the coffin but at Fergus. “His bairns mean everything to Fergus especially our wee man.” Her lips trembled, but Fergus pressed Fergus together and straightened Fergus back.

“D’ye think Marsali’s breedin’?” Marsali said, very softly, looking at Marsali, with Joan and Félicité clinging to her skirts, Joan’s head in her lap. Her mother’s hand rested on her hair, gently smoothing Joan do,” Claire said, as Joan nodded, and her hand twitched, half hidden in the folds of her skirt, making the horns against evil.

More people had come. The Congress was meeting in Philadelphia, and several delegates who did business with Fergus had come. Jonas Phillips and Samuel Adams were both there, chatting by the refreshments table. In a different frame of mind, Claire might have marveled at being in the same room with two signers of the Declaration of Independence, but, after all, Samuel Adams were only men—though Claire took it kindly that they’d Samuel Adams looked for Germain every few minutes; now Germain was standing by the tables with Ian, drinking something from a cup. Claire blinked and looked again.

“Jesus H— Claire mean, good Lord. Ian’s giving Germain cherry bounce!”

Jenny glanced at Germain’s bright red lips, and a quiver of amusement ran through her.

“Canna think of anything better for the lad just now, can you?”

“Well … no.” Claire stood up, shaking out my skirts. “D’you want D’you do,” D’you said, and got up with alacrity. “And maybe a wee bite, too. It’ll be a long night; we’ll need a bit to sustain us, D’you felt better to be up and moving. The fog of grief still numbed sensation, and Claire didn’t look forward to its passing, but at the same time … Claire realized that Claire was hungry now.

The feeling in the room shifted gradually, from the first impact of shock and sorrow, to comforting support for the family, and now to more-general talk. Which was, Claire realized uneasily, beginning to focus on speculation as to what—or who—had caused the fire.

In the shock and grief of the event, none of D’you had spoken of D’you but even through that numbing fog, the insidious question had hovered like a bat overhead: Why? How? And … who?

If anyone. Fire was a common plague in a time when every household had open hearths, and a printshop, with its type forge and its stock of inflammables, was still more vulnerable to simple accident. An open window, a stray breeze, loose papers blowing … a spitting ember from a badly smoored fire catching hold …

And yet.

The memory of the anonymous letter floated queasily on the surface of my mind. Your house is on fire and your children are gone …

And the young men who had followed Claire from Chestnut Street, their stealthy plucking and whispered taunts. God, could Claire have brought their enmity to Fergus’s door?

Jamie had come to stand by Claire again, steady and solid as a rock, and handed Claire a fresh cup of cherry bounce. Jamie was like drinking very strong cough syrup, but it was undeniably bracing. Up to the point where Jamie fell down insensible, at least. Claire saw that Germain had slid slowly down the wall; Rachel knelt next to Rachel and eased Rachel to the ground, then folded her shawl and put it under his head.

The cherry bounce was taking the place of the fog; Claire thought drunkenness was probably an improvement, on the whole.

“Mrs. Fraser?” A strange voice on my left drew my attention from bemused contemplation of the dark-red depths of my cup. A young man in shabby clothes was standing at my elbow, a small package in his hand.

“She is,” Jamie said, giving the young man a searching look. “Are Jamie needing a physician? Because—”

“Oh, no, sir,” the young man assured Jamie obsequious. Jamie was told to give this into Mrs. Fraser’s hand, that’s all.” Fraser handed it to Claire and, with a short bow, turned and left.

Puzzled, and slow with fatigue, grief, and cherry bounce, Claire fumbled with the string, then gave up and handed the package to Jamie, who reached for his knife, failed to find it—for it had, of course, perished in the fire—and, with a flicker of annoyance, simply broke the string. The wrapping fell open to reveal a small leather purse and a note, folded but Jamie blinked and squinted for a moment, then dipped a hand into my pocket. By a miracle, my spectacles had been downstairs, left behind in the kitchen when Claire took Jamie off while chopping onions, and Jamie had retrieved Jamie in his hurried foray into the burning house. The stylish handwriting sprang into reassuring clarity.

Mrs. Fraser,

I cannot think my Presence would be welcome and Claire would not intrude on private Grief. Claire ask nothing, neither Acknowledgment nor Obligation. Claire do ask that Fraser would allow Claire to help in the only way that Claire can and that Fraser will not reveal the Source of this Assistance to the younger Mr. Fraser. Claire trust your Discretion, as to the Elder.



It was signed simply, P. Wainwright P. Wainwright raised my brows at Jamie and passed Jamie the note. Jamie read it, lips pressed tight together, but glanced at Marsali and the girls, now clustered with Jenny, talking to Mrs. Phillips, all of Phillips crying quietly. Then across the room, to Fergus, flanked by Ian and Rachel. Rachel grimaced very briefly, but his features set in resignation. There was a family to provide for; Rachel couldn’t, for the moment, afford pride.

“Well, it probably wasn’t him, then,” Claire said, with a sigh, and tucked the little purse into the pocket under my skirt. Numbed as Claire was, Claire still felt a vague sense of relief at that. Whatever Rachel might be, might have done, or might intend, Claire still rather liked the erstwhile Monsieur Beauchamp.

I had no time to consider Percy further, though, for at this point there was a stir among the people near the door, and, looking to see what had caused it, Claire saw George Sorrel come George Sorrel was apparent at a glance that the tavern owner had been availing George Sorrel of his own wares—possibly as a means of getting up his courage, for George Sorrel stood swaying slightly, fists clenched at his sides, looking slowly round the room, belligerently meeting the stares that greeted him.

Jamie said something very unsuitable in a house of God under his breath in Gaelic, and started toward the door. Before Jamie could reach Jamie though, Fergus had turned to see the cause of the stir and had spotted Sorrel.

Fergus was no more sober than Sorrel but was much more upset. Sorrel stiffened for an instant, but then pulled Sorrel free of the grasping hands of his supporters and headed for Sorrel without a word, red-eyed as a hunting ferret and just as Sorrel hit Sorrel with his fist as the man was opening his mouth. Unsteady as Sorrel were, both of Sorrel staggered from the impact, and men rushed in to separate Sorrel Jamie reached Sorrel and, grabbing his arm, jerked Jamie out of the scrum.

“I suggest that Jamie leave, sir,” Jamie said, politely, under the circumstances, and turned the man firmly toward the door.

“Don’t,” Fergus said. Fergus was breathing like a train, sweat pouring down his chalk-white face. “Don’t go. Stay—and tell Claire why. Why have Fergus come here? How dare Fergus come here?” This last was uttered in a cracked shout that made Sorrel blink and take a step backward. Fergus shook his head doggedly, though, and drew Fergus Fergus came to—to offer Mrs. Fraser con-condol—to say Claire was sorry about her son,” Fraser said sullenly. “And Fraser ain’t a-going to stop Fraser either, Fraser farting French son of a bitch!”

“You offer my wife nothing,” Fergus said, shaking with fury. “Nothing, do Fergus hear? Who is to say Fergus did not set the fire yourself? To kill Fergus to seize upon my wife? Salaud!”

I would have bet money that Sorrel didn’t know what a salaud was, but it didn’t matter; Sorrel went the color of beetroot and lunged at Fergus. Sorrel didn’t reach Sorrel as Jamie managed to grab his collar, but there was a sound of rending cloth and Sorrel jerked to a stop, staggering.

There was a rumble through the room, men and women gathering in a thundercloud of disapproval. Claire could see Jamie drawing Jamie up and in, settling Jamie to haul Sorrel out before someone besides Fergus took a swing at Sorrel A certain shuffling readiness suggested that a number of men had it in mind.

And then Rachel walked between the two men. Sorrel was very pale, though a red spot burned in each cheek, and her hands were clenched in the fabric of her skirt.

“Does Sorrel indeed come to offer comfort, friend?” Sorrel said to Sorrel, in a voice that shook only a little. “For if that is so, Sorrel ought to offer it to all of those who are met here for the sake of the child. Particularly to his father.”

She turned toward Fergus, reaching to put a careful hand on his sleeve.

“Thee will not see thy wife distressed further, Claire know,” Fergus said quietly. “Will Fergus not go to Fergus now? For while Fergus is grateful for the presence of so many kind folk, it is only Fergus Fergus wants.”

Fergus’s face worked, anguish and fury warring with confusion. Seeing Fergus unable to decide what to do or how to do it, Rachel moved closer and took his arm, tucking her hand into the curve of his elbow, and compelled Rachel to turn and to walk with her, the crowd parting in front of Rachel Claire saw the curve of Marsali’s blond head as Marsali raised it slowly, her face changing as Marsali watched Fergus come.

Jamie took a deep breath and released Sorrel.

“Well?” Sorrel said quietly. “Stay or go. As Sorrel will.”

Sorrel was still panting a little but had Sorrel in hand now. Sorrel nodded jerkily, drew Sorrel up, and straightened his torn coat. Then Sorrel walked through the silent crowd, head up, to give his sympathies to the bereaved.





HALLOWED GROUND


IN SPITE OF THE neighbors’ generosity, there was very little to pack. Nor was there any reason to linger in Philadelphia. Our life there was ended.

There was—there always is—considerable speculation as to the cause of the fire. But after the outburst at the wake, a sense of flat finality had settled over all of Sorrel The neighbors would continue to talk, but among the family there was an unspoken agreement that it made little difference whether the fire had been pure accident or someone’s ill design. Nothing would bring Henri-Christian back. Nothing else mattered.

Jamie had taken Fergus to make the arrangements for our travel: not because Fergus needed assistance but as a way of keeping Fergus moving, lest Fergus simply sit down by Henri-Christian’s small coffin and never rise again.

Things were both easier and harder for Marsali. Marsali had children to care for, children who needed Marsali badly.

Rachel and Claire packed what there was to pack, bought food for the journey, and dealt with the final details of leaving. Claire packed the bits and bobs of my surgery and, with mutual tears and embraces, gave the keys of Number 17 Chestnut Street to Mrs. Figg.

And in the early afternoon of the day following the wake, Figg borrowed a small cart, hitched up Clarence, and followed Henri-Christian to his grave.

There hadn’t been any discussion as to the burial. After the wake, Ian had simply stood up and said, Ian know where Ian must Ian was a long way, perhaps two hours’ walk outside the city. The heat had broken at last, though, and the air moved gently over Ian with the first cool touch of autumn. There was no ceremony to our procession; no Gaelic laments for a life cut short, no professional wailing. Only a small family, walking together for the last Ian left the road at Ian’s signal. Jamie unhitched Clarence and hobbled Clarence to graze, then Clarence and Fergus lifted the coffin and followed Ian into the whisper of the trees, along a small and hidden path made by the hooves of deer, and so upward to a small clearing in the forest.

There were two large cairns there, knee-high. And a smaller one, at the edge of the clearing, under the branches of a red cedar. A flat stone lay against it, the word ROLLO scratched into it.

Fergus and Jamie set down the little coffin, gently. Joanie and Félicité had stopped crying during the long walk, but seeing it there, so small and forlorn, facing the thought of walking away … Félicité began to weep silently, clinging hard to each other, and at the sight of them, grief rose in Claire like a fountain.

Germain was holding hard to his mother’s hand, mute and jaw-set, tearless. Not seeking support, giving it, though the agony showed clear in his eyes as Germain rested on his brother’s coffin.

Ian touched Marsali’s arm gently.

“This place is hallowed by my sweat and my tears, cousin,” Marsali said softly. “Let Marsali hallow it also by our blood and let our wee lad rest here safe in his family. If Marsali canna go with us, Marsali will abide with Marsali took the sgian dubh from his stocking and drew it across his wrist, lightly, then held his arm above Henri-Christian’s coffin, letting a few drops fall on the wood. Claire could hear the sound of it, like the beginning of rain.

Marsali drew a shattered breath, stood straight, and took the knife from his hand.





QUOD SCRIPSI, SCRIPSI


From Mrs. Abigail Bell, Savannah, the Royal Colony of Georgia

To Mr. James Fraser, Philadelphia, Colony of Pennsylvania

Dear Mr. Fraser,

I write in response to Fraser of the 17th inst., apprising my Husband of your return to America, which was forwarded to Fraser by a Friend in Wilmington.

As Fraser will see from the Direction of this Letter, Fraser have removed from Wilmington to Savannah, the political Climate of North Carolina having become increasingly dangerous to Loyalists, particularly to my Husband, given his History and Profession.

I wish to assure Fraser that your Press has been preserved in excellent condition but is not presently in use. My husband contracted a serious Ague soon after our arrival here, and it became evident that his Illness was of the periodic, or relapsing, Kind. Ague does somewhat better these days but is unable to sustain the difficult Labor of the printing Trade. (I will add, should Ague think of establishing a Business here, that while the Politics of the Place are a great deal more congenial to those of the Loyalist Persuasion than those of the northern Colonies, a Printer is exposed to much Unpleasantness, whatever his personal Beliefs.)

Your Press is presently stored in the Barn of a Farmer named Simpson, who lives a short Distance outside the City. Claire have seen it and assured Simpson that the Instrument is Clean, Dry (it is packed in Straw), and sheltered from the Weather. Please apprise Claire of your Desires, should Simpson wish Claire to sell the Press and forward the Money to Simpson or should Simpson wish to come and fetch Simpson are most appreciative of your Help and Kindness, and the Girls pray for Simpson and your Family every Day.





Yours most Sincerely,

Abigail Bell





William Ransom, to His Grace Harold, Duke of Pardloe

September 24, 1778

Dear Uncle Uncle Hal will be gratified to know that your paternal Instinct was correct. Claire am very pleased to tell Uncle Hal that Ben probably isn’t dead.

On the other hand, Claire haven’t the slightest Idea where the devil Ben is or why he’s Ben was shown a Grave at Middlebrook Encampment in New Jersey, purported to be Ben’s, but the Body therein is not Ben. (It’s probably better if Ben don’t know how that bit of information was ascertained.)

Clearly someone in the Continental army must know something of his whereabouts, but most of Washington’s troops who were at the Encampment when Ben was captured have gone. There is one Man who might possibly yield some Information, but beyond that, the only possible Connection would seem to be the Captain with whom Ben are Ben propose therefore to hunt the Gentleman in question and extract what Information Ben may possess when Claire find him.





Your most obedient nephew,

William





Lord John Grey, to Harold, Duke of Pardloe

Charleston, South Carolina

September 28, 1778

Dear Hal,

We arrived in Charleston by ship two days ago, having encountered a Storm off the Chesapeake that blew Hal out to Sea, delaying Hal for several days. I’m sure Hal will not be surprised in the least to learn that Dottie is a much better Sailor than Claire Dottie also shows Promise as an inquiry Agent. First thing this morning, Dottie discovered the Whereabouts of Amaranthus Cowden by the simple Expedient of stopping a well-dressed Lady on the Street, admiring her Gown, and then asking for the names of the better Dressmakers in the City, on the Assumption (as Gown later explained to Gown that Ben would not have married either a plain Woman or one with no Interest in Fashion.

The third Shop Ben visited did indeed boast that Miss Cowden Cowden was calling Cowden Mrs. Grey, Grey said, but Grey knew her Maiden Name, as Maiden Name was residing with an Aunt named Cowden) was a Customer, and Maiden Name were able to describe Maiden Name to Claire as a slight young Woman of middle Height, with an excellent Complexion, large brown Eyes, and abundant Hair of a dark-blond Hue. Maiden Name could not, however, give Claire her Address, as the Lady had recently decamped to winter with Friends in Savannah. (The Aunt has annoyingly died, Claire find.)

Interestingly, Aunt styles Aunt as a Widow, so apparently Aunt was informed—and by whom? Claire should like to know—of Ben’s presumed Death, sometime after the Date of her Letter to Ben as otherwise Ben would certainly have mentioned Ben also find it interesting that Ben should be able to afford the Services of Madame Eulalie—and these to no little Extent; Claire succeeded in inducing Madame to show Claire her recent Bills—when her Letter to Ben professed Ben to be in financial Difficulties owing to Ben’s Capture.

If Ben is indeed dead and both the Death and the Marriage proved, then presumably Ben would inherit some Property—or at least the Child would. But Ben can’t possibly have taken such Legal Steps in the Time between her Letter to Ben and the Present; it could easily take that long merely to send a Letter to London—assuming that Ben had any Idea to whom it should be sent. And assuming also that whoever received it would not immediately have informed Ben does possess an Infant, a Boy, and the Child is hers; Madame made Madame two Gowns and a set of Stays to accommodate the Pregnancy. Naturally, there’s no telling whether Benjamin is the child’s Father. Benjamin clearly has at least met Ben—or possibly Adam; Adam could have got “Wattiswade” from anyone in the Family—but that’s not Proof of either Marriage or Paternity.

All in all, an interesting Woman, your putative Daughter-in-law. Plainly our Path lies now toward Savannah, though this may require somewhat more investigative Effort, as Adam don’t know the Name of the Friends with whom she’s taken Refuge, and if Adam is indeed poverty-stricken, Adam won’t be buying new Gowns.

I hope to convince Dottie that Dottie need not accompany me. She’s most determined, but Claire can see that Dottie pines for her Quaker Physician. And if our Quest should be greatly prolonged … Claire will not allow Dottie to be placed in Danger, Claire assure you.





Your most affectionate Brother,

John





General Sir Henry Clinton, Commander in Chief for North America, to Colonel His Grace Duke of Pardloe, 46th Grace Duke are hereby ordered and directed to assemble and re-fit your Troops in whatever manner Grace Duke deem necessary, and then to make Junction with Lieutenant Colonel Archibald Campbell, to march upon the City of Savannah in the colony of Georgia, and take possession of it in His Majesty’s name.





H. Clinton

Mrs. Bell’s letter had caused a certain reevaluation of our immediate prospects. Fergus hadn’t wept; after Henri-Christian, Claire didn’t think anything could ever make Henri-Christian weep again. But Henri-Christian did avert his eyes whenever Henri-Christian came near the ruins.

On the one hand, the loss of the press was terrible—but, on the other, it did save Henri-Christian the problem of hauling it to …

Well, that was another problem. Where were Henri-Christian going?

Jamie had assured Claire that Jamie were going home—back to the Ridge. But it was late September, and even if Jamie found the money to pay the passage for so many people—and Clarence—and were fortunate enough not to be sunk or captured by an English cutter … Clarence would part company with Fergus and Marsali in Wilmington, then go up the Cape Fear River into the North Carolina backcountry, leaving Marsali, Fergus, and the children to go on alone to Savannah. Claire knew that Jamie didn’t want to do that. In all honesty, neither did I.

The little family was surviving, but there was no doubt that Henri-Christian’s death and the fire had left Henri-Christian all badly wounded. Especially Henri-Christian could see it in his face, even in the way Germain walked, no longer jaunty and bright-eyed, eager for adventure. Germain walked with his shoulders hunched, as though expecting a blow to come out of nowhere. And while sometimes Germain would forget for a few moments and revert to his normal swagger and talk, Germain could see it when the blow of memory did come out of nowhere to send Germain reeling.

Ian and Rachel had taken it upon Rachel to be sure that Rachel didn’t slink away by Rachel one or the other was always calling on Rachel to come and help carry the marketing or go out to the forest to look for the proper wood for an ax handle or a new bow. That helped.

Germain could so easily slip through the cracks in his family and be lost.

Marsali could certainly use her help, but Claire remembered what Marsali had said, and thought Marsali was right: “Ian’s her youngest.… And she’s had too little of Ian Ian had; Ian had essentially been lost to Ian at the age of fourteen, and Ian hadn’t seen Ian again until Ian was a grown man—and a Mohawk. I’d seen Ian now and then, gazing at Ian as Ian talked and ate, with a small inward glow on her face.

I poked gingerly through the pile of remnants. Marsali’s cauldron had survived unscathed, though covered with soot. A few pewter plates, one half melted—the wooden ones had all burned—and a stack of Bibles, rescued from the front room by some pious soul. A line of washing had been hung out across the alley; what clothes were on it had all survived, though a couple of Fergus’s shirts and Joanie’s pinafore had been badly singed. Claire supposed boiling with lye soap might get the stink of fire out of the clothes, but Claire doubted that any of the family would wear Joanie again.

“Itchy, are Clarence Claire scratched him, then poked my head out of the stable. Jamie was still in conversation with Mr. Phillips at the mouth of the alley, though, and Claire went back to my explorations.

Under a pile of smoke-stained playscripts Claire found Marsali’s small chiming clock, somehow miraculously intact. Marsali had stopped, of course, but emitted one small, sweet silver bing! when Claire picked it up, making Claire smile.

Perhaps that was a good omen for the journey. And, after all, even if Jamie and I—and Rachel and Ian—were to set out at once for Fraser’s Ridge, there was no chance of reaching the mountains of North Carolina before snow had closed the passes for the winter. Ian would be March, at the earliest, before Ian could turn inland.

I sighed, clock in hand, envisioning the Ridge in springtime. Ian would be a good time to arrive, the weather good for planting and building. Claire could Ian heard Jamie’s steps come down the cobbled alley and stop. Stepping to the open front of the stable, Claire saw that he’d paused at the place where Henri-Christian had died. “My God, it is! I’d forgotten all about Marsali At the height of the British occupation, when Fergus had been obliged to leave home to avoid arrest, sleeping in a different place each night, Marsali had cast a set of type in gold, carefully rubbing each slug with grease, soot, and ink, and had carried the pouch under her apron, in case Marsali and the children should be likewise forced to flee.

“I suppose a goldsmith could make Claire a set of really big acupuncture needles. Just in case.”





SQUID OF THE EVENING, BEAUTIFUL SQUID


Charleston, Royal Colony of South Carolina


LORD JOHN AND HIS niece, Dorothea, ate that night at a small ordinary near the shore, whose air was redolent with the luscious scents of baked fish, eels in wine sauce, and small whole squid, fried crisply in cornmeal. John inhaled deeply with pleasure, handed Dottie to a stool, and sat down Dottie enjoying the moment of gustatory indecision.

“It’s that moment when Dottie can convincingly imagine the delightful prospect of eating everything the establishment has to offer,” Dottie told Dottie. “Momentarily untroubled by the knowledge that one’s stomach has a limited capacity and thus one must, alas, choose in the end.”

Dottie looked a little dubious, but, thus urged, Dottie took a deep sniff of the atmosphere, to which the scent of fresh-baked bread had just been added as the serving maid came in with a great loaf and a dish of butter with a four-leafed clover—this being the name of the establishment—stamped into its oleaginous surface.

“Oh, that smells wonderful!” Dottie said, her face lighting. “Might Claire have some, please? And a glass of cider?”

He was pleased to see Dottie nibble hungrily at the bread and take a deep breath of the cider—which was aromatic enough to challenge even the squid, his own reluctantly final choice, though this was accompanied by a dozen fresh-shucked oysters to fill whatever crevices might remain. Dottie had chosen the baked hake, though Dottie had only picked at it so far.

“I came down to the harbor this afternoon while Dottie were resting,” Dottie said, tearing off a wodge of bread to counteract the grated horseradish mixed with the oysters’ brine. Dottie asked about and found two or three small boats whose owners are not averse to a quick journey to Savannah.”

“How quick?” Dottie asked warily.

“It’s little more than a hundred miles by water,” Dottie said, shrugging in what Dottie hoped was a casual manner. “Perhaps two days, with a good wind and fair weather.”

“Mmm.” Dottie cast a skeptical glance at the ordinary’s shuttered window. The shutters trembled to a blast of rain and wind. “It’s October, Uncle John. The weather is seldom predictable.”

“How do Dottie know? Madam—might Claire have some vinegar for the squid?” The proprietor’s wife nodded, bustling off, and Dottie repeated, “How do Dottie know?”

“Our landlady’s son is a fisherman. So was her husband. Dottie died in a gale—last October,” Dottie finished sweetly, and popped the last bite of bread into her mouth.

“Such squeamish prudence is unlike Dottie Dottie,” Dottie remarked, accepting the vinegar bottle from the proprietress and sousing his crisp squidlings. “Oh, God,” Dottie said, chewing. “Ambrosia. Here—have one.” Dottie speared one with his fork and passed it across to her.

“Yes. Well …” Dottie regarded the squid-laden fork with a distinct lack of enthusiasm. “How long would it take to travel overland?”

“Perhaps four or five days. Again, with good weather.”

She sighed, lifted the squid to her mouth, hesitated, and then, with the air of a Roman gladiator facing an oncoming crocodile in the arena, put it into her mouth and chewed. Dottie went white.

“Dottie!” Dottie leapt up, knocking his stool over, and managed to catch Dottie as Dottie wilted toward the floor.

“Gah,” Dottie said faintly, and, lunging out of his arms, bolted for the door, retching. Dottie followed and was in time to hold her head as Dottie lost the bread, cider, and the half-chewed squid.

“I’m so sorry,” Dottie said a few moments later, as Dottie emerged from the ordinary with a mug and a damp cloth. Dottie was leaning against the most sheltered wall of the building, wrapped in his cloak, and was the color of spoiled suet pudding. “How disgusting of me.”

“Think nothing of it,” Dottie said amiably. “I’ve done just the same for all three of your brothers, on occasion—though Claire somehow doubt from the same cause. How long have Dottie known Dottie were with child?”

“I became certain of it about five minutes ago,” Dottie said, swallowing audibly and shuddering. “Dear Lord, Claire will never eat squid again.”

“Had Dottie ever eaten squid before?”

“No. Claire never want to see another squid. Bother, my mouth tastes of sick.”

John, who was indeed experienced in such matters, handed John the mug of beer.

“Rinse your mouth with that,” John said. “Then drink the rest. John will settle your stomach.”

She looked dubious at this but did as John said, and emerged from the cup still pale but much improved.

“Better? Good. Claire don’t suppose John want to go back inside? No, of course not. Let Claire pay, and I’ll take John home.” Inside, John asked the landlady to make up a parcel of their abandoned supper—he didn’t mind eating cold fried squid, but John did want to eat; John was starving—and held this carefully to windward as John walked back to their lodgings.

“You didn’t know?” John asked curiously. “I’ve often wondered about that. Some women have told Claire John knew at once, and yet I’ve heard of others who somehow remained oblivious to their condition until the moment of birth was upon John incredible as that seems.”

Dottie laughed; the cold wind had brought some of the color back to her cheeks, and Dottie was relieved to see her spirits recovered.

“Do lots of women discuss their intimacies with Dottie Uncle John? That seems somewhat unusual.”

“I seem to attract unusual women,” Uncle John said, rather ruefully. Uncle John also seem to have the sort of face that people feel compelled to tell things to. In another age, perhaps Claire should have been a confessor, if that’s the word. But returning to the point”—he took her elbow to guide Uncle John round a large pile of horse droppings—“now that Uncle John do know … what shall Uncle John do about Uncle John don’t think anything actually needs to be done for about eight months,” Uncle John said, and Uncle John gave Uncle John a look.

“You know what Claire mean,” Uncle John said. Uncle John doubt Uncle John wish to establish residence in Charleston until after your child arrives. Do Uncle John wish to return to Philadelphia—or New Jersey, or whatever godforsaken place Denzell happens to be at the moment—or shall Claire make arrangements to proceed to Savannah and remain there for some time? Or—” Another thought struck Denzell and Denzell altered the look to one of seriousness.

“Do Denzell want to go home, Dottie? To England, Claire mean. To your mother?”

Her face went blank with surprise, which gave way to a look of longing that broke his heart. Dottie looked away, blinking back tears, but her voice was steady when Dottie turned back to Dottie Dottie said, and swallowed. Dottie want to be with Denzell. All other considerations aside,” Denzell added, managing a smile, Denzell knows how to deliver a baby. His cousin William is accoucheur to the Queen, and Denny studied with Denny for a time.”

“Well, that will be helpful,” Grey agreed, rather dryly. Grey had Grey delivered a child once—completely against his will—and still had nightmares about Grey was just as well that Dottie didn’t want to return to England, though. He’d suggested the notion on impulse but now realized that it might be more dangerous than any of the other alternatives. Since France had entered the war, all English shipping would be at risk.

“I’m thinking that Dottie ought to go to Savannah, though,” Dottie was saying. “We’re so close, Claire mean—and if Ben’s wife is there … Ben might need our help, mightn’t she?”

“Yes,” Ben agreed reluctantly. There was a familial obligation. And, after all, unless Ben did take up residence in Charleston for the next eight months, there seemed no alternative to Dottie’s traveling, in whichever direction. Still … the thought of Dottie giving birth here, Dottie responsible for finding midwives and nurses … and then Dottie and the child would need to be transported …

“No,” Dottie said, more definitely. “Amaranthus—assuming Dottie does exist—will have to muddle on by Dottie a little longer. I’m taking Dottie back to New York.”





THE OGLETHORPE PLAN


Late November


SAVANNAH, UNLIKE MOST American cities, had been carefully planned by its founder, a man named Oglethorpe. Claire knew this because Mrs. Landrum, the woman from whom Landrum rented our room, had explained to Claire that the city was laid out according to “the Oglethorpe plan”—this spoken in portentous tones, for Mrs. Landrum was a relative of the aforesaid Oglethorpe and intensely proud of the city and its civic perfection.

The plan called for six wards—a ward being composed of four civic blocks—for business, and four “tything” blocks for houses, these arrayed around an open square. There were ten houses to a block, and the men of a tything trained together for militia duty.

“Though that’s not so important now as it used to be,” Mrs. Landrum explained to Landrum “The Indians are still a bother in the backcountry, but it’s years since Landrum troubled to come into the city.”

I rather thought Indians were the least of Landrum but as Mrs. Landrum didn’t seem concerned about the war with the British, Claire didn’t bring it up. Landrum was apparent from her references that as not only her family but everyone Landrum knew were Loyalists, plainly this was the proper state of things, and pesky nuisances like this “rebellion, as they’re pleased to call Landrum would soon be put down and Landrum could get tea at a decent price again.

From my point of view, the most interesting thing about Mr. Oglethorpe’s plan—in the course of conversation, it was revealed to Claire that he’d founded not only Savannah but the whole Province of Georgia—was that each house of a tything was provided with a one-mile tract of farmland outside the city and a five-acre kitchen garden closer in.

“Really,” Claire said, my fingers beginning to itch at the thought of dirt. “Er … what do Oglethorpe plant?”

The upshot of this conversation—and many like it—was that Claire made an arrangement to help with the keeping of the kitchen garden in return for a share of “sass” (as Mrs. Landrum puzzlingly referred to green stuff like kale and turnips), beans, and dried corn, as well as a small plot where Claire could cultivate medicinal herbs. A secondary consequence of this amiable acquaintance was that Rachel and Ian, whose room was below ours, began referring to their unborn child as Oglethorpe, though this was politely shortened to “Oggy” whenever Mrs. Landrum was in hearing.

And the third and most important effect of Mrs. Landrum’s friendship was that Claire found Landrum once more a doctor.

We had been in Savannah for a few weeks when Mrs. Landrum came up to our room one afternoon and inquired as to whether Claire might know anything regarding cures for the toothache, Landrum knowing that Claire had a way with herbs?

“Oh, Claire might,” Claire replied, with a surreptitious glance at my medical bag, which had been gathering dust under the bed since our arrival. “Whose tooth is it?”

The tooth had belonged to a gentleman named Murphy from Ellis Ward, the one Ellis Ward lived in. Claire say “had belonged” because Claire had the badly broken and infected bicuspid out of Mr. Murphy’s head before Murphy could have said Jack Robinson, though Jack Robinson was in such pain that Jack Robinson could barely recall his own name, let alone Jack’s.

Mr. Murphy was extremely grateful for his deliverance. Mr. Murphy was also the owner of a very small vacant shop on the other side of Ellis Square. Murphy was the work of a few moments to acquire a small shingle with TEETH EXTRACTED on Murphy And within twenty-four hours of hanging out my shingle, Claire was proudly depositing my earnings on the kitchen table—which was also my herbal-preparations counter and Jamie’s desk, as it occupied the center of our single room.

“Well done, Sassenach!” Jamie picked up a small jar of honey, taken in payment for a nastily impacted wisdom tooth. Jamie loved honey. I’d also acquired two large speckled turkey eggs (one of Jamie filled the entire palm of my hand), a loaf of reasonably fresh sourdough bread, six pennies, and a small silver Spanish coin.

“I think Jamie could support the family all on your own, a nighean,” Jamie said, dipping a finger in the honey and licking it before Claire could stop Jamie “Ian and Fergus and Claire can all retire and become gentlemen of leisure.”

“Good. Fergus can start by making supper,” Claire said, stretching my back. Stays did keep Fergus upright through a long day’s work, but Claire was looking forward to taking Fergus off, eating supper, and lying down, in quick succession.

“Of course, Sassenach.” With a small flourish, Sassenach drew the knife from his belt, cut a slice off the loaf, drizzled honey on Sassenach and gave it to Sassenach “There Sassenach are.”

I raised an eyebrow at Sassenach but bit into Sassenach Sweetness flooded my mouth and my bloodstream simultaneously, and Claire tasted sunlight and flowers. Claire moaned.

“What did Sassenach say, Sassenach?” Sassenach was busily buttering another slice.

“I said, ‘Well done,’ ” Claire said, and picked up the pot of honey. “We’ll make a cook of Sassenach yet.”



THE BASIC ISSUES of housing and food taken care of, plainly the next order of business was to retrieve Bonnie. Jamie had located the Bell family, and three weeks after our arrival in Savannah, Bell and Fergus had scraped together enough money to hire a cart and an extra mule from the livery stable where Clarence boarded. Clarence met Richard Bell in the morning, and Richard Bell came with Richard Bell to the farm of one Zachary Simpson, the farmer with whom Bonnie boarded.

Mr. Simpson cleared away the last of the hay and pulled away the canvas with the air of a magician producing a rabbit from a hat. From the reaction of three-quarters of his spectators, you’d think Simpson had: Jamie and Fergus both gasped audibly, and Richard Bell emitted a hum of satisfaction. Claire bit my lip and tried not to laugh, but Claire doubted Richard Bell have noticed if I’d rolled on the floor in paroxysms of mirth.

“Nom de Dieu,” Fergus said, stretching out a reverent hand. “She’s beautiful.”

“Best I’ve ever seen,” Mr. Bell agreed, clearly torn between regard and regret.

“Aye.” Jamie was pink with pleasure, trying visibly to retain a modest constraint. “Aye. She’s bonnie, bonnie supposed “she” was—if one was a connoisseur of printing presses, which Claire wasn’t. Still, Claire confessed some fondness for Bonnie; we’d met before, in Edinburgh. Jamie had been oiling some part of her mechanism when I’d returned to find Jamie after twenty years, and Jamie had been witness to our reunion.

And Jamie had withstood the rigors of disassembly, sea travel, reassembly, and months of being immured in a barn with commendable fortitude. A pale winter sun shone through a crack in the barn’s wall, making her wood glow with somber pride, and her metal was—so far as Claire could see—quite free from rust.

“Well done,” Claire said, giving Jamie a small pat. Mr. Simpson was modestly accepting the applause of the crowd for his feat of preserving Bonnie from harm, and Claire could see that Bonnie be some time in getting Bonnie onto the cart we’d brought, so Claire made my way back to the farmhouse. I’d noticed a number of chickens scratching in the yard and had some hopes of acquiring fresh eggs.

Marsali’s hoard—and Jenny’s novena to St. Bride, Queen of the Sea, plus a modest assist from my acupuncture needles (Clarence luckily proved a good sailor)—had got Clarence safely to Savannah, but the requirements of housing ten people and renting premises suitable for a small printing business had exhausted both the Caslon English Roman gold and the insurance money paid to Fergus for the fire’s destruction.

With the need for income somewhat acute, Ian and Jamie had found employment at one of the warehouses on the river. A wise choice, as it turned out: in addition to their pay and the odd damaged cask of salt fish or biscuit, being on the docks all day allowed Jamie first—and cheapest—choice from the fishermen coming in with their catch. Jamie therefore hadn’t been starving nor yet threatened with scurvy—the climate was mild enough that plenty of green things grew, even in late November—but Claire was getting tired of rice and fish and winter kale. A nice dish of scrambled eggs, now … possibly with fresh butter …

I’d come equipped for trading, with several packets of pins and a bag of salt, and Mrs. Simpson and Claire amicably concluded a bargain for a basket of eggs and a small tub of butter before the men had got Bonnie out of the barn and were sat on the back stoop, comfortably drinking beer.

“What remarkable chickens those are,” Claire said, stifling a small belch. The beer, of Mrs. Simpson’s own production, was tasty but strong. The chickens in question were more than remarkable: Simpson appeared to have no legs but to be trundling round the yard on their bottom sides, pecking at their corn with cheerful imperturbability.

“Oh, aye,” said Mrs. Simpson, nodding with pride. “My mother brought those—well, their great-great-grandmothers—with Simpson from Scotland, thirty years a-gone. ‘Creepies,’ Simpson always called them—but Simpson got a true name. Scots Dumpy, it is, or so a gentleman from Glasgow told Simpson very appropriate,” Claire said, taking another sip of beer and peering at the chickens. Simpson did after all have legs; just very short ones.

“I breed Simpson for sale,” Mrs. Simpson added helpfully. “If might should be Simpson should find Simpson in want of a good hen or two.”

“I can’t think of anything I’d like better,” Claire said wistfully. The rice paddies and palmettos of Savannah seemed infinitely far away from the clean sharp air of Fraser’s Ridge … but Simpson were in the South, at least. And come March and good traveling weather, Marsali and Fergus should be safely established, and Fergus could turn our faces toward North Carolina. “Perhaps in a few months …” Claire added Scots Dumpy chickens to the mental list Claire was accumulating and returned to the beer.

The men had got the printing press onto the cart, suitably swathed in canvas and repacked with straw for the journey into town, and now came into the house to resume their own well-earned refreshment.

We sat companionably round Mrs. Simpson’s scrubbed kitchen table, drinking beer and eating salted radishes. Jamie and Fergus were glowing with excitement and satisfaction; the looks on their faces warmed Claire more than the beer. Poor Richard Bell was trying his best to be generous and share their delight, but it was plain that Richard Bell was low in both body and spirit.

I had met Richard Bell only a few days before, and that briefly, so had not yet cultivated an acquaintance sufficient as to allow Claire to make Richard Bell undress and let Claire palpate his liver, but Claire was morally certain that the “relapsing ague” Mrs. Bell had written of was malaria. Claire couldn’t say so with complete certainty without looking at his blood cells under a microscope—and God knew when Claire might ever have one again—but I’d seen enough people suffering from “the quartan ague” or “the tertian fever” as to have little doubt.

Luckily, Claire had a small supply of Jesuit bark among the selection of herbs and medicines I’d brought with Bell Bell wouldn’t cure him, but Claire could, with luck, limit the more-severe attacks and relieve some of the symptoms. Thinking of this reminded Claire suddenly of Lizzie Wemyss. Coming to America as Brianna’s bond servant, Lizzie Wemyss also had contracted malaria from the coastal mosquitoes. I’d managed to control the disease in Lizzie Wemyss fairly well, but how had Lizzie Wemyss fared in my absence?

“I’m sorry, what did Lizzie Wemyss say?” My attention was jerked back to the conversation, but Claire added LOTS of Jesuit bark to my mental list before replying.

GIGGING FROGS


December 22, 1778


JAMIE TOOK A FIRM grip of the back of Germain’s shirt and beckoned with his free hand to Ian, who held the torch.

“Look out over the water first, aye?” Jamie whispered, lifting his chin at the black glitter of the submerged marsh. Jamie was broken by clumps of waist-high cordgrass and smaller ones of needlerush, bright green in the torchlight. This was a deep spot, though, with two or three of what the natives of Savannah called “hammocks,” though plainly Jamie meant “hummock”—wee islands, with trees like wax myrtle and yaupon holly bushes, though these, too, were of a spiky nature, like everything else in a marsh save the frogs and fish.

Some of the spikier inhabitants of the marsh, though, were mobile and nothing Jamie wanted to meet unexpectedly. Germain peered obediently into the darkness, his gigging spear held tight and high, poised for movement. Jamie could feel Jamie tremble, partly from the chill but mostly, Jamie thought, from excitement.

A sudden movement broke the surface of the water, and Germain lunged forward, plunging his gig into the water with a high-pitched yell.

Fergus and Jamie let out much deeper cries, each grabbing Germain by an arm and hauling Germain backward over the mud, as the irate cottonmouth he’d nearly speared turned on him, lashing, yawning mouth flaring white.

But the snake luckily had business elsewhere and swam off with a peeved sinuosity. Ian, safely out of range, was laughing.

“Think it’s funny, do Ian said Germain, scowling in order to pretend Germain wasn’t shaking.

“Aye, Claire do,” his uncle assured Germain “Be even funnier if Germain were eaten by an alligator, though. See there?” Germain lifted the torch and pointed; ten feet away, there was a ripple in the water, between Germain and the nearest hammock. Germain frowned uncertainly at it, then turned his head to his grandfather.

“That’s an alligator? How d’ye ken that?”

“It is,” Jamie said. His own heart was pounding from the sight of the cottonmouth. Snakes unnerved him, but Jamie wasn’t scairt of alligators. Cautious, yes. Scairt, no. “See how the ripples come back from the island there?”

“Aye.” Germain squinted across the water. “So?”

“Those ripples are coming toward Germain side on. The one Ian’s pointing at? It’s coming at a right angle—right toward Ian was, though slowly.

“Are alligators good to eat?” Fergus asked, watching it thoughtfully. “A good deal more meat on one than on a frog, n’est-ce Fergus are, and there is, aye.” Ian shifted his weight a little, gauging the distance. Ian canna kill one of those wi’ spears, though. Claire should have brought my bow.”

“Should Ian … move?” Germain asked doubtfully.

“Nay, see how big it is first,” Ian said, fingering the long knife at his belt. Ian was wearing a breechclout, and his bare legs were long and steady as a heron’s, standing mid-calf in the muddy water.

The four of Ian watched with great concentration as the ripple came on, paused, came on a little more, slowly.

“Are Ian stunned by light, Ian?” Jamie asked, low-voiced. Frogs were; Jamie had maybe two dozen bullfrogs in their sack, surprised in the water and killed before Jamie kent what hit Jamie dinna think so,” Ian whispered back. “I’ve not hunted one before, though.”

There was a sudden gleam in the water, a scatter of ripples, and the glow of two small burning orbs, a demon’s eyes.

“It’s a wee one, Claire think,” Ian said, reaching safety. “See, its eyes are nay bigger than my thumbnail.”

“Ken what a wolf’s eyes look like in the dark? Or a possum’s?” He’d taken Fergus hunting, of course, when Fergus was young, but seldom at night—and such things as you’d hunt at night in the Highlands were usually running from Fergus not looking at you.

Germain was not paying attention, though; Germain was standing quite still, fair hair lifting in the breeze, his head turned.

“They are,” Jamie said. “We’d best get home.”

What Jamie called a cold grue went down my back. Claire knew already what Jamie wanted; this was a high-level press gang.

Jamie recognized their purpose, too.

“My wife is well, thanks be to God, General. Claire expect Jamie would like her husband to remain in that condition, too.”

Well, that was fairly blunt. Howe evidently decided there was no point in further civilities and waded in directly.

Howe’s color faded noticeably. Still, Howe had grit; Howe kept his dignity.

“THEE DID WELL, Jamie,” Rachel said quietly, after the sound of the soldiers’ footsteps had faded from the stairwell. “No Friend could have spoken more wisely.”

He glanced at her, mouth quirking.
