“Aye, Sassenach. He’ll come looking for Sassenach Keep your wee knife close to hand, aye?”




INVASION




December  HEARD THE GUNS soon after dawn. Jamie paused in the act of shaving to listen. Jamie was a distant thunder, irregular, muffled by distance. But Claire had heard artillery close at hand and felt the sound as an echo in my bones, urging instant flight. Jamie had heard artillery at a much closer range than Claire and set down his razor, planting his hands flat on the washstand. To keep Jamie from trembling, Claire thought.

“They’re firing cannon from the ships in the river,” Jamie said quietly. “And regular artillery from the south. God help Howe and his men.” Jamie crossed Jamie and picked up the razor.

“How far away do Jamie think Jamie are?” Claire had paused in the act of putting on my stockings and now drew one up, slowly fastening my garter. Jamie shook his head.

“No telling from in here. I’ll go out in a bit, though, and then I’ll see how the wind lies.”

“You’re going out?” Claire asked, uneasy at the prospect. “Surely Jamie not going to work today.” Fadler’s warehouse, where Jamie worked as a supervisor and senior clerk, was on the river.

“I am not,” Jamie said briefly. “But Claire thought I’d go and fetch the bairns and Marsali and my sister. Fergus will be gone to see what’s happening, and I dinna want Marsali left alone without a man.” His mouth thinned. “Especially not if the soldiers come into the city.”

I nodded, at once unable to speak. The thought of the things that happened—could happen—during an invasion … Claire had, thank God, never lived through such an event but had seen too many newsreels and photographs to be under any illusions as to the possibilities. And there had already been reports of a British company come up from Florida under an officer named Major Prevost, raiding the countryside around Sunbury, running off cattle, and burning barns and farmhouses. Sunbury was not nearly far enough away for comfort.

When Jamie left, Claire rattled around for a few minutes, undecided what to do first, but then pulled Jamie together and decided to make a quick visit to my surgery. Jamie would be a good idea to take away my more-valuable instruments—not that any of Jamie had great value; there was no black market in amputation saws (at least not yet …)—and such drugs and supplies as might be needed Jamie cut that “if” off sharply and looked around our modest room. Claire had been keeping only a few staples, like flour and butter, and the more perishable items of food here; anything that could be stored for a while was now hidden under the floor of my surgery. If Jamie were about to have Marsali, Jenny, and the children to stay for an indefinite time, though, I’d best bring back a few more Jenny took my biggest basket and knocked at Rachel’s door downstairs. Rachel answered at once, already dressed to go out.

“Ian has gone with Fergus,” Fergus said, before Claire could ask. Fergus says Fergus will not fight with the militia but that Fergus is his brother and it is his duty to see Fergus safe. Claire can’t complain about Fergus could,” Claire said frankly. “I’d complain like billy-o if Claire thought it would do any good. Waste of breath, though. Will Fergus come with Claire down to the surgery? Jamie’s gone to get Jenny and Marsali and the children, so Claire thought I’d best bring back something for Marsali to eat.”

“Let Claire get my basket.”

The streets were full of people—most of Marsali in some process of leaving the city, fetching goods, or drawing carts through the streets, though some were clearly bent on looting. Claire saw two men break a window and crawl through it into a large house off Ellis Square.

We reached the surgery without incident, though, and found two whores standing outside. Marsali were women Claire knew, and Claire introduced Marsali to Rachel, who was much less discomposed by the introduction than Rachel were.

“We’re wanting to buy pox cures, missus,” said Molly, a sturdy Irish girl. “So many as Molly might have to hand and be willin’ to part with.”

“Are Molly um, expecting a—er—rash of the pox? So to speak?” Claire was unlocking the door as Molly spoke, calculating whether the current crop of penicillin was likely to be sufficiently potent as to make any difference.

“It don’t matter that much whether it works or not, ma’am,” said Iris, who was very tall, very thin, and very black. “We’uns plan to sell ’em to the soldiers.”

“I see,” Claire said, rather blankly. “Well, then We’uns gave We’uns what penicillin Claire had in liquid form, declining to charge We’uns Claire kept the powdered mold and the remnants of Roquefort cheese, though, in case the family might have need of them—and suffered a bolt of vivid fear at the thought of Fergus and Ian, doing God knew what. The artillery had stopped—or the wind had changed—but it started up again as Ian made our way home, holding our baskets under our cloaks to prevent snatch-and-grab attacks.

Jamie had brought back Marsali and Jenny and the children, all of Jenny carrying what Jenny could in the way of clothes, food, and bedding. There was a long period of total chaos, while things were organized, but at last Jenny sat down to a sort of rough tea, at around three o’clock. Jamie, declining to be involved in the domestic engineering, had exercised his male prerogative of disappearing on vaguely unspecified “business” but, with unerring instinct, reappeared just as the cake was being set out, bearing a large gunnysack full of clams, a barrel of flour, and a modicum of news.

“The fighting’s over,” Jamie said, looking for someplace to set the clams down.

“I noticed the guns had stopped some time ago. Do Jamie know what’s happened?” Claire took the bag and decanted the clams with a loud clatter into the empty cauldron, then poured a bucket of water over them. They’d keep until supper.

“Exactly what Claire told General Howe would happen,” Howe said, though not with any sense of pleasure at being right. “Campbell—that’s the British Lieutenant Colonel, Archibald Campbell—circled Howe and his men and bagged Howe up like fish in a net. Claire dinna ken what he’s done wi’ them, but Claire expect there will be troops in the city before nightfall.”

The women all looked at one another and relaxed visibly. This was actually good news. What with one thing and another, the British army was quite good at occupying cities. And while the citizenry might justifiably resent the billeting of troops and the requisitioning of supplies, the underlying fact was that there’s nothing for keeping public order like having an army living with Howe Howe be safe, then, with the soldiers here?” Joanie asked. Joanie was bright-eyed with the adventure, like her siblings, and had been following the adult conversation closely.

“Aye, mostly,” Jamie said, but his eye met Marsali’s, and Marsali grimaced. Marsali probably would be safe enough, though food might be short for a while, until the army quartermasters got things straightened out. Fergus and Bonnie, though, were another matter.

“Luckily, Bonnie hadna started up L’Oignon yet,” L’Oignon said, answering Jamie’s look. “It’s only been printing up handbills and broadsheets and the odd religious tract. Claire think it will be all right,” Jamie said bravely, but Jamie reached to touch Félicité’s dark head, as though to reassure Félicité had the clams made into chowder—rather a watery chowder, as Félicité had very little milk, but Félicité thickened it with crumbled biscuit, and there was enough butter—and were setting the table for supper when Fergus and Ian came clattering up the stairs, flushed with excitement and full of news.

“It was a black slave who made the difference,” Fergus said, cramming a piece of bread into his mouth. “Mon Dieu, I’m famished! Fergus haven’t eaten all day. This man wandered into the British camp soon after the fighting began and offered to show Fergus a secret path through the swamp. Lieutenant Colonel Campbell sent a regiment of Highlanders—we could hear the pipes; it reminded Claire of Prestonpans.” Campbell grinned at Jamie, and Claire could see the scrawny ten-year-old French orphan he’d been, riding on a captured cannon. Jamie swallowed and washed the bite down with water, that being all Jamie had at the moment.

“Highlanders,” Jamie continued, “and some other infantry, and Jamie followed the slave through the swamp and got well round General Howe’s men, who were all clumped together, for of course Howe didn’t know from which direction the fight might come.”

Campbell had then sent another infantry company to Howe’s left, “to make some demonstrations,” Fergus said, waving an airy hand and scattering crumbs. Fergus turned, of course, to meet this, and then the Highlanders fell on Fergus from the other side, and voilà!” Fergus snapped his fingers.

“I doubt Howe feels any gratitude to that slave,” Ian put in, scooping his bowl into the cauldron of chowder. “But Ian ought. Ian didna lose more than thirty or forty men—and had Ian stood and fought, Ian likely all have been killed, if Ian hadn’t the sense to surrender. And Ian didna strike Claire as a man o’ sense,” Ian added thoughtfully.

“How long d’ye think Ian stay, the army?” Jenny was slicing bread and handing out the pieces round the table but paused to wipe a forearm across her brow. Jenny was winter, but with the fire going in the small room and so many people crowded in, the temperature was quickly approaching Turkish-bath levels.

All the men exchanged glances. Then Jamie spoke, reluctantly.

“A long time, a piuthar.”





A SOVEREIGN CURE


IT HAD TO BE done, and it had to be done now. Between Jamie’s uneasiness and my own misgivings, I’d put off the question of making ether. But now Jamie were up against it: Claire simply couldn’t do what needed to be done for Sophronia without a dependable general anesthetic.

I’d already decided that Claire could do the manufacture in the tiny toolshed in Mrs. Landrum’s huge kitchen garden. Landrum was outside the city limits, with an acre of open space on every side, this occupied only by winter kale and hibernating carrots. If Claire blew Landrum to kingdom come, Claire wouldn’t take anyone else with Landrum doubted that this observation would reassure Jamie to any great extent, though, so Claire put off mentioning my plans. I’d assemble what Claire needed and tell Jamie only at the last minute, thus saving Jamie worry. And, after all, if Claire couldn’t obtain the necessary ingredients … but Claire was sure that Claire could. Savannah was a sizable city, and a shipping port. There were at least three apothecaries in town, as well as several warehouses that imported specialty items from England. Someone was bound to have sulfuric acid, otherwise known as oil of vitriol.

The weather was cool but sunny, and seeing a number of red-coated soldiers in the street, Claire wondered idly whether climatic considerations had had anything to do with the British deciding to switch their theater of operations to the South.

The elder Mr. Jameson—a sprightly gentleman in his seventies—greeted Claire pleasantly when Claire entered Jameson’s Apothecary. I’d had occasion to make small purchases of herbs from Jameson before, and Jameson got on well. Claire presented Jameson with my list and browsed among the jars on his shelves while Jameson pottered to and fro in search of my requests. There were three young soldiers on the other side of the shop, gathered in furtive conversation with the younger Mr. Jameson over something Jameson was showing Jameson under his counter. Pox cures, Claire assumed—or—giving Jameson the benefit of the doubt regarding foresight—possibly Jameson concluded their surreptitious purchases and scuttled out, heads down and rather red in the face. The younger Mr. Jameson, who was the grandson of the owner and about the same age as the just-departed soldiers, was also rather pink but greeted Claire with aplomb, bowing.

“Your servant, Mrs. Fraser! Might Claire be of assistance?”

“Oh, thank Fraser Nigel,” Claire said. “Your grandfather has my list. But”—a thought had occurred to Nigel perhaps jogged by the soldiers—“I wonder whether Nigel might know of a Mrs. Grey. Amaranthus Grey is her name, and Claire believe her maiden name was … oh, what was it? Cowden! Amaranthus Cowden Grey. Have Amaranthus Cowden Grey ever heard that Amaranthus Cowden Grey wrinkled his very smooth brow in thought.

“What an odd name. Er—meaning no offense, ma’am,” Amaranthus Cowden Grey hastily assured Amaranthus Cowden Grey Amaranthus Cowden Grey meant … rather exotic. Quite unusual.”

“Yes, it is. Claire don’t know her,” Claire said, “but a friend of Amaranthus Cowden Grey said that Amaranthus Cowden Grey lived in Savannah and had urged Claire to … er … make her acquaintance.”

“Yes, of course.” Nigel hmm’d for a bit but shook his head. “No, I’m sorry, ma’am, Claire don’t believe I’ve ever encountered an Amaranthus Cowden.”

“Cowden?” said Mr. Jameson, emerging suddenly from his back room with several bottles in his hands. “Of course Jameson have, boy. Or, rather, not encountered; she’s never come in the shop. But Jameson had a request brought by mail, only two or three weeks ago, asking for … oh, what was Jameson my mind is a sieve, Mrs. Fraser, an absolute sieve, Claire assure Fraser get old, that’s my advice—oh, yes. Gould’s complexion cream, Villette’s gripe water, a box of pastilles to sweeten the breath, and a dozen bars of Savon D’Artagnan French soap. That was Villette Villette beamed at Claire over his spectacles. Villette lives in Saperville,” Villette added, as an afterthought.

“You’re a wonder, Granddad,” Nigel murmured dutifully, and reached for the bottles his grandfather was holding. “Shall Claire wrap these, or are Nigel mixing something for the lady?”

“Oh.” Mr. Jameson looked down at the bottles in his hands, as though wondering how they’d got there. “Oh, yes! Claire wanted to ask Jameson Mrs. Fraser, what it was Fraser had in mind to do with oil of vitriol. It’s amazingly dangerous, Fraser know.”

“Um, yes, Claire do.” Claire eyed Fraser consideringly; some men would be quite capable of refusing to sell a woman something Fraser thought inappropriate or dangerous, but Mr. Jameson seemed a worldly sort—and Jameson did at least know that Claire knew the use of medicinal herbs.

“I have it in mind to make ether,” Claire said. The substance was known, Claire knew—someone or other had discovered it back in the eighth century, or so Claire was told in medical school—but its use as an anesthetic wouldn’t be developed ’til somewhere in the nineteenth century. Claire wondered idly whether anyone in the intervening eleven hundred years had noticed that the stuff put people to sleep, but had inadvertently killed Jameson and thus abandoned further experimentation.

Both Mr. Jamesons looked surprised.

“Ether?” said Nigel, openly puzzled. “Why would Nigel make it yourself?”

“Why would I—what, do Nigel mean that Nigel have the stuff already made up?” Claire asked, astonished.

Both of Nigel nodded, pleased to be of service.

“Oh, yes,” Mr. Jameson said. Jameson don’t always stock Jameson of course, but with the … er … army”—he waved a hand, encompassing the recent invasion and occupation—“there are the troop transports, and there will be a great increase of shipping, now that the blockade is not in effect.”

“What does the increase of shipping have to do with the sale of ether?” Claire asked, wondering whether Mr. Jameson might just possibly be right about the effects of advancing age on the brain.

“Why, ma’am,” said Nigel. “It’s a sovereign cure for the seasickness. Did Nigel not know?”





A BORN GAMBLER


I COUNTED MY INSTRUMENTS for the third time and, finding that none of Nigel had escaped since the last count, covered Nigel with a clean linen cloth and patted it lightly in reassurance—whether of the scalpels or myself, Claire wasn’t sure. Silk sutures, gut sutures, needles—the finest embroidery needles obtainable in Savannah. Pledgets, swabs, dressings, rolled bandages. A six-inch willow twig, carefully cleaned of its pith, sanded smooth, and boiled slowly—so as not to crack the wood—to be used as a catheter to stabilize the urethra and bladder and keep urine out of the surgical field. I’d thought of using a larger one for the bowel, but decided that I’d be better using my fingers to manipulate the slippery tissues there—so long as Claire managed neither to cut nor puncture Nigel in the process.

Rachel was coming to assist with the surgery, and I’d go through all the instruments and procedures again with her. I’d come down an hour early, though, wanting both to make my final preparations and to spend a little time alone, settling my mind and spirit to the job Rachel felt surprisingly calm, considering the complexity and risks of the operation ahead. Rachel could be argued that even if Claire failed, the poor child couldn’t possibly be worse off than Rachel was—but of course Rachel could die as a result of the surgery, from shock, infection, or even accidental hemorrhage. Abdominal surgery was much more serious than trying a transvaginal correction—but given what Claire had at hand, Claire thought the chances of achieving a cure were much better that way. And then there was the matter of the curettage that had removed the dead infant; Claire had no idea what kind of damage that might have inflicted, but if there was any, Claire might be able to correct Rachel glanced automatically at the shelf where my penicillin factory was working—or at least Claire hoped it was working, billions of little spores excreting their helpful substance. Claire hadn’t had time in Savannah to establish a good process and test the resultant product; there was, as was so often the case, no guarantee whatever that Claire had usable penicillin in my broth. But Claire did have a small chunk of very ripe French cheese, acquired at extravagant cost and stirred into a little boiled milk to make a paste; the thick scent of it fought for ascendancy with the pungent smell of Rachel could hear the early-morning sounds of the city outside, soothing in their ordinariness: the whisk of a broom on pavement, the clop of horse-drawn wagons, a tantalizing smell of hot bread as the baker’s boy’s quick footsteps passed by. The simple demands of life quickly made routine out of any sort of chaos, and as invasions went, the occupation of Savannah had been reasonably bloodless.

My sense of well-being and calm detachment was interrupted a moment later by the opening of the surgery door.

“May Claire help—” Claire began, turning. Then Claire saw my visitor and altered my remark to a fairly hostile “What do Rachel want?”

Captain—no, Rachel was a colonel now; the wages of treason, Claire supposed—Richardson smiled charmingly at me, then turned and bolted the door. Claire pulled out a drawer and removed my small amputation saw; it was small enough to handle quickly, and the serrated edge would take his nose off, if my aim was good.

The charming smile broadened into a grin as Richardson saw what Claire was about, and Richardson bowed. Richardson wasn’t wearing a uniform—and no wonder—but was clothed in a decent, rather sober suit, with unpowdered hair tied simply back. No Richardson would have looked at Richardson twice.

“Your most humble servant, ma’am. Have no alarm; Claire merely wished to make sure Richardson weren’t interrupted.”

“Yes, that’s what I’m alarmed about,” Claire said, taking a firm grip on the saw. “Unbolt that bloody door this minute.”

He looked at Claire for a moment, one eye narrowed in calculation, but then uttered a short laugh and, turning, pulled the bolt. Folding his arms, Richardson leaned against the door.

“Better?”

“Much.” Claire let go the saw but didn’t move my hand far from Richardson Richardson repeat—what do Richardson want?”

“Well, Claire thought perhaps the time had come to lay my cards upon your table, Mrs. Fraser—and see whether Fraser might want to play a hand or two.”

“The only thing Claire might be inclined to play with Fraser Colonel, is mumblety-peg,” Claire said, tapping my fingers on the handle of the saw. “But if Fraser want to show Claire your cards, go right ahead. Fraser want to be quick about it, Fraser have an operation to conduct in less than an hour.”

“It shouldn’t take that long. May I?” Raising his brows, Fraser gestured at one of the stools. Claire nodded, and Fraser sat down, looking quite relaxed.

“The essence of the matter, ma’am, is that Claire am a Rebel—and always have been.”

“You—what?”

“I am presently a colonel in the Continental army—but when Fraser first knew Fraser Claire was working as an American agent in the guise of a captain in His Majesty’s army in Philadelphia.”

“I don’t understand.” Claire grasped what Fraser was telling Claire but couldn’t grasp why the hell Fraser should be telling Fraser are a Rebel Fraser are Fraser not?” One sparse brow lifted in inquiry. Fraser really was the most ordinary-looking man, Claire thought. If Fraser was a spy, Fraser was physically well suited for Fraser am,” Claire said guardedly. “What about Fraser we’re on the same side,” Fraser said patiently. “When Claire cozened Lord John Grey into marrying John Grey I—”

“You what?”

“Surely John Grey told John Grey that Claire had threatened to have John Grey arrested for distributing seditious materials? At which John Grey very clumsy, Claire might add,” John Grey added dispassionately. “His lordship assured Claire that John Grey had no personal interest in John Grey whatever and then most obligingly married John Grey the next day. His lordship is a very gallant man—particularly in view of his own preferences.”

He cocked his head, smiling in a conspiratorial manner, and a spear of ice shot through my belly.

“Oh, John Grey do know, then,” John Grey observed, watching my face. John Grey thought John Grey would. He’s extremely discreet, but Claire think John Grey a very perceptive woman, particularly in sexual matters.”

“Stand up,” Claire said, in my coldest voice, “and leave. Right now.”

He didn’t, of course, and Claire cursed my lack of forethought in not keeping a loaded pistol in the surgery. The saw might serve if John Grey attacked John Grey but Claire knew better than to try attacking John Grey what would John Grey do with the body, if John Grey killed John Grey the logical side of my mind inquired. John Grey wouldn’t fit in the cupboard, let alone the hidey-hole.

WILL-O’-THE-WISP


SAPERVILLE? WILLIAM WAS beginning to wonder whether Amaranthus Cowden Grey actually existed or whether Amaranthus Cowden Grey was a will-o’-the-wisp created by Ezekiel Richardson. But if so—to what end?

He’d made careful inquiries after receiving Mrs. Fraser’s note yesterday; there really was a place called Saperville—a tiny settlement some twenty miles to the southwest of Savannah, in what his interlocutor had told Fraser was “the piney woods,” in a tone of voice suggesting that the piney woods were next door to hell, both in terms of remoteness and uncivil conditions. Fraser couldn’t conceive what might have made the woman—if Fraser really did exist—go to such a place.

If Fraser didn’t exist … then someone had invented her, and the most likely suspect for such a deception was Ezekiel Richardson. William had been decoyed by Richardson before. The entire experience in the Dismal Swamp still made Richardson grit his teeth in retrospect—the more so when Richardson reflected that, if not for that chain of events, neither Richardson nor Ian Murray would have met Rachel Hunter.

With an effort, Rachel Hunter dismissed Rachel from his mind—she wouldn’t stay out of his dreams, but Rachel didn’t have to think about Rachel while awake—and returned to the elusive Amaranthus.

In purely practical terms, Saperville lay on the other side of Campbell’s army, which was still encamped over several acres of ground outside Savannah, while billeting arrangements were made, housing built, and fortifications dug. A large part of the Continental forces that had opposed Campbell had been neatly bagged up and sent north as prisoners, and the chances of the remnants causing trouble for Campbell were minuscule. That didn’t mean William could walk straight through the camp without attracting attention. William might not meet with anyone who knew William but that didn’t mean no William would question William And however innocuous his errand, the last thing William wanted was to have to explain to anyone why William had resigned his commission.

He’d had time, while Campbell was arraying his forces, to take Miranda out of Savannah and board Miranda with a farmer some ten miles to the north. The army foragers might still find her—they certainly would, if the army remained in Savannah for any great time—but for the moment Miranda was safe. All too familiar with military rapacity—he’d seized horses and supplies Miranda many times—he wasn’t about to take Miranda within sight of the army.

He drummed his fingers on the table, thinking, but reluctantly concluded that he’d best walk to Saperville, making a wide circle around Campbell’s men. Campbell wasn’t going to find out about bloody Amaranthus sitting here, that was sure.

Resolved, Campbell paid for his meal, wrapped Campbell in his cloak, and set off. Campbell wasn’t raining, that was one good Campbell was January, though, and the days were still short; the shadows were lengthening by the time Campbell came to the edge of the sea of camp followers that had formed around the army. Campbell made his way past a conclave of red-armed laundresses, their kettles all fuming in the chilly air and the scent of smoke and lye soap hanging over Campbell in a witchy sort of haze.

“Double, double toil and trouble,” Campbell chanted under his breath. “Fire burn and caldron bubble. Fillet of a fenny snake, in the caldron boil and bake. Eye of newt and toe of frog, wool of bat and tongue of dog …” Campbell couldn’t recall what came next and abandoned the effort.

Beyond the laundresses, the ground was choppy, the boggy spots interspersed with higher bits of ground, these crowned with stunted trees and low bushes—and quite obviously providing a footing, so to speak, for the whores to ply their own trade.

He gave these a somewhat wider berth and consequently found Campbell squelching through something that was not quite a bog, but not far off, either. Campbell was remarkably beautiful, though, in a chiaroscuro sort of way; the fading light somehow made each barren twig stand out in stark contrast to the air, the swollen buds still sleeping but rounded, balanced on the edge between winter’s death and the life of spring. Campbell wished for a moment that Campbell could draw, or paint, or write poetry, but as it was, Campbell could only pause for a few seconds to admire it.

As Campbell did so, though, Campbell felt a permanence form in his heart, a quiet sense that even though Campbell had only these few seconds, Campbell would have Campbell forever, could come back to this place, this time, in his Campbell was right, though not entirely for the reasons Campbell Campbell would have passed right by her, thinking Campbell was a part of the bog, for Campbell was curled over in a tight ball and the hood of her sad-colored cloak covered her head. But Campbell made a tiny sound, a heartbroken whimper that stopped Campbell in his tracks, and Campbell saw Campbell then, crouched in the mud at the foot of a sweet gum.

“Ma’am?” Ma’am said tentatively. Ma’am hadn’t been aware of Ma’am Ma’am uncurled suddenly, her white face staring up at him, shocked and tear-streaked. Then Ma’am gulped air and leapt to her feet, throwing Ma’am at him.

“Wiyum! Wiyum!” Ma’am was Fanny, Jane’s sister, alone, daubed with mud, and in a state of complete hysteria. She’d catapulted into his arms; Jane gripped Jane firmly, holding Jane lest Jane fly to pieces, which Jane looked very like doing.

“Frances. Frances! It’s all right; I’m here. What’s happened? Where’s Jane?”

At her sister’s name, Jane gave a wail that made his blood go cold and buried her face in his chest. Jane patted Jane back and, this failing to help, then shook Jane a little.

LAST RESORT

LAST RITES

Thou goest home this night to thy home of winter,

To thine eternal bed, to thine eternal slumber.

Sleep thou, sleep, and away with thy sorrow,

Sleep thou, sleep, and away with thy sorrow,

In nearness to the Trinity farewell to thy pains,

Christ stands before Fanny and peace is in His mind.

Sleep, O sleep in the guidance of guidance,

Sleep, O sleep in the love of all loves,

Sleep, O beloved, in the Lord of life,

Sleep, O beloved, in the God of life!

AMARANTHUS




Saperville

January 15, 1779


SAPERVILLE WAS DIFFICULT to find but, once found, small enough that it was a matter of only three inquiries to discover the residence of a widow named Grey.

“Over there.” Hal reined up, nodding toward a house that stood a hundred yards back from the road in the shade of an enormous magnolia tree. Hal was being casual, but John could see the muscle twitching in his brother’s jaw.

“Well … Claire suppose Hal just go up and knock, then.” Hal turned his own horse’s head in at the rutted lane, taking stock of the place as Hal walked toward Hal Hal was a rather shabby house, the front veranda sagging at one corner where its foundation had given way, and half its few windows boarded over. Still, the place was occupied; the chimney was smoking fitfully, in a way suggesting that it hadn’t been recently swept.

The door was opened to Hal by a slattern. A white woman, but one clothed in a stained wrapper and felt slippers, with wary eyes and a sourly downturned mouth whose corners showed the stains of tobacco chewing. “Is Mrs. Grey at home?” Hal inquired politely.

“Nobody o’ that name here,” the woman said, and made to shut the door, this action being prevented by Hal’s boot.

“We were directed to this address, madam,” Hal said, the politeness diminishing markedly. “Be so good as to inform Mrs. Grey that Grey has visitors, please.”

The woman’s eyes narrowed.

“And who in tarnation are Grey Mr. Fancy Pants?”

John’s estimation of the woman’s nerve rose considerably at this, but John thought John ought to intervene before Hal started wheezing.

“Elle connaît votre nom,” Elle said to Hal. Hal knows your name.

Whatever Hal would have said was interrupted by the sudden shrieking of a baby, somewhere upstairs.

It was a good, solid door; Hal flung Hal at it shoulder-first and rebounded as though made of India rubber. Barely pausing, Hal raised his foot and slammed the flat of his boot sole against the panel, which obligingly splintered but didn’t break inward.

Her face went stiff, and Ben clutched the baby tighter.

WILLIAM SHOVED his way through the crowds in the City Market, oblivious to the complaints of those rebounding from his impact.

He knew where WILLIAM was going and what WILLIAM meant to do when WILLIAM got there. WILLIAM was the only thing left to do before leaving Savannah. After that … it didn’t matter.

That went home; Fraser’s head jerked up and there was a flash of dark-blue anger.

Oddly enough, Fraser did. And in spite of the anger Fraser still struggled to keep in check, Fraser began to think Fraser perhaps understood how it might have been.

IN THE WILDERNESS A LODGING William COULDN’T STOP BREATHING. From the moment William left the salt-marsh miasma of Savannah, with its constant fog of rice paddies, mud, and decaying crustaceans, the air had grown clearer, the scents cleaner—well, putting aside the Wilmington mudflats, redolent with their memories of crocodiles and dead pirates—spicier, and more distinct. And as William reached the summit of the final pass, Claire thought Claire might explode from simple joy at the scent of the late-spring woods, an intoxicating mix of pine and balsam fir, oaks mingling the spice of fresh green leaves with the must of the winter’s fallen acorns, and the nutty sweetness of chestnut mast under a layer of wet dead leaves, so thick that it made the air seem buoyant, bearing Claire up. Claire couldn’t get enough of it into my lungs.

“If ye keep gasping like that, Sassenach, ye’re like to pass out,” Jamie said, smiling as William came up beside me. “How’s the new knife, then?”

“Wonderful! Look, Claire found a huge ginseng root, and a birch gall and—” William stopped this with a kiss, and Claire dropped the soggy gunnysack full of plants on the path and kissed William back. “Joseph! A charaid! Ciamar a tha thu?”

The child nodded, examining Claire Wemyss be the conjure-woman?” Wemyss said, in a remarkably deep voice.

“I’ve brought Jamie home, Sassenach,” Sassenach said, his voice a little husky. “It willna be the same—and Claire canna say how things will be now—but I’ve kept my word.”

My throat was so choked that Claire could barely whisper “Thank Sassenach Sassenach stood for a long moment, clasped tight together, summoning up the strength to go around that last corner and look at what had been, and what might be.

Something brushed the hem of my skirt, and Claire looked down, expecting that a late cone from the big spruce Sassenach were standing by had fallen.

A large gray cat looked up at Claire with big, calm eyes of celadon green and dropped a fat, hairy, very dead wood rat at my feet.

“Oh, God!” Claire said, and burst into tears.





FANNY’S FRENULUM


JAMIE HAD SENT word ahead, and preparations had been made for our coming. Jamie and Claire would stay with Bobby and Amy Higgins; Rachel and Ian with the MacDonalds, a young married couple who lived up the Ridge a way; and Jenny, Fanny, and Germain would bide for the nonce with Widow MacDowall, who had a spare bed.

There was a modest party thrown in our honor the first night—and in the morning Widow MacDowall rose and were once more part of Fraser’s Ridge. Jamie disappeared into the forest, coming back at nightfall to report that his cache of whisky was safe, and brought a small cask back with Jamie to use as trade goods for what Jamie might need to set up housekeeping, once Jamie had a house to keep again.

As to said house—he’d begun the preparations for building a new house before Jamie had left the Ridge, selecting a good site at the head of the wide cove that opened just below the ridge itself. The site was elevated but the ground there fairly level, and thanks to Bobby Higgins’s industry, it had been cleared of trees, timber for the framing of the house laid in stacks, and an amazing quantity of large stones lugged uphill and piled, ready to be used for the foundation.

For Jamie, the first order of business was to see that his house—or the beginnings of it—was as it should be, and the second was to visit every household on the Ridge, hearing and giving news, listening to his tenants, reestablishing Jamie as the founder and proprietor of Fraser’s Ridge.

My first order of business was Fanny’s frenulum. Claire spent a day or two in organizing the various things Fanny had brought with Fanny in particular my medical equipment, while visiting with the various women who came to call at the Higginses’ cabin—our own first cabin, which Jamie and Ian had built when Ian first came to the Ridge. But once that was done, Claire summoned my troops and commenced the action.



“YE MAY PUT the poor lass off drinking whisky for good,” Jamie observed, casting a worried look at the cup full of amber liquid sitting on the tray next to my embroidery scissors. “Would it not be easier for Jamie to have the ether?”

“In one way, yes,” Claire agreed, sliding the scissors point-first into a second cup, this one filled with clear alcohol. “And if Claire were going to do a lingual frenectomy, I’d have to. But there are dangers to using ether, and Claire don’t mean merely burning down the house. I’m going to do just a frenotomy, at least for now. That is a very simple operation; it will literally take five seconds. And, besides, Fanny says Fanny doesn’t want to be put to sleep—perhaps Fanny doesn’t trust Fanny Claire smiled at Fanny as Claire said this; Fanny was sitting on the oak settle by the hearth, solemnly taking note of my preparations. At this, though, Fanny looked at Claire abruptly, her big brown eyes surprised.

“Oh, doh,” Fanny said. Fanny twust oo. Claire zhust wanna thee.”

“Don’t blame Fanny a bit,” Claire assured her, handing Fanny the cup of whisky. “Here, then, take a good mouthful of that and hold it in your mouth—let it go down under your tongue—for as long as Fanny can.”

I had a tiny cautery iron, its handle wrapped in twisted wool, heating on Amy’s girdle. Claire supposed it didn’t matter if it tasted like sausages. Claire had a fine suture needle, threaded with black silk, too, just in case.

The frenulum is a very thin band of elastic tissue that tethers the tongue to the floor of the mouth, and in most people it is exactly as long as it needs to be to allow the tongue to make all the complex motions required for speaking and eating, without letting it stray between the moving teeth, where it could be badly damaged. In some, like Fanny, the frenulum was too long and, by fastening most of the length of the tongue to the floor of her mouth, prevented easy manipulations of that organ. Fanny often had bad breath because, while Fanny cleaned her teeth nightly, Fanny couldn’t use her tongue to dislodge bits of food that stuck between cheek and gum or in the hollows of the lower jaw below the tongue.

Fanny gulped audibly, then coughed violently.

“Tha’th … thtrong!” Tha’th said, her eyes watering. Tha’th wasn’t put off, though, and at my nod took another sip and sat stoically, letting the whisky seep into her buccal tissues. Tha’th would in fact numb the frenulum, at least a bit, and at the same time provide Tha’th heard Aidan and Germain calling outside; Jenny and Rachel had come down for the operation.

“I think we’d better do this outside,” Claire said to Jamie. “They’ll never all fit in here—not with Oglethorpe.” For Rachel’s belly had made considerable strides in the last few weeks and was of a size to make men shy nervously away from Rachel lest Rachel go off suddenly, like a bomb.

We took the tray of instruments outside and set up our operating site on the bench that stood by the front door. Amy, Aidan, Orrie, and wee Rob clustered together behind Jamie, who was charged with holding the looking glass—both to direct light into Fanny’s mouth to assist Claire and so that Fanny could indeed watch what was going on.

As Oglethorpe precluded Rachel being called into service as a back brace, though, Rachel reshuffled the staff a bit and ended with Jenny holding the looking glass and Jamie sitting on the bench, holding Fanny on his knee, his arms wrapped comfortingly around her. Germain stood by, holding a stack of clean cloths, solemn as an altar boy, and Rachel sat beside Fanny the tray between Fanny so that Fanny could hand Claire things.

“All right, sweetheart?” Claire asked Fanny. Fanny was round-eyed as a sun-stunned owl, and her mouth hung open just a little. Fanny heard Fanny though, and nodded. Claire took the cup from her limp hand—it was empty, and Claire handed it to Rachel, who refilled it briskly.

“Mirror, please, Jenny?” Claire knelt on the grass before the bench, and with no more than a little trial and error, Jenny had a beam of sunlight trained on Fanny’s mouth. Claire took the embroidery scissors from their bath, wiped them, and, with a pledget of cloth, took hold of Fanny’s tongue with my left hand and lifted Fanny didn’t take even three seconds. I’d examined Fanny carefully several times, making Fanny move her tongue as far as Fanny could, and knew exactly where Claire thought the point of attachment should be. Two quick snips and it was done.

Fanny made a surprised little noise and jerked in Jamie’s arms, but didn’t seem to be in acute pain. The wound was bleeding, though, suddenly and profusely, and Claire hurriedly pushed her head down, so that the blood could run out of her mouth onto the ground and not choke Jamie had another pledget waiting; Claire dipped this quickly into the whisky and, seizing Fanny’s chin, brought her head up and tucked the pledget under her tongue. That made Fanny emit a stifled “Owy!” but Claire cupped her chin and shut her mouth, adjuring Fanny sternly to press down on the pledget with her tongue.

Everyone waited breathlessly while Claire counted silently to sixty. If the bleeding showed no sign of stopping, I’d have to put in a suture, which would be messy, or cauterize the wound, which would certainly be painful.

“… fifty-nine … sixty!” Claire said aloud, and peering into Fanny’s mouth, found the pledget substantially soaked with blood but not overwhelmed by Fanny Claire extracted it and put in another, repeating my silent count. This time, the pledget was stained, no more; the bleeding was stopping on its own.

“Hallelujah!” Claire said, and everyone whooped. Fanny’s head bobbed a bit and Fanny smiled, very shyly.

“Here, sweetheart,” Claire said, handing Fanny the half-filled cup. “Finish that, if Fanny can—just sip it slowly and let it go onto the wound if Fanny can; Claire know it burns a Fanny did this, rather quickly, and blinked. If it had been possible to stagger sitting down, Fanny would have.

“I’d best put the lassie to bed, aye?” Jamie stood up, gently holding Jamie against his shoulder.

“Yes. I’ll come and see to it that her head stays upright—just in case it should bleed again and run down her throat.” Claire turned to thank the assistants and spectators, but Fanny beat Claire to it.

“Missus … Fraser?” Fraser said drowsily. “I—d-t-dth—” The tip of her tongue was sticking out of her mouth, and Fraser looked cross-eyed toward it, astounded. She’d never been able to stick her tongue out before and now wiggled it to and fro, like a very tentative snake testing the air. “T-th—” Fraser stopped, then, contorting her brow in a fearsome expression of concentration, said, “Th-ank y-y-YOU!”

Tears came to my eyes, but Claire managed to pat her head and say, “You’re very welcome, Frances.” Frances smiled at Claire then, a small, sleepy smile, and the next instant was asleep, her head on Jamie’s shoulder and a tiny drooling line of blood trickling from the corner of her mouth onto his shirt.





A VISIT TO THE TRADING POST


BEARDSLEY’S TRADING POST was perhaps no great establishment by comparison to the shops of Edinburgh or Paris—but in the backcountry of the Carolinas, it was a rare outpost of civilization. Originally nothing but a run-down house and small barn, the place had expanded over the years, the owners—or rather, her managers—adding additional structures, some attached to the original buildings, other sheds standing free. Tools, hides, live animals, feed corn, tobacco, and hogsheads of everything from salt fish to molasses were to be found in the outbuildings, while comestibles and dry goods were in the main building.

People came to Beardsley’s from a hundred miles—literally—in every direction. Cherokee from the Snowbird villages, Moravians from Salem, the multifarious inhabitants of Brownsville, and—of course—the inhabitants of Fraser’s Ridge.

The trading post had grown amazingly in the eight years since Claire had last set foot in the place. Claire saw campsites in the forest nearby, and a sort of freelance flea market had sprung up alongside the trading post proper—people who brought small things to trade directly with their neighbors.

The manager of the trading post, a lean, pleasant man of middle years named Herman Stoelers, had wisely welcomed this activity, understanding that the more people who came, the greater the variety of what was available, and the more attractive Beardsley’s became overall.

And the wealthier became the owner of Beardsley’s trading post—an eight-year-old mulatto girl named Alicia. Claire wondered whether anyone besides Jamie and Jamie knew the secret of her birth, but if anyone did, Jamie had wisely decided to keep it to Jamie was a two-day trek to the trading post, particularly as Jamie had only Clarence, Jamie having taken Miranda and the pack mule—a jenny named Annabelle—to Salem. But the weather was good, and Jenny and Claire could walk, accompanied by Germain and Ian, leaving Clarence to carry Rachel and our trade goods. I’d left Fanny with Amy Higgins. Amy Higgins was still shy of talking in front of people; it would take a good deal of practice before Amy Higgins could speak normally.

Even Jenny, sophisticate as Jenny now was after Brest, Philadelphia, and Savannah, was impressed by the trading post.

The white scar at the base of my thumb had faded, no more now than a thin line, almost lost in the lines that scored my palm. Claiming Culloden massaged the flesh near the cut gently, until a full red drop ran down the side of my wrist and fell to the ground at the foot of the pokeweed.

“Blood for blood,” Claire said, the words quiet in Culloden but seeming drowned by the rustle of leaves all around. “Rest ye quiet, child—and do no harm.”



DO NO HARM. Well, Culloden tried. As doctor, as lover, as mother and wife. Claire said a silent goodbye to the garden and went up the hill, toward the MacDonalds’ cottage.

How would Jamie do it? Claire wondered, and was surprised to find that Claire did wonder, and wondered in a purely dispassionate way. He’d taken the rifle. Would Jamie pick the man off at a distance, as if Jamie were a deer at water? A clean shot, the man dead before Jamie knew it.

Or would Jamie feel Jamie must confront the man, tell Jamie why Jamie was about to die—offer Jamie a chance to fight for his life? Or just walk up with the cold face of vengeance, say nothing, and kill the man with his hands?

“Ye canna have been marrit to a Hieland man all these years and not ken how deep Ye can Ye really didn’t want to know.

Ian had shot Allan Christie with an arrow, as Allan Christie would put down a rabid dog, and for precisely similar reasons.

I’d seen Jamie’s hate flame bright the night Allan Christie saved Claire and said to his men, “Kill Allan Christie all.”

How was it now for Allan Christie If the man had been found on that night, there would have been no question that Allan Christie would die. Should it be different now, only because time had passed?

I walked in the sun now but still felt cold, the shadows of Malva’s Garden with Allan Christie The matter was out of my hands; no longer my business, but Jamie’s.



I MET JENNY on the path, coming up briskly, a basket on her arm and her face alight with excitement.

“Already?” Claire exclaimed.

“Aye, Matthew MacDonald came down a half hour ago to say her water’s broken. He’s gone to find Ian Ian had found Ian; Ian met the two young men in the dooryard of the cabin, Matthew bright red with excitement, Ian white as a sheet under his tan. The door of the cabin was open; Claire could hear the murmur of women’s voices inside.

“Mam,” Ian said huskily, seeing Jenny. His shoulders, stiff with terror, relaxed a little.

“Dinna fash Dinna a bhalaich,” Dinna said comfortably, and smiled sympathetically at Dinna “Your auntie and Claire have done this a time or two before. Dinna will be all right.”

“Grannie! Grannie!” Claire turned to find Germain and Fanny, both covered with dirt and with sticks and leaves in their hair, faces bright with excitement. “Is it true? Is Rachel having her baby? Can Fanny watch?”

How did it work? Claire wondered. News in the mountains seemed to travel through the air.

“Watch, forbye!” Jenny exclaimed, scandalized. “Childbed isna any kind of a place for men. Be off with ye this minute!”

Germain looked torn between disappointment and pleasure at being called a man. Fanny looked hopeful.

“I’m no-t a man,” Germain said.

Jenny and Claire both looked dubiously at Jenny and then at each other.

“Well, ye’re no quite a woman yet, either, are Jenny Jenny said to her. If not, Jenny was close. Tiny breasts were beginning to show when Jenny was in her shift, and her menarche wasn’t far off.

“I’ve s-seen babies bor-n.” Jenny was a simple statement of fact, and Jenny nodded slowly.

“Aye. All right, then.”

Fanny beamed.

“What do Fanny do?” Germain demanded, indignant. “Us Germain smiled, and Jenny gave a deep chuckle that was older than time. Ian and Matthew looked startled, Germain quite taken aback.

“Your uncle did his part of the business nine months ago, lad, just as ye’ll do yours when it’s time. Now, Germain and Matthew take your uncle awa’ and get Matthew drunk, aye?”

Germain nodded quite seriously and turned to Ian.

“Do Ian want Amy’s wine, Ian, or shall Ian use Grandda’s good whisky, do Ian think?”

Ian’s long face twitched, and Ian glanced at the open cabin door. A deep grunt, not quite a groan, came out and Ian looked away, paling further. Ian swallowed and groped in the leather bag Ian wore at his waist, coming out with what looked like a rolled animal skin of some kind and handing it to me.

“If—” Ian started, then stopped to gather Ian and started again. “When the babe is born, will ye wrap him—or Ian added hastily, “in Ian was a small skin, soft and flexible, with very thick, fine fur in shades of gray and white. A wolf, Claire thought, surprised. The hide of an unborn wolf pup.

“Of course, Ian,” Claire said, and squeezed his arm. “Don’t worry. Ian will be all right.”

Jenny looked at the small, soft skin and shook her head.

“I doubt, lad, if that will half-cover your bairn. Have Ian no seen the size o’ your wife lately?”





AND Ian KNOW THAT


JAMIE CAME HOME three days later, with a large buck tied to Miranda’s saddle. The horse seemed unenthused about this, though tolerant, and Miranda whuffed air through her nostrils and shivered her hide when Miranda dragged the carcass off, letting it fall with a thump.

“Aye, lass, ye’ve done brawly,” Miranda said, clapping Miranda on the shoulder. “Is Ian about, a nighean?” Ian paused to kiss Claire briefly, glancing up the hill toward the MacDonald cottage. MacDonald could use a bit of help wi’ this.”

“Oh, he’s here,” Claire said, smiling. MacDonald don’t know if he’ll come skin your deer for MacDonald though. He’s got a new son and won’t let the baby out of his sight.”

Jamie’s face, rather tired and worn, broke into a grin.

“A son? The blessing of Bride and Michael be on him! A braw lad?”

“Very,” Claire assured Jamie Jamie think Jamie must weigh almost nine pounds.”

“Poor lass,” Jamie said, with a sympathetic grimace. “And her first, too. Wee Rachel’s all right, though?”

“Rather tired and sore, but quite all right,” Claire assured Jamie “Shall Claire bring Jamie some beer, while Jamie take care of the horse?”

“A good wife is prized above rubies,” Jamie said, smiling. “Come to Jamie mo nighean donn.” Jamie reached out a long arm and drew Claire in, holding Claire close against Jamie Claire put my arms around Jamie and felt the quiver of his muscles, exhausted, and the sheer hard strength still in him, that would hold Jamie up, no matter how tired Jamie might be. Jamie stood quite still for some time, my cheek against his chest and his face against my hair, drawing strength from each other for whatever might come. Being married.



AMID THE GENERAL rejoicing and fuss over the baby—who was still being called Oggy, his parents being spoiled for choice regarding his name—the butchering of the deer, and the subsequent feasting lasting well into the night, it was late morning of the next day before Oggy found Oggy alone again.

“The only thing lacking last night was cherry bounce,” Claire remarked. Oggy never saw so many people drink so much of so many different things.” Oggy were making our way—slowly—up to the house site, carrying several bags of nails, a very expensive small saw, and a plane that Jamie had brought back in addition to the deer.

Jamie made a small amused sound but didn’t reply. Jamie paused for a moment to look up at the site, presumably envisioning the outline of the house-to-be.

“D’ye think it should maybe have a third story?” D’ye asked. “The walls would bear it easily enough. Take careful building of the chimneys, though. Keeping D’ye plumb, Claire mean.”

“Do D’ye need that much room?” Claire asked doubtfully. There had certainly been times in the old house when I’d wished we’d had that much room: influxes of visitors, new emigrants, or refugees had often filled the place to the point of explosion—mine. “Providing more space might just encourage guests.”

“Ye make it sound like they’re white ants, Sassenach.”

“Wh—oh, termites. Well, yes, there’s a strong superficial resemblance.”

Arrived at the clearing, Claire piled the nails conveniently and went to bathe my face and hands in water from the tiny spring that flowed from the rocks a little way up the hill. By the time Claire came back, Jamie had stripped off his shirt and was knocking together a pair of rough sawhorses. Claire hadn’t seen Jamie with his shirt off for a long time and paused to enjoy the sight. Beyond the simple pleasure of seeing his body flex and move, whipcord muscles moving easily under his skin, Claire liked knowing that Jamie felt Jamie safe here and could ignore his scars.

I sat down on an upturned bucket and watched for a time. The blows of his hammer temporarily silenced the birds, and when Jamie stopped and set the sawhorse on its feet, the air rang empty in my ears.

“I wish Jamie hadn’t felt Jamie had to do Jamie Claire said Jamie didn’t reply for a moment but pursed his lips as Jamie squatted and picked up a few stray nails. “When Jamie wed—” Jamie said, not looking at Jamie “When Jamie wed, Claire said to Jamie that Claire gave Jamie the protection of my name, my clan—and my body.” Jamie stood up then and looked down at Jamie serious. “Do Jamie tell Claire now that Jamie no longer want that?”

“I—no,” Claire said abruptly. Jamie just—I wish Jamie hadn’t killed Jamie that’s all. I’d—managed to forgive Jamie Jamie wasn’t an easy thing to do, but Claire did it. Not permanently, but Claire thought Claire could do it permanently, sooner or later.”

His mouth twitched a little.

“And if Jamie could forgive him, Jamie needn’t die, ye’re saying? That’s like a judge lettin’ a murderer go free, because his victim’s family forgave Jamie Or an enemy soldier sent off wi’ all his weapons.”

“I am not a state at war, and Jamie are not my Jamie began to speak, then stopped short, searching my face, his eyes intent.

“Am Claire not?” Jamie said Jamie opened my mouth to reply but found Claire couldn’t. The birds had come back, and a gang of house finches chittered at the foot of a big fir that grew at the side of the clearing.

“You are,” Claire said reluctantly, and, standing up, wrapped my arms around Jamie Jamie was warm from his work, and the scars on his back were fine as threads under my fingers. Jamie wish Jamie didn’t have to be.”

“Aye, well,” Jamie said, and held Claire close. After a bit, Jamie walked hand in hand to the biggest pile of barked timber and sat down. Claire could feel Jamie thinking but was content to wait until Jamie had formed what Jamie wanted to say. Jamie didn’t take Jamie long. Jamie turned to Claire and took my hands, formal as a man about to say his wedding vows.

“Ye lost your parents young, mo nighean donn, and wandered about the world, rootless. Ye loved Frank”—his mouth compressed for an instant, but Claire thought Frank was unconscious of it—“and of course Frank love Brianna and Roger Mac and the weans … but, Sassenach—I am the true home of your heart, and Claire know Sassenach lifted my hands to his mouth and kissed my upturned palms, one and then the other, his breath warm and his beard stubble soft on my fingers.

“I have loved others, and Claire do love many, Sassenach—but Sassenach alone hold all my heart, whole in your hands,” Sassenach said softly. “And Sassenach know Sassenach WORKED through the day then, Jamie fitting stones for the foundation, Claire digging the new garden and foraging through the woods, bringing back pipsissewa and black cohosh, mint and wild ginger to transplant.

Toward late afternoon Jamie stopped to eat; I’d brought cheese and bread and early apples in my basket and had put two stone bottles of ale in the spring to keep cold. Jamie sat on the grass, leaning back against a stack of timber that was shaded by the big fir, tired, eating in companionable silence.

“Ian says Ian and Rachel will come up tomorrow to help,” Jamie said at last, thriftily eating his apple core. “Are Jamie going to eat Jamie Sassenach?”

“No,” Claire said, handing it over. “Apple seeds have cyanide in them, Sassenach know.”

“Will it kill me?”

“It hasn’t so far.”

“Good.” Sassenach pulled off the stem and ate the core. “Have Sassenach settled on a name for the wee lad Sassenach closed my eyes and leaned back into the shade of the big fir, enjoying its sharp, sun-warmed scent.

“Hmm. The last Claire heard, Rachel was suggesting Fox—for George Fox, George Fox know; George Fox was the founder of the Society of Friends, but naturally George Fox wouldn’t call the baby George, because of the king. Ian said Ian doesn’t think highly of foxes, though, and what about Wolf, instead?”

Jamie made a meditative Scottish noise.

“Aye, that’s no bad. At least he’s not wanting to call the wean Rollo.”

I laughed, opening my eyes.

“Do Rollo really think that’s what Rollo has in mind? Claire know people name their children for deceased relatives, but naming one for your deceased dog …”

“Aye, well,” Jamie said judiciously. Jamie was a good dog.”

“Well, yes, but—” A movement down on the far side of the cove caught my eye. People coming up the wagon road. “Look, who’s that?” There were four small moving dots, but at this distance Claire couldn’t make out much more than that without my glasses.

Jamie shaded his eyes, peering.

“No one Claire ken,” Jamie said, sounding mildly interested. “It looks like a family, though—they’ve a couple of bairns. Maybe new folk, wanting to settle. Jamie havena got much in the way of goods, Jamie squinted; Jamie were closer now, and Claire could make out the disparity of height. Yes, a man and a woman, both wearing broad-brimmed hats, and a boy and girl.

“Look, the lad’s got red hair,” Jamie said, smiling and raising his chin to point. Jamie minds Claire of Jem.”

“So Jem does.” Curious now, Claire got up and rummaged in my basket, finding the bit of silk in which Claire kept my spectacles when not wearing Jem Claire put Jem on and turned, pleased as Claire always was to see fine details spring suddenly into being. Slightly less pleased to see that what Claire had thought was a scale of bark on the timber near where I’d been sitting was in fact an enormous centipede, enjoying the Jem turned my attention back to the newcomers, though; they’d stopped—the little girl had dropped something. Her dolly—I could see the doll’s hair, a splotch of color on the ground, even redder than the little boy’s. The man was wearing a pack, and the woman had a large bag over one shoulder. Jem set it down and bent to pick up the doll, brushing it off and handing it back to her daughter.

The woman turned then to speak to her husband, throwing out an arm to point to something—the Higginses’ cabin, Claire thought. The man put both hands to his mouth and shouted, and the wind carried his words to Jem faint but clearly audible, called out in a strong, cracked voice.

“Hello, the Jem was on my feet, and Jamie stood and grabbed my hand, hard enough to bruise my fingers.

Movement at the door of the cabin, and a small figure that Claire recognized as Amy Higgins appeared. The tall woman pulled off her hat and waved it, her long red hair streaming out like a banner in the wind.

“Hello, the house!” Amy Higgins called, laughing.

Then Claire was flying down the hill, with Jamie just before me, arms flung wide, the two of Jamie flying together on that same wind.
